Same as Ectropion.

entry.ety: Gr. � for abortion; 'ek out + � to wound, cause mischief to
entry.def: Having a tendency to prevent the development of anything, especially of a disease.

entry.ety: L. ectypus worked in high relief, Gr. �; out + � stamp, figure. See Type
entry.def: Copied, reproduced as a molding or cast, in contradistinction from the original model.

sd.def: A copy, as in pottery, of an artist's original work. Hence:
A work sculptured in relief, as a cameo, or in bas-relief (in this sense used loosely).

sn.def: A copy from an original; a type of something that has previously existed.
sn.q: Some regarded him [Klopstock] as an ectype of the ancient prophets.

entry.def: A method of etching in which the design upon the plate is produced in relief.

entry.cs: Ecumenical Bishop a title assumed by the popes. Ecumenical council. See under Council.
entry.ety: L. oecumenicus, Gr. � (sc. �) the inhabited world, fr. � to inhabit, from o'i^kos house, dwelling. See Economy
entry.def: General; universal; in ecclesiastical usage, that which concerns the whole church; as, an ecumenical council.
A stable.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`kzema; "ek out + zei^n to boil
entry.def: An inflammatory disease of the skin, characterized by the presence of redness and itching, an eruption of small vesicles, and the discharge of a watery exudation, which often dries up, leaving the skin covered with crusts; -- called also tetter milk crust, and salt rheum.
Pertaining to eczema; having the characteristic of eczema.

entries.entry: -ed. The termination of the past participle of regular, or weak, verbs; also, of analogous participial adjectives from nouns; as, pigmented; talented.

entry.ety: L. edax edacis, fr. edere to eat
entry.def: Given to eating; voracious; devouring.
entry.q: Swallowed in the depths of edacious Time.

entry.def: Greediness; voracity; ravenousness; rapacity.

entries.entry: E"dam n.orEdam cheese . A mild Dutch pressed cheese of yellow color and fine flavor, made in balls weighing three or four pounds, and usually colored crimson outside; -- so called from the village of Edam, near Amsterdam. Also, cheese of the same type, wherever made.

entry.def: an extinct heavy-bodied reptile of the late Paleozoic having a dorsal sail or crest.

entries.entry: Ed"da ☞ There are two Eddas. The older, consisting of 39 poems, was reduced to writing from oral tradition in Iceland between 1050 and 1133. The younger or prose Edda, called also the Edda of Snorri, is the work of several writers, though usually ascribed to Snorri Sturleson, who was born in 1178. n.; pl.Eddas #. Icel., lit. great-grandmotheri. e., of Scandinavian poetry), so called by Bishop Brynjúlf Sveinsson, who brought it again to light in 1643 The religious or mythological book of the old Scandinavian tribes of German origin, containing two collections of Sagas (legends, myths) of the old northern gods and heroes.

entry.def: Relating to the Eddas; resembling the Eddas.
An adder or serpent.

entry.ety: AS. edor hedge, fence; akin to etar
entry.def: Flexible wood worked into the top of hedge stakes, to bind them together.
To bind the top interweaving edder; as, to edder a hedge.

entry.ety: AS. edisc; cf. AS. pref. ed- again, anew. Cf. Eddy, and Arrish
entry.def: Aftermath; also, stubble and stubble field. See Arrish.
The tubers of Colocasia antiquorum. See Taro.

entries.entry:
Ed"dy Used also adjectively; as, eddy winds. ĕd"d� n.; pl.Eddies ĕd"dĭz. Prob. fr. Icel. iða; cf. Icel. pref. ið- back, AS. ed-, OS. idug-, OHG. ita-; Goth. id-
A current of air or water running back, or in a direction contrary to the main current.
A current of water or air moving in a circular direction; a whirlpool. And smiling eddies dimpled on the main. Wheel through the air, in circling eddies play.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eddied; p. pr. & vb. n. Eddying
entry.def: To move as an eddy, or as in an eddy; to move in a circle.
entry.q: Eddying round and round they sink.

entry.def: To collect as into an eddy.
entry.q: The circling mountains eddy in From the bare wild the dissipated storm.

entries.entry: Ed"dy cur"rent. Elec An induced electric current circulating wholly within a mass of metal; -- called also Foucault current.

Ed"dy kite. Called also Malay kite. After William A. Eddy, American kite expert A quadrilateral, tailless kite, with convex surfaces exposed to the wind. This kite was extensively used by Eddy in his famous meteorological experiments. It is now generally superseded by the box kite.

entry.ety: G., fr. edel noble + weiss white
entry.def: A little, perennial, white, woolly plant (Leontopodium alpinum), growing at high elevations in the Alps. It is the national flower of Austria.
Same as œdema.
Same as œdematous.

entry.ety: Heb. ēden delight, pleasure; also, a place of pleasure, Eden
entry.def: The garden where Adam and Eve first dwelt; hence, a delightful region or residence.
Of or pertaining to Eden; paradisaic.
entry.q: Edenicjoys.

entry.def: A variety of amphibole. See Amphibole.
Admitted to a state of paradisaic happiness.
See Edentate a.
See Edentate a.

entry.ety: NL., neut. pl. from L. edentatus, p. p. of edentare to render toothless; e out + dens dentis, tooth
entry.def: An order of mammals including the armadillos, sloths, and anteaters; -- called also Bruta. The incisor teeth are rarely developed, and in some groups all the teeth are lacking.

sn.def: Destitute of teeth; as, an edentate quadruped; an edentate leaf.
Belonging to the Edentata.

entry.def: One of the Edentata.
Same as Edentate a.
A depriving of teeth.

entry.ety: L. edentulus; e out + dens dentis, tooth
entry.def: Toothless.

entry.cs: Edge joint Carp a joint formed by two edges making a corner. Edge mill a crushing or grinding mill in which stones roll around on their edges, on a level circular bed; -- used for ore, and as an oil mill. Called also Chilian mill. Edge molding Arch a molding whose section is made up of two curves meeting in an angle. Edge plane. Carp A plane for edging boards. Shoemaking A plane for edging soles. Edge play a kind of swordplay in which backswords or cutlasses are used, and the edge, rather than the point, is employed. Edge rail. Railroad A rail set on edge; -- applied to a rail of more depth than width. A guard rail by the side of the main rail at a switch. Knight. Edge railway a railway having the rails set on edge. Edge stone a curbstone. Edge tool. Any tool or instrument having a sharp edge intended for cutting. A tool for forming or dressing an edge; an edging tool. To be on edge to be eager, impatient, or anxious. to be irritable or nervous. on edge See to be on edge. See to set the teeth on edge. To set the teeth on edge to cause a disagreeable tingling sensation in the teeth, as by bringing acids into contact with them. archaic Bacon. to produce a disagreeable or unpleasant sensation; to annoy or repel; -- often used of sounds; as, the screeching of of the subway train wheels sets my teeth on edge .
entry.ety: OE. eg egge, AS. ecg; akin to OHG. ekka, G. ecke, Icel. & Sw. egg, Dan. eg, and to L. acies, Gr. 'akh` point, Skr. açri edge. √1. Cf. Egg v. t. Eager Ear spike of corn, Acute

sn.def: The thin cutting side of the blade of an instrument; as, the edge of an ax, knife, sword, or scythe.
that which cuts as an edge does, or wounds deeply, etc.
sn.q: He which hath the sharp sword with two edges.
Slander, Whose edge is sharper than the sword.

sn.def: Any sharp terminating border; a margin; a brink; extreme verge; as, the edge of a table, a precipice.
sn.q: Upon the edge of yonder coppice.
In worst extremes, and on the perilous edge Of battle.
Pursue even to the very edge of destruction.

sn.def: Sharpness; readiness or fitness to cut; keenness; intenseness of desire.
sn.q: The full edge of our indignation.
Death and persecution lose all the ill that they can have, if we do not set an edge upon them by our fears and by our vices.

sn.def: The border or part adjacent to the line of division; the beginning or early part; as, in the edge of evening.
sn.q: On theedgeof winter.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Edged; p. pr. & vb. n. Edging

sn.def: To furnish with an edge as a tool or weapon; to sharpen.
sn.q: To edge her champion's sword.

sn.def: To shape or dress the edge of, as with a tool.
To furnish with a fringe or border; as, to edge a dress; to edge a garden with box.
sn.q: Hills whose tops were edged with groves.

sn.def: To make sharp or keen, figuratively; to incite; to exasperate; to goad; to urge or egg on.
sn.q: By such reasonings, the simple were blinded, and the malicious edged.

sn.def: To move by little and little or cautiously, as by pressing forward edgewise; as, edging their chairs forwards.

cs.cd: to increase the distance gradually from the shore, vessel, or other object.
to approach by slow degrees, as when a sailing vessel approaches an object in an oblique direction from the windward.
to get in edgewise; to get in by degrees.
as with a coast or vessel Naut, to advance gradually, but not directly, toward it.

sn.def: To move sideways; to move gradually; as, edge along this way.
To sail close to the wind.
sn.q: I must edge up on a point of wind.

entry.def: Same as Aitchbone.

sn.def: having a specified kind of border or edge; as, a black-edged card; dried sweat left salt-edged patches.
having a cutting edge or especially an edge or edges as specified; often used in combination; as, a dull-edged blade. Opposit of edgeless.
having a biting effect, implying criticism; -- used of words or language; as, edged satire.

entry.def: Without an edge; not sharp; blunt; obtuse; as, an edgeless sword or weapon.
In the direction of the edge.
entry.q: Three hundred thousand pieces have you stuckEdgelong into the ground.

entry.def: Having an edge planed, -- said of a board.

cs.col: to get a word in edgewise
cs.cd: to succeed in expressing an opinion in a conversation, in spite of constant speech from another or others; as, he talked incessantly and I couldn't get a word in edgewise .
cs.note: the form edgeways is now uncommon.

entry.def: With the edge towards anything; in the direction of the edge.
entry.q: Glad to get in a word, as they say, edgeways.

cs.cd: a machine tool with a revolving cutter, for dressing edges, as of boards, or metal plates, to a pattern or templet.

sn.def: That which forms an edge or border, as the fringe, trimming, etc., of a garment, or a border in a garden.
The operation of shaping or dressing the edge of anything, as of a piece of metal.

entry.def: Gradually; gingerly.

sn.def: Easily irritated; sharp; as, an edgy temper.
Having some of the forms, such as drapery or the like, too sharply defined.
sn.q: Anedgystyle of sculpture.

entry.def: The name of the Anglo-Saxon letter ð, capital form Ð. It is sounded as “English th in a similar word: ōðer, other, dôð, doth.”
Suitableness for being eaten; edibleness.

entry.cs: Edible bird's nest. See Bird's nest, 2. Edible crab Zoöl any species of crab used as food, esp. the American blue crab (Callinectes hastatus). See Crab. Edible frog Zoöl the common European frog (Rana esculenta), used as food. Edible snail Zoöl any snail used as food, esp. Helix pomatia and H. aspersa of Europe.
entry.ety: L. edibilis, fr. edere to eat. See Eat
entry.def: Fit to be eaten as food; eatable; esculent; as, edible fishes.
Suitableness for being eaten.

cs.cd: an edict issued by Henry IV. (A. D. 1598), giving toleration to Protestants. Its revocation by Louis XIV. (A. D. 1685) was followed by terrible persecutions and the expatriation of thousands of French Protestants.

entry.ety: L. edictum, fr. edicere edictum, to declare, proclaim; e out + dicere to say: cf. F. édit. See Diction
entry.def: A public command or ordinance by the sovereign power; the proclamation of a law made by an absolute authority, as if by the very act of announcement; a decree; as, the edicts of the Roman emperors; the edicts of the French monarch.
entry.q: It stands as an edict in destiny.
entry.syn: Decree; proclamation; law; ordinance; statute; rule; order; manifesti; command. See Law.

entry.def: Relating to, or consisting of, edicts; as, the Roman edictal law.

entry.ety: L. aedificans -antis, p. pr. of aedificare. See Edify
entry.def: Building; constructing.

entry.ety: L. aedificatio: cf. F. édification. See Edify

sn.def: The act of edifying, or the state of being edified; a building up, especially in a moral or spiritual sense; moral, intellectual, or spiritual improvement; instruction.
sn.q: The assured edification of his church.
Out of these magazines I shall supply the town with what may tend to their edification.

sn.def: A building or edifice.

entry.def: Tending to edification.

entry.ety: L. aedificium, fr. aedificare: cf. F. édifice. See Edify
entry.def: A building; a structure; an architectural fabric; -- chiefly applied to elegant houses, and other large buildings; as, a palace, a church, a statehouse.
Pertaining to an edifice; structural.

sn.def: One who builds.
One who edifies, builds up, or strengthens another by moral or religious instruction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Edified; p. pr. & vb. n. Edifying
entry.ety: F. édifier, L. aedificare; aedes a building, house, orig., a fireplace (akin to Gr. � to burn, Skr. idh to kindle, OHG. eit funeral pile, AS. ād, OIr. aed fire) + facere to make. See Fact -fy

sn.def: To build; to construct.
sn.q: There was a holy chapel edified.

sn.def: To instruct and improve, especially in moral and religious knowledge; to teach.
sn.q: It does not appear probable that our dispute [about miracles] would either edify or enlighten the public.

sn.def: To teach or persuade.

entry.def: To improve.
Instructing; improving; as, an edifying conversation.

entry.ety: L. aedilis: cf. F. édile. Cf. Ædile
entry.def: See Ædile.
The office of ædile.
A grayish white zeolitic mineral, in tetragonal crystals. It is a hydrous silicate of alumina and baryta.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Edited; p. pr. & vb. n. Editing
entry.ety: F. éditer, or L. editus, p. p. of edere to give out, put forth, publish; e out + dare to give. See Date a point of time
entry.def: To superintend the publication of; to revise and prepare for publication; to select, correct, arrange, etc., the matter of, for publication; as, to edit a newspaper.
entry.q: Philosophical treatises which have never been edited.

entry.def: improved or corrected by critical editing.

entry.ety: L. editio, fr. edere to publish; cf. F. édition. See Edit

sn.def: A literary work edited and published, as by a certain editor or in a certain manner; as, a good edition of Chaucer; Chalmers' edition of Shakespeare.
The whole number of copies of a work printed and published at one time; as, the first edition was soon sold.

entries.entry: É`di`tion" de luxe" É`di`tion" de luxe". F See Luxe.

entry.def: An editor.

entry.ety: L., that which produces, from edere to publish: cf. F. éditeur
entry.def: One who edits; esp., a person who prepares, superintends, revises, and corrects a book, magazine, or newspaper, etc., for publication.
Of or pertaining to an editor; written or sanctioned by an editor; as, editorial labors; editorial remarks.
A leading article in a newspaper or magazine; an editorial article; an article published as an expression of the views of the editor.

sn.def: to write an opinion in an editorial in a publication.
to insert personal opinions into an article or statement that is supposed to be an objective statement of facts.

entry.def: In the manner or character of an editor or of an editorial article.
The office or charge of an editor; care and superintendence of a publication.
A female editor.

entry.ety: LL. aedituatus, p. p. of aedituare, fr. L. aedituus a temple warden; aedes building, temple + tueri to guard
entry.def: To guard as a churchwarden does.
One of the descendants of Esau or Edom, the brother of Jacob; an Idumean.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. "edrai^os steadfast + 'ofqalmo`s the eye
entry.def: A group of Crustacea in which the eyes are without stalks; the Arthrostraca.
Pertaining to the Edriophthalma.
Capability of being educated.
Capable of being educated.
entry.q: Men areeducable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Educated ĕd"�*kā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Educating ĕd"�*kā`tĭng
entry.ety: L. educatus, p. p. of educare to bring up a child physically or mentally, to educate, fr. educere to lead forth, bring up (a child). See Educe
entry.def: To bring up or guide the powers of, as a child; to develop and cultivate, whether physically, mentally, or morally, but more commonly limited to the mental activities or senses; to expand, strengthen, and discipline, as the mind, a faculty, etc.; to form and regulate the principles and character of; to prepare and fit for any calling or business by systematic instruction; to cultivate; to train; to instruct; as, to educate a child; to educate the eye or the taste.
entry.syn: To develop; instruct; teach; inform; enlighten; edify; bring up; train; breed; rear; discipline; indoctrinate.

entry.def: Formed or developed by education; as, an educated man.
a learner who is enrolled in an educational institution.

entry.usage: Education, properly a drawing forth, implies not so much the communication of knowledge as the discipline of the intellect, the establishment of the principles, and the regulation of the heart. Instruction is that part of education which furnishes the mind with knowledge. Teaching is the same, being simply more familiar. It is also applied to practice; as, teaching to speak a language; teaching a dog to do tricks. Training is a department of education in which the chief element is exercise or practice for the purpose of imparting facility in any physical or mental operation. Breeding commonly relates to the manners and outward conduct.
entry.def: The act or process of educating; the result of educating, as determined by the knowledge skill, or discipline of character, acquired; also, the act or process of training by a prescribed or customary course of study or discipline; as, an education for the bar or the pulpit; he has finished his education.
entry.q: To prepare us for complete living is the function which education has to discharge.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to education.
entry.q: Hiseducationalestablishment.

entry.def: a specialist in the theory of eduction.
One who is versed in the theories of, or who advocates and promotes, education.
Tending to educate; that gives education; as, an educative process; an educative experience.
One who educates; a teacher.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Educed; p. pr. & vb. n. Educing
entry.ety: L. educere; e out + ducere to lead. See Duke
entry.def: To bring or draw out; to cause to appear; to produce against counter agency or influence; to extract; to evolve; as, to educe a form from matter.
entry.q: The eternal art educing good from ill.
They want to educe and cultivate what is best and noblest in themselves.

entry.def: Capable of being educed.
That which is educed, as by analysis.

entry.cs: Eduction pipeandEduction port . See Exhaust pipe and Exhaust port, under Exhaust a.
entry.def: The act of drawing out or bringing into view.
Tending to draw out; extractive.
One who, or that which, brings forth, elicits, or extracts.
entry.q: Stimulus must be called an eductor of vital ether.

entry.def: Having a tendency to purify or to sweeten by removing or correcting acidity and acrimony.
An edulcorant remedy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Edulcorated; p. pr. & vb. n. Edulcorating
entry.ety: L. e out + dulcoratus, p. p. of dulcorare to sweeten, fr. dulcor sweetness, fr. dulcis sweet: cf. F. édulcorer

sn.def: To render sweet; to sweeten; to free from acidity.
sn.q: Succory . . . edulcorated with sugar and vinegar.

sn.def: To free from acids, salts, or other soluble substances, by washing; to purify.
The act of sweetening or edulcorating.
The act of freeing from acids or any soluble substances, by affusions of water.

entry.def: Tending to �weeten or purify by affusions of water.
A contrivance used to supply small quantities of sweetened liquid, water, etc., to any mixture, or to test tubes, etc.; a dropping bottle.

entry.ety: L. edulis, fr. edere to eat
entry.def: Edible.
entry.q: Eduliouspulses.

entries.entry: -ee. Formed on the F. p. p. ending -é, masc A suffix used, chiefly in law terms, in a passive signification, to indicate the direct or indirect object of an action, or the one to whom an act is done or on whom a right is conferred; as in assignee, donee, alienee, grantee, etc. It is correlative to -or, the agent or doer.

entry.def: See Eke.

entry.ety: AS. �l; akin to D., G., & Dan. aal, Icel. āll, Sw. ål
entry.def: An elongated fish of many genera and species. The common eels of Europe and America belong to the genus Anguilla. The electrical eel is a species of Gymnotus. The so called vinegar eel is a minute nematode worm. See Conger eel Electric eel, and Gymnotus.
An eelpot or eel basket.

entry.ety: Eel + fare a journey or passage
entry.def: A brood of eels.
A plant (Zostera marina), with very long and narrow leaves, growing abundantly in shallow bays along the North Atlantic coast.
The eelpout.
A boxlike structure with funnel-shaped traps for catching eels; an eelbuck.

A European fish (Zoarces viviparus), remarkable for producing living young; -- called also greenbone guffer bard, and Maroona eel. Also, an American species (Z. anguillaris), -- called also mutton fish, and, erroneously, congo eel ling, and lamper eel. Both are edible, but of little value.
A fresh-water fish, the burbot.
A spear with barbed forks for spearing eels.
A contraction for even. See Even.
entry.q: I have e'en done with you.

entry.def: The old plural of Eye.
entry.q: And eke with fatness swollen were his een.

entry.def: A contraction for ever. See Ever.

sn.def: Serving to inspire fear, esp. a dread of seeing ghosts; wild; weird; as, eerie stories.
sn.q: She whose elfin prancer springs By night to eery warblings.

sn.def: Affected with fear; affrighted.

entry.def: In a strange, unearthly way.
Causing fear; eerie.
imp. of Eat.

entry.ety: L. effabilis; ex out + fari to speak
entry.def: Capable of being uttered or explained; utterable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Effacing
entry.ety: F. effacer; pref. es-L. ex) + face face; prop., to destroy the face or form. See Face, and cf. Deface

sn.def: To cause to disappear (as anything impresses or inscribed upon a surface) by rubbing out, striking out, etc.; to erase; to render illegible or indiscernible; as, to efface the letters on a monument, or the inscription on a coin.
To destroy, as a mental impression; to wear away.
sn.q: Efface from his mind the theories and notions vulgarly received.
sn.syn: To blot out; expunge; erase; obliterate; cancel; destroy.Efface Deface. To deface is to injure or impair a figure; to efface is to rub out or destroy, so as to render invisible.

entry.def: Capable of being effaced.
The act if effacing; also, the result of the act.
To charm; to bewitch.
A charming; state of being bewitched or deluded.

entry.cs:
For effect for an exaggerated impression or excitement. In effect in fact; in substance. See 8, above.
Of no effect Of none effect To no effectorWithout effect
destitute of results, validity, force, and the like; vain; fruitless. “Making the word of God of none effect through your tradition.” Mark vii. 13. “All my study be to no effect.” Shak. To give effect to to make valid; to carry out in practice; to push to its results. To take effect to become operative, to accomplish aims. Shak.
entry.usage: These words indicate things which arise out of some antecedent, or follow as a consequent. Effect, which may be regarded as the generic term, denotes that which springs directly from something which can properly be termed a cause. A consequence is more remote, not being strictly caused, nor yet a mere sequence, but following out of and following indirectly, or in the train of events, something on which it truly depends. A result is still more remote and variable, like the rebound of an elastic body which falls in very different directions. We may foresee the effects of a measure, may conjecture its consequences, but can rarely discover its final results.
entry.ety: L. effectus, fr. efficere effectum, to effect; ex + facere to make: cf. F. effet, formerly also spelled effect. See Fact

sn.def: Execution; performance; realization; operation; as, the law goes into effect in May.
sn.q: That no compunctious visitings of nature Shake my fell purpose, nor keep peace between The effect and it.

sn.def: Manifestation; expression; sign.
sn.q: All the large effects That troop with majesty.

sn.def: In general: That which is produced by an agent or cause; the event which follows immediately from an antecedent, called the cause; result; consequence; outcome; fruit; as, the effect of luxury.
sn.q: The effect is the unfailing index of the amount of the cause.

sn.def: Impression left on the mind; sensation produced.
sn.q: Patchwork . . . introduced for oratorical effect.
The effect was heightened by the wild and lonely nature of the place.

sn.def: Power to produce results; efficiency; force; importance; account; as, to speak with effect .
Consequence intended; purpose; meaning; general intent; -- with to.
sn.q: They spake to her to that effect.

sn.def: The purport; the sum and substance.
sn.q: Theeffectof his intent.

sn.def: Reality; actual meaning; fact, as distinguished from mere appearance.
sn.q: No other in effect than what it seems.

sn.def: Goods; movables; personal estate; -- sometimes used to embrace real as well as personal property; as, the people escaped from the town with their effects .
sn.q: Resolving all events, with their effects And manifold results, into the will And arbitration wise of the Supreme.
Shun the bitter consequence, for know, The day thou eatest thereof, . . . thou shalt die.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effected; p. pr. & vb. n. Effecting

sn.def: To produce, as a cause or agent; to cause to be.
sn.q: So great a body such exploits to effect.

sn.def: To bring to pass; to execute; to enforce; to achieve; to accomplish.
sn.q: To effect that which the divine counsels had decreed.
They sailed away without effecting their purpose.
sn.syn: To accomplish; fulfill; achieve; complete; execute; perform; attain. See Accomplish.

entry.def: One who effects.
Capable of being done or achieved; practicable; feasible.
Creation; a doing.
Having the power to produce an effect or effects; producing a decided or decisive effect; efficient; serviceable; operative; as, an effective force, remedy, speech; the effective men in a regiment.
entry.q: They are not effective of anything, nor leave no work behind them.
Whosoever is an effective, real cause of doing his heighbor wrong, is criminal.
entry.syn: Efficient; forcible; active; powerful; energetic; competent. See Effectual.

sn.def: That which produces a given effect; a cause.
One who is capable of active service.
sn.q: He assembled his army -- 20,000 effectivesat Corinth.

sn.ety: F. effectif real, effective, real amount
sn.def: Specie or coin, as distinguished from paper currency; -- a term used in many parts of Europe.
The serviceable soldiers in a country; an army or any military body, collectively; as, France's effective .

entry.def: With effect; powerfully; completely; thoroughly.
The quality of being effective.
Without effect or advantage; useless; bootless.
An effecter.

cs.cd: a doctrine concerning the work of the Holy Spirit in producing conviction of sin and acceptance of salvation by Christ, -- one of the five points of Calvinism. See Calvinism.

entry.usage: An efficacious remedy is had recourse to, and proves effective if it does decided good, effectual if it does all the good desired.
entry.def: Producing, or having adequate power or force to produce, an intended effect; adequate; efficient; operative; decisive.
entry.q: Effectual steps for the suppression of the rebellion.

entry.def: the power to be effective.

sn.def: With effect; efficaciously.
Actually; in effect.

entry.def: The quality of being effectual.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effectuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Effectuating
entry.ety: Cf. F. effectuer. See Effect n. & v. t.
entry.def: To bring to pass; to effect; to achieve; to accomplish; to fulfill.
entry.q: A fit instrument to effectuate his desire.
In order to effectuate the thorough reform.

entry.def: Act of effectuating.
Effective.
Effectively.

entries.entry:
Ef*fem"i*na*cy n.; pl.Effeminacies #. From Effeminate
Characteristic quality of a woman, such as softness, luxuriousness, delicacy, or weakness, which is unbecoming a man; womanish delicacy or softness; -- used reproachfully of men.

entry.note: ☞ Effeminate and womanish are generally used in a reproachful sense; feminine and womanly, applied to women, are epithets of propriety or commendation.
entry.ety: L. effeminatus, p. p. of effeminare to make a woman of; ex out + femina a woman. See Feminine a.

sn.def: Having some characteristic of a woman, as delicacy, luxuriousness, etc.; soft or delicate to an unmanly degree; womanish; weak.
sn.q: The king, by his voluptuous life and mean marriage, became effeminate, and less sensible of honor.
An effeminate and unmanly foppery.

sn.def: Womanlike; womanly; tender; -- in a good sense.
sn.q: Gentle, kind, effeminate remorse.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effeminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Effeminating
entry.def: To make womanish; to make soft and delicate; to weaken.
entry.q: It will not corrupt or effeminate children's minds.

entry.def: To grow womanish or weak.
entry.q: In a slothful peace both courage will effeminate and manners corrupt.

sn.def: In an effeminate or womanish manner; weakly; softly; delicately.
sn.q: Proud andeffeminatelygay.

sn.def: By means of a woman; by the power or art of a woman.
sn.q: Effeminatelyvanquished.

entry.def: The state of being effeminate; unmanly softness.
Effeminacy; womanishness.
To make effeminate.

entry.ety: Turk. efendi, fr. Modern Gr. �, fr. Gr. � a chief. See Authentic
entry.def: Master; sir; -- a Turkish title of respect, applied esp. to a state official or man of learning, as one learned in the law, but often simply as the courtesy title of a gentleman.

entry.ety: L. efferens -entis, p. pr. of effere to bear out; ex out + ferre to bear
entry.def: Conveying outward, or discharging; -- applied to certain blood vessels, lymphatics, nerves, etc.
Conveyed outward; as, efferent impulses, i. e., such as are conveyed by the motor or efferent nerves from the central nervous organ outwards; -- opposed to afferent.
An efferent duct or stream.

entry.ety: L. efferus savage; exintens.) + ferus wild
entry.def: Like a wild beast; fierce.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effervesced; p. pr. & vb. n. Effervescing
entry.ety: L. effervescere; ex + fervescere to begin boiling, incho., fr. fervere to boil. See Fervent

sn.def: To be in a state of natural ebullition; to bubble and hiss, as fermenting liquors, or any fluid, when some part escapes in a gaseous form.
To exhibit, in lively natural expression, feelings that can not be repressed or concealed; as, to effervesce with joy or merriment.

entry.def: A kind of natural ebullition; that commotion of a fluid which takes place when some part of the mass flies off in a gaseous form, producing innumerable small bubbles; as, the effervescence of a carbonate with citric acid.

entry.ety: L. effervescences, p. pr. of effervescere: cf. F. effervescent
entry.def: Gently boiling or bubbling, by means of the disengagement of gas
Capable of effervescing.
Tending to produce effervescence.
entry.q: Aneffervesciveforce.

entry.def: The common newt; -- called also asker eft evat, and ewt.

entry.ety: L. effetus that has brought forth, exhausted; ex + fetus that has brought forth. See Fetus
entry.def: No longer capable of producing young, as an animal, or fruit, as the earth; hence, worn out with age; exhausted of energy; incapable of efficient action; no longer productive; barren; sterile.
entry.q: Effete results from virile efforts.
If they find the old governments effete, worn out, . . . they may seek new ones.

entry.ety: L. eficax -acis, fr. efficere. See Effect n.
entry.def: Possessing the quality of being effective; productive of, or powerful to produce, the effect intended; as, an efficacious law.
the capacity or power to produce a desired effect.
Efficacy.

entry.ety: L. efficacia, fr. efficax. See Efficacious
entry.def: Power to produce effects; operation or energy of an agent or force; production of the effect intended; as, the efficacy of medicine in counteracting disease; the efficacy of prayer.
entry.q: Of noxiousefficacy.

cs.cd: the ratio of the work done by an engine, to the work due to the heat supplied to it.

sn.def: The quality of being efficient or producing an effect or effects; efficient power; effectual agency.
sn.q: The manner of this divine efficiency being far above us.

sn.def: The ratio of useful work to energy expended.

entry.def: a small apartment{4}, sometimes furnished, with minimal kitchen and bath facilities. The unit may comprise a single room plus a bathroom, and the kitchen facilities are often open to the main room, or may form a small niche in a corner. There are many variations of efficiency apartment, including some in which furnishings such as a bed may be pulled out from a wall recess and stored there again when not in use. Also called an efficiency.

entry.ety: L. efficiens -entis, p. pr. of efficere to effect: cf. F. efficient. See Effect n.
entry.def: Causing effects; producing results; that makes the effect to be what it is; actively operative; not inactive, slack, or incapable; characterized by energetic and useful activity; as, an efficient officer, power.
entry.q: The efficient cause is the working cause.
entry.syn: Effective; effectual; competent; able; capable; material; potent.

entry.def: An efficient cause; a prime mover.
entry.q: God . . . moveth mere natural agents as an efficient only.

entry.def: With effect; effectively.
To make fierce.
Relating to an effigy.

entry.ety: L. effigiatus, p. p. of effigiare to form, fr. effigies. See Effigy
entry.def: To form as an effigy; hence, to fashion; to adapt.
entry.q: He musteffigiate and conform himself to those circumstances.

entry.def: The act of forming in resemblance; an effigy.
See Effigy.

entries.entry:
Ef"fi*gy
To burn in effigyorTo hang in effigy
to burn or to hang an image or picture of a person, as a token of public odium.
n.; pl.Effigies #. L. effigies, fr. effingere to form, fashion; ex + fingere to form, shape, devise. See Feign
The image, likeness, or representation of a person, whether a full figure, or a part; an imitative figure; -- commonly applied to sculptured likenesses, as those on monuments, or to those of the heads of princes on coins and medals, sometimes applied to portraits.

entry.ety: L. efflagitatus, p. p. of efflagitare
entry.def: To ask urgently.

entry.ety: L. efflatus, p. p. of efflare to blow or breathe out; ex + flare to blow
entry.def: To fill with breath; to puff up.
The act of filling with wind; a breathing or puffing out; a puff, as of wind.
entry.q: A soft efflation of celestial fire.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effloresced; p. pr. & vb. n. Efflorescing
entry.ety: L. efflorescere to bloom, blossom; ex + florescere to begin to blossom, incho., fr. florere to blossom, fr. flos a flower. See Flower

sn.def: To blossom forth.

To change on the surface, or throughout, to a whitish, mealy, or crystalline powder, from a gradual decomposition, esp. from the loss of water, on simple exposure to the air; as, Glauber's salts, and many others, effloresce .

To become covered with a whitish crust or light crystallization, from a slow chemical change between some of the ingredients of the matter covered and an acid proceeding commonly from an external source; as, the walls of limestone caverns sometimes effloresce with nitrate of calcium in consequence of the action of nitric acid formed in the atmosphere.
Flowering, or state of flowering; the blooming of flowers; blowth.
A redness of the skin; eruption, as in rash, measles, smallpox, scarlatina, etc.

sd.def: The formation of the whitish powder or crust on the surface of efflorescing bodies, as salts, etc.
The powder or crust thus formed.

entry.def: The state or quality of being efflorescent; efflorescence.

entry.ety: F. efflorescent, L. efflorescens -entis, blooming, p. pr. of efflorescere. See Effloresce v. i.

sn.def: That effloresces, or is liable to effloresce on exposure; as, an efflorescent salt.
Covered with an efflorescence.

entry.def: To remove the epidermis of (a skin) with a concave knife, blunt in its middle part, -- as in making chamois leather.

sn.def: A flowing out, or emanation.
That which flows or issues from any body or substance; issue; efflux.
sn.q: Bright effluence of bright essence increate!
And, as if the gloom of the earth and sky had been but the effluence of these two mortal hearts, it vanished with their sorrow.

entry.def: Effluence.

entry.ety: L. effluens -entis, p. pr. of effluere to flow out; ex + fluere to flow: cf. F. effluent. See Fluent
entry.def: Flowing out; as, effluent beams.
A stream that flows out of another stream or lake.
Capable of being given off as an effluvium.
entry.q: Effluviablematter.

entry.def: Belonging to effluvia.
To give forth effluvium.
entry.q: Aneffluviatingpower.

entries.entry:
Ef*flu"vi*um n.; pl.Effluvia #. L., a flowing out, fr. effluere to flow out. See Effluent a.
Subtile or invisible emanation; exhalation perceived by the sense of smell; especially, noisome or noxious exhalation; as, the effluvium from diseased or putrefying bodies, or from ill drainage.

sn.def: The act or process of flowing out, or issuing forth; effusion; outflow; as, the efflux of matter from an ulcer; the efflux of men's piety.
sn.q: It is then that the devout affections . . . are incessantly in efflux.

sn.def: That which flows out; emanation; effluence.
sn.q: Prime cheerer, light! . . . Efflux divine.

entry.def: To run out; to flow forth; to pass away.

sn.def: The act of flowing out; effusion.
That which flows out; effluvium; emanation.
sn.q: Some light effluxions from spirit to spirit.

entry.ety: L. effodiens, p. pr. of effodere to dig out; ex + fodere to dig
entry.def: Digging up.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Efforced; p. pr. & vb. n. Efforcing
entry.ety: OF. esforcierF. s'efforcer to exert one's self), LL. exforciare; L. ex + fortis strong. See Force
entry.def: To force; to constrain; to compel to yield.
To form; to shape.
entry.q: Efforming their words within their lips.

entry.def: The act of giving shape or form.

entry.ety: F. effort, OF. esfort, for esfors esforz, fr. esforcier. See Efforce

sn.def: An exertion of strength or power, whether physical or mental, in performing an act or aiming at an object; more or less strenuous endeavor; struggle directed to the accomplishment of an object; as, an effort to scale a wall.
sn.q: We prize the stronger effort of his power.

sn.def: A force acting on a body in the direction of its motion.
sn.syn: Endeavor; exertion; struggle; strain; straining; attempt; trial; essay. See Attempt.

entry.def: To stimulate.
entry.q: Heeffortedhis spirits.

entry.sn: requiring great physical effort. Opposite of effortless.Narrower terms: arduous, backbreaking, back-breaking, grueling, gruelling, hard, heavy, laborious, labourious, punishing, slavish, strenuous, toilsome; exhausting, tiring, wearing, wearying Also See: difficult hard.

sn.def: Making no effort.
requiring little or no effort; as, an effortless victory.

entry.def: A digging out or up.
entry.q: Theeffossionof coins.

entry.ety: Pref. ex- + franchise: cf. OF. esfranchir
entry.def: To enfranchise.
To frighten; to scare.
Frightful.

entry.ety: L. effrenatio, fr. effrenare to unbridle; ex + frenum a bridle
entry.def: Unbridled license; unruliness.
To give assurance to.

entries.entry:
Ef*front"er*y n.; pl.Effronteries #. F. effronterie, fr. effronté shameless, fr. L. effrons -ontis, putting forth the forehead, i. e., barefaced, shameless; ex + frons the forehead. See Front
Impudence or boldness in confronting or in transgressing the bounds of duty or decorum; insulting presumptuousness; shameless boldness; barefaced assurance. Corruption lost nothing of its effrontery. Impudence; sauciness. See Impudence.

entry.def: Marked by impudence.
Impudently.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effulged; p. pr. & vb. n. Effulging
entry.ety: L. effulgere to shine forth; ex + fulgere to flash, shine. See Fulgent
entry.def: To cause to shine with abundance of light; to radiate; to beam.
entry.q: His eyes effulging a peculiar fire.

entry.def: To shine forth; to beam.
The state of being effulgent; extreme brilliancy; a flood of light; great luster or brightness; splendor.
entry.q: The effulgence of his glory abides.
The bright and the balmy effulgence of morn.

entry.ety: L. effulgens -entis, p. pr. of effulgere
entry.def: Diffusing a flood of light; shining; luminous; beaming; bright; splendid.
entry.q: Effulgentrays of light.

entry.def: In an effulgent manner.
The capability of flying off in fumes or vapor.

entry.ety: L. effumare to emit smoke; ex + fumare to smoke, fr. fumus smoke
entry.def: To breathe or puff out.
To pour out.

entry.ety: L. effusus, p. p. of effundere to pour out; ex + fundere to pour. See Fuse to melt

sn.def: Poured out freely; profuse.
sn.q: So should our joy be very effuse.

sn.def: Disposed to pour out freely; prodigal.
Spreading loosely, especially on one side; as, an effuse inflorescence.
Having the lips, or edges, of the aperture abruptly spreading; -- said of certain shells.

entry.def: Effusion; loss.
entry.q: Mucheffuseof blood.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Effused; p. pr. & vb. n. Effusing
entry.def: To pour out like a stream or freely; to cause to exude; to shed.
entry.q: With gushing blood effused.

entry.def: To emanate; to issue.

sn.def: The act of pouring out; as, effusion of water, of blood, of grace, of words, and the like.
sn.q: To save the effusion of my people's blood.

sn.def: That which is poured out, literally or figuratively.
sn.q: Wash me with that precious effusion, and I shall be whiter than sow.
The light effusions of a heedless boy.

sd.def: The escape of a fluid out of its natural vessel, either by rupture of the vessel, or by exudation through its walls. It may pass into the substance of an organ, or issue upon a free surface.
The liquid escaping or exuded.

cs.cd: volcanic rocks formed by a nonexplosive outpouring of lava in molten or plastic form; in distinction from so-called intrusive, or plutonic, rocks.

sn.def: Pouring out; pouring forth freely.
sn.q: Washed with theeffusivewave.

sn.def: formed by an outpouring of molten lava, or pertaining to rocks so formed.

overly demonstrative; expressing emotion in an unrestrained manner; exhibiting unrestrained enthusiasm; -- of people and human actions; as, effusive thanks; an effusive letter of recommendation. Contrasted with reserved.

entry.def: a friendly open trait of a talkative person; enthusiasm exhibited with little restraint.
See Afrit.
A European lizard of the genus Seps.
A salamander, esp. the European smooth newt (Triton punctatus).

entry.ety: AS. eft æft, again, back, afterward. See Aft After
entry.def: Again; afterwards; soon; quickly.
entry.q: I wold never eft comen into the snare.

entry.ety: OE. eftsone eftsones; AS. eft + sōna soon. See Eft, and Soon
entry.def: Again; anew; a second time; at once; speedily.
entry.q: And, if he fall from his capel [horseeftsone.
The champion stout eftsoons dismounted.

entry.ety: Euphemistic corruption of the oath, “by God.”
entry.def: An exclamation expressing exultation or surprise, etc.
Equal; impartial.
Equality.
See Ægean.

entry.ety: L. egens -entis, p. pr. of egere to be needy, suffer want
entry.def: The state of needing, or of suffering a natural want.
Sharp; bitter; acid; sour.
entry.q: The egre words of thy friend.

entry.def: An impetuous flood; a bore. See Eagre.
To germinate.

entry.ety: L. egestus, p. p. of egerere to carry out, to discharge; e out + gerere to carry
entry.def: To cast or throw out; to void, as excrement; to excrete, as the indigestible matter of the food; in an extended sense, to excrete by the lungs, skin, or kidneys.

entry.ety: NL., neut. pl. from p. p. of L. egere. See Egest
entry.def: That which is egested or thrown off from the body by the various excretory channels; excrements; -- opposed to ingesta.
Act or process of egesting; a voiding.

entry.note: ☞ Egg is used adjectively, or as the first part of self-explaining compounds; as, egg beater or egg-beater, egg case, egg ladle, egg-shaped, etc.

cs.cd: see egg-and-dart in the vocabulary, below; -- called also egg and dart, and egg and tongue. See Anchor n., 5.

a process of cleavage or segmentation, by which the egg undergoes endogenous division with formation of a mass of nearly similar cells, from the growth and differentiation of which the new organism is ultimately formed. See Segmentation of the ovum, under Segmentation.
the process of the development of an egg, by which the embryo is formed.
any mite which devours the eggs of insects, as Nothrus ovivorus, which destroys those of the canker worm.
any small hymenopterous insect, which, in the larval stage, lives within the eggs of other insects. Many genera and species are known.

entry.ety: OE., fr. Icel. egg; akin to AS. ægwhence OE. ey), Sw. ägg, Dan. æg, G. & D. ei, and prob. to OSlav. aje jaje, L. ovum, Gr. 'w,o`n, Ir. ugh, Gael. ubh, and perh. to L. avis bird. Cf. Oval

sn.def: The oval or roundish body laid by domestic poultry and other birds, tortoises, etc. It consists of a yolk, usually surrounded by the “white” or albumen, and inclosed in a shell or strong membrane.
A simple cell, from the development of which the young of animals are formed; ovum; germ cell.
Anything resembling an egg in form.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Egged; p. pr. & vb. n. Egging
entry.ety: OE. eggen, Icel. eggja, fr. egg edge. ��. See Edge
entry.def: To urge on; to instigate; to incite�
entry.q: Adam and Eve he egged to ill.
She] did egg him on to tell How fair she was.

entry.def: same as egg-and-dart.

a decorative ovolo molding, having a series of egg-shaped figures alternating with another shape in the form of a dart or anchor. Also used attributively; as, an egg-and-dart molding; an egg-and-dart design. Called also egg and dart, and egg and tongue
entry.syn: egg-and-anchor, egg and anchor, egg-and-tongue, egg and tongue.

entry.def: same as egg-and-dart.
Any bombycid moth of the genera Eriogaster and Lasiocampa; as, the oak eggar L. roboris) of Europe.

a small device having one or usually two blades, each having several stiff oval wires at the tip. The blades are swirled or rotated for beating eggs or whipping cream. The electrical variety typically have two such blades, which are arranged so that the tips of the blades interlace while rotating.
A species of tern, esp. the sooty tern (Sterna fuliginosa) of the West Indies. In the Bahama Islands the name is applied to the tropic bird, Phaëthon flavirostris.
A cup used for holding an egg, at table.
Instigation; incitement.
One who gathers eggs; an eggler.
One who eggs or incites.
A place where eggs are deposited (as by sea birds) or kept; a nest of eggs.
A small sandglass, running about three minutes, for marking time in boiling eggs; also, a small glass for holding an egg, at table.
A kind of posset made of eggs, brandy, sugar, and ale.
One who gathers, or deals in, eggs.
A drink consisting of eggs beaten up with sugar, milk, and (usually) wine or spirits.

sn.def: A plant (Solanum Melongena), of East Indian origin, allied to the tomato, and bearing a large, glossy, edible fruit, shaped somewhat like an egg; mad-apple. It is widely cultivated for its fruit, commonly eaten as a vegetable.
sn.syn: eggplant, aubergine, brinjal, eggplant bush, garden egg, mad apple, Solanum melongena.

sn.def: The fruit of the eggplant{1.

entry.def: same as young-bearing.
a milkshake with egg in it.
Resembling an egg in form; ovoid.
entry.syn: elliptic, elliptical, oval, ovate, oviform, ovoid, prolate.

sn.def: The shell or exterior covering of an egg. Also used figuratively for anything resembling an eggshell.
A smooth, white, marine, gastropod shell of the genus Ovulum, resembling an egg in form.
of a pale, yellowish-white color; as, an eggshell ceiling and light green walls.
having a smooth but not glossy texture like that of a hen's egg; as, a latex paint giving an eggshell finish. Also referred to as matte glaze or non-lustrous glaze.

entries.entry: Egg" squash`. A variety of squash with small egg-shaped fruit.

entry.def: Eyes.
Pertaining to, of the nature of, or affected with, an Ægilops, or tumor in the corner of the eye.
See Ægilops.
Destitute of glands.

entry.note: ☞ Milton, in the following lines, has applied the name to some twining plant, perhaps the honeysuckle.Through the sweetbrier, or the vine, Or the twisted eglantine. L'Allegro, 47. “In our early writers and in Gerarde and the herbalists, it was a shrub with white flowers.” Dr. Prior.
entry.ety: F. églantine, fr. OF. aiglent brier, hip tree, fr. (assumed) LL. acuculentus, fr. a dim. of L. acus needle; cf. F. aiguille needle. Cf. Aglet
entry.def: A species of rose (Rosa Eglanteria), with fragrant foliage and flowers of various colors.
The sweetbrier (R. rubiginosa).
Eglantine.
The European perch when two years old.
To unwind, as a thread from a ball.

entries.entry:
e"go n.; pl.egos. L., I The conscious and permanent subject of all psychical experiences, whether held to be directly known or the product of reflective thought; the subject consciously considered as “I” by a person; -- opposed to non-ego.
Psychoanalysis that one of the three parts of a person's psychic apparatus that mediates consciously between the drives of the id and the realities of the external physical and social environment, by integrating perceptions of the external world and organizing the reactions to it. Contrasted with the id and superego.
egotism; as, a job requiring a diplomat without too much ego .
self-esteem; as, he has an overinflated ego .

entry.def: having an attitude which is almost exclusively concerned with one's own needs or desires.
a self-centered person with little regard for others.
the personality trait that causes one to attempt to get personal recognition for oneself (especially by unacceptable means).
Pertaining to egoism.

entry.ety: F. égoïsme, fr. L. -ego I. See I, and cf. Egotism

sn.def: The doctrine of certain extreme adherents or disciples of Descartes and Johann Gottlieb Fichte, which finds all the elements of knowledge in the ego and the relations which it implies or provides for.
Excessive love and thought of self; the habit of regarding one's self as the center of every interest; selfishness; -- opposed to altruism.
One given overmuch to egoism or thoughts of self.
sn.q: I, dullard egoist, taking no special recognition of such nobleness.

sn.def: A believer in egoism.

entry.def: Pertaining to egoism; imbued with egoism or excessive thoughts of self; self-loving.
entry.q: Ill-natured feeling, or egoistic pleasure in making men miserable.

entry.def: In an egoistic manner.
Personality.
Egoism.
Belonging to, or resembling, egophony.
The sound of a patient's voice so modified as to resemble the bleating of a goat, heard on applying the ear to the chest in certain diseases within its cavity, as in pleurisy with effusion.
The deification of self.

entry.ety: L. ego I + ending -tism for -ism, prob. influenced by other English words in -tism fr. the Greek, where t is not part of the ending, as baptism. See Egoism
entry.def: The practice of too frequently using the word I; hence, a speaking or writing overmuch of one's self; self-exaltation; self-praise; the act or practice of magnifying one's self or parading one's own doings. The word is also used in the sense of egoism.
entry.q: His excessive egotism, which filled all objects with himself.
entry.syn: Egotism Self-conceit Vanity Egoism. Self-conceit is an overweening opinion of one's talents, capacity, attractions, etc.; egotism is the acting out of self-conceit, or self-importance, in words and exterior conduct; vanity is inflation of mind arising from the idea of being thought highly of by others. It shows itself by its eagerness to catch the notice of others. Egoism is a state in which the feelings are concentrated on one's self. Its expression is egotism.

entry.ety: L. ego I + ending -tist for -ist. See Egotism, and cf. Egoist
entry.def: One addicted to egotism; one who speaks much of himself or magnifies his own achievements or affairs.
Addicted to, or manifesting, egotism; having an exaggerated view of one's own importance or good qualities.
entry.syn: egotistic; narcissistic; self-loving; conceited; vain; self-important; opinionated.

entry.def: With egotism.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Egotized; p. pr. & vb. n. Egotizing
entry.def: To talk or write as an egotist.
Having no granules, as chlorophyll in certain conditions.
See Eager, and Eagre.

entry.ety: L. egregius; lit., separated or chosen from the herd, i. e., distinguished, excellent; e out + grex gregis, herd. See Gregarious
entry.def: Surpassing; extraordinary; distinguished (in a bad sense); -- formerly used with words importing a good quality, but now joined with words having a bad sense; as, an egregious rascal; an egregious ass; an egregious mistake.
entry.q: The egregious impudence of this fellow.
His [Wyclif'segregious labors are not to be neglected.

entry.def: Greatly; enormously; shamefully; as, egregiously cheated.
The state of being egregious.
Agrimony (Agrimonia Eupatoria).

entry.ety: L. egressus, fr. egredi to go out; e out + gradi to go. See Grade

sn.def: The act of going out or leaving, or the power to leave; departure.
sn.q: Embarred from all egress and regress.
Gates of burning adamant, Barred over us, prohibit all egress.

sn.def: The passing off from the sun's disk of an inferior planet, in a transit.

entry.def: To go out; to depart; to leave.
The act of going; egress.
One who goes out.

sn.def: The name of several species of herons which bear plumes on the back. They are generally white. Among the best known species are the American egret (Ardea egretta syn. Herodias egretta); the great egret (Ardea alba); the little egret (Ardea garzetta), of Europe; and the American snowy egret (Ardea candidissima).
sn.q: A bunch of egrets killed for their plumage.

sn.def: A plume or tuft of feathers worn as a part of a headdress, or anything imitating such an ornament; an aigrette.
The flying feathery or hairy crown of seeds or achenes, as the down of the thistle.
A kind of ape.

entry.def: Same as Egret n., 2.
The herb agrimony.
Sorrow.

entry.ety: F. aigrette griotte, formerly agriote; cf. aigre sour
entry.def: A kind of sour cherry.
Sickness; ailment; sorrow.
a country at the northeastern corner of Africa. At one time it was joined with Syria to form the United Arab Republic.

entry.cs: Egyptian bean. Bot The beanlike fruit of an aquatic plant (Nelumbium speciosum), somewhat resembling the water lily. See under Bean, 1. Egyptian cross. See Illust.No. 6) of Cross. Egyptian thorn Bot a medium-sized tree (Acacia vera). It is one of the chief sources of the best gum arabic.
entry.ety: L. Aegyptius, Gr. �, fr. � (L. Aegyptus) Egypt: cf. F. égyptien. Cf. Gypsy
entry.def: Pertaining to Egypt, in Africa.

sn.def: A native, or one of the people, of Egypt; also, the Egyptian language.
A gypsy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Egyptized; p. pr. & vb. n. Egyptizing
entry.def: To give an Egyptian character or appearance to.
One skilled in the antiquities of Egypt; a student of Egyptology.
Of, pertaining to, or devoted to, Egyptology.
The science or study of Egyptian antiquities, esp. the hieroglyphics.
An expression of inquiry or slight surprise.

entry.ety: From Ehl near Linz, where it occurs
entry.def: A mineral of a green color and pearly luster; a hydrous phosphate of copper.

entry.cs:
Eider down. Cf. Icel. æðardūn, Sw. eiderdūn, Dan. ederduun
Down of the eider duck, much sought after as an article of luxury.
entry.ety: Of Scand. origin, cf. Icel æ�r; akin to Sw. eider, Dan. ederfugl
entry.def: Any species of sea duck of the genus Somateria, esp. Somateria mollissima, which breeds in the northern parts of Europe and America, and lines its nest with fine down (taken from its own body) which is an article of commerce; -- called also eider duck. The American eider (S. Dresseri), the king eider (S. spectabilis), and the spectacled eider (Arctonetta Fischeri) are related species.
An instrument for copying drawings on the same or a different scale; a form of the pantograph.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � image. See Idol
entry.def: An image or representation; a form; a phantom; an apparition.
An exclamation expressing delight.
An island in a river; an ait.
entry.q: Osiers on theireights.

entry.ety: AS. eahta; akin to OS. ahto, OFries. achta, D. & G. acht, OHG. ahto, Icel. ātta, Sw. åtta, Dan. otte, Goth. ahtau, Lith. asztůni, Ir. & Gael. ochd, W. wyth, Armor. eich eiz, L. octo, Gr. 'oktw`, Skr. ashṭan. √306. Cf. Octave
entry.def: Seven and one; as, eight years.

sn.def: The number greater by a unit than seven; eight units or objects.
A symbol representing eight units, as 8 or viii.

entry.ety: AS. eahtatȳne eahtatēne. See Eight, and Ten, and cf. Eighty
entry.def: Eight and ten; as, eighteen pounds.

sn.def: The number greater by a unit than seventeen; eighteen units or objects.
A symbol denoting eighteen units, as 18 or xviii.

entry.def: See Octodecimo.

sn.def: Next in order after the seventeenth.
Consisting of one of eighteen equal parts or divisions of a thing.
The quotient of a unit divided by eighteen; one of eighteen equal parts or divisions.
The eighth after the tenth.

entry.ety: OE., fr. AS. eahtateóða; eahta eight + teóða tenth. Cf. Eighteenth Tenth
entry.def: Eighteenth.
Eight times a quantity.

cs.cd: the eighth part of a whole note, or semibreve; a quaver.

sn.def: Next in order after the seventh.
Consisting of one of eight equal divisions of a thing.
The quotient of a unit divided by eight; one of eight equal parts; an eighth part.
The interval of an octave.

entry.def: As the eighth in order.
the decade from 1980 to 1989.

sn.def: the time of life between 80 and 90.
The next in order after seventy-ninth.
Consisting of one of eighty equal parts or divisions.

entry.def: The quotient of a unit divided by eighty; one of eighty equal parts.
A compound or twin crystal made up of eight individuals.
Eight times twenty; a hundred and sixty.
eight people considered as a unit; as, there was an eightsome ahead of us on the golf course.

sn.def: a Scottish reel for eight dancers.

entry.def: a playing card with eight pips on the face; an eight.
the size of a book (ca. 16 x 23 cm) whose pages are made by folding a sheet of paper three times to form eight leaves. The pages have about half the area of a quarto. Symbolized as 8vo, and 8°.

entry.ety: AS. eahtatig, where the ending -tig is akin to English ten; cf. G. achtzig. See Eight, and Ten
entry.def: Eight times ten; fourscore.

sn.def: The sum of eight times ten; eighty units or objects.
A symbol representing eighty units, or ten eight times repeated, as 80 or lxxx.

cs.cd: a bastard eldest son whose parents afterwards intermarry.

entry.ety: OF. aisné ainsné, F. aîné, fr. L. ante natus born before. Cf. Esnecy

sn.def: Eldest; firstborn.
Entailed; belonging to the eldest son.

entry.def: See Eking.

sn.def: An image or effigy; -- used rather in an abstract sense, and rarely for a work of art.
an ikon.

entry.ety: Gr. e'ikw`n e'iko`nos, image + root of gi`gnesqai to be born
entry.def: The sodium salt of a sulphonic acid of a naphthol, C10H5(OH)(NH2)SO3Na used as a developer.
A solid hydrocarbon, C20H42, of the paraffin series, of artificial production, and also probably occurring in petroleum.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C20H38, of the acetylene series, obtained from brown coal.
Age.
Air.
the Irish name for Ireland; the name used in 1937 to 1949 for the Republic of Ireland.
A justice of the peace; irenarch.
Pacific. See Irenic.
See Aerie, and Eyrie.

entry.ety: OF. aisil aissil, fr. L. acetum. Cf. Acetic
entry.def: Vinegar; verjuice.

entry.ety: W., session, fr. eistedd to sit
entry.def: An assembly or session of the Welsh bards; an annual congress of bards, minstrels and literati of Wales, -- being a patriotic revival of the old custom.

entry.ety: OE. either aither, AS. ǣgðer ǣghwæðerakin to OHG. ēogiwedar, MHG. iegeweder); ā + ge + hwæðer whether. See Each, and Whether, and cf. Or conj

sn.def: One of two; the one or the other; -- properly used of two things, but sometimes of a larger number, for any one.
sn.q: Lepidus flatters both, Of both is flattered; but he neither loves, Nor either cares for him.
Scarce a palm of ground could be gotten by either of the three.
There have been three talkers in Great British, either of whom would illustrate what I say about dogmatists.

sn.def: Each of two; the one and the other; both; -- formerly, also, each of any number.
sn.q: His flowing hair In curls on either cheek played.
On either side . . . was there the tree of life.
The extreme right and left of either army never engaged.

entry.note: ☞ Either was formerly sometimes used without any correlation, and where we should now use or.
entry.def: Either precedes two, or more, coördinate words or phrases, and is introductory to an alternative. It is correlative to or.
entry.q: Either he is talking, or he is pursuing, or he is in a journey, or peradventure he sleepeth.
Few writers hesitate to use either in what is called a triple alternative; such as, We must either stay where we are, proceed, or recede.
Can the fig tree, my brethren, bear olive berries? either a vine, figs?

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ejaculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Ejaculating
entry.ety: L. ejaculatus, p. p. of ejaculari to throw out; e out + ejaculari to throw, fr. jaculum javelin, dart, fr. jacere to throw. See Eject

sn.def: To throw out suddenly and swiftly, as if a dart; to dart; to eject.
sn.q: Its active rays ejaculated thence.

sn.def: To throw out, as an exclamation; to utter by a brief and sudden impulse; as, to ejaculate a prayer.
To utter ejaculations; to make short and hasty exclamations.
sn.q: Ejaculatingto himself.

sn.def: to eject semen; -- of a male animal (esp. a human or other mammal) during coitus.
The act of throwing or darting out with a sudden force and rapid flight.
sn.q: Anejaculationor irradiation of the eye.

sn.def: The uttering of a short, sudden exclamation or prayer, or the exclamation or prayer uttered.
sn.q: In your dressing, let there be jaculations fitted to the several actions of dressing.

sn.def: The act of ejecting or suddenly throwing, as a fluid from a duct.

entry.def: A muscle which helps ejaculation.

sn.def: Casting or throwing out; fitted to eject; as, ejaculatory vessels.
Suddenly darted out; uttered in short sentences; as, an ejaculatory prayer or petition.
Sudden; hasty.
sn.q: Ejaculatoryrepentances, that take us by fits and starts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ejected; p. pr. & vb. n. Ejecting
entry.ety: L. ejectus, p. p. of ejicere; e out + jacere to throw. See Jet a shooting forth

sn.def: To expel; to dismiss; to cast forth; to thrust or drive out; to discharge; as, to eject a person from a room; to eject a traitor from the country; to eject words from the language.
sn.q: Eyesejectingflame.

sn.def: To cast out; to evict; to dispossess; as, to eject tenants from an estate.
sn.syn: To expel; banish; drive out; discharge; oust; evict; dislodge; extrude; void.

entry.def: An object that is a conscious or living object, and hence not a direct object, but an inferred object or act of a subject, not myself; -- a term invented by W. K. Clifford.

entry.ety: L., neut. pl. of ejectus cast out. See Eject
entry.def: Matter ejected; material thrown out; as, the ejecta of a volcano; the ejecta, or excreta, of the body.

sn.def: The act of ejecting or casting out; discharge; expulsion; evacuation.
sn.q: Vastejectionof ashes.
Theejectionof a word.

sn.def: The act or process of discharging anything from the body, particularly the excretions.
The state of being ejected or cast out; dispossession; banishment.
A casting out; a dispossession; an expulsion; ejection; as, the ejectment of tenants from their homes.
A species of mixed action, which lies for the recovery of possession of real property, and damages and costs for the wrongful withholding of it.

cs.cd: a condenser in which the vacuum is maintained by a jet pump.

sn.def: One who, or that which, ejects or dispossesses.
A jet jump for lifting water or withdrawing air from a space.
That part of the mechanism of a breech-loading firearm which ejects the empty shell.

entry.def: Gomuti fiber. See Gomuti.

entry.ety: L. ejulatio, fr. ejulare to wail, lament
entry.def: A wailing; lamentation.
entry.q: Ejulationin the pangs of death.

entry.ety: G., fr. Skr. ēka one + G. bor boron, E. boron
entry.def: The name given by Mendelejeff in accordance with the periodic law, and by prediction, to a hypothetical element then unknown, but since discovered and named scandium; -- so called because it was a missing analogue of the boron group. See Scandium.
The name given to a hypothetical element, -- later discovered and called gallium. See Gallium, and cf. Ekabor.
The name of a hypothetical element predicted and afterwards discovered and named germanium; -- so called because it was a missing analogue of the silicon group. See Germanium, and cf. Ekabor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eked; p. pr. & vb. n. Eking
entry.ety: AS. ēkan ȳkan; akin to OFries, āka, OS. �kian, OHG. ouhhōn to add, Icel. auka to increase, Sw. öka, Dan. öge, Goth. aukan, L. augere, Skr. �jas strength, ugra mighty, and probably to English wax, v. i. Cf. Augment Nickname
entry.def: To increase; to add to; to augment; -- now commonly used with out, the notion conveyed being to add to, or piece out by a laborious, inferior, or scanty addition; as, to eke out a scanty supply of one kind with some other.
entry.q: Toekemy pain.
He eked out by his wits an income of barely fifty pounds.

entry.note: ☞ Eke serves less to unite than to render prominent a subjoined more important sentence or notion.
entry.ety: AS. eác; akin to OFries. ák, OS. �k, D. �ok, OHG. ouh, G. auch, Icel. auk, Sw. och and, Dan. og, Goth. auk for, but. Prob. from the preceding verb
entry.def: In addition; also; likewise.
entry.q: 'T will be prodigious hard to prove That this is eke the throne of love.
A trainband captain eke was he Of famous London town.

entry.def: An addition.
entry.q: Clumsy ekes that may well be spared.

entry.def: A variety of scapolite.
An additional or epithet name; a nickname.
A lengthening or filling piece to make good a deficiency in length.
The carved work under the quarter piece at the aft part of the quarter gallery.
Originally, the highest note in the scale of Guido; hence, proverbially, any extravagant saying.
entry.q: Why, this is aboveE-la!

entry.ety: L. elaboratus, p. p. of elaborare to work out; e out + laborare to labor, labor labor. See Labor
entry.def: Wrought with labor; finished with great care; studied; executed with exactness or painstaking; as, an elaborate discourse; an elaborate performance; elaborate research.
entry.q: Drawn to the life in each elaborate page.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Elaborated; p. pr. & vb. n. Elaborating

sn.def: To produce with labor
sn.q: They in full joy elaborate a sigh,

sn.def: To perfect with painstaking; to improve or refine with labor and study, or by successive operations; as, to elaborate a painting or a literary work.
sn.q: The sap is . . . still more elaborated and exalted as it circulates through the vessels of the plant.

sn.def: The act or process of producing or refining with labor; improvement by successive operations; refinement.

The natural process of formation or assimilation, performed by the living organs in animals and vegetables, by which a crude substance is changed into something of a higher order; as, the elaboration of food into chyme; the elaboration of chyle, or sap, or tissues.

cs.cd: the intellectual power of discerning relations and of viewing objects by means of, or in, relations; the discursive faculty; thought.

entry.def: Serving or tending to elaborate; constructing with labor and minute attention to details.
One who, or that which, elaborates.
Tending to elaborate.
A laboratory.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a Bœotian marsh plant; � olive + � sacred, pure
entry.def: A genus of shrubs or small trees, having the foliage covered with small silvery scales; oleaster.

entry.note: ☞ Elæis Guineensis, the African oil palm, is a tree twenty or thirty feet high, with immense pinnate leaves and large masses of fruit. The berries are rather larger than olives, and when boiled in water yield the orange-red palm oil.
entry.def: A genus of palms.

cs.cd: a kind of syenite characterized by the presence of elæolite.

entry.def: A variety of hephelite, usually massive, of greasy luster, and gray to reddish color.

entry.ety: Gr. � olive oil, oil + � winged, fleeting
entry.def: The more liquid or volatile portion of certain oily substance, as distinguished from stearoptene, the more solid parts.
A salt of elaidic acid.

cs.cd: a fatty acid isomeric with oleic acid, and obtained from it by the action of nitrous acid.

entry.def: Relating to oleic acid, or elaine.
A solid isomeric modification of olein.

entry.ety: Gr. � olive oil, oil, from � the olive tree: cf. F. élaïne
entry.def: Same as Olein.

entry.ety: Gr. � olive oil, oil + e'i^dos form
entry.def: Derived from castor oil; ricinoleic; as, elaiodic acid.
An apparatus for determining the amount of oil contained in any substance, or for ascertaining the degree of purity of oil.
A dweller in Flam (or Susiana), an ancient kingdom of Southwestern Asia, afterwards a province of Persia.
Shining.
Ardor inspired by passion or enthusiasm.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Elanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Elancing
entry.ety: F. élancer, OF. eslancier; pref. es-L. ex) + F. lancer to dart, throw, fr. lance
entry.def: To throw as a lance; to hurl; to dart.
entry.q: While thy unerring hand elanced . . . a dart.

entry.ety: D. eland elk, of Slav. origin; cf. Pol. jelen stag, Russ. oléne, Lith. elnis; perh. akin to E. elk

sn.def: A species of large South African antelope (Oreas canna). It is valued both for its hide and flesh, and is rapidly disappearing in the settled districts; -- called also Cape elk.
The elk or moose.

entry.def: A kite of the genus Elanus.
See Elæolite.
a genus of snakes comprising the Old World and American rat snakes.
a venomous snake of the family Elapidae, including the .
a natural family of snakes including the cobras, kraits, mambas, the New World coral snakes, and Australian taipan and tiger snakes.
See Elæoptene.
Pertaining to, resembling, or characteristic of, the stag, or Cervus elaphus.
A species of deer (Elaphurus Davidianus) found in china. It is about four feet high at the shoulder and has peculiar antlers.

entry.ety: L. elapidatus cleared from stones; e out + lapis stone
entry.def: A clearing away of stones.
Like or pertaining to the Elapidæ, a family of poisonous serpents, including the cobras. See Ophidia.
A genus of venomous snakes found both in America and the Old World. Many species are known. See Coral snake, under Coral.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Elapsed; p. pr. & vb. n. Elapsing
entry.ety: L. elapsus, p. p. of elabi to glide away; e out + labi to fall, slide. See Lapse
entry.def: To slip or glide away; to pass away silently, as time; -- used chiefly in reference to time.
entry.q: Eight days elapsed; at length a pilgrim came.

entry.def: The act of elapsing.

entry.ety: L. elaqueatus, p. p. of elaqueare to unfetter
entry.def: To disentangle.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � metal beaten out, metal plate + -poda
entry.def: An order of holothurians mostly found in the deep sea. They are remarkable for their bilateral symmetry and curious forms.
Of or pertaining to the Elasmobranchii.
Of or pertaining to Elasmobranchii.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a metal plate + L. branchia a gill
entry.def: A subclass of fishes, comprising the sharks, the rays, and the Chimæra. The skeleton is mainly cartilaginous.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a metal plate + � a lizard
entry.def: An extinct, long-necked, marine, cretaceous reptile from Kansas, allied to Plesiosaurus.

entry.cs: Elastic bitumen. Min See Elaterite. Elastic curve. Geom The curve made by a thin elastic rod fixed horizontally at one end and loaded at the other. Mech The figure assumed by the longitudinal axis of an originally straight bar under any system of bending forces. Rankine. Elastic fluids those which have the property of expanding in all directions on the removal of external pressure, as the air, steam, and other gases and vapors. Elastic limit Mech the limit of distortion, by bending, stretching, etc., that a body can undergo and yet return to its original form when relieved from stress; also, the unit force or stress required to produce this distortion. Within the elastic limit the distortion is directly proportional to the stress producing it. Elastic tissue Anat a variety of connective tissue consisting of a network of slender and very elastic fibers which are but slightly affected by acids or alkalies. Gum elastic caoutchouc.
entry.ety: Formed fr. Gr. 'elay`nein to drive; prob. akin to L. alacer lively, brisk, and E. alacrity: cf. F. élastique

sn.def: Springing back; having a power or inherent property of returning to the form from which a substance is bent, drawn, pressed, or twisted; springy; having the power of rebounding; as, a bow is elastic; the air is elastic; India rubber is elastic.
sn.q: Capable of being drawn out by force like a piece of elastic gum, and by its own elasticity returning, when the force is removed, to its former position.

sn.def: Able to return quickly to a former state or condition, after being depressed or overtaxed; having power to recover easily from shocks and trials; as, elastic spirits; an elastic constitution.

entry.def: An elastic woven fabric, as a belt, braces or suspenders, etc., made in part of India rubber.
Elastic.
Same as rubber band.
In an elastic manner; by an elastic power; with a spring.

cs.cd: the quotient of a stress (of a given kind), by the strain (of a given kind) which it produces; -- called also coefficient of resistance.
the pedal surface of an ellipsoid (see Pedal); a surface used in explaining the phenomena of double refraction and their relation to the elastic force of the luminous ether in crystalline media.

sn.def: The quality of being elastic; the inherent property in bodies by which they recover their former figure or dimensions, after the removal of external pressure or altering force; springiness; resilience; tendency to rebound; as, the elasticity of caoutchouc; the elasticity of the air.
Power of resistance to, or recovery from, depression or overwork; -- usually referred to as resilience3].

entry.def: made with strands or inserts of elastic, allowing it to stretch; -- of fabrics; as, slacks with an elasticized waistband.
The quality of being elastic; elasticity.

A nitrogenous substance, somewhat resembling albumin, which forms the chemical basis of elastic tissue. It is very insoluble in most fluids, but is gradually dissolved when digested with either pepsin or trypsin.
an elastic bandage.

entry.ety: L. elatus elevated, fig., elated, proud (the figure, perh., being borrowed from a prancing horse); e out + latusused as p. p. of ferre to bear), for tlatus, and akin to E. tolerate. See Tolerate, and cf. Extol

sn.def: Lifted up; raised; elevated.
sn.q: With upper lip elate.
And sovereign law, that State's collected will, O'er thrones and globes, elate, Sits empress, crowning good, repressing ill.

sn.def: Having the spirits raised by success, or by hope; flushed or exalted with confidence; elated; exultant.
sn.q: O, thoughtless mortals! ever blind to fate, Too soon dejected, and dejected, and too soon elate.
Our nineteenth century is wonderfully set up in its own esteem, wonderfully elate at its progress.
sn.syn: Puffed up; lofty; proud; haughty; exalted; inspirited; transported; delighted; overjoyed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Elated; p. pr. & vb. n. Elating

sn.def: To raise; to exalt.
sn.q: By the potent sun elated high.

sn.def: To exalt the spirit of; to fill with confidence or exultation; to elevate or flush with success; to puff up; to make proud.
sn.q: Foolishly elated by spiritual pride.
You ought not be elated at the chance mishaps of your enemies.

entry.def: With elation.
The state of being elated.
One who, or that which, elates.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � driver, fr. � to drive

sn.def: An elastic spiral filament for dispersing the spores, as in some liverworts.

Any beetle of the family Elateridæ, having the habit, when laid on the back, of giving a sudden upward spring, by a quick movement of the articulation between the abdomen and thorax; -- called also click beetle spring beetle, and snapping beetle.
The caudal spring used by Podura and related insects for leaping. See Collembola.

entry.def: The active principle of elaterium, being found in the juice of the wild or squirting cucumber (Ecballium agreste, formerly Motordica Elaterium) and other related species. It is extracted as a bitter, white, crystalline substance, which is a violent purgative.
A mineral resin, of a blackish brown color, occurring in soft, flexible masses; -- called also mineral caoutchouc, and elastic bitumen.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, neut. of � driving. See 2d Elater
entry.def: A cathartic substance obtained, in the form of yellowish or greenish cakes, as the dried residue of the juice of the wild or squirting cucumber (Ecballium agreste, formerly called Momordica Elaterium).
Same as Elatrometer.
Acting force; elasticity.
A lifting up by success; exaltation; inriation with pride of prosperity.
entry.q: Felt theelationof triumph.

entry.def: Raised; lifted up; -- a term applied to what is also called the absolute superlative, denoting a high or intense degree of a quality, but not excluding the idea that an equal degree may exist in other cases.
An instrument for measuring the degree of rarefaction of air contained in the receiver of an air pump.
Olefiant gas or ethylene; -- so called by Berzelius from its forming an oil combining with chlorine. elayle See Ethylene.

entry.note: ☞ Elbow is used adjectively or as part of a compound, to denote something shaped like, or acting like an elbow; as, elbow joint; elbow tongs or elbow-tongs; elbowroom, elbow-room, or elbow room.

cs.cd: very near; at hand.
energetic application of force in manual labor.
the twisting together of two cables by which a vessel rides at anchor, caused by swinging completely round once.
scissors bent in the blade or shank for convenience in cutting.
with coat worn through at the elbows; shabby; in needy circumstances.

entry.ety: AS. elboga elnbogaakin to D. elleboga, OHG. elinbogo, G. ellbogen ellenbogen, Icel. �lnbogi; prop.; arm-bend); eln ell (orig., forearm) + boga a bending. See 1st Ell, and 4th Bow

sn.def: The joint or bend of the arm; the outer curve in the middle of the arm when bent.
sn.q: Her arms to the elbows naked.
