sn.def: The angular distance of a planet from the sun; as, the elongation of Venus or Mercury.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eloped; p. pr. & vb. n. Eloping
entry.ety: D. ontloopen to run away; pref. ont-akin to G. ent-, AS. and-, cf. E. answer) + loopen to run; akin to E. leap. See Leap v. t.
entry.def: To run away, or escape privately, from the place or station to which one is bound by duty; -- said especially of a woman or a man, either married or unmarried, who runs away with a paramour or a sweetheart.
entry.q: Great numbers of them [the women] have eloped from their allegiance.

entry.def: The act of eloping; secret departure; -- said of a woman and a man, one or both, who run away from their homes for marriage or for cohabitation.
One who elopes.

entry.ety: L. elops helops, a kind of sea fish, Gr. �

sn.def: A genus of fishes. See Saury.
A mythical serpent.

entry.ety: F. éloquence, L. eloquentia, fr. eloquens. See Eloquent

sn.def: Fluent, forcible, elegant, and persuasive speech in public; the power of expressing strong emotions in striking and appropriate language either spoken or written, thereby producing conviction or persuasion.
sn.q: Eloquence is speaking out . . . out of the abundance of the heart.

sn.def: Fig.: Whatever produces the effect of moving and persuasive speech.
sn.q: Silence that spoke and eloquence of eyes.
The hearts of men are their books; events are their tutors; great actions are their eloquence.

sn.def: That which is eloquently uttered or written.
sn.q: O, let my books be then the eloquence And dumb presagers of my speaking breast.

entry.ety: F. éloquent, L. eloquens -entis, p. pr. of eloqui to speak out, declaim; e + loqui to speak. See Loquacious

sn.def: Having the power of expressing strong emotions or forcible arguments in an elevated, impassioned, and effective manner; as, an eloquent orator or preacher.
sn.q: O Death, all-eloquent! You only prove What dust we dote on when 't is man we love.

sn.def: Adapted to express strong emotion or to state facts arguments with fluency and power; as, an eloquent address or statement; an eloquent appeal to a jury.

entry.def: In an eloquent manner.
Ghastly; preternatural. Same as Eldritch.

entry.note: ☞ This word always follows its noun. It is usual to give the possessive form to else rather than to the substantive; as, somebody else's; no one else's. “A boy who is fond of somebody else's pencil case.” G. Eliot. “A suit of clothes like everybody else's.” Thackeray.
entry.ety: OE. & AS. elles otherwise, gen. sing. of an adj. signifying other; akin to OHG. elles otherwise, OSw. äljes, Sw. eljest, Goth. aljis, adj., other, L. alius, Gr. �. Cf. Alias Alien
entry.def: Other; one or something beside; as, Who else is coming? What else shall I give? Do you expect anything else?
entry.q: Bastards andelse.

entry.note: ☞ After ‘or', else is sometimes used expletively, as simply noting an alternative. “Will you give thanks, . . . or else shall I?”

sn.def: Besides; except that mentioned; in addition; as, nowhere else; no one else.
Otherwise; in the other, or the contrary, case; if the facts were different.
sn.q: For thou desirest not sacrifice; else would I give it.

sn.def: In any other place; as, these trees are not to be found elsewhere .
In some other place; in other places, indefinitely; as, it is reported in town and elsewhere .

entry.def: To some, or any, other place; as, you will have to go elsewhither for it.
entry.q: Forelsewhitherwas I bound.

entry.def: Otherwise.
A shoemaker's awl.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Elucidated; p. pr. & vb. n. Elucidating
entry.ety: LL. elucidatus, p. p. of elucidare; e + lucidus full of light, clear. See Lucid
entry.def: To make clear or manifest; to render more intelligible; to illustrate; as, an example will elucidate the subject.
A making clear; the act of elucidating or that which elucidates, as an explanation, an exposition, an illustration; as, one example may serve for further elucidation of the subject.
Making clear; tending to elucidate; as, an elucidative note.
One who explains or elucidates; an expositor.
Tending to elucidate; elucidative.

entry.ety: L. eluctatus, p. p. of eluctari to struggle out; e + luctari to wrestle
entry.def: To struggle out; -- with out.
A struggling out of any difficulty.

entry.ety: L. elucubratus, p. p. of elucubrare to compose by lamplight
entry.def: See Lucubrate.
See Lucubration.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eluded; p. pr. & vb. n. Eluding
entry.ety: L. eludere elusum; e + ludere to play: cf. F. éluder. See Ludicrous
entry.def: To avoid slyly, by artifice, stratagem, or dexterity; to escape from in a covert manner; to mock by an unexpected escape; to baffle; as, to elude an officer; to elude detection, inquiry, search, comprehension; to elude the force of an argument or a blow.
entry.q: Me gentle Delia beckons from the plain, Then, hid in shades, eludes he eager swain.
The transition from fetichism to polytheism seems a gradual process of which the stages elude close definition.
entry.syn: To evade; avoid; escape; shun; eschew; flee; mock; baffle; frustrate; foil.

entry.def: Capable of being eluded; evadible.
The sixth month of the Jewish year, by the sacred reckoning, or the twelfth, by the civil reckoning, corresponding nearly to the month of September.
Weak or lame in the loins.

entry.ety: LL. elusio, fr. L. eludere, elusum. See Elude
entry.def: Act of eluding; adroit escape, as by artifice; a mockery; a cheat; trickery.
Tending to elude; using arts or deception to escape; adroitly escaping or evading; eluding the grasp; fallacious.
entry.q: Elusive of the bridal day, she gives Fond hopes to all, and all with hopes deceives.

entry.def: Tending to elude or deceive; evasive; fraudulent; fallacious; deceitful; deceptive.

entry.ety: L. elutus, p. p. of eluers to elute; e + luere to wash
entry.def: To wash out.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Elutriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Elutriating
entry.ety: L. elutriatus, p. p. of elutriare
entry.def: To wash or strain out so as to purify; as, to elutriate the blood as it passes through the lungs; to strain off or decant, as a powder which is separated from heavier particles by being drawn off with water; to cleanse, as by washing.
The process of elutriating; a decanting or racking off by means of water, as finer particles from heavier.
To dislocate; to luxate.
Dislocation; luxation.

sn.def: Pertaining to elves; elvish.
Of or pertaining to certain veins of feldspathic or porphyritic rock crossing metalliferous veins in the mining districts of Cornwall; as, an elvan course.

entry.def: The rock of an elvan vein, or the elvan vein itself; an elvan course.
An old form of Elf.
A young eel; a young conger or sea eel; -- called also elvene.

entries.entry: Elves n.; pl. of Elf.

sn.def: Pertaining to elves; implike; mischievous; weird; also, vacant; absent in demeanor. See Elfish.
sn.q: He seemeth elvish by his countenance.

sn.def: Mysterious; also, foolish.

entry.def: In an elvish manner.
See Ellwand.
Pertaining, or the abode of the blessed after death; hence, yielding the highest pleasures; exceedingly delightful; beatific.
entry.q: Elysianshades.
Elysianage.
This life of mortal breath Is but a suburb of the life elysian.

entries.entry:
E*ly"sium n.; pl. E. Elysiums #, L. Elysia #. L., fr. Gr. �, � �, Elysian field Anc. Myth
A dwelling place assigned to happy souls after death; the seat of future happiness; Paradise.
Hence, any delightful place. An Elysian more pure and bright than that pf the Greeks.

entry.def: Having the form, or structure, of an elytron.
See Chitin.
Resembling a beetle's wing case.

entries.entry:
El"y*tron ?; 277 El"y*trum -tr�m
n.; pl.Elytra #. NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to roll round Zoöl One of the anterior pair of wings in the Coleoptera and some other insects, when they are thick and serve only as a protection for the posterior pair. See Coleoptera. One of the shieldlike dorsal scales of certain annelids. See Chætopoda.

entry.def: Applied to books or editions (esp. of the Greek New Testament and the classics) printed and published by the Elzevir family at Amsterdam, Leyden, etc., from about 1592 to 1680; also, applied to a round open type introduced by them.
entry.q: The Elzevir editions are valued for their neatness, and the elegant small types used.

entries.entry: 'Em. An obsolete or colloquial contraction of the old form hem, them.

entry.def: The portion of a line formerly occupied by the letter m, then a square type, used as a unit by which to measure the amount of printed matter on a page; the square of the body of a type.

entries.entry: Em-. A prefix. See En-.

entry.ety: L. emaceratus emaciated; e + macerare to make soft
entry.def: To make lean or to become lean; to emaciate.
Emaciation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emaciated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emaciating
entry.ety: L. emaciatus, p. p. of emaciare to make lean; e + maciare to make lean or meager, fr. macies leanness, akin to macer lean. See Meager
entry.def: To lose flesh gradually and become very lean; to waste away in flesh.
entry.q: Heemaciatedand pined away.

entry.def: To cause to waste away in flesh and become very lean; as, his sickness emaciated him.
Emaciated.
entry.q: Emaciatesteeds.

entry.def: having become so thin that the bones noticeably protude under the skin; as, emaciated bony hands.
entry.syn: bony, cadaverous, gaunt, haggard, pinched, skeletal, wasted.

sn.def: The act of making very lean.
The state of being emaciated or reduced to excessive leanness; an excessively lean condition.

entry.ety: L. emaculatus, p. p. of emaculare to clear from spots. See Maculate
entry.def: To clear from spots or stains, or from any imperfection.
The act of clearing from spots.
electronic mail; a digitally encoded message sent from one computer to another through an electronic communications medium, especially by means of a computer network.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. E-mailed; p. pr. & vb. n. E-mailing
entry.def: to send (an e-mail message) to someone; as, I emailed the article to the editor; she emailed me her report.

entries.entry: Æ`mail` om`brant" Æ`mail` om`brant". F., shaded enamel Fine Arts An art or process of flooding transparent colored glaze over designs stamped or molded on earthenware or porcelain.

entry.ety: L. emanans -antis, p. pr. of emanare. See Emanate
entry.def: Issuing or flowing forth; emanating; passing forth into an act, or making itself apparent by an effect; -- said of mental acts; as, an emanant volition.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emanated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emanating
entry.ety: L. emanare emanatum, to emanate; e out + manare to flow, prob. for madnare, and akin to madere to be wet, drip, madidus wet, drenched, drunk, Gr. �, �, wet, � to be wet, Skr. mad to boil, matta drunk. Cf. Emane

sn.def: To issue forth from a source; to flow out from more or less constantly; as, fragrance emanates from flowers.
To proceed from, as a source or fountain; to take origin; to arise, to originate.
sn.q: That subsisting from of government from which all special laws emanate.
sn.syn: To flow; arise; proceed; issue; originate.

entry.def: Issuing forth; emanant.

sn.def: The act of flowing or proceeding from a fountain head or origin.
sn.q: Those profitable and excellent emanations from God.

sn.def: That which issues, flows, or proceeds from any object as a source; efflux; an effluence; as, perfume is an emanation from a flower.
sn.q: An emanation of the indwelling life.

entry.def: Issuing forth; effluent.
By an emanation.
Emanative; of the nature of an emanation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emancipated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emancipating
entry.ety: L. emancipatus, p. p. of emancipare to emancipate; e + mancipare to transfer ownership in, fr. manceps purchaser, as being one who laid his hand on the thing bought; manus hand + capere to take. See Manual, and Capable
entry.def: To set free from the power of another; to liberate; as: To set free, as a minor from a parent; as, a father may emancipate a child. To set free from bondage; to give freedom to; to manumit; as, to emancipate a slave, or a country.
entry.q: Brasidas . . . declaring that he was sent to emancipate Hellas.
entry.def: To free from any controlling influence, especially from anything which exerts undue or evil influence; as, to emancipate one from prejudices or error.
entry.q: From how many troublesome and slavish impertinences . . . he had emancipated and freed himself.
To emancipate the human conscience.

entry.def: Set at liberty.

sn.def: free from traditional social restraints; -- used especially of women; as, an emancipated young woman pursuing her career.
freed from bondage.

entry.def: permitting or conducive to the reduction of restraints on behavior.

The act of setting free from the power of another, from slavery, subjection, dependence, or controlling influence; also, the state of being thus set free; the act or process of emancipation, or the state thereby achieved; liberation; as, the emancipation of slaves; the emancipation of minors; the emancipation of a person from prejudices; the emancipation of the mind from superstition; the emancipation of a nation from tyranny or subjection.
entry.syn: Deliverance; liberation; release; freedom; manumission; enfranchisement.

entry.def: An advocate of emancipation, esp. the emancipation of slaves.
One who emancipates.
Pertaining to emancipation, or tending to effect emancipation.
entry.q: Emancipatorylaws.

entry.def: A freed convict.

entry.ety: L. emarginare; e out + marginare to furnish with a margin, fr. margo margin
entry.def: To take away the margin of.

sn.def: Having the margin interrupted by a notch or shallow sinus.
Notched at the summit.
Having the edges truncated.

entry.def: In an emarginate manner.
The act of notching or indenting the margin, or the state of being so notched; also, a notch or shallow sinus in a margin.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emasculated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emasculating
entry.ety: L. emasculare; e + masculus male, masculine. See Male masculine

sn.def: To deprive of virile or procreative power; to castrate power; to castrate; to geld.
To deprive of masculine vigor or spirit; to weaken; to render effeminate; to vitiate by unmanly softness.
sn.q: Luxury had not emasculated their minds.

entry.def: Deprived of virility or vigor; unmanned; weak.
entry.q: Emasculateslave.

sn.def: having the testicles removed; -- of a male animal.
deprived of virility, vigor, or manly character.
The act of depriving of virility, or the state of being so deprived; castration.
The act of depriving, or state of being deprived, of vigor or strength; unmanly weakness.

entry.def: One who, or that which, emasculates.
Serving or tending to emasculate.
See Embase.

entry.ety: F. emballer; pref. em-L. in) + balle bale. See 1st Bale

sn.def: To make up into a bale or pack.
To bind up; to inclose.
sn.q: Legs . . . embaled in golden buskins.

entry.def: To encircle or embrace.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embalmed; p. pr. & vb. n. Embalming
entry.ety: F. embaumer; pref. em-L. in) + baume balm. See Balm

sn.def: To anoint all over with balm; especially, to preserve from decay by means of balm or other aromatic oils, or spices; to fill or impregnate (a dead body), with aromatics and drugs that it may resist putrefaction.
sn.q: Joseph commanded his servants, the physicians, to embalm �is father; and the physicians embalmed Israel.

sn.def: To fill or imbue with sweet odor; to perfume.
sn.q: With fresh dews embalmed the earth.

sn.def: To preserve from decay or oblivion as if with balm; to perpetuate in remembrance.
sn.q: Those tears eternal that embalm the dead.

entry.def: One who embalms.
The act of embalming.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embanked; p. pr. & vb. n. Embanking
entry.def: To throw up a bank so as to confine or to defend; to protect by a bank of earth or stone.

sn.def: The act of surrounding or defending with a bank.
A structure of earth, gravel, etc., raised to prevent water from overflowing a level tract of country, to retain water in a reservoir, or to carry a roadway, etc.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embarred; p. pr. & vb. n. Embanking
entry.ety: Pref. em- + bar: cf. F. embarrer. Cf. Embargo

sn.def: To bar or shut in; to inclose securely, as with bars.
sn.q: Where fast embarred in mighty brazen wall.

sn.def: To stop; to hinder by prohibition; to block up.
sn.q: He embarred all further trade.

entry.def: Same as Embarkation.
To put in a barge.

entries.entry:
Em*bar"go ☞ If the embargo is laid on an enemy's ships, it is called a hostile embargo; if on the ships belonging to citizens of the embargoing state, it is called a civil embargo. n.; pl.Embargoes #. Sp., fr. embargar to arrest, restrain; pref. em-L. in) + Sp. barra bar, akin to F. barre bar. See Bar
An edict or order of the government prohibiting the departure of ships of commerce from some or all of the ports within its dominions; a prohibition to sail.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embargoed; p. pr. & vb. n. Embargoing
entry.def: To lay an embargo on and thus detain; to prohibit from leaving port; -- said of ships, also of commerce and goods.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embarked; p. pr. & vb. n. Embarking
entry.ety: F. embarquer; pref. em-L. in) + barque bark: cf. Sp. embarcar, It. imbarcare. See Bark. a vessel

sn.def: To cause to go on board a vessel or boat; to put on shipboard.
To engage, enlist, or invest (as persons, money, etc.) in any affair; as, he embarked his fortune in trade.
sn.q: It was the reputation of the sect upon which St. Paul embarked his salvation.

sn.def: To go on board a vessel or a boat for a voyage; as, the troops embarked for Lisbon.
To engage in any affair.
sn.q: Slow to embark in such an undertaking.

sn.def: The act of putting or going on board of a vessel; as, the embarkation of troops.
That which is embarked; as, an embarkation of Jesuits.

entry.def: Embarkation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embarrassed ĕm*băr"r�st; p. pr. & vb. n. Embarrassing
entry.ety: F. embarrassercf. Sp. embarazar, Pg. embaraçar, Pr. barras bar); pref. em-L. in) + LL. barra bar. See Bar

sn.def: To hinder from freedom of thought, speech, or action by something which impedes or confuses mental action; to make (a person) unpleasantly self-conscious; to perplex; to discompose; to disconcert; as, laughter may embarrass an orator.
To hinder from liberty of movement; to impede; to obstruct; as, business is embarrassed; public affairs are embarrassed.

To involve in difficulties concerning money matters; to incumber with debt; to beset with urgent claims or demands; -- said of a person or his affairs; as, a man or his business is embarrassed when he can not meet his pecuniary engagements.
sn.syn: To hinder; perplex; entangle; confuse; puzzle; disconcert; abash; distress. -- To Embarrass Puzzle Perplex. We are puzzled when our faculties are confused by something we do not understand. We are perplexed when our feelings, as well as judgment, are so affected that we know not how to decide or act. We are embarrassed when there is some bar or hindrance upon us which impedes our powers of thought, speech, or motion. A schoolboy is puzzled by a difficult sum; a reasoner is perplexed by the subtleties of his opponent; a youth is sometimes so embarrassed before strangers as to lose his presence of mind.

entry.ety: F. embarras. See Embarrass v. t.
entry.def: Embarrassment.

sn.def: feeling uneasily or unpleasantly self-conscious due to some event or circumstance; as, she was embarrassed by her child's tantrums.
feeling inferior or unworthy and hence unpleasantly self-conscious; as, too embarrassed to say hello to his drunken father on the street.
hard to deal with; as, greeted with an embarrassing silence.
sn.syn: awkward, disconcerting, off-putting, sticky, tight, unenviable.

sn.def: causing to feel shame or chagrin or vexation.
A state of being embarrassed; perplexity; impediment to freedom of action; entanglement; hindrance; confusion or discomposure of mind, as from not knowing what to do or to say; disconcertedness.
sn.q: The embarrassment which inexperienced minds have often to express themselves upon paper.
The embarrassments tom commerce growing out of the late regulations.

sn.def: Difficulty or perplexity arising from the want of money to pay debts.

entry.ety: Pref. em- + base, a. or v. t.: cf. OF. embaissier
entry.def: To bring down or lower, as in position, value, etc.; to debase; to degrade; to deteriorate.
entry.q: Embased the valleys, and embossed the hills.
Alloy in coin of gold . . . may make the metal work the better, but it embaseth it.
Such pitiful embellishments of speech as serve for nothing but to embase divinity.

entry.def: Act of bringing down; depravation; deterioration.
An embassy. See Ambassade.

entry.ety: F. ambassadeur, Sp. embajador, LL. ambassiator ambasciator. See Embassy, and cf. Ambassador
entry.def: Same as Ambassador.
entry.q: Stilbon, that was a wise embassadour, Was sent to Corinth.
Myself my king's embassador will go.

entry.def: Same as Ambassadorial.
Same as Ambassadress.
Embassy.

sn.def: An embassy.
sn.q: He sent a solemnembassage.
Except your embassages have better success.

sn.def: Message; errand.

entries.entry:
Em"bas*sy ☞ Sometimes, but rarely, spelled ambassy. n.; pl.Embassies #. OF. ambassée embascée, LL. ambasciata, fr. ambasciare for ambactiare to go on a mission, fr. L. ambactus vassal, dependent, of Celtic or German origin; cf. W. amaeth husbandman, Goth. andbahts servant, G. amt office, OHG. ambaht. Cf. Ambassador
The public function of an ambassador; the charge or business intrusted to an ambassador or to envoys; a public message to; foreign court concerning state affairs; hence, any solemn message. He sends the angels on embassies with his decrees.
The person or persons sent as ambassadors or envoys; the ambassador and his suite; envoys.
The residence or office of an ambassador.

entry.def: To bastardize.
To bathe; to imbathe.
To furnish with battlements; to fortify as with battlements.
entry.q: To embattail and to wall about thy cause With iron-worded proof.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embattled; p. pr. & vb. n. Embattling
entry.ety: OF. embataillier; pref. em-L. in) + F. bataille battle. See Battle, and cf. Battlement
entry.def: To arrange in order of battle; to array for battle; also, to prepare or arm for battle; to equip as for battle.
entry.q: One in bright arms embattled full strong.
Here once the embattled farmers stood And fired the shot heard round the world.

entry.def: To be arrayed for battle.
To furnish with battlements.
entry.q: Embattledhouse.

sn.def: Having indentations like a battlement.
Having the edge broken like battlements; -- said of a bearing such as a fess, bend, or the like.
Having been the place of battle; as, an embattled plain or field.
An intended parapet; a battlement.
The fortifying of a building or a wall by means of battlements.

entry.def: To bathe; to soothe or lull as by bathing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embayed; p. pr. & vb. n. Embaying
entry.def: To shut in, or shelter, as in a bay.
entry.q: If that the Turkish fleet Be not ensheltered and embayed, they are drowned.

entry.def: A bay.
entry.q: The embayment which is terminated by the land of North Berwick.

entry.def: To make brilliant with beams.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embedded; p. pr. & vb. n. Embedding
entry.def: To lay as in a bed; to lay in surrounding matter; to bed; as, to embed a thing in clay, mortar, or sand.

sn.def: enclosed or fixed firmly in a surrounding mass; surrounded on all sides; as, found pebbles embedded in the silt; stone containing many embedded fossils; as, peach and plum seeds embedded in a sweet edible pulp.
inserted as an integral part of a surrounding whole; as, confused by the embedded Latin quotations; an embedded subordinate clause.

entry.def: The act of embedding, or the state of being embedded.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embellished; p. pr. & vb. n. Embellishing
entry.ety: OE. embelisen embelisshen, F. embellir; pref. em-L. in) + bel beau, beautiful. See Beauty
entry.def: To make beautiful or elegant by ornaments; to decorate; to adorn; as, to embellish a book with pictures, a garden with shrubs and flowers, a narrative with striking anecdotes, or style with metaphors.
entry.syn: To adorn; beautify; deck; bedeck; decorate; garnish; enrich; ornament; illustrate. See Adorn.

entry.def: One who embellishes.

sn.def: The act of adorning, or the state of being adorned; adornment.
sn.q: In the selection of their ground, as well as in the embellishment of it.

sn.def: That which adds beauty or elegance; ornament; decoration; as, pictorial embellishments .
sn.q: The graces and embellishments of the exterior man.

entry.ety: OE. emmeres emeres, AS. �myrie; akin to Icel. eimyrja, Dan. emmer, MHG. eimere; cf. Icel. eimr vapor, smoke
entry.def: A lighted coal, smoldering amid ashes; -- used chiefly in the plural, to signify mingled coals and ashes; the smoldering remains of a fire.
entry.q: He rakes hotembers.
He takes a lighted ember out of the covered vessel.

cs.cd: days set apart for fasting and prayer in each of the four seasons of the year. The Council of Placentia [A. D. 1095] appointed for ember days the Wednesday, Friday, and Saturday after the first Sunday in Lent, Whitsuntide, the 14th of September, and the 13th of December. The weeks in which these days fall are called ember weeks.

entry.ety: OE. ymber, AS. ymbren ymbryne, prop., running around, circuit; ymbe around + ryne a running, fr. rinnan to run. See Amb-, and Run
entry.def: Making a circuit of the year of the seasons; recurring in each quarter of the year; as, ember fasts.

entry.ety: Cf. Norw. embergaas hav-imber hav-immer, Icel. himbrin himbrimi
entry.def: The loon or great northern diver. See Loon.
Ember days.
To make better.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Embezzled ĕm*bĕz"z'ld; p. pr. & vb. n. Embezzling
entry.ety: Norm. F. embeseiller to destroy; cf. OF. besillier to ill treat, ravage, destroy. Cf. Bezzle

sn.def: To appropriate fraudulently to one's own use, as property intrusted to one's care; to apply to one's private uses by a breach of trust; as, to embezzle money held in trust.
To misappropriate; to waste; to dissipate in extravagance.
sn.q: To embezzle our money in drinking or gaming.

sn.def: taken for one's own use in violation of a trust; -- of money; as, the banker absconded with embezzled payroll; the embezzled funds amounted to millions of dollars.

entry.note: ☞ Larceny denotes a taking, by fraud or stealth, from another's possession; embezzlement denotes an appropriation, by fraud or stealth, of property already in the wrongdoer's possession. In England and in most of the United States embezzlement is made indictable by statute.
entry.def: The fraudulent appropriation of property by a person to whom it has been intrusted; as, the embezzlement by a clerk of his employer's money; embezzlement of public funds by the public officer having them in charge.
One who embezzles.
To swell or heave like a wave of the sea.
a natural family of viviparous percoid fishes comprising the surf fishes.

entry.ety: NL. Embiotoca, the name of one genus + -oid
entry.def: Belonging to, or resembling, the Embiotocidæ.

def2.def: One of a family of fishes (Embiotocidæ) abundant on the coast of California, remarkable for being viviparous; -- also called surf fish and viviparous fish. See Illust. in Appendix.

entry.def: To make bitter or sad. See Imbitter.
The act of embittering; also, that which embitters.
To whiten. See Blanch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emblazed; p. pr. & vb. n. Emblazing

sn.def: To adorn with glittering embellishments.

sn.def: To paint or adorn with armorial figures; to blazon, or emblazon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emblazoned; p. pr. & vb. n. Emblazoning

sn.def: To depict or represent; -- said of heraldic bearings. See Blazon.
To deck in glaring colors; to set off conspicuously; to display pompously; to decorate.
sn.q: The walls were . . . emblazoned with legends in commemoration of the illustrious pair.

entry.def: One who emblazons; also, one who publishes and displays anything with pomp.
The act or art of heraldic decoration; delineation of armorial bearings.
An emblazoning.

entries.entry: Em*bla"zon*ry n.; pl.Emblazonries. The act or art of an emblazoner; heraldic or ornamental decoration, as pictures or figures on shields, standards, etc.; emblazonment. Thine ancient standard's rich emblazonry.

entry.note: ☞ Writers and artists of the 17th century gave much attention and study to the composition of such emblems, and many collections of them were published.
entry.usage: Sign Emblem Symbol Type. Sign is the generic word comprehending all significant representations. An emblem is a visible object representing another by a natural suggestion of characteristic qualities, or an habitual and recognized association; as, a circle, having no apparent beginning or end, is an emblem of eternity; a particular flag is the emblem of the country or ship which has adopted it for a sign and with which it is habitually associated. Between emblem and symbol the distinction is slight, and often one may be substituted for the other without impropriety. See Symbol. Thus, a circle is either an emblem or a symbol of eternity; a scepter, either an emblem or a symbol of authority; a lamb, either an emblem or a symbol of meekness. “An emblem is always of something simple; a symbol may be of something complex, as of a transaction . . . In consequence we do not speak of actions emblematic.” C. J. Smith. A type is a representative example, or model, exhibiting the qualities common to all individuals of the class to which it belongs; as, the Monitor is a type of a class of war vessels.
entry.ety: F. emblème, L. emblema -atis, that which is put in or on, inlaid work, fr. Gr. � a thing put in or on, fr. � to throw, lay, put in; � in + � to throw. See In, and Parable

sn.def: Inlay; inlaid or mosaic work; something ornamental inserted in a surface.

A visible sign of an idea; an object, or the figure of an object, symbolizing and suggesting another object, or an idea, by natural aptness or by association; a figurative representation; a typical designation; a symbol; as, a balance is an emblem of justice; a scepter, the emblem of sovereignty or power; a circle, the emblem of eternity.
sn.q: His cicatrice, anemblemof war, here on his sinister cheek.

sn.def: A picture accompanied with a motto, a set of verse, or the like, intended as a moral lesson or meditation.
sn.syn: Sign; symbol; type; device; signal; token.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emblemed; p. pr. & vb. n. Embleming
entry.def: To represent by an emblem; to symbolize.
entry.q: Emblemed by the cozening fig tree.

entry.def: Pertaining to, containing, or consisting in, an emblem; symbolic; typically representative; representing as an emblem; as, emblematic language or ornaments; a crown is emblematic of royalty; white is emblematic of purity.
To render emblematic; as, to emblematicize a picture.
A writer or inventor of emblems.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emblematized; p. pr. & vb. n. Emblematizing
entry.def: To represent by, or as by, an emblem; to symbolize.
entry.q: Anciently the sun was commonly emblematized by a starry or radiate figure.

entry.ety: OF. embleer to sow with corn, F. emblaver, fr. LL. imbladare; pref. in- + LL. bladum grain, F. blé
entry.def: The growing crop, or profits of a crop which has been sown or planted; -- used especially in the plural. The produce of grass, trees, and the like, is not emblement.

entry.def: One who embodies.

sn.def: The act of embodying; the state of being embodied.
That which embodies or is embodied; representation in a physical body; a completely organized system, like the body; as, the embodiment of courage, or of courtesy; the embodiment of true piety.

entry.ety: F., fr. emboîter to fit in, insert; en in + boîte box
entry.def: The hypothesis that all living things proceed from preëxisting germs, and that these encase the germs of all future living things, inclosed one within another.

entry.ety: L. embolismus, from Gr. � to throw or put in, insert; cf. � intercalated: cf. F. embolisme. See Emblem

Em"bo*lus n.; pl.Emboli #. L., fr. Gr. � pointed so as to be put or thrust in, fr. � to throw, thrust, or put in. See Emblem
Something inserted, as a wedge; the piston or sucker of a pump or syringe.
Med A plug of some substance lodged in a blood vessel, being brought thither by the blood current. It consists most frequently of a clot of fibrin, a detached shred of a morbid growth, a globule of fat, or a microscopic organism.

entry.def: Embolic invagination. See under Invagination.

entry.ety: F., fr. en bon point in good condition. See Bon, and Point

Needlework used to enrich textile fabrics, leather, etc.; also, the art of embroidering.
Diversified ornaments, especially by contrasted figures and colors; variegated decoration. Fields in spring's embroidery are dressed. A mere rhetorical embroidery of phrases.

entries.entry:
Em"bry*o
In embryo in an incipient or undeveloped state; in conception, but not yet executed. “The company little suspected what a noble work I had then in embryo.” Swift.
n.; pl.Embryos #. F. embryon, Gr. 'e`mbryon, perh. fr. � in (akin to L. � E. in) + � to be full of, swell with; perh. akin to E. brew
Biol The first rudiments of an organism, whether animal or plant; as: The young of an animal in the womb, or more specifically, before its parts are developed and it becomes a fetus (see Fetus). The germ of the plant, which is inclosed in the seed and which is developed by germination.

entry.def: Pertaining to an embryo; rudimentary; undeveloped; as, an embryo bud.
Pertaining to the development of an embryo.

entry.ety: Gr. 'e`mbryon an embryo + root of � to produce: cf. F. embryogénie
entry.def: The production and development of an embryo.
The formation of an embryo.
The general description of embryos.
Of or pertaining to embryology.
One skilled in embryology.

entry.ety: Gr. 'e`mbryon an embryo + -logy: cf. F. embryologie
entry.def: The science which relates to the formation and development of the embryo in animals and plants; a study of the gradual development of the ovum until it reaches the adult stage.
See Embryo.
Pertaining to an embryo, or the initial state of any organ; embryonic.
Embryonic.
In the state of, or having, an embryonal.

cs.cd: the vesicle within which the embryo is developed in the ovule; -- sometimes called also amnios sac, and embryonal sac.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an embryo; embryonal; rudimentary.
Having an embryo.
Like an embryo in form.
Relating to, or aiding in, the formation of an embryo; as, embryoplastic cells.

entries.entry: Em"bry*o sac`. Bot See under Embryonic.

entry.def: Embryonic.

entry.ety: Gr. 'e`mbryon an embryo + te`mnein to cut: cf. F. embryotomie
entry.def: The cutting a fetus into pieces within the womb, so as to effect its removal.
The material from which an embryo is formed and nourished.
Embryonic; undeveloped.
To enlarge in the way of bulk.
To furnish with money; to imburse.
To place or hide in a thicket; to ambush.

entry.ety: OE. embusshement, OF. embuschement, F. embûchement
entry.def: An ambush.
To employ.
An uncle.
Same as Emir.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emended; p. pr. & vb. n. Emending
entry.ety: L. emendare; e out + menda mendum, fault, blemish: cf. F. émender. Cf. Amend Mend
entry.def: To purge of faults; to make better; to correct; esp., to make corrections in (a literary work); to alter for the better by textual criticism, generally verbal.
entry.syn: To amend; correct; improve; better; reform; rectify. See Amend.

entry.def: Corrigible; amendable.
Without fault; correctly.

sn.q: He lies in his sin without repentance oremendation.
