entry.def: One who emends or critically edits.
Pertaining to emendation; corrective.
entry.q: Emendatorycriticism.

entry.def: One who emends.

entry.ety: L. emendicatus, p. p. of emendicare to obtain by begging. See Mendicate
entry.def: To beg.

entry.note: ☞ This line is printed in the type called emerald.
entry.ety: OE. emeraude, OF. esmeraude esmeralde, F. émeraude, L. smaragdus, fr. Gr. �; cf. �kr. marakata

sn.def: A precious stone of a rich green color, a variety of beryl. See Beryl.
A kind of type, in size between minion and nonpare�l. It is used by English printers.

entry.cs:
Emerald fish Zoöl a fish of the Gulf of Mexico (Gobionellus oceanicus), remarkable for the brilliant green and blue color of the base of the tongue; -- whence the name; -- called also esmeralda. Emerald green a very durable pigment, of a vivid light green color, made from the arseniate of copper; green bice; Scheele's green; -- also used adjectively; as, emerald green crystals. Emerald Isle a name given to Ireland on account of the brightness of its verdure.
Emerald spodumeneorLithia emerald . Min See Hiddenite. Emerald nickel. Min See Zaratite.
entry.def: Of a rich green color, like that of the emerald.
entry.q: Emeraldmeadows.

entry.def: A green compound used as a dyestuff, produced from aniline blue when acted upon by acid.
An emerald.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emerged; p. pr. & vb. n. Emerging
entry.ety: L. emergere emersum; e out + mergere to dip, plunge. See Merge
entry.def: To rise out of a fluid; to come forth from that in which anything has been plunged, enveloped, or concealed; to issue and appear; as, to emerge from the water or the ocean; the sun emerges from behind the moon in an eclipse; to emerge from poverty or obscurity.
entry.q: Thetis . . .emergingfrom the deep.
Those who have emerged from very low, some from the lowest, classes of society.

entries.entry: E*mer"gence n.; pl.Emergences. The act of rising out of a fluid, or coming forth from envelopment or concealment, or of rising into view; sudden uprisal or appearance. The white color of all refracted light, at its very first emergence . . . is compounded of various colors. When from the deep thy bright emergence sprung.

E*mer"gen*cy n.; pl.Emergencies #. See Emergence
Sudden or unexpected appearance; an unforeseen occurrence; a sudden occasion. Most our rarities have been found out by casual emergency.
An unforeseen occurrence or combination of circumstances which calls for immediate action or remedy; pressing necessity; exigency. To whom she might her doubts propose, On all emergencies that rose. A safe counselor in most difficult emergencies. Crisis; conjuncture; exigency; pinch; strait; necessity.

cs.cd: the epoch or date from which any people begin to compute their time or dates; as, the emergent year of Christendom is that of the birth of Christ; the emergent year of the United States is that of the declaration of their independence.

entry.ety: L. emergens, p. pr. of emergere

sn.def: Rising or emerging out of a fluid or anything that covers or conceals; issuing; coming to light.
sn.q: The mountains huge appear emergent.

sn.def: Suddenly appearing; arising unexpectedly; calling for prompt action; urgent.
sn.q: Protection granted in emergent danger.

sn.def: Emery.
A glazier's diamond.

entry.def: Considered as having done sufficient public service, and therefore honorably discharged.

entry.ety: L., having served out his time, p. p. of emerere emereri, to obtain by service, serve out one's term; e out + merere mereri, to merit, earn, serve
entry.def: Honorably discharged from the performance of public duty on account of age, infirmity, or long and faithful services; -- said of an officer of a college or pastor of a church.

entries.entry: E*mer"i*tus‖n.; pl.Emeriti #. L A veteran who has honorably completed his service.

entry.def: Hemorrhoids; piles; tumors; boils.

entry.ety: L. emersus, p. p. See Emerge
entry.def: Standing out of, or rising above, water.

sn.def: The act of emerging, or of rising out of anything; as, emersion from the sea; emersion from obscurity or difficulties.
sn.q: Their immersion into water and their emersion out of the same.

sn.def: The reappearance of a heavenly body after an eclipse or occultation; as, the emersion of the moon from the shadow of the earth; the emersion of a star from behind the moon.

cs.cd: cardboard pulp mixed with emery and molded into convenient.
cloth or paper on which the powder of emery is spread and glued for scouring and polishing.
a wheel containing emery, or having a surface of emery. In machine shops, it is sometimes called a buff wheel, and by the manufacturers of cutlery, a glazer.

entry.ety: F. émeri, earlier émeril, It. smeriglio, fr. Gr. �, �, �, cf. � to wipe; perh. akin to E. smear. Cf. Emeril
entry.def: Corundum in the form of grains or powder, used in the arts for grinding and polishing hard substances. Native emery is mixed with more or less magnetic iron. See the Note under Corundum.
A vomiting.

entry.ety: L. emeticus, Gr. �, fr. � to vomit, akin to L. vomere: cf. F. émétique. See Vomit
entry.def: Inducing to vomit; exciting the stomach to discharge its contents by the mouth.
Inducing to vomit; producing vomiting; emetic.
A white crystalline bitter alkaloid extracted from ipecacuanha root, and regarded as its peculiar emetic principle.
Producing vomiting and purging at the same time.
See Emu.
A seditious tumult; an outbreak.
An abbreviation for electro-motive force.

cs.cd: so far as lies in my power.

entry.ety: AS. em- emn-, in comp. equiv. to efen equal + forð forth
entry.def: According to; conformably to.
The South African wart hog. See Wart hog.

entry.ety: L. emicans, p. pr. of emicare. See Emication
entry.def: Beaming forth; flashing.
entry.q: Which emicant did this and that way dart.

entry.ety: L. emicatio, fr. emicare to spring out or forth; e out + micare to move quickly to and fro, to sparkle
entry.def: A flying off in small particles, as heated iron or fermenting liquors; a sparkling; scintillation.

entry.ety: L. e out + mingere mictum, to make water

sn.def: The voiding of urine.
What is voided by the urinary passages; urine.

entry.def: Diuretic.

entry.ety: L. emigrans -antis, p. pr. of emigrare to emigrate: cf. F. émigrant. See Emigrate v. i.

sn.def: Removing from one country to another; emigrating; as, an emigrant company or nation.
Pertaining to an emigrant; used for emigrants; as, an emigrant ship or hospital.

entry.def: One who emigrates, or quits one country or region to settle in another.
entry.syn: Emigrant Immigrant. Emigrant and emigration have reference to the country from which the migration is made; the correlative words immigrant and immigration have reference to the country into which the migration is made, the former marking the going out from a country, the latter the coming into it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emigrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emigrating
entry.ety: L. emigratus, p. p. of emigrare to remove, emigrate; e out + migrare to migrate. See Migrate
entry.def: To remove from one country or State to another, for the purpose of residence; to migrate from home.
entry.q: Forced to emigrate in a body to America.
They [the Huns] were emigrating from Tartary into Europe in the time of the Goths.

entry.def: Migratory; roving.

sn.def: The act of emigrating; removal from one country or state to another, for the purpose of residence, as from Europe to America, or, in America, from the Atlantic States to the Western.
A body emigrants; emigrants collectively; as, the German emigration .

entry.def: Relating to emigration.
An advocate or promoter of emigration.
One who emigrates; am emigrant.
One of the natives of France who were opposed to the first Revolution, and who left their country in consequence.

entry.ety: L. eminentia, fr. eminens eminent: cf. F. éminence

sn.def: That which is eminent or lofty; a high ground or place; a height.
sn.q: Without either eminences or cavities.
The temple of honor ought to be seated on an eminence.

sn.def: An elevated condition among men; a place or station above men in general, either in rank, office, or celebrity; social or moral loftiness; high rank; distinction; preferment.
sn.q: You 've too a woman's heart, which ever yet Affected eminence, wealth, sovereignty.

sn.def: A title of honor, especially applied to a cardinal in the Roman Catholic Church.

entries.entry:
Em"i*nen*cy n.; pl.Eminences. State of being eminent; eminence.
Eminencyof estate.

entry.cs: Right of eminent domain. Law See under Domain.
entry.ety: L. eminens -entis, p. pr. of eminere to stand out, be prominent; e out + minerein comp.) to project; of uncertain origin: cf. F. éminent. Cf. Menace

sn.def: High; lofty; towering; prominent.
sn.q: A veryeminentpromontory.

sn.def: Being, metaphorically, above others, whether by birth, high station, merit, or virtue; high in public estimation; distinguished; conspicuous; as, an eminent station; an eminent historian, statements, statesman, or saint.
sn.syn: Lofty; elevated; exalted; conspicuous; prominent; remarkable; distinguished; illustrious; famous; celebrated; renowned; well-known. See Distinguished.

entry.def: In an eminent manner; in a high degree; conspicuously; as, to be eminently learned.

entry.ety: Ar. emīr amīr, commander: cf. F. émir. Cf. Admiral Ameer
entry.def: An Arabian military commander, independent chieftain, or ruler of a province; also, an honorary title given to the descendants of Mohammed, in the line of his daughter Fatima; among the Turks, likewise, a title of dignity, given to certain high officials.
The rank or office of an Emir.

entries.entry:
Em"is*sa*ry A spy is one who enters an enemy's camp or territories to learn the condition of the enemy; an emissary may be a secret agent appointed not only to detect the schemes of an opposing party, but to influence their councils. A spy must be concealed, or he suffers death; an emissary may in some cases be known as the agent of an adversary without incurring similar hazard. n.; pl.Emissaries #. L. emissarius, fr. emittere emissum, to send out: cf. F. émissaire. See Emit
An agent employed to advance, in a covert manner, the interests of his employers; one sent out by any power that is at war with another, to create dissatisfaction among the people of the latter. Buzzing emissaries fill the ears Of listening crowds with jealousies and fears.
Emissary Spy.

sn.def: Exploring; spying.
Applied to the veins which pass out of the cranium through apertures in its walls.

entry.def: The office of an emissary.

cs.cd: the theory of Newton, regarding light as consisting of emitted particles or corpuscles. See Corpuscular theory, under Corpuscular.

entry.ety: L. emissio: cf. F. émission. See Emit

sn.def: The act of sending or throwing out; the act of sending forth or putting into circulation; issue; as, the emission of light from the sun; the emission of heat from a fire; the emission of bank notes.
That which is sent out, issued, or put in circulation at one time; issue; as, the emission was mostly blood.

entry.def: Looking, or narrowly examining; prying.
entry.q: Thoseemissitiouseyes.

entry.def: Sending out; emitting; as, emissive powers.
Tendency to emission; comparative facility of emission, or rate at which emission takes place;
the rate of emission of heat from a bounding surface per degree of temperature difference between the surface and surrounding substances (called by Fourier external conductivity).
Same as Emissary a., 2.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Emitting
entry.ety: L. emittere to send out; e out + mittere to send. See Mission

sn.def: To send forth; to throw or give out; to cause to issue; to give vent to; to eject; to discharge; as, fire emits heat and smoke; boiling water emits steam; the sun emits light.
sn.q: Lest, wrathful, the far-shooting god emit His fatal arrows.

sn.def: To issue forth, as an order or decree; to print and send into circulation, as notes or bills of credit.
sn.q: No State shall . . . emit bills of credit.

entry.def: Sending forth; emissive.
giving off light or heat or radiation; as, the physical temperature of the emitting material.

sn.def: a genus of plants consisting of one species, the yellow bells.

entry.ety: Pref. em-L. in) + mantle: cf. F. emmanteler. Cf. Inmantle
entry.def: To cover over with, or as with, a mantle; to put about as a protection.
See Immanuel.
To turn to marble; to harden.
entry.q: Thou dost emmarble the proud heart.

entry.ety: Gr. �, n. pl., menses (� in + � month) + � leading, fr. � to lead: cf. F. emménagogue
entry.def: A medicine that promotes the menstrual discharge.
a type of large-holed Swiss cheese.
a hard red wheat (Triticum dicoccum) grown especially in Russia and Germany; also grown in the U. S. as stock feed.
entry.syn: starch wheat, two-grain spelt, Triticum dicoccum.

cs.cd: the wryneck{3, a type of bird related to the woodpeckers.

entry.ety: OE. emete amete, AS. æmete. See Ant
entry.def: An ant.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`mmetros in measure, proportioned, suitable ('en in + me`tron measure) + 'w`ps 'wpo`s, eye
entry.def: That refractive condition of the eye in which the rays of light are all brought accurately and without undue effort to a focus upon the retina; -- opposed to hypermetropia myopia, and astigmatism.
Pertaining to, or characterized by, emmetropia.
entry.q: The normal or emmetropic eye adjusts itself perfectly for all distances.

entry.def: Same as Emmetropia.

entry.ety: Pref. em-L. in) + mew. Cf. Immew
entry.def: To mew or coop up.

entry.ety: For emove: cf. F. émouvoir, L. emovere. See Emotion
entry.def: To move; to rouse; to excite.
An orange-red crystalline substance, C15H10O5, obtained from the buckthorn, rhubarb, etc., and regarded as a derivative of anthraquinone; -- so called from a species of rhubarb (Rheum emodei).

entry.ety: L. e out + mollescere, incho. fr. mollere to be soft, mollis soft
entry.def: That degree of softness in a body beginning to melt which alters its shape; the first or lowest degree of fusibility.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emolliated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emolliating
entry.def: To soften; to render effeminate.
entry.q: Emolliated by four centuries of Roman domination, the Belgic colonies had forgotten their pristine valor.

entry.ety: L. emolliens -entis, p. pr. of emollire to soften; e out + mollire to soften, mollis soft: cf. F. émollient. See Mollify
entry.def: Softening; making supple; acting as an emollient.
entry.q: Emollientapplications.

entry.def: An external something or soothing application to allay irritation, soreness, etc.
The act of softening or relaxing; relaxation.

entry.ety: L. emolumentum, lit., a working out, fr. emoliri to move out, work out; e out + moliri to set in motion, exert one's self, fr. moles a huge, heavy mass: cf. F. émolument. See Mole a mound
entry.def: The profit arising from office, employment, or labor; gain; compensation; advantage; perquisites, fees, or salary.
entry.q: A long . . . enjoyment of the emoluments of office.

entry.def: Pertaining to an emolument; profitable.
Among.

entry.usage: Emotion Feeling Agitation. Feeling is the weaker term, and may be of the body or the mind. Emotion is of the mind alone, being the excited action of some inward susceptibility or feeling; as, an emotion of pity, terror, etc. Agitation may be bodily or mental, and usually arises in the latter case from a vehement struggle between contending desires or emotions. See Passion. “Agitations have but one character, viz., that of violence; emotions vary with the objects that awaken them. There are emotions either of tenderness or anger, either gentle or strong, either painful or pleasing.” Crabb.
entry.ety: L. emovere emotum, to remove, shake, stir up; e out + movere to move: cf. F. émotion. See Move, and cf. Emmove
entry.def: A moving of the mind or soul; excitement of the feelings, whether pleasing or painful; disturbance or agitation of mind caused by a specific exciting cause and manifested by some sensible effect on the body.
entry.q: How different the emotions between departure and return!
Some vague emotion of delight.
entry.syn: Feeling; agitation; tremor; trepidation; perturbation; passion; excitement.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or characterized by, emotion; excitable; easily moved; sensational; as, an emotional nature.
The cultivation of an emotional state of mind; tendency to regard things in an emotional manner.
To give an emotional character to.
entry.q: Brought up in a pious family where religion was not talked about emotionalized, but was accepted as the rule of thought and conduct.

entry.def: Affected with emotion.
entry.q: Theemotionedsoul.

entry.sn: unsusceptible to, destitute of, or showing no emotion; unmoved by feeling. Opposite of emotional; as, he kept his emotionless objectivity and faith in the cause he served.Narrower terms: matter-of-fact, prosaic; philosophical, philosophic; phlegmatic, phlegmatical, stolid; stoic, stoical; unblinking Also See: cool passionless unmovedpredicate), unmoving. unemotional, passionless.

entry.def: Attended by, or having the character of, emotion.
Susceptibility to emotion.
Emotiveness.
To move.
To impair.

entry.ety: Gr. � (sc. �), fr. � to stamp in; � in + � to strike
entry.def: Having to do with inlaid work; -- especially used with reference to work of the ancient Greeks.

entry.ety: Pref. em-L. in) + pale: cf. OF. empalir
entry.def: To make pale.
entry.q: No bloodless malady empales their face.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Empaled; p. pr. & vb. n. Empaling
entry.ety: OF. empaler to palisade, pierce, F. empaler to punish by empalement; pref. em-L. in) + OF. & F. pal a pale, stake. See Pale a stake, and cf. Impale

sn.def: To fence or fortify with stakes; to surround with a line of stakes for defense; to impale.
sn.q: All that dwell near enemies empale villages, to save themselves from surprise.

sn.def: To inclose; to surround. See Impale.
To put to death by thrusting a sharpened stake through the body.
Same as Impale.

entry.ety: Cf. F. empalement, fr. empaler. See Empale

sn.def: A fencing, inclosing, or fortifying with stakes.
A putting to death by thrusting a sharpened stake through the body.
Same as Impalement.

entry.def: A list of jurors; a panel.
See Impanel.
Completely armed; panoplied.
Same as Imparadise.

entry.ety: Pref. em- + park: cf. OF. emparchier emparkier. Cf. Impark
entry.def: To make a park of; to inclose, as with a fence; to impark.
Parley; imparlance.

entry.ety: F. empasme, fr. Gr. � to sprinkle in or on; � in + � to sprinkle
entry.def: A perfumed powder sprinkled upon the body to mask the odor of sweat.
To move with passion; to affect strongly. See Impassion.
entry.q: Those sights empassion me full near.

entry.def: Strongly affected.
entry.q: The Briton Prince was sore empassionate.

entry.def: To put in pawn; to pledge; to impawn.
entry.q: To sell, empawn, and alienate the estates.

entry.def: To hinder. See Impeach.
To form like pearls; to decorate with, or as with, pearls; to impearl.
To form into a people or community; to inhabit; to people.
entry.q: We now know 't is very well empeopled.

entry.def: See Empress.
An empress.
To put in peril. See Imperil.
Perished; decayed.
entry.q: I deem thy brain emperished be.

entry.cs: Emperor goose Zoöl a large and handsome goose (Philacte canagica), found in Alaska. Emperor moth Zoöl one of several large and beautiful bombycid moths, with transparent spots on the wings; as the American Cecropia moth (Platysamia cecropia), and the European species (Saturnia pavonia). Emperor paper. See under Paper. Purple emperor Zoöl a large, strong British butterfly (Apatura iris).
entry.ety: OF. empereor empereour, F. empereur, L. imperator, fr. imperare to command; in in + parare to prepare, order. See Parade, and cf. Imperative Empress
entry.def: The sovereign or supreme monarch of an empire; -- a title of dignity superior to that of king; as, the emperor of Germany or of Austria; the emperor or Czar of Russia.
The rank or office of an emperor.

entry.ety: L. imperium, influenced by OF. emperie empire. See Empire
entry.def: Empire; sovereignty; dominion.
entry.q: Struggling for my woman's empery.

entry.def: a natural family of heathlike shrubs including the crowberry (Empetrum nigrum).
A genus of heathlike shrubs including the crowberry Empetrum nigrum).

entries.entry:
em"pha*sis ĕm"fȧ*sĭs n.; pl.Emphases ĕm"fȧ*sēz. L., fr. Gr. 'e`mfasis significance, force of expression, fr. 'emfai`nein to show in, indicate; 'en in + fai`nein to show. See In, and Phase
Rhet A particular stress of utterance, or force of voice, given in reading and speaking to one or more words whose signification the speaker intends to impress specially upon his audience. The province of emphasis is so much more important than accent, that the customary seat of the latter is changed, when the claims of emphasis require it.
A peculiar impressiveness of expression or weight of thought; vivid representation, enforcing assent; as, to dwell on a subject with great emphasis . External objects stand before us . . . in all the life and emphasis of extension, figure, and color.
a special attention given to, or extra importance attached to, something; as, a guided tour of Egypt with emphasis on the monuments along the Nile.
something to which great importance is attached; as, the need for increased spending on education was the emphasis of his speech.

entry.def: To place emphasis on; same as emphasize.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emphasized; p. pr. & vb. n. Emphasizing
entry.def: To utter or pronounce with a particular stress of voice; to make emphatic; as, to emphasize a word or a phrase.
Having stress or emphasis.
The act of giving special importance or significance to something.

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. emphatique. See Emphasis

sn.def: Uttered with emphasis; made prominent and impressive by a peculiar stress of voice; laying stress; deserving of stress or emphasis; forcible; impressive; strong; as, to remonstrate in an emphatic manner; emphatic denials; an emphatic word; an emphatic tone; emphatic reasoning.
Striking the sense; attracting special attention; impressive; forcible.
sn.q: Emphaticalcolors.
Emphaticalevils.

sn.def: Forceful and definite in expression or action; -- of statements, actions, or sections of documents; as, the document contained a particularly emphatic guarantee of religious liberty.
Sudden and strong; -- of statements; as, an emphatic no.
sn.syn: Forcible; earnest; impressive; energetic; striking; positive; important; special; significant.

sn.def: With emphasis; forcibly; in a striking manner or degree; preëminently; as, he emphatically denied the allegations.
sn.q: He was indeed emphatically a popular writer.

sn.def: Not really, but apparently.

entry.def: The quality of being emphatic; emphasis.

entry.ety: Gr. � obstructing, fr. � to block up
entry.def: Having the quality of closing the pores of the skin.
To madden.

cs.cd: a common disease of the lungs in which the air cells are distended and their partition walls ruptured by an abnormal pressure of the air contained in them.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � inflation, fr. � to inflate; � in + � to blow: cf. F. emphysème
entry.def: A swelling produced by gas or air diffused in the cellular tissue.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, emphysema; swelled; bloated.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, lit., an implanting, fr. � to plant or improve land; � in + � to plant
entry.def: A real right, susceptible of assignment and of descent, charged on productive real estate, the right being coupled with the enjoyment of the property on condition of taking care of the estate and paying taxes, and sometimes a small rent.
Of or pertaining to an emphyteusis; as, emphyteutic lands.
One who holds lands by emphyteusis.
To pierce; to impierce.
Fixed; settled; fastened.

entry.cs: Celestial empire. See under Celestial. Empire City a common designation of the city of New York. Empire State a common designation of the State of New York.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. imperium a command, sovereignty, dominion, empire, fr. imperare. See Emperor; cf. Imperial

sn.def: Supreme power; sovereignty; sway; dominion.
sn.q: Theempireof the sea.
Over hell extend His empire, and with iron scepter rule.

sn.def: The dominion of an emperor; the territory or countries under the jurisdiction and dominion of an emperor (rarely of a king), usually of greater extent than a kingdom, always comprising a variety in the nationality of, or the forms of administration in, constituent and subordinate portions; as, the Austrian empire .
sn.q: Empire carries with it the idea of a vast and complicated government.

sn.def: Any dominion; supreme control; governing influence; rule; sway; as, the empire of mind or of reason.
sn.q: Under theempireof facts.
Another force which, in the Middle Ages, shared with chivalry the empire over the minds of men.
sn.syn: Sway; dominion; rule; control; reign; sovereignty; government; kingdom; realm; state.

entries.entry: Empire State. New York; -- a nickname alluding to its size and wealth.
Empire State of the South. Georgia; -- a nickname.
Empire State of the West. Missouri; -- a nickname.

entry.ety: L. empiricus an empiric, Gr. � experienced, equiv. to �; � in + � a trial, experiment; akin to � ford, way, and E. fare: cf. F. empirique. See In, and Fare

sn.def: One who follows an empirical method; one who relies upon practical experience.

One who confines himself to applying the results of mere experience or his own observation; especially, in medicine, one who deviates from the rules of science and regular practice; an ignorant and unlicensed pretender; a quack; a charlatan.
sn.q: Among the Greek physicians, those who founded their practice on experience called themselves empirics.
Swallow down opinions as silly people do empirics' pills.

entry.cs: Empirical formula. Chem See under Formula.

sn.def: Pertaining to, or founded upon, experiment or experience; depending upon the observation of phenomena; versed in experiments.
sn.q: In philosophical language, the term empirical means simply what belongs to or is the product of experience or observation.
The village carpenter . . . lays out his work by empirical rules learnt in his apprenticeship.

sn.def: Depending upon experience or observation alone, without due regard to science and theory; -- said especially of medical practice, remedies, etc.; wanting in science and deep insight; as, empiric skill, remedies.

entry.def: By experiment or experience; without science; in the manner of quacks.

sn.def: The method or practice of an empiric; pursuit of knowledge by observation and experiment.
Specifically, a practice of medicine founded on mere experience, without the aid of science or a knowledge of principles; ignorant and unscientific practice; charlatanry; quackery.
The philosophical theory which attributes the origin of all our knowledge to experience.

entry.def: An empiric.
Relating to, or resulting from, experience, or experiment; following from empirical methods or data; -- opposed to nativistic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emplaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Emplacing
entry.ety: Cf. F. emplacer. See En-; Place v. & n.
entry.def: To put into place or position; to fix on an emplacement.
A putting in, or assigning to, a definite place; localization; as, the emplacement of a structure.

entry.ety: OF. emplastre, F. emplâtre, L. emplastrum a plaster or salve, fr. Gr. �, fr. � to plaster up, daub over; � in + � to form, mold, apply as a plaster
entry.def: See Plaster.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. emplastrer, F. emplâtrer. See Emplaster n.
entry.def: To plaster over; to cover over so as to present a good appearance.
entry.q: Fair as ye his nameemplaster.

entry.ety: Cf. F. emplastique, fr. Gr. � clogging. See Emplaster
entry.def: Fit to be applied as a plaster; glutinous; adhesive; as, emplastic applications.
A medicine causing constipation.

sn.def: The act or process of grafting by inoculation; budding.
The application of a plaster or salve.

entry.ety: Pref. em-L. in) + plead: cf. F. emplaidier. Cf. Implead
entry.def: To accuse; to indict. See Implead.
See Emplecton.

entry.ety: F. or L. emplecton, fr. Gr. �, fr. � interwoven, fr. � to plait or weave in; � in + � to twist, weave
entry.def: A kind of masonry in which the outer faces of the wall are ashlar, the space between being filled with broken stone and mortar. Cross layers of stone are interlaid as binders.
See Implore.

cs.cd: to apply or devote one's time and attention; to busy one's self.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Employed; p. pr. & vb. n. Employing
entry.ety: F. employer, fr. L. implicare to fold into, infold, involve, implicate, engage; in + plicare to fold. See Ply, and cf. Imply Implicate

sn.def: To inclose; to infold.

To use; to have in service; to cause to be engaged in doing something; -- often followed by in about on, or upon, and sometimes by to; as: To make use of, as an instrument, a means, a material, etc., for a specific purpose; to apply; as, to employ the pen in writing, bricks in building, words and phrases in speaking; to employ the mind; to employ one's energies.
sn.q: This is a day in which the thoughts . . . ought to be employed on serious subjects.

sd.def: To occupy; as, to employ time in study.
To have or keep at work; to give employment or occupation to; to intrust with some duty or behest; as, to employ a hundred workmen; to employ an envoy.
sd.q: Jonathan . . . and Jahaziah . . . were employed about this matter.
Thy vineyard must employ the sturdy steer To turn the glebe.
sd.syn: To use; busy; apply; exercise; occupy; engross; engage. See Use.

cs.cd: in one's service.

entry.def: That which engages or occupies a person; fixed or regular service or business; employment.
entry.q: The whole employ of body and of mind.

entry.def: Capable of being employed; capable of being used; fit or proper for use.
One employed by another; a clerk or workman in the service of an employer.
One employed by another.
One who employs another; as, an employer of workmen.

sn.def: The act of employing or using; also, the state of being employed.

That which engages or occupies; that which consumes time or attention; office or post of business; service; as, agricultural employments; mechanical employments; public employments; in the employment of government.
sn.q: Cares are employments, and without employ The soul is on a rack.
sn.syn: Work; business; occupation; vocation; calling; office; service; commission; trade; profession.

entry.def: Plumed.
To plunge; to implunge.

entry.ety: F. empoisonner; pref. em- + F. poison. See Poison, and cf. Impoison
entry.def: To poison; to impoison.
Poison.
Poisoner.
The act of poisoning.
Pertaining to an emporium; relating to merchandise.

entries.entry:
Em*po"ri*um n.; pl.Emporiums #, L. Emporia #. L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � belonging to commerce, fr. � traveler, trader; � in + � way through and over, path. See In, and Empiric Fare
A place of trade; a market place; a mart; esp., a city or town with extensive commerce; the commercial center of a country. That wonderful emporiumManchester] . . . was then a mean and ill-built market town. It is pride . . . which fills our streets, our emporiums, our theathers.
Physiol The brain. Obs

entry.def: See Impoverish.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Empowered; p. pr. & vb. n. Empowering

sn.def: To give authority to; to delegate power to; to commission; to authorize (having commonly a legal force); as, the Supreme Court is empowered to try and decide cases, civil or criminal; the attorney is empowered to sign an acquittance, and discharge the debtor.
To give moral or physical power, faculties, or abilities to.
sn.q: These eyes . . .empoweredto gaze.

sn.def: to enable or permit; to give more opportunity for independent action.
invested with legal power or official authority especially as symbolized by having a scepter.
enabled or permitted; as, the women's liberation movement empowered wives to take more control of their own lives.

cs.cd: a cloth for ladies' dresses, either wholly of wool, or with cotton warp and wool weft. It resembles merino, but is not twilled.

entry.ety: OE. empress emperice, OF. empereis empereris, fr. L. imperatrix, fem. of imperator. See Emperor

sn.def: The consort of an emperor.
A female sovereign.
A sovereign mistress.
sn.q: Empressof my soul.

entries.entry: Em`presse`ment"‖n. F., fr s'empresser to hasten Demonstrative warmth or cordiality of manner; display of enthusiasm. He grasped my hand with a nervous empressement.

entry.def: See Imprint.

entry.ety: OF. emprise, fr. emprendre to undertake; pref. em-L. in) + F. prendre to take, L. prehendere prendere; prae before + a verb akin to E. get. See Get, and cf. Enterprise Impresa

sn.def: An enterprise; endeavor; adventure.
sn.q: In brave pursuit of chivalrous emprise.
The deeds of love and high emprise.

sn.def: The qualifies which prompt one to undertake difficult and dangerous exploits.
sn.q: I love thy courage yet and bolt emprise; But here thy sword can do thee little stead.

entry.def: To undertake.
Full of daring; adventurous.
See Imprison.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � forward + � to draw
entry.def: A drawing of the body forward, in consequence of the spasmodic action of some of the muscles.
To empty.
One who, or that which, empties.
of Empty.

sn.def: The state of being empty; absence of contents; void space; vacuum; as, the emptiness of a vessel; emptiness of the stomach.
Want of solidity or substance; unsatisfactoriness; inability to satisfy desire; vacuity; hollowness; as, the emptiness of earthly glory.
Want of knowledge; lack of sense; vacuity of mind.
sn.q: Eternal smiles his emptiness betray.
The sins of emptiness, gossip, and spite.

entry.ety: L. emptio, fr. emere to buy
entry.def: The act of buying.
Capable of being purchased.

entry.note: ☞ Empty is used as the first element in a compound; as, empty-handed, having nothing in the hands, destitute; empty-headed, having few ideas; empty-hearted, destitute of feeling.
entry.ety: AS. emtig æmtig æmetig, fr. æmta æmetta, quiet, leisure, rest; of uncertain origin; cf. G. emsig busy

sn.def: Containing nothing; not holding or having anything within; void of contents or appropriate contents; not filled; -- said of an inclosure, or a container, as a box, room, house, etc.; as, an empty chest, room, purse, or pitcher; an empty stomach; empty shackles.
Free; clear; devoid; -- often with of.
sn.q: That fair female troop . . .emptyof all good.
I shall find you empty of that fault.

sn.def: Having nothing to carry; unburdened.
sn.q: Anemptymessenger.
When ye go ye shall not go empty.

sn.def: Destitute of effect, sincerity, or sense; -- said of language; as, empty words, or threats.
sn.q: Words are but empty thanks.

sn.def: Unable to satisfy; unsatisfactory; hollow; vain; -- said of pleasure, the world, etc.
sn.q: Pleas'd in the silent shade with empty praise.

sn.def: Producing nothing; unfruitful; -- said of a plant or tree; as, an empty vine.
sn.q: Seven empty ears blasted with the east wind.

sn.def: Destitute of, or lacking, sense, knowledge, or courtesy; as, empty brains; an empty coxcomb.
sn.q: That in civility thou seem'st so empty.

sn.def: Destitute of reality, or real existence; unsubstantial; as, empty dreams.

entries.entry: Emp"ty n.; pl.Empties. An empty box, crate, cask, etc.; -- used in commerce, esp. in transportation of freight; as, “special rates for empties .”

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emptied; p. pr. & vb. n. Emptying
entry.def: To deprive of the contents; to exhaust; to make void or destitute; to make vacant; to pour out; to discharge; as, to empty a vessel; to empty a well or a cistern.
entry.q: The clouds . . . empty themselves upon the earth.

sn.def: To discharge itself; as, a river empties into the ocean.
To become empty.
sn.q: The chapelempties.

entry.def: needing nourishment; hungry; as, empty-bellied children.
having acquired or gained nothing; as, the returned from the negotiations empty-handed .

sn.def: carrying nothing in the hands.

entry.def: lacking seriousness; given to frivolity.
entry.syn: airheaded, dizzy, featherbrained, giddy, lightheaded, light-headed, silly.

sn.def: The act of making empty.
The lees of beer, cider, etc.; yeast.

entry.def: See Impugn.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Empurpled; p. pr. & vb. n. Empurpling
entry.def: To tinge or dye of a purple color; to color with purple; to impurple.
entry.q: The deepempurpledran.

entry.def: A phantom or specter.
To puzzle.

entry.note: ☞ The term empyema is now restricted to a collection of pus in the cavity of the pleura.
entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, from � to suppurate; � in + � pus
entry.def: A collection of blood, pus, or other fluid, in some cavity of the body, especially that of the pleura.
An eruption of pustules.

cs.cd: oxygen gas.

entry.ety: L. empyrius empyreus, fiery, Gr. �, �, in fire, fiery; � in + � fire. See In, and Fire
entry.def: Formed of pure fire or light; refined beyond aërial substance; pertaining to the highest and purest region of heaven.
entry.q: Go, soar with Plato to the empyreal sphere.

entry.def: Empyrean.
The highest heaven, where the pure element of fire was supposed by the ancients to subsist.
entry.q: The empyrean rung With hallelujahs.

entry.def: Empyreal.

entries.entry:
Em`py*reu"ma‖n. NL., from Gr. � a live coal covered with ashes, fr. � to set on fire, fr. �: cf. F. empyreume. See Empyreal
Chem The peculiar smell and taste arising from products of decomposition of animal or vegetable substances when burnt in close vessels.

cs.cd: oils obtained by distilling various organic substances at high temperatures.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to empyreuma; as, an empyreumatic odor.
To render empyreumatic.
Containing the combustible principle of coal.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; � in + � to burn
entry.def: A general fire; a conflagration.
See Emerods.

entry.note: ☞ The name is sometimes erroneously applied, by the Brazilians, to the rhea, or South American ostrich.
entry.cs: Emu wren. See in the Vocabulary.
entry.ety: Cf. Pg. ema ostrich, F. émou émeu, emu
entry.def: A large Australian bird, of two species (Dromaius Novæ-Hollandiæ and D. irroratus), related to the cassowary and the ostrich. The emu runs swiftly, but is unable to fly.
Capable of being emulated.
entry.q: Some imitable and emulable good.

entry.ety: L. aemulatus, p. p. of aemulari, fr. aemulus emulous; prob. akin to E. imitate
entry.def: Striving to excel; ambitious; emulous.
entry.q: A mostemulatepride.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Emulated; p. pr. & vb. n. Emulating
entry.def: To strive to equal or to excel in qualities or actions; to imitate, with a view to equal or to outdo, to vie with; to rival; as, to emulate the good and the great.
entry.q: Thine eye would emulate the diamond.

sn.def: The endeavor to equal or to excel another in qualities or actions; an assiduous striving to equal or excel another; rivalry.
sn.q: A noble emulation heats your breast.

sn.def: Jealous rivalry; envy; envious contention.
sn.q: Such factious emulations shall arise.

sn.def: imitation (of an admired model) for the purpose of improving one's own qualities.
sn.q: Chivalry was] an ideal which, if never met with in real life, was acknowledged by all as the highest model for emulation.

sn.def: the imitation of the actions of a computer system or component, especially a processor, by means of a computer program, with the goal of predicting the behavior and performance characteristics of that system without actually manufacturing it.
sn.q: 1996 marked the year that emulation became a mainstream design verification tool.
sn.syn: Competition; rivalry; contest; contention; strife.Emulation Competition Rivalry. Competition is the struggle of two or more persons for the same object. Emulation is an ardent desire for superiority, arising from competition, but now implying, of necessity, any improper feeling. Rivalry is a personal contest, and, almost of course, has a selfish object and gives rise to envy. “Competition and emulation have honor for their basis; rivalry is but a desire for selfish gratification. Competition and emulation animate to effort; rivalry usually produces hatred. Competition and emulation seek to merit success; rivalry is contented with obtaining it.”

entry.def: Inclined to emulation; aspiring to competition; rivaling; as, an emulative person or effort.
entry.q: Emulativezeal.

entry.def: In an emulative manner; with emulation.
One who emulates, or strives to equal or surpass.
entry.q: As Virgil rivaled Homer, Milton was the emulator of both.

entry.def: Pertaining to emulation; connected with rivalry.
entry.q: Emulatoryofficiousness.

entry.def: A female emulator.
To emulate.
entry.q: Emuledof many.

entry.ety: L. emulgere emulsum; e out + mulgere to milk; akin to E. milk. See Milk
entry.def: To milk out; to drain.

entry.ety: L. emulgens, p. pr. of emulgere to milk out: cf. F. émulgent. So called because regarded by the ancients as straining out the serum, as if by milking, and so producing the urine
entry.def: Pertaining to the kidneys; renal; as, emulgent arteries and veins.

def2.def: An emulgent vessel, as a renal artery or vein.

entry.def: A medicine that excites the flow of bile.

sn.def: Ambitiously desirous to equal or even to excel another; eager to emulate or vie with another; desirous of like excellence with another; -- with of; as, emulous of another's example or virtues.
Vying with; rivaling; hence, contentious, envious.
sn.q: EmulousCarthage.
Emulous missions 'mongst the gods.

entry.def: In an emulous manner.
The quality of being emulous.
Pertaining to, or produced from, emulsin; as, emulsic acid.

To convert into an emulsion; to form an emulsion; to reduce from an oily substance to a milky fluid in which the fat globules are in a very finely divided state, giving it the semblance of solution; as, the pancreatic juice emulsifies the oily part of food.
The white milky pulp or extract of bitter almonds.
An unorganized ferment (contained in this extract and in other vegetable juices), which effects the decomposition of certain glucosides.

entry.ety: From L. emulgere emulsum: cf. F. émulsion. See Emulge
entry.def: Any liquid preparation of a color and consistency resembling milk; as: In pharmacy, an extract of seeds, or a mixture of oil and water united by a mucilaginous substance. In photography, a liquid preparation of collodion holding salt of silver, used in the photographic process.

sn.def: Softening; milklike.
Yielding oil by expression; as, emulsive seeds.
Producing or yielding a milklike substance; as, emulsive acids.

entries.entry:
E*munc"to*ry n.; pl.Emunctories #. L. emunctorium a pair of snuffers, fr. emungere emunctum, to blow the nose, hence, to wipe, cleanse; e out + mungere to blow the nose: cf. F. émonctoire, formerly spelled also émonctoire
Physiol Any organ or part of the body (as the kidneys, skin, etc.,) which serves to carry off excrementitious or waste matter.

entry.ety: L. emuscare to clear from moss; e out + muscus moss
entry.def: A freeing from moss.

entries.entry: E"mu wren`. Zoöl A small wrenlike Australian bird (Stipiturus malachurus), having the tail feathers long and loosely barbed, like emu feathers.

E"myd n.; pl. E. Emyds #, E. Emyd�� #. See Emydea
Zoöl A fresh-water tortoise of the family Emydidæ.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Emys a genus of tortoises, L. emys a kind of fresh-water tortoise, Gr. �
entry.def: A group of chelonians which comprises many species of fresh-water tortoises and terrapins.

entries.entry:
En-. F. en-, L. in
A prefix signifying in or into, used in many English words, chiefly those borrowed from the French. Some English words are written indifferently with en-or in-. For ease of pronunciation it is commonly changed to em-before p b, and m, as in employ, embody, emmew. It is sometimes used to give a causal force, as in enable, enfeeble, to cause to be, or to make, able, or feeble; and sometimes merely gives an intensive force, as in enchasten. See In-.
A prefix from Gr. � in, meaning in; as, encephalon, entomology. See In-.

-en. A suffix from AS. -an, formerly used to form the plural of many nouns, as in ashen, eyen, oxen, all obs. except oxen. In some cases, such as children and brethren, it has been added to older plural forms.
A suffix corresponding to AS. -en and -on, formerly used to form the plural of verbs, as in housen, escapen.
A suffix signifying to make to cause, used to form verbs from nouns and adjectives; as in strengthen, quicken, frighten. This must not be confused with -en corresponding in Old English to the AS. infinitive ending -an.
AS. -en; akin to Goth. -eins, L. -inus, Gr. � An adjectival suffix, meaning made of; as in golden, leaden, wooden.
AS. -en; akin to Skr. -na
The termination of the past participle of many strong verbs; as, in broken, gotten, trodden .

entry.def: Half an em, that is, half of the unit of space in measuring printed matter. See Em.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enabled; p. pr. & vb. n. Enabling

sn.def: To give strength or ability to; to make firm and strong.
sn.q: Who hathenabledme.
Receive the Holy Ghost, said Christ to his apostles, when he enabled them with priestly power.

sn.def: To make able (to do, or to be, something); to confer sufficient power upon; to furnish with means, opportunities, and the like; to render competent for; to empower; to endow.
sn.q: Temperance gives Nature her full play, and enables her to exert herself in all her force and vigor.

entry.def: The act of enabling, or the state of being enabled; ability.

cs.cd: that clause of a bill which formally expresses the legislative sanction.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enacted; p. pr. & vb. n. Enacting

sn.def: To decree; to establish by legal and authoritative act; to make into a law; especially, to perform the legislative act with reference to (a bill) which gives it the validity of law.
To act; to perform; to do; to effect.
sn.q: The king enacts more wonders than a man.

sn.def: To act the part of; to represent; to play.
sn.q: I did enact Julius Caesar.

entry.def: Purpose; determination.
Having power to enact or establish as a law.

sn.def: The passing of a bill into a law; the giving of legislative sanction and executive approval to a bill whereby it is established as a law.
That which is enacted or passed into a law; a law; a decree; a statute; a prescribed requirement; as, a prohibitory enactment; a social enactment.

entry.def: One who enacts a law; one who decrees or establishes as a law.
Enactment; resolution.
One of the Enaliosauria.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � marine (� in + � the sea) + � a lizard
entry.def: An extinct group of marine reptiles, embracing both the Ichthyosauria and the Plesiosauria, now regarded as distinct orders.
Pertaining to the Enaliosauria.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. � an exchange, fr. � to exchange; � in + � to change
entry.def: A substitution, as of one part of speech for another, of one gender, number, case, person, tense, mode, or voice, of the same word, for another.
To ambush.

cs.cd: painting with enamel colors upon a ground of metal, porcelain, or the like, the colors being afterwards fixed by fire.
paper glazed a metallic coating.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + amel. See Amel Smelt v. t.

sn.def: A variety of glass, used in ornament, to cover a surface, as of metal or pottery, and admitting of after decoration in color, or used itself for inlaying or application in varied colors.
A glassy, opaque bead obtained by the blowpipe.
That which is enameled; also, any smooth, glossy surface, resembling enamel, especially if variegated.

The intensely hard calcified tissue entering into the composition of teeth. It merely covers the exposed parts of the teeth of man, but in many animals is intermixed in various ways with the dentine and cement.
Any one of various preparations for giving a smooth, glossy surface like that of enamel.
A cosmetic intended to give the appearance of a smooth and beautiful complexion.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enameled or Enamelled; p. pr. & vb. n. Enameling or Enamelling

sn.def: To lay enamel upon; to decorate with enamel whether inlaid or painted.
To variegate with colors as if with enamel.
sn.q: Oft he [the serpent]bowed His turret crest and sleek enameled neck.

sn.def: To form a glossy surface like enamel upon; as, to enamel card paper; to enamel leather or cloth.
To disguise with cosmetics, as a woman's complexion.

entry.def: To practice the art of enameling.
Relating to the art of enameling; as, enamel painting.
Consisting of enamel; resembling enamel; smooth; glossy.
Coated or adorned with enamel; having a glossy or variegated surface; glazed.
One who enamels; a workman or artist who applies enamels in ornamental work.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enamored; p. pr. & vb. n. Enamoring
entry.ety: OF. enamourer enamorer; pref. en-L. in) + OF. & F. amour love, L. amor. See Amour, and cf. Inamorato
entry.def: To inflame with love; to charm; to captivate; -- with of, or with, before the person or thing; as, to be enamored with a lady; to be enamored of books or science.
entry.q: Passionately enamored of this shadow of a dream.

entry.def: The state of being enamored.

either of a pair of optical isomers of a chemical substance whose molecules are mirror images of each other, i. e., are related to each other as a right-handed to a left-handed glove; -- meaningful only for structures which have internal asymmetry.
Similar, but not superposable, i. e., related to each other as a right-handed to a left-handed glove; -- said of certain hemihedral crystals.
Serving to palliate; palliative.

entry.ety: Gr. � of contrary properties or affections; 'enanti`os opposite + � suffering, affection, fr. �, �, to suffer

sn.def: An opposite passion or affection.
Allopathy; -- a term used by followers of Hahnemann, or homeopathists.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � contradiction, fr. 'enanti`os opposite
entry.def: A figure of speech by which what is to be understood affirmatively is stated negatively, and the contrary; affirmation by contraries.
To arch.
Bent into a curve; -- said of a bend or other ordinary.
An iron-black mineral of metallic luster, occurring in small orthorhombic crystals, also massive. It contains sulphur, arsenic, copper, and often silver.
Same as Armed, 3.
A detailed exposition; relation.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � in + �. See Arthrodia
entry.def: See Enarthrosis.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, fr. � jointed; � in + � joint
entry.def: A ball and socket joint, or the kind of articulation represented by such a joint. See Articulation.

entry.ety: L. enascens, p. pr. of enasci to spring up; e out + nasci to be born
entry.def: Coming into being; nascent.

entry.ety: L. enatare to swim out. See Natation
entry.def: A swimming out.

entry.ety: L. enatus, p. p. of enasci. See Enascent
entry.def: Growing out.
Any unusual outgrowth from the surface of a thing, as of a petal; also, the capacity or act of producing such an outgrowth.
Lest that.

entry.ety: L. enavigatus, p. p. of enavigare
entry.def: To sail away or over.
Embattled.
To imbibe.

entries.entry:
En` bloc"‖. F. Cf. Block n.
In a lump; as a whole; all together. Movement of the ossiclesen bloc.
En bloc they are known as “the herd”.

entry.def: See Embroude.
same as Encenia.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encaged; p. pr. & vb. n. Engaging
entry.ety: Pref. en- + cage: cf. F. encager
entry.def: To confine in a cage; to coop up.
To register in a calendar; to calendar.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encamped ?; 215; p. pr. & vb. n. Encamping
entry.def: To form and occupy a camp; to prepare and settle in temporary habitations, as tents or huts; to halt on a march, pitch tents, or form huts, and remain for the night or for a longer time, as an army or a company traveling.
entry.q: The host of the Philistines encamped in the valley of Rephaim.

entry.def: To form into a camp; to place in a temporary habitation, or quarters.
entry.q: Bid him encamp his soldiers.

sn.def: The act of pitching tents or forming huts, as by an army or traveling company, for temporary lodging or rest.
The place where an army or a company is encamped; a camp; tents pitched or huts erected for temporary lodgings.
sn.q: A square of about seven hundred yards was sufficient for the encampment of twenty thousand Romans.
A green encampment yonder meets the eye.

entry.def: To canker.
The act of inclosing in a capsule; the growth of a membrane around (any part) so as to inclose it in a capsule.
To carnalize; to make gross.
entry.q: Encarnalizetheir spirits.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � containing fruit; � in + � fruit; cf. L. encarpa, pl., Gr. �
entry.def: An ornament on a frieze or capital, consisting of festoons of fruit, flowers, leaves, etc.
To inclose in or as if in a case. See Incase.
covered or protected with or as if with a case; as, products encased in leatherette.

sn.def: The act of encasing; also, that which encases.
An old theory of generation similar to emboîtement. See Ovulist.

entry.def: To turn into cash; to cash.
The payment in cash of a note, draft, etc.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. � mark caused by burning, fr. �. See Encaustic
entry.def: An ulcer in the eye, upon the cornea, which causes the loss of the humors.

cs.cd: painting by means of wax with which the colors are combined, and which is afterwards fused with hot irons, thus fixing the colors.
an earthenware tile which has a decorative pattern and is not wholly of one color.

entry.ety: L. encausticus, Gr. �, fr. � to burn in; � in + � to burn: cf. F. encaustique. See Caustic, and cf. Ink
entry.def: Prepared by means of heat; burned in.

entry.ety: L. encaustica, Gr. � (sc. �): cf. F. encaustique. See Encaustic a.
entry.def: The method of painting in heated wax, or in any way where heat is used to fix the colors.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + cave: cf. F. encaver. Cf. Incavated
entry.def: To hide in, or as in, a cave or recess.
entry.q: Do butencaveyourself.

entries.entry:
-ence. F. -ence, L. -entia
A noun suffix signifying action state, or quality; also, that which relates to the action or state; as in emergence, diffidence, diligence, influence, difference, excellence. See -ance.

entry.ety: F., fr. enceindre to gird about, surround, L. incingere; inintens). + cingere to gird. See Cincture

sn.def: The line of works which forms the main inclosure of a fortress or place; -- called also body of the place.
The area or town inclosed by a line of fortification.
sn.q: The suburbs are not unfrequently larger than their enceinte.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. in not + cinctus, p. p. of cingere to gird about
entry.def: Pregnant; with child.

entry.ety: LL. encaenia, fr. Gr. � a feast of dedication; � in + � new
entry.def: A festival commemorative of the founding of a city or the consecration of a church; also, the ceremonies (as at Oxford and Cambridge, England) commemorative of founders or benefactors.

entry.ety: F. encenser, fr. encens. See Incense n.
entry.def: To offer incense to or upon; to burn incense.
any of numerous cycads of the genus Encephalartos having stout cylindrical trunks and a terminal crown of long, often spiny pinnate leaves.
Pertaining to the encephalon or brain.
Inflammation of the brain.
Hernia of the brain.

cs.cd: a very malignant form of cancer of brainlike consistency. See under Cancer.

entry.def: Resembling the material of the brain; cerebriform.
An encephaloid cancer.
The science which treats of the brain, its structure and functions.

entries.entry:
en*ceph"a*lon n.; pl.encephala. NL. See Encephalos
Anat The contents of the cranium; the brain.

entry.ety: Gr. 'egke`falos the brain + pa`schein paqei^n, to suffer
entry.def: Any disease or symptoms of disease referable to disorders of the brain; as, lead encephalopathy, the cerebral symptoms attending chronic lead poisoning.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'egke`falos; 'en in + kefalh` head
entry.def: The encephalon.
entry.q: In man the encephalos reaches its full size about seven years of age.

entry.def: The act or art of dissecting the brain.
Having a head; -- said of most Mollusca; -- opposed to acephalous.
To chafe; to enrage; to heat.
Heating; burning.
entry.q: The wicked enchaufing or ardure of this sin [lust].

entry.ety: F. enchaîner; pref. en-L. in chaîne chain. See Chain, and cf. Incatenation

sn.def: To bind with a chain; to hold in chains.
To hold fast; to confine; as, to enchain attention.
To link together; to connect.

entry.def: The act of enchaining, or state of being enchained.
To seat in a chair.
To make run in a channel.
entry.q: Its waters wereenchanneled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enchanted; p. pr. & vb. n. Enchanting
entry.ety: F. enchanter, L. incantare to chant or utter a magic formula over or against one, to bewitch; in in, against + cantare to sing. See Chant, and cf. Incantation

sn.def: To charm by sorcery; to act on by enchantment; to get control of by magical words and rites.
sn.q: And now about the caldron sing, Like elves and fairies in a ring,Enchanting all that you put in.
He is enchanted, cannot speak.

sn.def: To delight in a high degree; to charm; to enrapture; as, music enchants the ear.
sn.q: Arcadia was the charmed circle where all his spirits forever should be enchanted.
sn.syn: To charm; bewitch; fascinate. Cf. Charm.

entry.def: Under the power of enchantment; possessed or exercised by enchanters; as, an enchanted castle.

cs.cd: a genus (Circæa) of low inconspicuous, perennial plants, found in damp, shady places.

entry.def: One who enchants; a sorcerer or magician; also, one who delights as by an enchantment.
entry.q: Like ghosts from an enchanter fleeing.

entry.def: Having a power of enchantment; charming; fascinating.

sn.def: The act of enchanting; the production of certain wonderful effects by the aid of demons, or the agency of supposed spirits; the use of magic arts, spells, or charms; incantation.
sn.q: After the last enchantment you did here.

sn.def: The effect produced by the act; the state of being enchanted; as, to break an enchantment .
That which captivates the heart and senses; an influence or power which fascinates or highly delights.
sn.q: Such an enchantment as there is in words.
sn.syn: Incantation; necromancy; magic; sorcery; witchcraft; spell; charm; fascination; witchery.

entry.def: A woman versed in magical arts; a sorceress; also, a woman who fascinates.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encharged; p. pr. & vb. n. Encharging
entry.ety: OF. enchargier, F. encharger; pref. en-L. in) + F. charger. See Charge
entry.def: To charge (with); to impose (a charge) upon.
entry.q: His countenance would express the spirit and the passion of the part he was encharged with.

entry.def: A charge.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enchased; p. pr. & vb. n. Enchasing
entry.ety: F. enchâsser; pref. en-L. in) + châsse box containing relics, frame, case, the same word as caisse case. See 1st Case, and cf. Chase Encase Incase

sn.def: To incase or inclose in a border or rim; to surround with an ornamental casing, as a gem with gold; to encircle; to inclose; to adorn.
sn.q: Enchased with a wanton ivy twine.
An precious stones, in studs of gold enchased, The shaggy velvet of his buskins graced.

sn.def: To chase; to ornament by embossing or engraving; as, to enchase a watch case.
sn.q: With golden letters . . . well enchased.

sn.def: To delineate or describe, as by writing.
sn.q: All which . . . for to enchase, Him needeth sure a golden pen, I ween.

entry.def: One who enchases.
To chasten.

entry.ety: OF. enchaison, fr. L. incidere to happen; in + cadere to fall
entry.def: Occasion, cause, or reason.
To inclose in a chest.
Handbook; a manual of devotions.
To cut with a chisel.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a spear + 'odoy`s 'odo`ntos, a tooth
entry.def: A genus of extinct Cretaceous fishes; -- so named from their spear-shaped teeth. They were allied to the pike (Esox).

entries.entry:
