entry.def: Belonging to, or used in, a country; native; domestic; popular; common; -- said especially of the written characters employed by the common people of ancient Egypt, in distinction from the hieroglyphics. See Demotic.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � to pour in + � anything received
entry.def: The basal substance of the cell nucleus; a hyaline or granular substance, more or less fluid during life, in which the other parts of the nucleus are imbedded.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`gchyma an infusion; 'en in + chei^n to pour
entry.def: The primitive formative juice, from which the tissues, particularly the cellular tissue, are formed.
A cincture.
entry.q: The vast encincture of that gloomy sea.

entry.def: Burnt to cinders.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encircled; p. pr. & vb. n. Encircling
entry.ety: Pref. en- + circle: cf. OF. encercler
entry.def: To form a circle about; to inclose within a circle or ring; to surround; as, to encircle one in the arms; the army encircled the city.
entry.q: Her brows encircled with his serpent rod.

entry.def: A small circle; a ring.
surrounding.
To clasp. See Inclasp.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. in + clavus a nail
entry.def: A tract of land or a territory inclosed within another territory of which it is independent. See Exclave.
To inclose within an alien territory.
The state of being an enclave.

entry.ety: L. encliticus, Gr. 'egkli`tikos, fr. 'egkli`nein to incline; 'en in + kli`nein to bend. See In, and Lean v. i.
entry.def: Affixed; subjoined; -- said of a word or particle which leans back upon the preceding word so as to become a part of it, and to lose its own independent accent, generally varying also the accent of the preceding word.
A word which is joined to another so closely as to lose its proper accent, as the pronoun thee in pritheepray thee).
In an enclitic manner; by throwing the accent back.
The art of declining and conjugating words.
To shut up in a cloister; to cloister.

entry.ety: F. enclos, p. p. of enclore to enclose; pref. en-L. in) + clore to close. See Close, and cf. Inclose Include
entry.def: To inclose. See Inclose.

entries.entry: enclosed adj. surrounded or closed in, usually on all sides. Opposite of unenclosed.Narrower terms: basined; capsulate, capsulated; closed, closed in(predicate; coarctate; confined, fenced in, penned; embedded, fixed; embedded, surrounded; encircled; enveloped; fogbound; self-enclosed; surrounded, encircled

entry.def: the act of surrounding something with something else, so that it is inside the surrounding object.

entry.note: ☞ The words enclose and enclosure are written indiscriminately enclose or inclose and enclosure or inclosure.
entry.def: Inclosure. See Inclosure.
To clothe.
To envelop in clouds; to cloud.
To carry in a coach.
To put in a coffin.
To render cold.
To furnish or surround with a collar.
To color.
The neck of horse.
See Encumber.
Hindrance; molestation.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to praise, fr. � encomium: cf. F. encomiaste. See Encomium
entry.def: One who praises; a panegyrist.
Bestowing praise; praising; eulogistic; laudatory; as, an encomiastic address or discourse.
A panegyric.
Encomium; panegyric.

entries.entry:
En*co"mi*um n.; pl.Encomiums #. NL., fr. Gr. � (a song) chanted in a Bacchic festival in praise of the god; � in + � a jovial festivity, revel. See Comedy
Warm or high praise; panegyric; strong commendation. His encomiums awakened all my ardor. See Eulogy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encompassed; p. pr. & vb. n. Encompassing
entry.def: To circumscribe or go round so as to surround closely; to encircle; to inclose; to environ; as, a ring encompasses the finger; an army encompasses a city; a voyage encompassing the world.
entry.q: A question may be encompassed with difficulty.
The love of all thy sons encompass thee.
entry.syn: To encircle; inclose; surround; include; environ; invest; hem in; shut up.

entry.def: closely enveloping or surrounding on all sides.
The act of surrounding, or the state of being surrounded; circumvention.
entry.q: By this encompassment and drift of question.

entry.ety: F. The last part of the word is fr. L. hora hour. See Hour
entry.def: Once more; again; -- used by the auditors and spectators of plays, concerts, and other entertainments, to call for a repetition of a particular part.
A call or demand (as, by continued applause) for a repetition; as, the encores were numerous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encored; p. pr. & vb. n. Encoring
entry.def: To call for a repetition or reappearance of; as, to encore a song or a singer.
entry.q: Rebecca] insisted upon encoring one of the duets.

entry.def: Incorporation.

entry.ety: F., Pg. encorberto encuberto, lit., covered
entry.def: One of several species of armadillos of the genera Dasypus and Euphractus, having five toes both on the fore and hind feet.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encountered; p. pr. & vb. n. Encountering
entry.ety: OF. encontrer; pref. en-L. in) + contre against, L. contra. See Counter adv.
entry.def: To come against face to face; to meet; to confront, either by chance, suddenly, or deliberately; especially, to meet in opposition or with hostile intent; to engage in conflict with; to oppose; to struggle with; as, to encounter a friend in traveling; two armies encounter each other; to encounter obstacles or difficulties, to encounter strong evidence of a truth.
entry.q: Then certain philosophers of the Epicureans, and of the Stoics, encountered him.
I am most fortunate thus accidentally to encounter you.

entry.def: To meet face to face; to have a meeting; to meet, esp. as enemies; to engage in combat; to fight; as, three armies encountered at Waterloo.
entry.q: I will encounter with Andronicus.
Perception and judgment, employed in the investigation of all truth, have in the first place to encounter with particulars.

entry.ety: OF. encontre, fr. encontrer. See Encounter v. t.

sn.def: A meeting face to face; a running against; a sudden or incidental meeting; an interview.
sn.q: To shun the encounter of the vulgar crowd.

entry.sn: A meeting, with hostile purpose; hence, a combat; a battle; as, a bloody encounter . As one for . . . fierce encounters fit. Spenser. To join their dark encounter in mid-air. Milton.Contest; conflict; fight; combat; assault; rencounter; attack; engagement; onset. See Contest.

entry.def: One who encounters; an opponent; an antagonist.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encouraged ?; 48; p. pr. & vb. n. Encouraging
entry.ety: F. encourager; pref. en-L. in) + courage courage. See Courage
entry.def: To give courage to; to inspire with courage, spirit, or hope; to raise, or to increase, the confidence of; to animate; enhearten; to incite; to help forward; -- the opposite of discourage.
entry.q: David encouraged himself in the Lord.
entry.syn: To embolden; inspirit; animate; enhearten; hearten; incite; cheer; urge; impel; stimulate; instigate; countenance; comfort; promote; advance; forward; strengthen.

entry.def: made to feel more courage, hope, or optimism.

sn.def: The act of encouraging; incitement to action or to practice; as, the encouragement of youth in generosity.
sn.q: All generous encouragement of arts.

sn.def: That which serves to incite, support, promote, or advance, as favor, countenance, reward, etc.; incentive; increase of confidence; as, the fine arts find little encouragement among a rude people.
sn.q: To think of his paternal care, Is a most sweet encouragement to prayer.

entry.def: One who encourages, incites, or helps forward; a favorer.
entry.q: The pope is . . . a great encourager of arts.

entry.def: Furnishing ground to hope; inspiriting; favoring.
To make a monk (or wearer of a cowl) of.
To lay in a cradle.

entry.ety: L. Encratitae, pl., fr. Gr. � self-disciplined; � in + � strength
entry.def: One of a sect in the 2d century who abstained from marriage, wine, and animal food; -- called also Continent.
See Increase.
To give a crimson or red color to; to crimson.
Relating to encrinites; containing encrinites, as certain kinds of limestone.

entry.ety: Gr. � in + � a lily: cf. F. encrinite
entry.def: A fossil crinoid, esp. one belonging to, or resembling, the genus Encrinus. Sometimes used in a general sense for any crinoid.
Pertaining to encrinites; encrinal.

That order of the Crinoidea which includes most of the living and many fossil forms, having jointed arms around the margin of the oral disk; -- also called Brachiata and Articulata. See Illusts. under Comatula and Crinoidea.

entries.entry:
En"cri*nus En"cri*nus n.; pl.Encrini #. NL. See Encrinite
Paleon A genus of fossil encrinoidea, from the Mesozoic rocks.

entry.def: Curled.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encroached; p. pr. & vb. n. Encroaching
entry.ety: OF. encrochier to perch, prop., to hook, fasten a hook (perh. confused with acrochier, F. accrocher, to hook, get hold of, E. accroach); pref. en-L. in) + F. croc hook. See Crook, and cf. Accroach
entry.def: To enter by gradual steps or by stealth into the possessions or rights of another; to trespass; to intrude; to trench; -- commonly with on or upon; as, to encroach on a neighbor; to encroach on the highway.
entry.q: No sense, faculty, or member must encroach upon or interfere with the duty and office of another.
Superstition, . . . a creeping and encroaching evil.
Exclude the encroaching cattle from thy ground.
entry.syn: To intrude; trench; infringe; invade; trespass.

entry.def: Encroachment.
One who by gradual steps enters on, and takes possession of, what is not his own.
By way of encroachment.

sn.def: The act of entering gradually or silently upon the rights or possessions of another; unlawful intrusion.
sn.q: An unconstitutional encroachment of military power on the civil establishment.

sn.def: That which is taken by encroaching on another.
An unlawful diminution of the possessions of another.

entry.def: To incrust. See Incrust.
covered with or hardened into a crust.
That which is formed as a crust; incrustment; incrustation.
entry.q: Disengaging truth from its encrustment of error.

entry.def: to convert ordinary language into code; to hide the meaning of a message by converting it into a form that cannot be interpreted without knowing the secret method for interpretation, called the key.
entry.syn: encode, code, encipher, cipher, cypher, inscribe, write in code.

entry.def: converted into a coded form that cannot be interpreted without knowing the secret method for interpretation, called the key; -- of messages or other forms of information.
entry.syn: encoded, coded, enciphered, ciphered, cyphered, written in code.

entry.note: Encryption is used commonly to allow messages to be transmitted between parties at a distance without permitting others to read and understand the message. It is also used to make data more secure from possible discovery and uninterpretable by unauthorized people accessing the data. In order to read an encrypted message, a party normally requires knowledge of both the method of encryption and the secret key, which may be a single word or more complex sequence of characters. Until recently, transmission of such secret messages required that the key be transmitted secretly by some seecure and reliable method to the party receiving the message. More recently, a mathematical method was discovered to allow a party to publish an encoding key (the public key) which allows anyone to encode a message, but the message thus encoded can only be decoded by the person possessing a corresponding key, called the private key. This two-key system is called the public-key encryption method.
entry.def: the process of converting messages in ordinary language, or other information into a secret coded form that cannot be interpreted without knowing the secret method for interpretation, called the key.
entry.syn: encoding, coding, enciphering, ciphering, cyphering, writing in code.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Encumbered; p. pr. & vb. n. Encumbering
entry.ety: F. encombrer; pref. en-L. in) + OF. combrer to hinder. See Cumber, and cf. Incumber

sn.def: To impede the motion or action of, as with a burden; to retard with something superfluous; to weigh down; to obstruct or embarrass; as, his movements were encumbered by his mantle; his mind is encumbered with useless learning.
sn.q: Not encumbered with any notable inconvenience.

sn.def: To load with debts, or other legal claims; as, to encumber an estate with mortgages.
sn.syn: To load; clog; oppress; overload; embarrass; perplex; hinder; retard; obstruct; check; block.

entry.def: Encumbrance.

sn.def: That which encumbers; a burden which impedes action, or renders it difficult and laborious; a clog; an impediment. See Incumbrance.
Same as Incumbrance.

entry.def: Same as Incumbrancer.
To inclose with curtains.

entries.entry:
-en*cy. L. -entia
A noun suffix having much the same meaning as -ence, but more commonly signifying the quality or state; as, emergency, efficiency . See -ancy.

entry.ety: L. encyclios of a circle, general, Gr. �; � in + � circle: cf. F. encyclique. See Cycle
entry.def: Sent to many persons or places; intended for many, or for a whole order of men; general; circular; as, an encyclical letter of a council, of a bishop, or the pope.
An encyclical letter, esp. one from a pope.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �, for � �, instruction in the circle of arts and sciences: cf. F. encyclopédie. See Cyclopedia, and Encyclical
entry.def: The circle of arts and sciences; a comprehensive summary of knowledge, or of a branch of knowledge; esp., a work in which the various branches of science or art are discussed separately, and usually in alphabetical order; a cyclopedia.
Encyclopedic.
Embracing the whole circle of learning, or a wide range of subjects.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, an encyclopedia; broad in scope or content; embracing a wide range of subjects; as, a person having encyclopedic knowledge of a subject.
The art of writing or compiling encyclopedias; also, possession of the whole range of knowledge; encyclopedic learning.

cs.cd: the writers of the great French encyclopedia which appeared in 1751-1772. The editors were Diderot and D'Alembert. Among the contributors were Voltaire and Rousseau.

entry.def: The compiler of an encyclopedia, or one who assists in such compilation; also, one whose knowledge embraces the whole range of the sciences.
To inclose in a cyst.
Encystment.
Inclosed in a cyst, or a sac, bladder, or vesicle; as, an encysted tumor.
entry.q: The encysted venom, or poison bag, beneath the adder's fang.

entry.note: ☞ The animal (a) first contracts its body to a globular mass (b) and then secretes a transparent cyst (c), after which the mass divides into two or more parts (as in d e), each of which attains freedom by the bursting of the cyst, and becomes an individual animal.

sn.def: A process which, among some of the lower forms of life, precedes reproduction by budding, fission, spore formation, etc.
A process by which many internal parasites, esp. in their larval states, become inclosed within a cyst in the muscles, liver, etc. See Trichina.

entry.cs: An end. On end; upright; erect; endways. Spenser To the end; continuously. Obs Richardson. End bulb Anat one of the bulblike bodies in which some sensory nerve fibers end in certain parts of the skin and mucous membranes; -- also called end corpuscles. End fly a bobfly. End for end one end for the other; in reversed order. End man the last man in a row; one of the two men at the extremities of a line of minstrels. End on Naut bow foremost. End organ Anat the structure in which a nerve fiber ends, either peripherally or centrally. End plate Anat one of the flat expansions in which motor nerve fibers terminate on muscular fibers. End play Mach movement endwise, or room for such movement. End stone Horol one of the two plates of a jewel in a timepiece; the part that limits the pivot's end play. Ends of the earth the remotest regions of the earth. In the end finally. Shak. On end upright; erect. To the end in order. Bacon. To make both ends meet to live within one's income. Fuller. To put an end to to destroy.
entry.ety: OE. & AS. ende; akin to OS. endi, D. einde eind, OHG. enti, G. ende, Icel. endir endi, Sw. ände, Dan. ende, Goth. andeis, Skr. anta. √208. Cf. Ante- Anti- Answer

sn.def: The extreme or last point or part of any material thing considered lengthwise (the extremity of breadth being side); hence, extremity, in general; the concluding part; termination; close; limit; as, the end of a field, line, pole, road; the end of a year, of a discourse; put an end to pain; -- opposed to beginning, when used of anything having a first part.
sn.q: Better is the end of a thing than the beginning thereof.

sn.def: Point beyond which no procession can be made; conclusion; issue; result, whether successful or otherwise; conclusive event; consequence.
sn.q: My guilt be on my head, and there an end.
O that a man might know The end of this day's business ere it come!

sn.def: Termination of being; death; destruction; extermination; also, cause of death or destruction.
sn.q: Unblamed through life, lamented in thy end.
Confound your hidden falsehood, and award Either of you to be the other's end.
I shall see an end of him.

sn.def: The object aimed at in any effort considered as the close and effect of exertion; ppurpose; intention; aim; as, to labor for private or public ends .
sn.q: Losing her, the end of living lose.
When every man is his own end, all things will come to a bad end.

sn.def: That which is left; a remnant; a fragment; a scrap; as, odds and ends .
sn.q: I clothe my naked villainy With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ, And seem a saint, when most I play the devil.

sn.def: One of the yarns of the worsted warp in a Brussels carpet.

cs.cd: to lift or tilt, so as to set on end; as, to end up a hogshead.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ended; p. pr. & vb. n. Ending

sn.def: To bring to an end or conclusion; to finish; to close; to terminate; as, to end a speech.
sn.q: I shallendthis strife.
On the seventh day God ended his work.

sn.def: To form or be at the end of; as, the letter k ends the word back .
To destroy; to put to death.
sn.q: This sword hathendedhim.

entry.def: To come to the ultimate point; to be finished; to come to a close; to cease; to terminate; as, a voyage ends; life ends; winter ends.
That may be ended; terminable.

sn.def: Complete termination.
sn.q: That but this blow Might be the be-all and the end-all here.

sn.def: the primary or only purpose or goal; as, winning office is the be-all and end-all of a politician's life.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endamaged ?; 48; p. pr. & vb. n. Endamaging
entry.ety: Pref. en- + damage: cf. F. endommager
entry.def: To bring loss or damage to; to harm; to injure.
entry.q: The trial hath endamaged thee no way.

entry.def: Capable of being damaged, or injured; damageable.
Damage; injury; harm.
To damnify; to injure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endangered; p. pr. & vb. n. Endangering

sn.def: To put to hazard; to bring into danger or peril; to expose to loss or injury; as, to endanger life or peace.
sn.q: All the other difficulties of his reign only exercised without endangering him.

sn.def: To incur the hazard of; to risk.
sn.q: He that turneth the humors back . . . endangereth malign ulcers.

sn.def: Being in a condition or situation where life or serious harm is possible; in danger; at risk.
Small in numbers, with significant possibility of extinction; -- of species.

entry.note: In the U. S. in recent years, development of certain tracts of land has been prohibited due to the likelihood that it will cause a reduction in the numbers of an endangered species. In some cases environmental organizations have initiated litigation to cause the courts to rule that a certain development plan is illegal due to a threat to an endangered species. Laws protecting endangered species have become in some cases a contentious political issue.
entry.def: A species of plant or animal that has declined in numbers to a point where further irreversible decline and extinction{3} has a significant chance. Lists of endangered species are maintained by government agencies, and in many cases the killing of such species or destruction of their habitat is prohibited by law.
Hazard; peril.
To darken.
Having the anterior scutes extending around the tarsus on the inner side; -- said of certain birds.
To dazzle.
entry.q: Endazzledeyes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endeared; p. pr. & vb. n. Endearing

sn.def: To make dear or beloved.
sn.q: To beendearedto a king.

sn.def: To raise the price or cost of; to make costly or expensive.

entry.def: With affection or endearment; dearly.
State of being endeared.
Making dear or beloved; causing love.
The act of endearing or the state of being endeared; also, that which manifests, excites, or increases, affection.
entry.q: The greatendearmentsof prudent and temperate speech.
Her first endearments twining round the soul.

entry.cs: To endeavor one's self to exert one's self strenuously to the fulfillment of a duty. Obs “A just man that endeavoreth himself to leave all wickedness.” Latimer.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endeavored; p. pr. & vb. n. Endeavoring
entry.ety: OE. endevor; pref. en- + dever devoir, duty, F. devoir: cf. F. se mettre en devoir de faire quelque chose to try to do a thing, to go about it. See Devoir Debt
entry.def: To exert physical or intellectual strength for the attainment of; to use efforts to effect; to strive to achieve or reach; to try; to attempt.
entry.q: It is our duty to endeavor the recovery of these beneficial subjects.

entry.note: Usually with an infinitive; as, to endeavor to outstrip an antagonist.He had . . . endeavored earnestly to do his duty. Prescott.
entry.def: To exert one's self; to work for a certain end.
entry.q: And such were praised who but endeavored well.
entry.syn: To attempt; try; strive; struggle; essay; aim; seek.

entry.cs: To do one's endeavor to do one's duty; to put forth strenuous efforts to attain an object; -- a phrase derived from the Middle English phrase “to do one's dever” (duty). “Mr. Prynne proceeded to show he had done endeavor to prepare his answer.” Fuller.
entry.def: An exertion of physical or intellectual strength toward the attainment of an object; a systematic or continuous attempt; an effort; a trial.
entry.q: To employ all my endeavor to obey you.
entry.syn: Essay; trial; effort; exertion. See Attempt.

entry.def: One who makes an effort or attempt.
Act of endeavoring; endeavor.
A plane figure of eleven sides and angles.
Having eleven pistils; as, an endecagynous flower.
One of the higher hydrocarbons of the paraffin series, C11H24, found as a constituent of petroleum.
Composed of eleven leaflets; -- said of a leaf.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to point out, show; � in + � to show
entry.def: Serving to show or exhibit; as, an endeictic dialogue, in the Platonic philosophy, is one which exhibits a specimen of skill.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � indication. See Endeictic
entry.def: An indication.
Endemic.

entry.note: ☞ An endemic disease is one which is constantly present to a greater or less degree in any place, as distinguished from an epidemic disease, which prevails widely at some one time, or periodically, and from a sporadic disease, of which a few instances occur now and then.
entry.ety: Gr. �, �; � + � the people: cf. F. endémique

sn.def: Peculiar to a district or particular locality, or class of persons; as, an endemic disease.

Belonging or native to a particular people or country; native as distinguished from introduced or naturalized; hence, regularly or ordinarily occurring in a given region; local; as, a plant endemic in Australia; -- often distinguished from exotic.
sn.q: The traditions of folklore . . . form a kind of endemic symbolism.

entry.def: An endemic disease.
entry.q: Fear, which is an endemic latent in every human heart, sometimes rises into an epidemic.

entry.def: In an endemic manner.
The science which treats of endemic affections.
The act of naturalizing.
To endenizen.
To admit to the privileges of a denizen; to naturalize.
One who, or that which, makes an end of something; as, the ender of my life.
Endermic.

cs.cd: that in which the medicine enters the system through the skin, being applied either to the sound skin, or to the surface denuded of the cuticle by a blister.

entry.def: Acting through the skin, or by direct application to the skin.
By the endermic method; as, applied endermically .
The deep sensitive and vascular layer of the skin and mucous membranes.
Diademed.
To decorate with a diaper pattern.
See Indict.
See Indictment.

cs.cd: day of death.

sn.def: Termination; concluding part; result; conclusion; destruction; death.
The final syllable or letter of a word; the part joined to the stem. See 3d Case, 5.

entry.def: See Indite.

cs.cd: chicory or succory.

entry.ety: F. endivecf. Pr., Sp. Pg., & It. endivia), fr. a deriv. of L. intibus intybus, endive
entry.def: A composite herb (Cichorium Endivia). Its finely divided and much curled leaves, when blanched, are used for salad.

entry.cs: Endless chain a chain which is made continuous by uniting its two ends. Endless screw. Mech See under Screw.

sn.def: Without end; having no end or conclusion; perpetual; interminable; -- applied to length, and to duration; as, an endless line; endless time; endless bliss; endless praise; endless clamor.
Infinite; excessive; unlimited.
Without profitable end; fruitless; unsatisfying.
sn.q: All loves areendless.

sn.def: Void of design; objectless; as, an endless pursuit.

having a linear or ribbonlike form with the two ends connected together, such as in a circle, ellipse, torus, or any other closed loop. Belts or chains used in drive mechanisms are considered endless in this sense. See endless chain.
sn.syn: Eternal; everlasting; interminable; infinite; unlimited; incessant; perpetual; uninterrupted; continual; unceasing; unending; boundless; undying; imperishable.

entry.def: In an endless manner.
The quality of being endless; perpetuity.
Lengthwise; along.
entry.q: The doors were all of adamants eterne, I-clenched overthwart and endelong With iron tough.
He pricketh endelong the large space.
To thrust the raft endlong across the moat.

entry.def: Farthest; remotest; at the very end.

entries.entry:
En"do- End- . Gr. 'e`ndon within, fr. � in. See In
A combining form signifying within; as, endocarp, endogen, endocuneiform, endaspidean.

entry.def: Entoblast; endoplast. See Nucleus,
Relating to the endoblast; as, the endoblastic layer.

sn.def: Pertaining to the endocardium.
Seated or generated within the heart; as, endocardial murmurs.

entry.def: Inflammation of the endocardium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + kardi`a heart
entry.def: The membrane lining the cavities of the heart.

entry.ety: Endo- + Gr. � fruit: cf. F. endocarpe
entry.def: The inner layer of a ripened or fructified ovary.
Growing or developing within cartilage; -- applied esp. to developing bone.
The coloring matter within the cells of plants, whether green, red, yellow, or any other color.
To teach; to indoctrinate.
The inner layer of the cells of Bryozoa.
The inner layer of the skin or integument of an animal.
The innermost layer of the blastoderm and the structures derived from it; the hypoblast; the entoblast. See Illust. of Ectoderm.
Of or pertaining to the endoderm.
A layer of cells forming a kind of cuticle inside of the proper cortical layer, or surrounding an individual fibrovascular bundle.

sn.def: the branch of dentistry dealing with diseases of the dental pulp.

the treatment of diseases of the dental pulp, especially by completely removing the pulp and nerve inside a tooth and its root, and replacing it with a filling material; root canal therapy; pulp canal therapy.

entry.def: a dentist specializing in endodontics.

entries.entry: endoergic adj. occurring with absorption of energy.Narrower terms: endothermic exoergic energy-absorbing.

sn.def: fertilized by pollen from another flower of the same plant.
of marriage within a class or tribe as required by custom or law; same as endogamous.

entry.def: Marrying within the same tribe; -- opposed to exogamous.
Marriage only within the tribe; a custom restricting a man in his choice of a wife to the tribe to which he belongs; -- opposed to exogamy.

A plant which increases in size by internal growth and elongation at the summit, having the wood in the form of bundles or threads, irregularly distributed throughout the whole diameter, not forming annual layers, and with no distinct pith. The leaves of the endogens have, usually, parallel veins, their flowers are mostly in three, or some multiple of three, parts, and their embryos have but a single cotyledon, with the first leaves alternate. The endogens constitute one of the great primary classes of plants, and included all palms, true lilies, grasses, rushes, orchids, the banana, pineapple, etc. See Exogen.
Endogeny.

sn.def: Relating to or arising from an internal process; same as endogenous.
Relating to the interior of the earth; of or pertaining to a metamorphic process occurring within a planet. Opposed to exogenetic.

cs.cd: a method of cell formation, seen in cells having a cell wall. The nucleus and protoplasm divide into two distinct masses; these in turn become divided and subdivided, each division becoming a new cell, until finally the original cell wall is ruptured and the new cells are liberated (see Segmentation, and Illust. of Cell Division, under Division). This mode of growth is characteristic of many forms of cells, both animal and vegetable.

sn.def: Increasing by internal growth and elongation at the summit, instead of externally, and having no distinction of pith, wood, and bark, as the rattan, the palm, the cornstalk.
Originating from within; increasing by internal growth.

entry.def: By endogenous growth.
Growth from within; multiplication of cells by endogenous division, as in the development of one or more cells in the interior of a parent cell.
The inner or principal branch of the oral appendages of Crustacea. See Maxilla.
Pertaining to the endognath.
The watery fluid contained in the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear.
Within a lymphatic vessel.
Pertaining to, or containing, endolymph; as, the endolymphatic duct.
Within a lymphatic vessel; endolymphangial.
To cover as with a dome.
Inflammation of the endometrium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + mh`tra the womb
entry.def: The membrane lining the inner surface of the uterus, or womb.
A crystal of one species inclosed within one of another, as one of rutile inclosed in quartz.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + my^s a muscle
entry.def: The delicate bands of connective tissue interspersed among muscular fibers.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + � a sinew, nerve
entry.def: The delicate bands of connective tissue among nerve fibers.
Any parasite which lives in the internal organs of an animal, as the tapeworms, Trichina, etc.; -- opposed to ectoparasite. See Entozoön.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + floio`s bark
entry.def: The inner layer of the bark of trees.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon + fra`gma a fence
entry.def: A chitinous structure above the nervous cord in the thorax of certain Crustacea.
Of or pertaining to the endophragma.
Wrapped up within a leaf or sheath.

entry.ety: Endo- + Gr. � anything formed or molded
entry.def: The protoplasm in the interior of a cell.
Same as Entoplasm and Endosarc.
See Nucleus.
A group of Rhizopoda having a distinct nucleus, as the amœba.

entry.ety: A dim. fr. endo- + Gr. � to mold
entry.def: See Nucleolus.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � within + � rib, side. See Pleura
entry.def: The inner coating of a seed. See Tegmen.
The portion of each apodeme developed from the interepimeral membrane in certain crustaceans.

entry.ety: Endo- + Gr. poy`s podo`s, a foot
entry.def: The internal or principal branch of the locomotive appendages of Crustacea. See Maxilliped.

entries.entry: En`do*rhi"za En`do*rhi"za ☞ Endorhiza was proposed by Richard as a substitute for the term endogen, and exorhiza as a substitute for the term exogen; but they have not been generally adopted. n.; pl.Endorhizæ #. NL., fr. Gr. � within + � root Bot Any monocotyledonous plant; -- so named because many monocotyledons have an endorhizal embryo.

entry.def: Having the radicle of the embryo sheathed by the cotyledon, through which the embryo bursts in germination, as in many monocotyledonous plants.

entry.note: ☞ Both endorse and indorse are used by good writers; but the tendency is to the more general use of indorse and its derivatives indorsee indorser, and indorsement.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endorsed; p. pr. & vb. n. Endorsing
entry.ety: Formerly endosse, fr. F. endosser to put on the back, to endorse; pref. en-L. in) + dos back, L. dorsum. See Dorsal, and cf. Indorse
entry.def: Same as Indorse.
A subordinary, resembling the pale, but of one fourth its width (according to some writers, one eighth).
Same as Indorsee.
Same as Indorsement.
Same as Indorser.
The semifluid, granular interior of certain unicellular organisms, as the inner layer of sarcode in the amœba; entoplasm; endoplasta.

An instrument for examining the interior of the body, consisting of a flexible tube with lenses and optical fibers permitting illumination of the interior site to be inspected, and visualization of the interior site from outside the body; it often has small surgical instruments attached to the end and manipulable from the outside, permitting biopsy or surgery. It is used as a non-invasive or minimally invasive tool for diagnosis or treatment, especially in organs having an external opening such as the rectum, the urethra, and the bladder.
Of or pertaining to endoscopy or an endoscope.
The art or process of examination or treatment by means of an endoscope.
Pertaining to, or connected with, the endoskeleton; as, endoskeletal muscles.
The bony, cartilaginous, or other internal framework of an animal, as distinguished from the exoskeleton.
An instrument for measuring the force or amount of endosmotic action.
Pertaining to, or designed for, the measurement of endosmotic action.

entry.ety: NL. endosmosis, fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + � a thrusting, impulsion, fr. � to push: cf. F. endosmose
entry.def: The transmission of a fluid or gas from without inward in the phenomena, or by the process, of osmose.
Endosmotic.
Pertaining to endosmose; of the nature endosmose; osmotic.
The albumen of a seed; -- limited by recent writers to that formed within the embryo sac.
Relating to, accompanied by, or containing, endosperm.
The thin inner coat of certain spores.
Having the spores contained in a case; -- applied to fungi.
To put upon the back or outside of anything; -- the older spelling of endorse.
Relating to endostosis; as, endosteal ossification.
The part of each apodeme derived from the intersternal membrane in Crustacea and insects.
The layer of vascular connective tissue lining the medullary cavities of bone.
A plate which supports the labrum in certain Crustacea.

sn.def: The foramen or passage through the inner integument of an ovule.
And endostoma.

entry.def: A process of bone formation in which ossification takes place within the substance of the cartilage.
A fold of the endoderm, which projects into the blood cavity of ascidians. See Tunicata.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. 'e`ndon within + qh`kh a case, box, fr. � to place
entry.def: The tissue which partially fills the interior of the interseptal chambers of most madreporarian corals. It usually consists of a series of oblique tranverse septa, one above another.
The inner lining of an anther cell.
Of, or relating to, endothelium.

entries.entry: En`do*the"li*um En`do*the"li*um n.; pl.Endothelia #. NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + � nipple Anat The thin epithelium lining the blood vessels, lymphatics, and serous cavities. See Epithelium.

entry.def: Like endothelium.
Designating, or pert. to, a reaction which occurs with absorption of heat; formed by such a reaction; as, an endothermic substance; -- opposed to exothermic.
An internal process of the sternal plates in the thorax of insects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endowed; p. pr. & vb. n. Endowing
entry.ety: OF. endouer; pref. en-L. in) + F. douer to endow, L. dotare. See Dower, and cf. 2d Endue

sn.def: To furnish with money or its equivalent, as a permanent fund for support; to make pecuniary provision for; to settle an income upon; especially, to furnish with dower; as, to endow a wife; to endow a public institution.
sn.q: Endowing hospitals and almshouses.

sn.def: To enrich or furnish with anything of the nature of a gift (as a quality or faculty); -- followed by with, rarely by of; as, man is endowed by his Maker with reason; to endow with privileges or benefits.

entry.ety: Cf. OF. endouairer. See Dower Endow
entry.def: To endow.
One who endows.

sn.def: The act of bestowing a dower, fund, or permanent provision for support.
That which is bestowed or settled on a person or an institution; property, fund, or revenue permanently appropriated to any object; as, the endowment of a church, a hospital, or a college.
That which is given or bestowed upon the person or mind; gift of nature; accomplishment; natural capacity; talents; -- usually in the plural.
sn.q: His early endowments had fitted him for the work he was to do.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`ndon within + zw^,on an animal
entry.def: See Entozoa.
Living within a living animal, usually as a parasite; as, endozoic worms. Contrasted with epizoic.
A point of termination or completion.
To make a drudge or slave of.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endued; p. pr. & vb. n. Enduing
entry.ety: L. induere, prob. confused with E. endow. See Indue
entry.def: To invest.
entry.q: Tarry ye in the city of Jerusalem, until ye be endued with power from on high.
Endue them . . . with heavenly gifts.

entry.def: An older spelling of Endow.
Act of enduing; induement.
Capable of being endured or borne; sufferable.
In an endurable manner.

sn.def: A state or quality of lasting or duration; lastingness; continuance.
sn.q: Slurring with an evasive answer the question concerning the endurance of his own possession.

sn.def: The act of bearing or suffering; a continuing under pain or distress without resistance, or without being overcome; sufferance; patience.
sn.q: Their fortitude was most admirable in their patience and endurance of all evils, of pain and of death.

entry.def: Capable of enduring fatigue, pain, hunger, etc.
entry.q: The ibex is a remarkably endurant animal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Endured; p. pr. & vb. n. Enduring
entry.ety: F. endurer; pref. en-L. in) + durer to last. See Dure v. i., and cf. Indurate

sn.def: To continue in the same state without perishing; to last; to remain.
sn.q: Their verdure still endure.
He shall hold it [his house] fast, but it shall not endure.

sn.def: To remain firm, as under trial or suffering; to suffer patiently or without yielding; to bear up under adversity; to hold out.
sn.q: Can thine heart endure, or can thine hands be strong in the days that I shall deal with thee?

sn.def: To remain firm under; to sustain; to undergo; to support without breaking or yielding; as, metals endure a certain degree of heat without melting; to endure wind and weather.
sn.q: Both were of shining steel, and wrought so pure, As might the strokes of two such arms endure.

sn.def: To bear with patience; to suffer without opposition or without sinking under the pressure or affliction; to bear up under; to put up with; to tolerate.
sn.q: I will no longer endure it.
Therefore I endure all things for the elect's sake.
How can I endure to see the evil that shall come unto my people?

sn.def: To harden; to toughen; to make hardy.
sn.q: Manly limbs endured with little ease.
sn.syn: To last; remain; continue; abide; brook; submit to; suffer.

entry.def: Endurance.
One who, or that which, endures or lasts; one who bears, suffers, or sustains.
Lasting; durable; long-suffering; as, an enduring disposition.
entry.q: A better andenduringsubstance.

entry.note: Purchasers of items who are not end-users include: reseller; value-added reseller, VAR; and producer, manufacturer.
entry.def: a person who uses an item of commerce for its designed purpose; -- contrasted with those who produce or resell the item or incorporate the item into another product.

sn.def: On end; erectly; in an upright position.
With the end forward.

entry.def: See Ependyma.

entries.entry: En"dy*sis En"dy*sis n.; pl.Endyses #. NL., fr. Gr. � a putting on, fr. � to put on Biol The act of developing a new coat of hair, a new set of feathers, scales, etc.; -- opposed to ecdysis.

entry.ety: L. enecatus, p. p. of enecare; e out, utterly + necare to kill
entry.def: To kill off; to destroy.
Same as Æneid.

entries.entry: En"e*ma n.; pl. L. Enemata #. L. enema, Gr. �, fr. � to send in; � in + � to send Med An injection, or clyster, thrown into the rectum as a medicine, or to impart nourishment.

En"e*my
The enemy Mil the hostile force. In this sense it is construed with the verb and pronoun either in the singular or the plural, but more commonly in the singular; as, we have met the enemy and he is ours or they are ours. It was difficult in such a country to track the enemy. It was impossible to drive him to bay. Macaulay.
n.; pl.Enemies #. OF. enemi, F. ennemi, from L. inimicus; in-negative) + amicus friend. See Amicable
One hostile to another; one who hates, and desires or attempts the injury of, another; a foe; an adversary; as, an enemy of or to a person; an enemy to truth, or to falsehood.
To all good he enemy was still. I say unto you, Love your enemies. Foe; antagonist; opponent. See Adversary.

entry.def: Hostile; inimical.
entry.q: They . . . every day grow more enemy to God.

entry.def: Applied to the skin without friction; -- said of medicines.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to work, be active, fr. � active. See Energy

sn.def: Having energy or energies; possessing a capacity for vigorous action or for exerting force; active.
sn.q: A Being eternallyenergetic.

sn.def: Exhibiting energy; operating with force, vigor, and effect; forcible; powerful; efficacious; as, energetic measures; energetic laws.
sn.syn: Forcible; powerful; efficacious; potent; vigorous; effective; strenuous.

entry.def: That branch of science which treats of the laws governing the physical or mechanical, in distinction from the vital, forces, and which comprehends the consideration and general investigation of the whole range of the forces concerned in physical phenomena.

sn.def: In a state of action; acting; operating.
Having energy or great power; energetic.
sn.q: The energic faculty that we call will.

entry.def: Same as energize.
entry.syn: stimulate, arouse, brace, energize, perk up.

entry.def: Same as energizing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Energized; p. pr. & vb. n. Energizing
entry.def: To use strength in action; to act or operate with force or vigor; to act in producing an effect.
entry.q: Of all men it is true that they feel and energize first, they reflect and judge afterwards.

entry.def: To give strength or force to; to make active; to alacrify; as, to energize the will.
One who, or that which, gives energy, or acts in producing an effect.

sn.def: imparting or capable of imparting vitality and energy.
sn.q: Those nobler exercises of energizing love.

sn.def: supplying motive force.

entry.ety: L. energumenos, fr. Gr. � possessed by an evil spirit, from �: cf. F. énergumène. See Energetic
entry.def: One possessed by an evil spirit; a demoniac.

entries.entry:
En"er*gy ☞ The kinetic energy of a body is the energy it has in virtue of being in motion. It is measured by one half of the product of the mass of each element of the body multiplied by the square of the velocity of the element, relative to some given body or point. The available kinetic energy of a material system unconnected with any other system is that energy which is due to the motions of the parts of the system relative to its center of mass. The potential energy of a body or system is that energy which is not kinetic; -- energy due to configuration. Kinetic energy is sometimes called actual energy. Kinetic energy is exemplified in the vis viva of moving bodies, in heat, electric currents, etc.; potential energy, in a bent spring, or a body suspended a given distance above the earth and acted on by gravity.
Accumulation Conservation CorrelationandDegradation of energy
etc. Physics See under Accumulation Conservation Correlation, etc.
n.; pl.Energies #. F. énergie, LL. energia, fr. Gr.�, fr. � active; � in + � work. See In, and Work
Internal or inherent power; capacity of acting, operating, or producing an effect, whether exerted or not; as, men possessing energies may suffer them to lie inactive. The great energies of nature are known to us only by their effects.
Power efficiently and forcibly exerted; vigorous or effectual operation; as, the energy of a magistrate.
Strength of expression; force of utterance; power to impress the mind and arouse the feelings; life; spirit; -- said of speech, language, words, style; as, a style full of energy .
Physics Capacity for performing work.
Force; power; potency; vigor; strength; spirit; efficiency; resolution.

entry.def: capable of absorbing energy; as, energy-absorbing bumpers reduce injury and damage in vehicle collisions.

entry.sn: releasing energy.Narrower terms: exothermic (vs. endothermic), exothermal exoergic.

sn.def: catabolic.
anabolic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enervated; p. pr. & vb. n. Enervating

entry.def: To deprive of nerve, force, strength, or courage; to render feeble or impotent; to make effeminate; to impair the moral powers of.
entry.q: A man . . . enervated by licentiousness.
And rhyme began t' enervate poetry.

lacking strength or vigor.
causing the loss of strength or vigor.

entry.def: Having power, or a tendency, to enervate; weakening.
To weaken; to enervate.
Lacking nerve or force; enervated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enfaced; p. pr. & vb. n. Enfacing

To write or print (a memorandum, direction, or the like) on the face of a draft, bill, etc.; as, to enface the words “Payable in Calcutta” upon the face of a draft.

One who, or that which, weakens or makes feeble.
To enfeeble.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + fever: cf. F. enfiévrer

To urge; to ply hard; to lay much stress upon.

To prove; to evince.
To strengthen; to grow strong.

Compelled; forced; not voluntary.

entry.cs: Engine driver one who manages an engine; specifically, the engineer of a locomotive. Engine lathe. Mach See under Lathe. Engine tool a machine tool. J. Whitworth. Engine turning Fine Arts a method of ornamentation by means of a rose engine.
entry.note: ☞ The term engine is more commonly applied to massive machines, or to those giving power, or which produce some difficult result. Engines, as motors, are distinguished according to the source of power, as steam engine air engine electro-magnetic engine; or the purpose on account of which the power is applied, as fire engine pumping engine locomotive engine; or some peculiarity of construction or operation, as single-acting or double-acting engine high-pressure or low-pressure engine condensing engine, etc.
entry.ety: F. engin skill, machine, engine, L. ingenium natural capacity, invention; in in + the root of gignere to produce. See Genius, and cf. Ingenious Gin a snare

sn.def: Natural capacity; ability; skill.
sn.q: A man hath sapiences three, Memory, engine, and intellect also.

sn.def: Anything used to effect a purpose; any device or contrivance; a machine; an agent.
sn.q: You see the ways the fisherman doth take To catch the fish; what engines doth he make?
Their promises, enticements, oaths, tokens, and all these engines of lust.

sn.def: Any instrument by which any effect is produced; especially, an instrument or machine of war or torture.
sn.q: Terribleenginesof death.

sn.def: A compound machine by which any physical power is applied to produce a given physical effect.

sn.def: To equip with an engine; -- said especially of steam vessels; as, vessels are often built by one firm and engined by another.
Pronounced, in this sense, �����.) To rack; to torture.

cs.cd: a person skilled in the science of civil engineering.
one who executes engineering works of a military nature. See under Engineering.

entry.ety: OE. enginer: cf. OF. engignier, F. ingénieur. See Engine n.

sn.def: A person skilled in the principles and practice of any branch of engineering; as, a civil engineer; an electronic engineer; a chemical engineer . See under Engineering n.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Engineered; p. pr. & vb. n. Engineering

sn.def: To lay out or construct, as an engineer; to perform the work of an engineer on; as, to engineer a road.
To use contrivance and effort for; to guide the course of; to manage; as, to engineer a bill through Congress.

entries.entry: En`gi*neer" Corps. In the United States army, the Corps of Engineers, a corps of officers and enlisted men consisting of one band and three battalions of engineers commanded by a brigadier general, whose title is Chief of Engineers. It has charge of the construction of fortifications for land and seacoast defense, the improvement of rivers and harbors, the construction of lighthouses, etc., and, in time of war, supervises the engineering operations of the armies in the field. In the United States navy, a corps made up of the engineers, which was amalgamated with the line by act of March 3, 1899. It consisted of assistant and passed assistant engineers, ranking with ensigns and lieutenants, chief engineers, ranking from lieutenant to captain, and engineer in chief, ranking with commodore and having charge of the Bureau of Steam Engineering.

entry.note: ☞ In a comprehensive sense, engineering includes architecture as a mechanical art, in distinction from architecture as a fine art. It was formerly divided into military engineering, which is the art of designing and constructing offensive and defensive works, and civil engineering, in a broad sense, as relating to other kinds of public works, machinery, etc.Civil engineering, in modern usage, is strictly the art of planning, laying out, and constructing fixed public works, such as railroads, highways, canals, aqueducts, water works, bridges, lighthouses, docks, embankments, breakwaters, dams, tunnels, etc.Mechanical engineering relates to machinery, such as steam engines, machine tools, mill work, etc.Mining engineering deals with the excavation and working of mines, and the extraction of metals from their ores, etc. Engineering is further divided into steam engineering, gas engineering, agricultural engineering, topographical engineering, electrical engineering, etc.
entry.def: Originally, the art of managing engines; in its modern and extended sense, the art and science by which the properties of matter are made useful to man, whether in structures, machines, chemical substances, or living organisms; the occupation and work of an engineer. In the modern sense, the application of mathematics or systematic knowledge beyond the routine skills of practise, for the design of any complex system which performs useful functions, may be considered as engineering, including such abstract tasks as designing software (software engineering).

entries.entry: En"gine*man n.; pl.Enginemen. A man who manages, or waits on, an engine.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to England, or to its inhabitants, or to the present so-called Anglo-Saxon race.

entry.note: ☞ The English language has been variously divided into periods by different writers. In the division most commonly recognized, the first period dates from about 450 to 1150. This is the period of full inflection, and is called Anglo-Saxon, or, by many recent writers, Old English. The second period dates from about 1150 to 1550 (or, if four periods be recognized, from about 1150 to 1350), and is called Early English Middle English, or more commonly (as in the usage of this book), Old English. During this period most of the inflections were dropped, and there was a great addition of French words to the language. The third period extends from about 1350 to 1550, and is Middle English. During this period orthography became comparatively fixed. The last period, from about 1550, is called Modern English.
The type called English.
entry.cs: The King's EnglishorThe Queen's English . See under King.

entry.note: ☞ Engraving on wood is called xylography; on copper, chalcography; on stone lithography. Engravings or prints take from wood blocks are usually called wood cuts, those from stone, lithographs.

entries.entry:
e*nig"ma �*nĭg"mȧ n.; pl.enigmas �*nĭg"mȧz. L. aenigma, Gr. a'i`nigma, fr. a'ini`ssesqai to speak darkly, fr. a'i^nos tale, fable
A dark, obscure, or inexplicable saying; a riddle; a statement, the hidden meaning of which is to be discovered or guessed. A custom was among the ancients of proposing an enigma at festivals.
An action, mode of action, or thing, which cannot be satisfactorily explained; a puzzle; as, his conduct is an enigma .

entry.def: Relating to or resembling an enigma; not easily explained or accounted for; darkly expressed; not clear to the understanding; obscure; puzzling; as, an enigmatical answer; I didn't grasp the meaning of that enigmatical comment until much later; prophetic texts so enigmatical that their meaning has been disputed for centuries.
Darkly; obscurely.
One who makes, or talks in, enigmas.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enigmatized; p. pr. & vb. n. Enigmatizing

entry.note: ☞ Enjoin has the force of pressing admonition with authority; as, a parent enjoins on his children the duty of obedience. But it has also the sense of command; as, the duties enjoined by God in the moral law. “This word is more authoritative than direct, and less imperious than command.”
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enjoined; p. pr. & vb. n. Enjoining

entry.cs:

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enlarged; p. pr. & vb. n. Enlarging

To illumine; to enlighten.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + lighten: cf. AS. inlīhtan. Cf. Enlight

sn.def: To supply with light; to illuminate; as, the sun enlightens the earth.
sn.q: His lightnings enlightened the world.

sn.def: To make clear to the intellect or conscience; to shed the light of truth and knowledge upon; to furnish with increase of knowledge; to instruct; as, to enlighten the mind or understanding.
sn.q: The conscience enlightened by the Word and Spirit of God.

entry.def: One who enlightens or illuminates; one who, or that which, communicates light to the eye, or clear views to the mind.

sn.def: enlightening so as to encourage intellectual or moral improvement.
tending to increase knowledge or dissipate ignorance; as, an enlightening glimpse of government in action.
Act of enlightening, or the state of being enlightened or instructed.
same as AufklÄrung.

entry.def: the Sumerian god of the air, and king of the Sumerian gods.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + limn. Cf. Enlumine Illuminate
entry.def: To adorn by illuminating or ornamenting with colored and decorated letters and figures, as a book or manuscript.
To chain together; to connect, as by links.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enlisted; p. pr. & vb. n. Enlisting

sn.def: To enter on a list; to enroll; to register.
To engage for military or naval service, the name being entered on a list or register; as, to enlist men.
To secure the support and aid of; to employ in advancing interest; as, to enlist persons in the cause of truth, or in a charitable enterprise.
To enroll and bind one's self for military or naval service; as, he enlisted in the regular army; the men enlisted for the war.
To enter heartily into a cause, as if enrolled.

entry.def: designating to those members of the armed forces not commissioned as an officer; as, an enlisted man.

sn.def: any new member of an organization or supporter of a cause.
an enlisted man or woman in the armed forces.
a person who enlisted voluntarily in the armed forces; -- contrasted with draftee.

entry.def: the act of getting recruits; convincing people to join the army, take a job, support a cause etc.

sn.def: The act or enlisting, or the state of being enlisted; voluntary enrollment to serve as a soldier or a sailor.
The writing by which an enlisted man is bound.

entry.def: To enliven.

entries.entry:
En*liv"en v. t.
imp. & p. p. Enlivened; p. pr. & vb. n. Enlivening
Pref. en- + liven . To give life, action, or motion to; to make vigorous or active; to excite; to quicken; as, fresh fuel enlivens a fire. Lo! of themselves th' enlivened chessmen move.
To give spirit or vivacity to; to make sprightly, gay, or cheerful; to animate; as, mirth and good humor enliven a company; enlivening strains of music.
To animate; rouse; inspire; cheer; encourage; comfort; exhilarate; inspirit; invigorate.

entry.def: One who, or that which, enlivens, animates, or invigorates.
To lock; to inclose.

entry.ety: F. enluminer; pref. en-L. in) + L. luminare to light up, illumine. See Illuminate, and cf. Limn
entry.def: To illumine.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + L. lutum mud, clay
entry.def: To coat with clay; to lute.

entry.ety: F.; pref. en-L. in) + manche sleeve
entry.def: Resembling, or covered with, a sleeve; -- said of the chief when lines are drawn from the middle point of the upper edge upper edge to the sides.
To make hard as marble; to harden.
To catch or entangle in, or as in, meshes.
entry.q: My doubts enmesh me if I try.

entry.def: See Emmew.
To infold, as in a mist.

entries.entry:
En"mi*ty n.; pl.Enmities #. OE. enemyte, fr. enemy: cf. F. inimitié, OF. enemistié. See Enemy, and cf. Amity
The quality of being an enemy; hostile or unfriendly disposition. No ground of enmity between us known.
A state of opposition; hostility. The friendship of the world is enmity with God. Rancor; hostility; hatred; aversion; antipathy; repugnance; animosity; ill will; malice; malevolence. See Animosity Rancor.

entry.def: Covered with moss; mossed.
See Emmove.
To muffle up.
To immure.
The ninth segment in insects.

cs.cd: the title given to the works of the philosopher Plotinus, published by his pupil Porphyry; -- so called because each of the six books into which it is divided contains nine chapters.

entry.def: The number nine or a group of nine.

entry.ety: Gr. 'enne`a nine + gwni`a corner, angle: cf. ennéagone
entry.def: A polygon or plane figure with nine sides and nine angles; a nonagon.
Belonging to an enneagon; having nine angles.
Having or producing nine pistils or styles; -- said of a flower or plant.
Having nine sides.
A figure having nine sides; a nonagon.

entries.entry:
En`ne*an"dri*a‖n. NL., fr. Gr. 'enne`a nine + 'anh`r 'andro`s, man, male: cf. F. ennéandrie
Bot A Linnæan class of plants having nine stamens.

entry.def: Having nine stamens.

entry.ety: Gr. 'enne`a nine + E. petalous: cf. F. ennéapétale
entry.def: Having nine petals, or flower leaves.
Having nine seeds; -- said of fruits.

cs.cd: every ninth day of a disease.
every ninth year of a man's life.

entry.def: Occurring once in every nine times, days, years, etc.; every ninth.
To make new.
To place in a niche.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Ennobled; p. pr. & vb. n. Ennobling
entry.ety: Pref. en- + noble: cf. F. ennoblir

sn.def: To make noble; to elevate in degree, qualities, or excellence; to dignify.
sn.q: Ennoblingall that he touches.
What can ennoble sots, or slaves, or cowards? Alas! not all the blood of all the Howards.

sn.def: To raise to the rank of nobility; as, to ennoble a commoner.
sn.syn: To raise; dignify; exalt; elevate; aggrandize.

sn.def: The act of making noble, or of exalting, dignifying, or advancing to nobility.
That which ennobles; excellence; dignity.

entry.def: One who ennobles.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. in odio in hatred. See Annoy
entry.def: A feeling of weariness and disgust; dullness and languor of spirits, arising from satiety or want of interest; tedium.

entry.ety: F., p. p. of ennuyer. See Ennui
entry.def: Affected with ennui; weary in spirits; emotionally exhausted.
One who is affected with ennui.
A woman affected with ennui.
Without a node.

entry.ety: L. enodatio explanation, fr. enodare to free from knots. See Enode
entry.def: The act or operation of clearing of knots, or of untying; hence, also, the solution of a difficulty.

entry.ety: L. enodare; e out + nodare to fill with knots, nodus a knot
entry.def: To clear of knots; to make clear.
Anointed.
The commander of an enomoty.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � sworn; � in + � to swear
entry.def: A band of sworn soldiers; a division of the Spartan army ranging from twenty-five to thirty-six men, bound together by oath.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � armed; � in + �, pl., armor
entry.def: One of the orders of Nemertina, characterized by the presence of a peculiar armature of spines or plates in the proboscis.
Divination by the use of a mirror.
Enormous.

entries.entry:
E*nor"mi*ty n.; pl.Enormities #. L. enormitas, fr. enormis enormous: cf. F. énormité. See Enormous
The state or quality of exceeding a measure or rule, or of being immoderate, monstrous, or outrageous. The enormity of his learned acquisitions.
That which is enormous; especially, an exceeding offense against order, right, or decency; an atrocious crime; flagitious villainy; an atrocity. These clamorous enormities which are grown too big and strong for law or shame.

entry.usage: Enormous Immense Excessive. We speak of a thing as enormous when it overpasses its ordinary law of existence or far exceeds its proper average or standard, and becomes -- so to speakabnormal in its magnitude, degree, etc.; as, a man of enormous strength; a deed of enormous wickedness. Immense expresses somewhat indefinitely an immeasurable quantity or extent. Excessive is applied to what is beyond a just measure or amount, and is always used in an evil; as, enormous size; an enormous crime; an immense expenditure; the expanse of ocean is immense. “Excessive levity and indulgence are ultimately excessive rigor.” V. Knox. “Complaisance becomes servitude when it is excessive.” La Rochefoucauld (Trans).
entry.ety: L. enormis enormous, out of rule; e out + norma rule: cf. F. énorme. See Normal

sn.def: Exceeding the usual rule, norm, or measure; out of due proportion; inordinate; abnormal.
sn.q: Enormousbliss.
Thisenormousstate.
The hoop'senormoussize.
Wallowing unwieldy, enormous in their gait.

sn.def: Exceedingly wicked; outrageous; atrocious; monstrous; as, an enormous crime.
sn.q: That detestable profession of a life so enormous.
sn.syn: Huge; vast; immoderate; immense; excessive; prodigious; monstrous.

entry.def: In an enormous degree.
The state of being enormous.

entry.ety: Gr. � in + � upright, correct + � to turn
entry.def: An optical toy; a card on which confused or imperfect figures are drawn, but which form to the eye regular figures when the card is rapidly revolved. See Thaumatrope.

entry.ety: OE. inoh inow enogh, AS. genōh genōg, a. & adv. (akin to OS. ginōg, D. genoeg, OHG. ginoug, G. genug, Icel. gnōgr, Sw. nog, Dan. nok, Goth. ganōhs), fr. geneah it suffices (akin to Goth. ganah); pref. ge- + a root akin to L. nancisci to get, Skr. naç, Gr. 'enegkei^n to carry
entry.def: Satisfying desire; giving content; adequate to meet the want; sufficient; -- usually, and more elegantly, following the noun to which it belongs.
entry.q: How many hired servants of my father's have bread enough and to spare!

entry.note: ☞ Enough usually follows the word it modifies.

sn.def: In a degree or quantity that satisfies; to satisfaction; sufficiently.
Fully; quite; -- used to express slight augmentation of the positive degree, and sometimes equivalent to very; as, he is ready enough to embrace the offer.
sn.q: I know you well enough; you are Signior Antonio.
Thou knowest well enough . . . that this is no time to lend money.

sn.def: In a tolerable degree; -- used to express mere acceptableness or acquiescence, and implying a degree or quantity rather less than is desired; as, the song was well enough .

entry.def: A sufficiency; a quantity which satisfies desire, is adequate to the want, or is equal to the power or ability; as, he had enough to do take care of himself.
entry.q: Enoughis as good as a feast.
And Esau said, I have enough, my brother.

entry.def: An exclamation denoting sufficiency, being a shortened form of it is enough.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Enounced; p. pr. & vb. n. Enouncing
entry.ety: F. énoncer, L. enuntiare; e out + nuntiare to announce, fr. nuntius messenger. See Nuncio, and cf. Enunciate

sn.def: To announce; to declare; to state, as a proposition or argument.
To utter; to articulate.
sn.q: The student should be able to enounce these [sounds] independently.

entry.def: Act of enouncing; that which is enounced.

entries.entry: E*now". A form of Enough. Archaic

En` pas`sant" En` pas`sant". F In passing; in the course of any procedure; said specif. Chess of the taking of an adverse pawn which makes a first move of two squares by a pawn already so advanced as to threaten the first of these squares. The pawn which takes en passant is advanced to the threatened square.

entry.def: To act the part of a patron towards; to patronize.

entry.ety: F. enrager to be enraged; pref. en-L. in) + rage rage. See Rage
entry.def: To fill with rage; to provoke to frenzy or madness; to make furious.
entry.syn: To irritate; incense; inflame; exasperate; provoke; anger; madden; infuriate.

entry.def: filled with or indicating extreme anger; as, an enraged bull.
Act of enraging or state of being enraged; excitement.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + range. Cf. Enrank Arrange

sn.def: To range in order; to put in rank; to arrange.
To rove over; to range.

entry.def: To invest or adorn with a robe; to attire.

entry.ety: Pref. en- + roll: cf. F. enrôler; pref. en-L. in) + rôle roll or register. See Roll n.

To surround.

sn.q: Henry but joined the roses that ensigned Particular families.

sn.def: To distinguish by a mark or ornament; esp. Her, by a crown; thus, any charge which has a crown immediately above or upon it, is said to be ensigned .

entry.def: To follow; to pursue; to follow and overtake.

entry.def: To follow or come afterward; to follow as a consequence or in chronological succession; to result; as, an ensuing conclusion or effect; the year ensuing was a cold one.

Damage to the mind or the body, or to both, ensues, unless the exciting cause be presently removed.
entry.syn: To follow; pursue; succeed. See Follow.

entry.def: subsequent, or occurring as a result; as, ensuing events confirmed the prediction.

sn.def: To make sure. See Insure.
To betroth.

entry.note: ☞ It is commonly divided into architrave, the part immediately above the column; frieze, the central space; and cornice, the upper projecting moldings.
entry.ety: OF. entablature: cf. It intavolatura, fr. LL. intabulare to construct a basis; L. in + tabulatum board work, flooring, fr. tabula. See Table

See Entablature.
To supply with tackle.
Toward the inside or central part; away from the surface; -- opposed to ectad.

entry.ety: OE. entaile carving, OF. entaille, F., an incision, fr. entailler to cut away; pref. en-L. in) + tailler to cut; LL. feudum talliatum a fee entailed, i. e., curtailed or limited. See Tail limitation, Tailor
entry.sn:
That which is entailed. Hence: Law
An estate in fee entailed, or limited in descent to a particular class of issue.
The rule by which the descent is fixed. A power of breaking the ancient entails, and of alienating their estates.

sn.def: Delicately carved ornamental work; intaglio.
sn.q: A work of richentail.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Entailed; p. pr. & vb. n. Entailing
entry.ety: OE. entailen to carve, OF. entailler. See Entail n.

sn.def: To settle or fix inalienably on a person or thing, or on a person and his descendants or a certain line of descendants; -- said especially of an estate; to bestow as an heritage.
sn.q: Allowing them to entail their estates.
I here entail The crown to thee and to thine heirs forever.

sn.def: To appoint hereditary possessor.
sn.q: To entail him and his heirs unto the crown.

sn.def: To cut or carve in an ornamental way.
sn.q: Entailed with curious antics.

A thing entailed.
sn.q: Brutality as an hereditary entailment becomes an ever weakening force.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or situated near, central or deep parts; inner; -- opposed to ectal.
To tame.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Entangled; p. pr. & vb. n. Entangling

sn.def: To twist or interweave in such a manner as not to be easily separated; to make tangled, confused, and intricate; as, to entangle yarn or the hair.

To involve in such complications as to render extrication a bewildering difficulty; hence, metaphorically, to insnare; to perplex; to bewilder; to puzzle; as, to entangle the feet in a net, or in briers.
sn.q: Entanglingalliances.
The difficulties that perplex men's thoughts and entangle their understandings.
Allowing her to entangle herself with a person whose future was so uncertain.

entry.sn: in a confused mass. Contrasted with untangled.Narrower terms: afoul(postnominal), foul, fouled; knotted, snarled, snarly; matted; rootbound; intertwined tangled.

sn.def: deeply involved especially in something problematic; as, entangled in the conflict.
constrained by or as if by a convoluted rope or net; ensnared.

An obstruction of cables and spars across a river or harbor entrance.

entry.def: One that entangles.

entry.def: Relating to any disease characterized by tonic spasms.

entry.ety: L. entelechia, Gr. �, prob. fr. � � � to be complete; � + � completion, end + � to have or hold
entry.def: An actuality; a conception completely actualized, in distinction from mere potential existence.

entry.ety: NL., the specific name, fr. Gr. � to command
entry.def: An East Indian long-tailed bearded monkey (Semnopithecus entellus) regarded as sacred by the natives. It is remarkable for the caplike arrangement of the hair on the head. Called also hoonoomaun and hungoor.

entry.ety: F. entendre, fr. L. intendere. See Intend
entry.def: To attend to; to apply one's self to.

sn.def: To make tender.
To treat with tenderness.

entry.def: Attentive; zealous.

entries.entry:
En"ter-. F. entre between, fr. L. inter. See Inter-
A prefix signifying between among part.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Entered; p. pr. & vb. n. Entering
entry.ety: OE. entren enteren, F. entrer, fr. L. intrare, fr. intro inward, contr. fr. interosc. loco), fr. inter in between, between. See Inter- In, and cf. Interior

sn.def: To come or go into; to pass into the interior of; to pass within the outer cover or shell of; to penetrate; to pierce; as, to enter a house, a closet, a country, a door, etc.; the river enters the sea.
sn.q: That darksome cave they enter.
I, . . . with the multitude of my redeemed, Shall enter heaven, long absent.

sn.def: To unite in; to join; to be admitted to; to become a member of; as, to enter an association, a college, an army.
To engage in; to become occupied with; as, to enter the legal profession, the book trade, etc.
To pass within the limits of; to attain; to begin; to commence upon; as, to enter one's teens, a new era, a new dispensation.

To cause to go (into), or to be received (into); to put in; to insert; to cause to be admitted; as, to enter a knife into a piece of wood, a wedge into a log; to enter a boy at college, a horse for a race, etc.

To inscribe; to enroll; to record; as, to enter a name, or a date, in a book, or a book in a catalogue; to enter the particulars of a sale in an account, a manifest of a ship or of merchandise at the customhouse.

sd.def: To go into or upon, as lands, and take actual possession of them.
To place in regular form before the court, usually in writing; to put upon record in proper from and order; as, to enter a writ, appearance, rule, or judgment.

sn.def: To make report of (a vessel or her cargo) at the customhouse; to submit a statement of (imported goods), with the original invoices, to the proper officer of the customs for estimating the duties. See Entry, 4.
To file or inscribe upon the records of the land office the required particulars concerning (a quantity of public land) in order to entitle a person to a right pf preëmption.
To deposit for copyright the title or description of (a book, picture, map, etc.); as, “entered according to act of Congress.”
To initiate; to introduce favorably.
To go or come in; -- often with in used pleonastically; also, to begin; to take the first steps.
sn.q: The yearentering.
No evil thing approach nor enter in.
Truth is fallen in the street, and equity can not enter.
For we which have believed do enter into rest.

sn.def: To get admission; to introduce one's self; to penetrate; to form or constitute a part; to become a partaker or participant; to share; to engage; -- usually with into; sometimes with on or upon; as, a ball enters into the body; water enters into a ship; he enters into the plan; to enter into a quarrel; a merchant enters into partnership with some one; to enter upon another's land; the boy enters on his tenth year; to enter upon a task; lead enters into the composition of pewter.
To penetrate mentally; to consider attentively; -- with into.
sn.q: He is particularly pleased with . . . Sallust for his entering into internal principles of action.

entry.def: A treatise upon, or description of, the intestinal glands.
The science which treats of the glands of the alimentary canal.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`nteron an intestine + � pain: cf. F. entéralgie
entry.def: Pain in the intestines; colic.
Mutual dealings; intercourse.
entry.q: The enterdeal of princes strange.

entry.def: One who makes an entrance or beginning.

cs.cd: typhoid fever.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the enteron, or alimentary canal; intestinal.
rod-shaped gram-negative bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae; most occur normally or pathogenically in intestines of humans and other animals; those of the genus Erwinia are found in plants.
incoming; -- of a person or group assuming a role. Opposite of leaving and outgoing.

entries.entry: En"ter*ing edgeorEn"trant edge . same as Advancing edge.

entry.def: An inflammation of the intestines.
See Interlace.

entry.ety: F. s'entremettre; entre between + mettre to place
entry.def: To interfere; to intermeddle.
A hawk gradually changing the color of its feathers, commonly in the second year.

entry.ety: F. entremise, fr. s'entremettre. See Entermete
entry.def: Mediation.

rod-shaped gram-negative bacteria of the family Enterobacteriaceae; most occur normally or pathogenically in intestines of humans and other animals; some, such as those of the genus Erwinia, are found in plants.

a natural family of rod-shaped gram-negative bacteria, most of which occur normally or pathogenically in intestines of humans and other animals, and some of which grow in plants. The type genus is Escherichia. They are aerobic and facultatively anaerobic, and may be motile or non-motile. Most are easily cultured on artificial growth media. Both pathogenic and non-pathogenic strains exist.
Of or pertaining to the enterobacteria.
one of the enterobacteria; a member of the family Enterobacteriaceae.
a genus of nematode worms.

entry.ety: Gr. 'enterokh`lh; 'e`nteron an intestine + kh`lh tumor, hernia
entry.def: A hernial tumor whose contents are intestine.

entry.ety: Gr. 'e`nteron an intestine + koi^lon a hollow
entry.def: A perivisceral cavity which arises as an outgrowth or outgrowths from the digestive tract; distinguished from a schizocœle, which arises by a splitting of the mesoblast of the embryo.
A treatise upon, or description of, the intestines; enterology.
An intestinal concretion.

entry.ety: Gr. 'e`nteron an intestine + -logy: cf. F. entérologie
entry.def: The science which treats of the viscera of the body.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`nteron an intestine, fr. 'ento`s within
entry.def: The whole alimentary, or enteric, canal.
Disease of the intestines.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'e`nteron an intestine + � to breathe
entry.def: A group of wormlike invertebrates having, along the sides of the body, branchial openings for the branchial sacs, which are formed by diverticula of the alimentary canal. Balanoglossus is the only known genus. See Illustration in Appendix.
The operation of sewing up a rent in the intestinal canal.
A kind of scissors used for opening the intestinal canal, as in post-mortem examinations.

entry.ety: Gr. 'e`nteron an intestine + te`mnein to cut
entry.def: Incision of the intestines, especially in reducing certain cases of hernia.
Mutual talk or conversation; conference.
Same as Interplead.

entry.ety: F. enterprise, fr. entreprendre to undertake; entre between (L. inter) + prendre to take. See Inter, and Emprise

sn.def: That which is undertaken; something attempted to be performed; a work projected which involves activity, courage, energy, and the like; a bold, arduous, or hazardous attempt; an undertaking; as, a manly enterprise; a warlike enterprise.
sn.q: Their hands can not perform their enterprise.

sn.def: Willingness or eagerness to engage in labor which requires boldness, promptness, energy, and like qualities; as, a man of great enterprise .
To undertake; to begin and attempt to perform; to venture upon.
sn.q: The business must be enterprised this night.
What would I not renounce or enterprise for you!

sn.def: To treat with hospitality; to entertain.
sn.q: Him at the threshold met, and well did enterprise.

entry.def: To undertake an enterprise, or something hazardous or difficult.
One who undertakes enterprises.
Having a disposition for enterprise; characterized by enterprise; resolute, active or prompt to attempt; as, an enterprising man or firm.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Entertained; p. pr. & vb. n. Entertaining
entry.ety: F. entretenir; entre between (L. inter) + tenir to hold, L. tenere. See Tenable

sn.def: To be at the charges of; to take or keep in one's service; to maintain; to support; to harbor; to keep.
sn.q: You, sir, I entertain for one of my hundred.

sn.def: To give hospitable reception and maintenance to; to receive at one's board, or into one's house; to receive as a guest.
sn.q: Be not forgetful to entertain strangers; for thereby some have entertained unawares.

sn.def: To engage the attention of agreeably; to amuse with that which makes the time pass pleasantly; to divert; as, to entertain friends with conversation, etc.
sn.q: The weary time she can not entertain.

sn.def: To give reception to; to receive, in general; to receive and take into consideration; to admit, treat, or make use of; as, to entertain a proposal.
sn.q: I am not here going to entertain so large a theme as the philosophy of Locke.
A rumor gained ground, -- and, however absurd, was entertained by some very sensible people.

sn.def: To meet or encounter, as an enemy.
To keep, hold, or maintain in the mind with favor; to keep in the mind; to harbor; to cherish; as, to entertain sentiments.
To lead on; to bring along; to introduce.
sn.q: To baptize all nations, and entertain them into the services institutions of the holy Jesus.
sn.syn: To amuse; divert; maintain. See Amuse.

entry.def: To receive, or provide entertainment for, guests; as, he entertains generously.
Entertainment.
p. p. of entertain.

sn.def: One who entertains; a host.
one who amuses people, such as a singer, dancer, comedian, magician, etc., especially one who does so as a profession.

entry.def: Affording entertainment; pleasing; amusing; diverting.

sn.def: The act of receiving as host, or of amusing, admitting, or cherishing; hospitable reception; also, reception or treatment, in general.
sn.q: The entertainment of Christ by faith.
