Gr. � , orig. an adj., nuptial; 'epi` upon, at + � bride chamber A nuptial song, or poem in honor of the bride and bridegroom. The kind of poem which was called epithalamium . . . sung when the bride was led into her chamber.
Ep`i*thal"a*my n.; pl.Epithalamies. Epithalamium. R

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'epi` upon + � a case, box, fr. � to place
entry.def: A continuous and, usually, structureless layer which covers more or less of the exterior of many corals.
Of or pertaining to epithelium; as, epithelial cells; epithelial cancer.
Like epithelium; as, epithelioid cells.
A malignant growth containing epithelial cells; -- called also epithelial cancer.

entries.entry: Ep`i*the"li*um n.; pl. E. Epitheliums #, L. Epithelia #. NL., fr. Gr. 'epi` upon + � nipple Anat The superficial layer of cells lining the alimentary canal and all its appendages, all glands and their ducts, blood vessels and lymphatics, serous cavities, etc. It often includes the epidermis (i. e., keratin-producing epithelial cells), and it is sometimes restricted to the alimentary canal, the glands and their appendages, -- the term endothelium being applied to the lining membrane of the blood vessels, lymphatics, and serous cavities.

entry.def: Epithelioid.

entry.ety: L. epithema, Gr. �, fr. � to lay or put on: cf. F. épithème. See Epithet
entry.def: Any external topical application to the body, except ointments and plasters, as a poultice, lotion, etc.

entry.ety: NL., from Gr. 'epi` upon + � a case, box, fr. � to place
entry.def: A horny excrescence upon the beak of birds.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a putting on; 'epi` upon + � to place
entry.def: The addition of a letter at the end of a word, without changing its sense; as, numb for num whilst for whiles .

entry.usage: The name epithet was formerly extended to nouns which give a title or describe character (as the “epithet of liar”), but is now confined wholly to adjectives. Some rhetoricians, as Whately, restrict it still further, considering the term epithet as belonging only to a limited class of adjectives, viz., those which add nothing to the sense of their noun, but simply hold forth some quality necessarily implied therein; as, the bright sun, the lofty heavens, etc. But this restriction does not prevail in general literature. Epithet is sometimes confounded with application, which is always a noun or its equivalent.
entry.ety: L. epitheton, Gr. �, fr. � added, fr. � to add; 'epi` upon, to + � to put, place: cf. F. épithète. See Do

sn.def: An adjective expressing some quality, attribute, or relation, that is properly or specially appropriate to a person or thing; as, a just man; a verdant lawn.
sn.q: A prince [Henry III.] to whom the epithet “worthless” seems best applicable.

sn.def: Term; expression; phrase.
sn.q: Stuffed withepithetsof war.

entry.def: To describe by an epithet.
entry.q: Never was a town better epitheted.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or abounding with, epithets.
entry.q: Inepitheticmeasured prose.

entry.def: A lazy, worthless fellow; a vagrant.
Epithumetical.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to long for, lust after; 'epi` + qymo`s soul, heart, desire
entry.def: Pertaining to sexual desire; sensual.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � to place upon. See Epithet
entry.def: The uppermost member of the cornice of an entablature.
An epitomist.

entries.entry:
E*pit"o*me n.; pl.Epitomes #. L., fr. Gr. � a surface incision, also, and abridgment, fr. � to cut into, cut short; 'epi` upon + te`mnein to cut: cf. F. épitome. See Tome
A work in which the contents of a former work are reduced within a smaller space by curtailment and condensation; a brief summary; an abridgement. Anepitome of the contents of a very large book.
A compact or condensed representation of anything; something possessing conspicuously or to a high degree the qualities of a class. An epitome of English fashionable life. A man so various that he seemed to be Not one, but all mankind's epitome. Abridgement; compendium; compend; abstract; synopsis; abbreviature. See Abridgment.

entry.def: One who makes an epitome; one who abridges; an epitomizer.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Epitomized; p. pr. & vb. n. Epitomizing

sn.def: To make an epitome of; to shorten or abridge, as a writing or discourse; to reduce within a smaller space; as, to epitomize the works of Justin.
To diminish, as by cutting off something; to curtail; as, to epitomize words.

entry.def: An epitomist.

entry.note: ☞ It is so called from being compounded of a spondee (which contains 4 times) with an iambus or a trochee (which contains 3 times). It is called 1st, 2d, 3d, or 4th epitrite according as the short syllable stands 1st, 2d, etc.
entry.ety: Gr. � containing an integer and one third (i. e., 4/3, or in the ratio of 4 to 3); 'epi` upon, over + � the third: cf. L. epitritos, F. épitrite
entry.def: A foot consisting of three long syllables and one short syllable.
A projection on the outer side of the distal end of the humerus; the external condyle.
Relating to the epitrochlea.
A kind of curve. See Epicycloid, any Trochoid.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. � reference, arbitration, fr. � to turn over, to give up, yield; 'epi` upon, over + � to turn
entry.def: A figure by which permission is either seriously or ironically granted to some one, to do what he proposes to do; e. g., “He that is unjust, let him be unjust still.”

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. � a fastening together, repetition, fr. � to fasten to or upon; 'epi` upon + � to join, yoke
entry.def: A figure by which a word is repeated with vehemence or emphasis, as in the following lines:
entry.q: Alone alone all all alone,Alone on a wide wide sea.

entry.def: An epizoön.
Living upon the exterior of another animal; ectozoic; -- said of external parasites.

entries.entry: Ep`i*zo"ön Ep`i*zo"ön n.; pl.Epizoa #. NL., fr. Gr. 'epi` upon + zw^,on animal Zoöl One of the artificial group of invertebrates of various kinds, which live parasitically upon the exterior of other animals; an ectozoön. Among them are the lice, ticks, many acari, the lerneans, or fish lice, and other crustaceans.

sn.def: Of or pertaining to an epizoön.
Containing fossil remains; -- said of rocks, formations, mountains, and the like.
sn.q: Epizoötic mountains are of secondary formation.

sn.def: Of the nature of a disease which attacks many animals at the same time; -- corresponding to epidemic diseases among men.
A disease attacking many animals at the same time; an epizootic disease.
A murrain; an epidemic influenza among horses.

entry.note: ☞ Epochs mark the beginning of new historical periods, and dates are often numbered from them.
entry.usage: Epoch Era. We speak of the era of the Reformation, when we think of it as a period, during which a new order of things prevailed; so also, the era of good feeling, etc. Had we been thinking of the time as marked by certain great events, or as a period in which great results were effected, we should have called the times when these events happened epochs, and the whole period an epoch.
entry.ety: LL. epocha, Gr. 'epochh` check, stop, an epoch of a star, an historical epoch, fr. 'epe`chein to hold on, check; 'epi` upon + 'e`chein to have, hold; akin to Skr. sah to overpower, Goth. sigis victory, AS. sigor sige, G. sieg: cf. F. époque. See Scheme

sn.def: A fixed point of time, established in history by the occurrence of some grand or remarkable event; a point of time marked by an event of great subsequent influence; as, the epoch of the creation; the birth of Christ was the epoch which gave rise to the Christian era.
sn.q: In divers ages, . . . divers epochs of time were used.
Great epochs and crises in the kingdom of God.
The acquittal of the bishops was not the only event which makes the 30th of June, 1688, a great epoch in history.

sn.def: A period of time, longer or shorter, remarkable for events of great subsequent influence; a memorable period; as, the epoch of maritime discovery, or of the Reformation.
sn.q: So vast anepochof time.
The influence of Chaucer continued to live even during the dreary interval which separates from one another two important epochs of our literary history.

sn.def: A division of time characterized by the prevalence of similar conditions of the earth; commonly a minor division or part of a period.
sn.q: The long geological epoch which stored up the vast coal measures.

sd.def: The date at which a planet or comet has a longitude or position.

An arbitrary fixed date, for which the elements used in computing the place of a planet, or other heavenly body, at any other date, are given; as, the epoch of Mars; lunar elements for the epoch March 1st, 1860.
sd.q: The capture of Constantinople is an epoch in the history of Mahometanism; but the flight of Mahomet is its era.

entry.def: See Epoch.
Belonging to an epoch; of the nature of an epoch.
entry.q: Epochalpoints.

entry.ety: L. epodos, Gr. �, fr. �, adj., singing to, sung or said after, fr. � to sing to; 'epi` upon, to + � to sing: cf. F. épode. See Ode
entry.def: The after song; the part of a lyric ode which follows the strophe and antistrophe, -- the ancient ode being divided into strophe, antistrophe, and epode.
A species of lyric poem, invented by Archilochus, in which a longer verse is followed by a shorter one; as, the Epodes of Horace. It does not include the elegiac distich.
Pertaining to, or resembling, an epode.

sn.def: The hypothetical individual who is assumed as the person from whom any race, city, etc., took its name; as, Hellen is an eponym of the Hellenes.
A name, as of a people, country, and the like, derived from that of an individual.

entry.def: Same as Eponymous.
entry.q: Tablets . . . which bear eponymic dates.

entry.def: One from whom a race, tribe, city, or the like, took its name; an eponym.
Relating to an eponym; giving one's name to a tribe, people, country, and the like.
entry.q: What becomes . . . of the Herakleid genealogy of the Spartan kings, when it is admitted that eponymous persons are to be canceled as fictions?

entry.ety: Gr. � a surname given after some person or thing
entry.def: The derivation of the name of a race, tribe, etc., from that of a fabulous hero, progenitor, etc.

entries.entry: Ep`o*öph"o*ron‖n. NL., from Gr. 'epi` upon + � egg + fe`rein to bear Anat See Parovarium.

entry.ety: F. épopée, Gr. �; 'e`pos song + � to make. See Epos
entry.def: An epic poem; epic poetry.

entry.ety: Gr. � one initiated into the Eleusinian mysteries
entry.def: One instructed in the mysteries of a secret system.
An epic.

entry.ety: L. epotare epotatum, to drink; e out + potare to drink
entry.def: A drinking up; a quaffing.
An apparatus for testing or proving the strength of gunpowder.
Native sulphate of magnesia or Epsom salt.

entries.entry: Ep"som salts`orEp"som salt` . Med Sulphate of magnesia having cathartic qualities; -- originally prepared by boiling down the mineral waters at Epsom, England, -- whence the name; afterwards prepared from sea water; but now from certain minerals, as from siliceous hydrate of magnesia.

entry.ety: L. epularis, fr. epulum a feast: cf. F. épulaire
entry.def: Of or pertaining to a feast or banquet.
A feasting or feast; banquet.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a gumboil; Gr. 'epi` upon + � gums
entry.def: A hard tumor developed from the gums.
Feasting to excess.
A feasting to excess.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to scar over or heal; 'epi` upon, over + � whole
entry.def: Promoting the skinning over or healing of sores; as, an epulotic ointment.

entry.ety: L. e out, quite + purare to purify, purus pure
entry.def: Purification.
A draught or model from which to build; especially, one of the full size of the work to be done; a detailed drawing.

entries.entry: Ep"worth League. A religious organization of Methodist young people, founded in 1889 at Cleveland, Ohio, and taking its name from John Wesley's birthplace, Epworth, Lincolnshire, England.

entry.ety: L. aequabilitas, fr. aequabilis. See Equable
entry.def: The quality or condition of being equable; evenness or uniformity; as, equability of temperature; the equability of the mind.
entry.q: For the celestial bodies, the equability and constancy of their motions argue them ordained by wisdom.

entry.ety: L. aequabilis, fr. aequare to make level or equal, fr. aequus even, equal. See Equal

sn.def: Equal and uniform; continuing the same at different times; -- said of motion, and the like; uniform in surface; smooth; as, an equable plain or globe.
Uniform in action or intensity; not variable or changing; -- said of the feelings or temper.

entry.def: Quality or state of being equable.
In an equable manner.

entry.cs: Equal temperament. Mus See Temperament.
entry.ety: L. aequalis, fr. aequus even, equal; akin to Skr. �ka, and perh. to L. unus for older oinos one, E. one

sn.def: Agreeing in quantity, size, quality, degree, value, etc.; having the same magnitude, the same value, the same degree, etc.; -- applied to number, degree, quantity, and intensity, and to any subject which admits of them; neither inferior nor superior, greater nor less, better nor worse; corresponding; alike; as, equal quantities of land, water, etc. ; houses of equal size; persons of equal stature or talents; commodities of equal value.
Bearing a suitable relation; of just proportion; having competent power, abilities, or means; adequate; as, he is not equal to the task.
sn.q: The Scots trusted not their own numbers as equal to fight with the English.
It is not permitted to me to make my commendations equal to your merit.
Whose voice an equal messenger Conveyed thy meaning mild.

sn.def: Not variable; equable; uniform; even; as, an equal movement.
sn.q: Anequaltemper.

sn.def: Evenly balanced; not unduly inclining to either side; characterized by fairness; unbiased; impartial; equitable; just.
sn.q: Are not my ways equal?
Thee, O Jove, no equal judge I deem.
Nor think it equal to answer deliberate reason with sudden heat and noise.

sn.def: Of the same interest or concern; indifferent.
sn.q: They who are not disposed to receive them may let them alone or reject them; it is equal to me.

sn.def: Intended for voices of one kind only, either all male or all female; -- opposed to mixed.
Exactly agreeing with respect to quantity.
sn.syn: Even; equable; uniform; adequate; proportionate; commensurate; fair; just; equitable.

sn.def: One not inferior or superior to another; one having the same or a similar age, rank, station, office, talents, strength, or other quality or condition; an equal quantity or number; as, “If equals be taken from equals the remainders are equal.”
sn.q: Those who were once his equals envy and defame him.

sn.def: State of being equal; equality.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equaled or Equalled; p. pr. & vb. n. Equaling or Equalling

sn.def: To be or become equal to; to have the same quantity, the same value, the same degree or rank, or the like, with; to be commen�urate with.
sn.q: On me whose all not equals Edward's moiety.

sn.def: To make equal return to; to recompense fully.
sn.q: Who answered all her cares, and equaled all her love.

sn.def: To make equal or equal to; to equalize; hence, to compare or regard as equals; to put on equality.
sn.q: He would not equal the mind that he found in himself to the infinite and incomprehensible.

entry.def: p. p. of equalise; same as equalized.

sn.def: an electronic circuit which reduces frequency distortion.
an equivalent counterbalancing weight.

entry.def: One who believes in equalizing the condition of men; a leveler.
the doctrine of the equality of mankind and the desirability of political and economic and social equality.

entries.entry:
E*qual"i*ty
Confessional equality. See under Confessional.
n.; pl.Equalities #. L. aequalitas, fr. aequalis equal. See Equal
The condition or quality of being equal; agreement in quantity or degree as compared; likeness in bulk, value, rank, properties, etc.; as, the equality of two bodies in length or thickness; an equality of rights.
A footing of equality with nobles.
Sameness in state or continued course; evenness; uniformity; as, an equality of temper or constitution.
Evenness; uniformity; as, an equality of surface.
Math Exact agreement between two expressions or magnitudes with respect to quantity; -- denoted by the symbol =; thus, a = x signifies that a contains the same number and kind of units of measure that x does.

entry.def: The act of equalizing, or state of being equalized.
entry.q: Their equalization with the rest of their fellow subjects.

cs.cd: a lever connecting two axle boxes, or two springs in a car truck or locomotive, to equalize the pressure on the axles.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equalized; p. pr. & vb. n. Equalizing

sn.def: To make equal; to cause to correspond, or be like, in amount or degree as compared; as, to equalize accounts, burdens, or taxes.
sn.q: One poor moment can suffice To equalize the lofty and the low.
No system of instruction will completely equalize natural powers.

sn.def: To pronounce equal; to compare as equal.
sn.q: Which we equalize, and perhaps would willingly prefer to the Iliad.

sn.def: To be equal to; equal; to match.
sn.q: It could not equalize the hundredth part Of what her eyes have kindled in my heart.

sn.def: One who, or that which, equalizes anything.
same as Equalizing bar.
A device, as a bar, for operating two brakes, esp. a pair of hub brakes for an automobile, with equal force.
Any device for equalizing the pull of electromagnets; also, a conductor of low resistance joining the armature ends of the series field coils of dynamos connected in parallel.
A sliding panel to preserve the lateral stability of an aëroplane.

a device or circuit within a sound-reproducing system that reproduces the original frequency distribution of the sound before recording by compensating for inequialities in the frequency response of the system.
a gun.

entry.def: In an equal manner or degree in equal shares or proportion; with equal and impartial justice; without difference; alike; evenly; justly; as, equally taxed, furnished, etc.
Equality; evenness.
Having equal angles; equiangular.

entry.ety: L. aequanimitas, fr. aequanimus: cf. F. équanimité. See Equanimous
entry.def: Evenness of mind; that calm temper or firmness of mind which is not easily elated or depressed; patience; calmness; composure; as, to bear misfortunes with equanimity .

entry.ety: L. aequanimus, fr. aequus equal + animus mind
entry.def: Of an even, composed frame of mind; of a steady temper; not easily elated or depressed.

entry.ety: L. aequans -antis, p. pr. of aequare: cf. F. équant. See Equate
entry.def: A circle around whose circumference a planet or the center of ann epicycle was conceived to move uniformly; -- called also eccentric equator.

cs.cd: adding to the measured distance one mile for each twenty feet of ascent.
adding half a mile for each 360 degrees of curvature.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equated; p. pr. & vb. n. Equating
entry.ety: L. aequatus, p. p. of aequare to make level or equal, fr. aequus level, equal. See Equal
entry.def: To make equal; to reduce to an average; to make such an allowance or correction in as will reduce to a common standard of comparison; to reduce to mean time or motion; as, to equate payments; to equate lines of railroad for grades or curves; equated distances.
entry.q: Palgrave gives both scrolle and scrowe and equates both to F[rench] rolle.

entry.def: the act of regarding as equal.

entry.cs:
Absolute equation. See under Absolute.
Equation boxorEquational box
a system of differential gearing used in spinning machines for regulating the twist of the yarn. It resembles gearing used in equation clocks for showing apparent time. Equation of the center Astron the difference between the place of a planet as supposed to move uniformly in a circle, and its place as moving in an ellipse. Equations of condition Math equations formed for deducing the true values of certain quantities from others on which they depend, when different sets of the latter, as given by observation, would yield different values of the quantities sought, and the number of equations that may be found is greater than the number of unknown quantities. Equation of a curve Math an equation which expresses the relation between the coördinates of every point in the curve. Equation of equinoxes Astron the difference between the mean and apparent places of the equinox. Equation of payments Arith the process of finding the mean time of payment of several sums due at different times. Equation of time Astron the difference between mean and apparent time, or between the time of day indicated by the sun, and that by a perfect clock going uniformly all the year round.
Equation clockorEquation watch
a timepiece made to exhibit the differences between mean solar and apparent solar time. Knight. Normal equation. See under Normal. Personal equation Astron the difference between an observed result and the true qualities or peculiarities in the observer; particularly the difference, in an average of a large number of observation, between the instant when an observer notes a phenomenon, as the transit of a star, and the assumed instant of its actual occurrence; or, relatively, the difference between these instants as noted by two observers. It is usually only a fraction of a second; -- sometimes applied loosely to differences of judgment or method occasioned by temperamental qualities of individuals. Theory of equations Math the branch of algebra that treats of the properties of a single algebraic equation of any degree containing one unknown quantity.
entry.ety: L. aequatio an equalizing: cf. F. équation equation. See Equate

sn.def: A making equal; equal division; equality; equilibrium.
sn.q: Again the golden day resumed its right, And ruled in just equation with the night.

sn.def: An expression of the condition of equality between two algebraic quantities or sets of quantities, the sign = being placed between them; as, a binomial equation; a quadratic equation; an algebraic equation; a transcendental equation; an exponential equation; a logarithmic equation; a differential equation, etc.

A quantity to be applied in computing the mean place or other element of a celestial body; that is, any one of the several quantities to be added to, or taken from, its position as calculated on the hypothesis of a mean uniform motion, in order to find its true position as resulting from its actual and unequal motion.

entry.cs:
Equator of the sunorEquator of a planet
Astron the great circle whose plane passes through through the center of the body, and is perpendicular to its axis of revolution. Magnetic equator. See Aclinic.
entry.ety: L. aequator one who equalizes: cf. F. équateur equator. See Equate

sn.def: The imaginary great circle on the earth's surface, everywhere equally distant from the two poles, and dividing the earth's surface into two hemispheres.

The great circle of the celestial sphere, coincident with the plane of the earth's equator; -- so called because when the sun is in it, the days and nights are of equal length; hence called also the equinoctial, and on maps, globes, etc., the equinoctial line.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to the equator; as, equatorial climates; also, pertaining to an equatorial instrument.

entry.note: ☞ The term equatorial, or equatorial instrument, is sometimes applied to any astronomical instrument which has its principal axis of rotation parallel to the axis of the earth.
entry.def: An instrument consisting of a telescope so mounted as to have two axes of motion at right angles to each other, one of them parallel to the axis of the earth, and each carrying a graduated circle, the one for measuring declination, and the other right ascension, or the hour angle, so that the telescope may be directed, even in the daytime, to any star or other object whose right ascension and declination are known. The motion in right ascension is sometimes communicated by clockwork, so as to keep the object constantly in the field of the telescope. Called also an equatorial telescope.
So as to have motion or direction parallel to the equator.

entries.entry:
Eq"uer*ry ☞ In England equerries are officers of the royal household in the department of the Master of the Horse. ?; 277 n.; pl.Equerries #. F. écurie stable, for older escurie escuirieconfused somewhat with F. écuyer, OF. escuyer, squire), LL. scuria, OHG. skiura sc�ra, barn, shed, G. scheuer, from a root meaning to cover protect, and akin to L. scutum shield. See Esquire, and cf. Ecurie Querry
A large stable or lodge for horses.
An officer of princes or nobles, charged with the care of their horses.

entry.def: Same as Equerry.

entry.ety: L. equester, from eques horseman, fr. equus horse: cf. F. équestre. See Equine

sn.def: Of or pertaining to horses or horsemen, or to horsemanship; as, equestrian feats, or games.
Being or riding on horseback; mounted; as, an equestrian statue.
sn.q: An equestrian lady appeared upon the plains.

sn.def: Belonging to, or composed of, the ancient Roman equities or knights; as, the equestrian order.

entry.def: One who rides on horseback; a horseman; a rider.
The art of riding on horseback; performance on horseback; horsemanship; as, feats equestrianism .

entry.ety: Formed after analogy of the French language
entry.def: A woman skilled in equestrianism; a horsewoman.

entries.entry:
E"qui-. L. aequus equal. See Equal
A prefix, meaning equally; as, equidistant; equiangular.

entry.def: Equiangular.

entry.cs:
Equiangular spiral. Math See under Spiral n.
Mutually equiangular applied to two figures, when every angle of the one has its equal among the angles of the other.
entry.def: Having equal angles; as, an equiangular figure; a square is equiangular.
Equal weight; equiponderance.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equibalanced; p. pr. & vb. n. Equibalancing
entry.def: To make of equal weight; to balance equally; to counterbalance; to equiponderate.
Increasing by equal increments; as, an equicrescent variable.

entry.ety: L. aequicrurius; aequus equal + crus cruris, leg
entry.def: Having equal legs or sides; isosceles.
entry.q: Equicruraltriangles.

entry.def: Equicrural.
Having equal differences; as, the terms of arithmetical progression are equidifferent .
Equal distance.

entry.ety: L. aequidistans -antis; aequus equal + distans distant: cf. F. équidistant
entry.def: Being at an equal distance from the same point or thing.
Pertaining to the time of equal day and night; -- applied to the equinoctial line.

entry.ety: L. aequiformis; aequus equal + forma form
entry.def: Having the same form; uniform.

cs.cd: one whose axes are equal.
one in which a transverse line drawn through the apex of the umbo bisects the valve, or divides it into two equal and symmetrical parts.
applied to two figures, when every side of the one has its equal among the sides of the other.

entry.ety: L. aequilateralis; aequus equal + latus lateris, side: cf. F. équilatéral
entry.def: Having all the sides equal; as, an equilateral triangle; an equilateral polygon.
A side exactly corresponding, or equal, to others; also, a figure of equal sides.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equilibrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Equilibrating
entry.ety: L. aequilibratus in equilibrium; aequus equal + libra balance. See Equilibrium
entry.def: To balance two scales, sides, or ends; to keep even with equal weight on each side; to keep in equipoise.

sn.def: Act of keeping a balance, or state of being balanced; equipoise.
sn.q: In . . . running, leaping, and dancing, nature's laws of equilibration are observed.

sn.def: The process by which animal and vegetable organisms preserve a physiological balance.

entry.def: Evenly poised; balanced.
One who balances himself in unnatural positions and hazardous movements; a balancer.
entry.q: When the equilibrist balances a rod upon his finger.

entry.ety: L. aequilibritas equal distribution. See Equilibrium
entry.def: The state of being balanced; equality of weight.

entries.entry:
E`qui*lib"ri*um
Equilibrium valve Steam Engine a balanced valve. See under Valve.
n.; pl. E. Equilibriums #, L. Equilibria #. L. aequilibrium, fr. aequilibris in equilibrium, level; aequus equal + libra balance. See Equal, and Librate
Equality of weight or force; an equipoise or a state of rest produced by the mutual counteraction of two or more forces.
A level position; a just poise or balance in respect to an object, so that it remains firm; equipoise; as, to preserve the equilibrium of the body. Health consists in the equilibrium between those two powers.
A balancing of the mind between motives or reasons, with consequent indecision and doubt.

entry.note: ☞ Two bodies or systems of bodies are said to be equimomental when their moments of inertia about all straight lines are equal each to each.

cs.col: Equimomental cone of a given rigid body
cs.cd: a conical surface that has any given vertex, and is described by a straight line which moves in such manner that the moment of inertia of the given rigid body about the line is in all its positions the same.

entry.def: Having equal moments of inertia.
Multiplied by the same number or quantity.
One of the products arising from the multiplication of two or more quantities by the same number or quantity. Thus, seven times 2, or 14, and seven times 4, or 28, are equimultiples of 2 and 4.
See Equine.
entry.q: Anequinalshape.

entry.ety: L. equinus, fr. equus horse; akin to Gr. �, Skr. a�va, OS. ehu, AS. eh eoh, Icel. j�r, OIr. ech, cf. Skr. a� to reach, overtake, perh. akin to E. acute edge eager a. Cf. Hippopotamus
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a horse.
entry.q: The shoulders, body, things, and mane are equine; the head completely bovine.

entry.def: Glanders.

cs.cd: the meridian passing through the equinoctial points.
the celestial equator; -- so called because when the sun is on it, the nights and days are of equal length in all parts of the world. See Equator.
cs.q: Thrice the equinoctial line He circled.
cs.cd: the two points where the celestial and ecliptic intersect each other; the one being in the first point of Aries, the other in the first point of Libra.
reckoned in any year from the instant when the mean sun is at the mean vernal equinoctial point.

entry.ety: L. aequinoctials, fr. aequinoctium equinox: cf. F. équinoxial. See Equinox

sn.def: Pertaining to an equinox, or the equinoxes, or to the time of equal day and night; as, the equinoctial line.
Pertaining to the regions or climate of the equinoctial line or equator; in or near that line; as, equinoctial heat; an equinoctial sun.
Pertaining to the time when the sun enters the equinoctial points; as, an equinoctial gale or storm, that is, one happening at or near the time of the equinox, in any part of the world.

entry.def: The equinoctial line.
Towards the equinox.

entry.ety: OE. equinoxium equenoxium, L. aequinoctium; aequus equal + nox noctis, night: cf. F. équinoxe. See Equal, and Night

sn.def: The time when the sun enters one of the equinoctial points, that is, about March 21 and September 22. See Autumnal equinox Vernal equinox, under Autumnal and Vernal.
sn.q: When descends on the Atlantic The gigantic Stormwind of the equinox.

sn.def: Equinoctial wind or storm.

entry.ety: Equi- + L. numerans, p. pr. of numerare to number
entry.def: Equal as to number.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equipped; p. pr. & vb. n. Equipping
entry.ety: F. équiper to supply, fit out, orig. said of a ship, OF. esquiper to embark; of German origin; cf. OHG. scif, G. schiff, Icel. skip, AS. scip. See Ship

sn.def: To furnish for service, or against a need or exigency; to fit out; to supply with whatever is necessary to efficient action in any way; to provide with arms or an armament, stores, munitions, rigging, etc.; -- said esp. of ships and of troops.
sn.q: Gave orders for equipping a considerable fleet.

sn.def: To dress up; to array; accouter.
sn.q: The country are led astray in following the town, and equipped in a ridiculous habit, when they fancy themselves in the height of the mode.

entry.ety: F. équipage, fr. équiper. See Equip

sn.def: Furniture or outfit, whether useful or ornamental; especially, the furniture and supplies of a vessel, fitting her for a voyage or for warlike purposes, or the furniture and necessaries of an army, a body of troops, or a single soldier, including whatever is necessary for efficient service; equipments; accouterments; habiliments; attire.
sn.q: Did their exercises on horseback with noble equipage.
First strip off all her equipage of Pride.

sn.def: Retinue; train; suite.
A carriage of state or of pleasure with all that accompanies it, as horses, liveried servants, etc., a showy turn-out.
sn.q: The rumbling equipages of fashion . . . were unknown in the settlement of New Amsterdam.

entry.def: Furnished with equipage.
entry.q: Well dressed, well bred. Well equipaged, is ticket good enough.

entry.def: Comparable.

entry.ety: L. aequiparatus, p. p. of aequiparare
entry.def: To compare.
Equal-footed; having the pairs of feet equal.
The act or condition of hanging in equipoise; not inclined or determined either way.

entry.ety: Equi- + pensatus, p. p. of pensare to weigh. Cf. Equipoise
entry.def: To weigh equally; to esteem alike.

sn.def: The act of equipping, or the state of being equipped, as for a voyage or expedition.
sn.q: The equipment of the fleet was hastened by De Witt.

sn.def: Whatever is used in equipping; necessaries for an expedition or voyage; the collective designation for the articles comprising an outfit; equipage; as, a railroad equipmentlocomotives, cars, etc. ; for carrying on business); horse equipments; infantry equipments; naval equipments; laboratory equipments.
sn.q: Armed and dight, In the equipments of a knight.

sn.def: Equality of weight or force; hence, equilibrium; a state in which the two ends or sides of a thing are balanced, and hence equal; state of being equally balanced; -- said of moral, political, or social interests or forces.
sn.q: The means of preserving the equipoise and the tranquillity of the commonwealth.
Our little lives are kept in equipoise By opposite attractions and desires.

sn.def: Counterpoise.
sn.q: The equipoise to the clergy being removed.

sn.def: Equality of power, force, signification, or application.
Sameness of signification of two or more propositions which differ in language.

entry.ety: L. aequipollens; aequus equal + pollens -entis, p. pr. of pollere to be strong, able: cf. F. équipollent

sn.def: Having equal power or force; equivalent.
Having equivalent signification and reach; expressing the same thing, but differently.

entry.def: With equal power.
Equality of weight; equipoise.
Being of the same weight.
entry.q: A column of air . . . equiponderant to a column of quicksilver.

entry.ety: Equi- + L. ponderare to weigh. See Ponderate
entry.def: To be equal in weight; to weigh as much as another thing.
To make equal in weight; to counterbalance.
entry.q: More thanequiponderatedthe declension in that direction.

entry.def: Having equal weight.

entry.ety: L. aequipondium an equal weight; aequus equal + pondus weight
entry.def: Of equal weight on both sides; balanced.

cs.cd: a surface for which the potential is for all points of the surface constant. Level surfaces on the earth are equipotential.

entry.def: Having the same potential.
Equally radical.
Having wheels of the same size or diameter; having equal rotation.
Belonging to the Equisetaceæ, or Horsetail family.
Having the form of the equisetum.

entries.entry: Eq`ui*se"tum Eq`ui*se"tum ☞ The Equiseta have hollow jointed stems and no true leaves. The cuticle often contains siliceous granules, so that one species (E. hyemale) is used for scouring and polishing, under the name of Dutch rush or scouring rush. n.; pl.Equiseta #. L., the horsetail, fr. equus horse + seta a thick,, stiff hair, bristle Bot A genus of vascular, cryptogamic, herbaceous plants; -- also called horsetails.

entry.ety: Equi- + L. sonans, p. pr. of sonare to sound: cf. F. équisonnance. See Sonant
entry.def: An equal sounding; the consonance of the unison and its octaves.
Of the same or like sound.

entry.ety: F. équitable, from équité. See Equity

sn.def: Possessing or exhibiting equity; according to natural right or natural justice; marked by a due consideration for what is fair, unbiased, or impartial; just; as, an equitable decision; an equitable distribution of an estate; equitable men.
sn.q: No two . . . had exactly the same notion of what was equitable.

sn.def: That can be sustained or made available or effective in a court of equity, or upon principles of equity jurisprudence; as, an equitable estate; equitable assets, assignment, mortgage, etc.
sn.syn: Just; fair; reasonable; right; honest; impartial; candid; upright.

entry.def: The quality of being equitable, just, or impartial; as, the equitableness of a judge, a decision, or distribution of property.
In an equitable manner; justly; as, the laws should be equitably administered.
Horsemanship.

entry.ety: L. equitans -antis, p. pr. of equitare to ride, fr. eques horseman, fr. equus horse

sn.def: Mounted on, or sitting upon, a horse; riding on horseback.
Overlapping each other; -- said of leaves whose bases are folded so as to overlap and bestride the leaves within or above them, as in the iris.

entry.ety: L. equitatio, fr. equitare: cf. F. équitation
entry.def: A riding, or the act of riding, on horseback; horsemanship.
entry.q: The pretender to equitation mounted.

entry.ety: L. aequus equal + tempus temporis, time
entry.def: Contemporaneous.

entry.ety: L., pl. of eques a horseman
entry.def: An order of knights holding a middle place between the senate and the commonalty; members of the Roman equestrian order.

entries.entry:
Eq"ui*ty ☞ Equitable jurisprudence in England and in the United States grew up from the inadequacy of common-law forms to secure justice in all cases; and this led to distinct courts by which equity was applied in the way of injunctions, bills of discovery, bills for specified performance, and other processes by which the merits of a case could be reached more summarily or more effectively than by common-law suits. By the recent English Judicature Act (1873), however, the English judges are bound to give effect, in common-law suits, to all equitable rights and remedies; and when the rules of equity and of common law, in any particular case, conflict, the rules of equity are to prevail. In many jurisdictions in the United States, equity and common law are thus blended; in others distinct equity tribunals are still maintained. See Chancery.
Equity of redemption Law the advantage, allowed to a mortgageor, of a certain or reasonable time to redeem lands mortgaged, after they have been forfeited at law by the nonpayment of the sum of money due on the mortgage at the appointed time. Blackstone.
n.; pl.Equities #. F. équité, L. aequitas, fr. aequus even, equal. See Equal
Equality of rights; natural justice or right; the giving, or desiring to give, to each man his due, according to reason, and the law of God to man; fairness in determination of conflicting claims; impartiality. Christianity secures both the private interests of men and the public peace, enforcing all justice and equity.
Law An equitable claim; an equity of redemption; as, an equity to a settlement, or wife's equity, etc.
I consider the wife's equity to be too well settled to be shaken.
Law A system of jurisprudence, supplemental to law, properly so called, and complemental of it.
Equity had been gradually shaping itself into a refined science which no human faculties could master without long and intense application. Right; justice; impartiality; rectitude; fairness; honesty; uprightness. See Justice.

sn.def: The condition of being equivalent or equal; equality of worth, value, signification, or force; as, an equivalence of definitions.
Equal power or force; equivalent amount.

sd.def: The quantity of the combining power of an atom, expressed in hydrogen units; the number of hydrogen atoms can combine with, or be exchanged for; valency. See Valence.
The degree of combining power as determined by relative weight. See Equivalent n., 2.

entry.def: To be equivalent or equal to; to counterbalance.
Same as Equivalence.

entry.ety: L. aequivalens -entis, p. pr. of aequivalere to have equal power; aequus equal + valere to be strong, be worth: cf. F. équivalent. See Equal, and Valiant

sn.def: Equal in worth or value, force, power, effect, import, and the like; alike in significance and value; of the same import or meaning.
sn.q: For now to serve and to minister, servile and ministerial, are terms equivalent.

sn.def: Equal in measure but not admitting of superposition; -- applied to magnitudes; as, a square may be equivalent to a triangle.
Contemporaneous in origin; as, the equivalent strata of different countries.

entry.note: ☞ This term was adopted by Wollaston to avoid using the conjectural expression atomic weight, with which, however, for a time it was practically synonymous. The attempt to limit the term to the meaning of a universally comparative combining weight failed, because of the possibility of several compounds of the substances by reason of the variation in combining power which most elements exhibit. The equivalent was really identical with, or a multiple of submultiple of, the atomic weight.

cs.cd: originally defined as the number of units of work which the unit of heat can perform, equivalent to the mechanical energy which must be expended to raise the temperature of a pound of water one degree Fahrenheit; later this value was defined as one British thermal unitB.t.u). Its value was found by Joule to be 772 foot pounds; later measurements give the value as 777.65 foot-pounds, equivalent to 107.5 kg-meters. This value was originally called Joule's equivalent, but the modern Joule is defined differently, being 107 ergs. The B.t.u. is now given as 1,054.35 absolute Joules, and therefore 1 calorie (the amount of heat needed to raise one gram of water one degree centigrade) is equivalent to 4.186 Joules.

entry.note: ☞ The original definition of the Mechanical equivalent of heat in the 1913 Webster was as below. The difference between foot pounds and kilogram-meters ("on the centigrade scale") is puzzling as it should be a factor of 7.23, and the figure given for kilogram-meters may be a mistaken misinterpretation of the report. -- PJC: The number of units of work which the unit of heat can perform; the mechanical energy which must be expended to raise the temperature of a unit weight of water from 0° C. to 1° C., or from 32° F. to 33° F. The term was introduced by Dr. Mayer of Heilbronn. Its value was found by Joule to be 1390 foot pounds upon the Centigrade, or 772 foot pounds upon the Fahrenheit, thermometric scale, whence it is often called Joule's equivalent, and represented by the symbol J. This is equal to 424 kilogram meters (Centigrade scale). A more recent determination by Professor Rowland gives the value 426.9 kilogram meters, for the latitude of Baltimore.

sn.def: Something equivalent; that which is equal in value, worth, weight, or force; as, to offer an equivalent for damage done.
sn.q: He owned that, if the Test Act were repealed, the Protestants were entitled to some equivalent. . . . During some weeks the word equivalent, then lately imported from France, was in the mouths of all the coffeehouse orators.

sn.def: That comparative quantity by weight of an element which possesses the same chemical value as other elements, as determined by actual experiment and reference to the same standard. Specifically: The comparative proportions by which one element replaces another in any particular compound; thus, as zinc replaces hydrogen in hydrochloric acid, their equivalents are 32.5 and 1. The combining proportion by weight of a substance, or the number expressing this proportion, in any particular compound; as, the equivalents of hydrogen and oxygen in water are respectively 1 and 8, and in hydric dioxide 1 and 16.
A combining unit, whether an atom, a radical, or a molecule; as, in acid salt two or more equivalents of acid unite with one or more equivalents of base.

entry.def: To make the equivalent to; to equal; equivalence.
In an equal manner.
To put an equal value upon; to put (something) on a par with another thing.
Having the valves equal in size and from, as in most bivalve shells.
Same as Equivalve or Equivalved.
Equivocalness.

cs.cd: a chord which can be resolved into several distinct keys; one whose intervals, being all minor thirds, do not clearly indicate its fundamental tone or root; the chord of the diminished triad, and the diminished seventh.

entry.usage: Equivocal Ambiguous. We call an expression ambiguous when it has one general meaning, and yet contains certain words which may be taken in two different senses; or certain clauses which can be so connected with other clauses as to divide the mind between different views of part of the meaning intended. We call an expression equivocal when, taken as a whole, it conveys a given thought with perfect clearness and propriety, and also another thought with equal propriety and clearness. Such were the responses often given by the Delphic oracle; as that to Crœsus when consulting about a war with Persia: “If you cross the Halys, you will destroy a great empire.” This he applied to the Persian empire, which lay beyond that river, and, having crossed, destroyed his own empire in the conflict. What is ambiguous is a mere blunder of language; what is equivocal is usually intended to deceive, though it may occur at times from mere inadvertence. Equivocation is applied only to cases where there is a design to deceive.
entry.ety: L. aequivocus: aequus equal + vox vocis, word. See Equal, and Voice, and cf. Equivoque

sn.def: Literally, called equally one thing or the other; hence:) Having two significations equally applicable; capable of double interpretation; of doubtful meaning; ambiguous; uncertain; as, equivocal words; an equivocal sentence.
sn.q: For the beauties of Shakespeare are not of so dim or equivocal a nature as to be visible only to learned eyes.

sn.def: Capable of being ascribed to different motives, or of signifying opposite feelings, purposes, or characters; deserving to be suspected; as, his actions are equivocal .
sn.q: Equivocalrepentances.

sn.def: Uncertain, as an indication or sign; doubtful.
sn.q: Howequivocala test.

entry.def: A word or expression capable of different meanings; an ambiguous term; an equivoque.
entry.q: In languages of great ductility, equivocals like that just referred to are rarely found.

entry.def: In an equivocal manner.
The state of being equivocal.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Equivocated; p. pr. & vb. n. Equivocating
entry.ety: L. aequivocatus, p. p. of aequivocari to be called by the same name, fr. L. aequivocus: cf. F. équivoquer. See Equivocal a.
entry.def: To use words of equivocal or doubtful signification; to express one's opinions in terms which admit of different senses, with intent to deceive; to use ambiguous expressions with a view to mislead; as, to equivocate is the work of duplicity.
entry.q: All that Garnet had to say for him was that he supposed he meant to equivocate.
entry.syn: To prevaricate; evade; shuffle; quibble. See Prevaricate.

entry.def: To render equivocal or ambiguous.
entry.q: He equivocated his vow by a mental reservation.

entry.def: The use of expressions susceptible of a double signification, with a purpose to mislead.
entry.q: There being no room for equivocations, there is no need of distinctions.
entry.syn: Prevarication; ambiguity; shuffling; evasion; guibbling. See Equivocal a., and Prevaricate v. i.

entry.def: One who equivocates.
entry.q: Here's an equivocator that could swear in both the scales against either scale, yet could not equivocate to heaven.

entry.def: Indicating, or characterized by, equivocation.

sn.def: An ambiguous term; a word susceptible of different significations.
An equivocation; a guibble.

entry.ety: L. equus horse + vorare to eat greedily
entry.def: Feeding on horseflesh; as, equivorous Tartars.
A genus of mammals, including the horse, ass, etc.
the chemical symbol for erbium, a rare earth element. It has atomic number 68 and an atomic weight of 167.26.

sn.def: The termination of many English words, denoting the agent; -- applied either to men or things; as in hater, farmer, heater, grater. At the end of names of places, -er signifies a man of the place; as, Londoneri. e., London man .

sn.ety: AS. -ra; akin to G. -er, Icel. -are -re, Goth. -iza -�za, L. -ior, Gr. �, Skr. -īyas
sn.def: A suffix used to form the comparative degree of adjectives and adverbs; as, warmer, sooner, lat(eer, earl(y)ier .

entries.entry:
E"ra n.; pl.Eras #. LL. aera an era, in earlier usage, the items of an account, counters, pl. of aes aeris, brass, money. See Ore
A fixed point of time, usually an epoch, from which a series of years is reckoned. The foundation of Solomon's temple is conjectured by Ideler to have been an era.
A period of time reckoned from some particular date or epoch; a succession of years dating from some important event; as, the era of Alexander; the era of Christ, or the Christian erasee under Christian).
The first century of our era.
A period of time in which a new order of things prevails; a signal stage of history; an epoch. Painting may truly be said to have opened the new era of culture. Epoch; time; date; period; age; dispensation. See Epoch.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eradiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Eradiating
entry.def: To shoot forth, as rays of light; to beam; to radiate.
Emission of radiance.
Capable of being eradicated.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eradicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Eradicating
entry.ety: L. eradicatus, p. p. of eradicare to eradicate; e out + radix radicis, root. See Radical

sn.def: To pluck up by the roots; to root up; as, an oak tree eradicated .
To root out; to destroy utterly; to extirpate; as, to eradicate diseases, or errors.
sn.q: This, although now an old an inveterate evil, might be eradicated by vigorous treatment.
sn.syn: To extirpate; root out; exterminate; destroy; annihilate.

sn.def: The act of plucking up by the roots; a rooting out; extirpation; utter destruction.
The state of being plucked up by the roots.

entry.def: Tending or serving to eradicate; curing or destroying thoroughly, as a disease or any evil.
A medicine that effects a radical cure.
a genus of annual or perennial grasses of tropics and subtropics.
A genus of plants of the buttercup family including the winter aconite Eranthis hyemalis.
Capable of being erased.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Erased �*rāst"; p. pr. & vb. n.. Erasing
entry.ety: L. erasus, p. p. of eradere to erase; e out + radere to scrape, scratch, shave. See Rase

sn.def: To rub or scrape out, as letters or characters written, engraved, or painted; to efface; to expunge; to cross out; as, to erase a word or a name.
Fig.: To obliterate; to expunge; to blot out; -- used of ideas in the mind or memory.
Rubbed or scraped out; effaced; obliterated.
Represented with jagged and uneven edges, as is torn off; -- used esp. of the head or limb of a beast. Cf. Couped.

entry.def: The act of erasing; a rubbing out; expunction; obliteration.
One who, or that which, erases; esp., a sharp instrument or a piece of rubber used to erase writings, drawings, etc.
The act of erasing; a rubbing out; obliteration.

One of the followers of Thomas Erastus, a German physician and theologian of the 16th century. He held that the punishment of all offenses should be referred to the civil power, and that holy communion was open to all. In the present day, an Erastian is one who would see the church placed entirely under the control of the State.
The principles of the Erastains.

sn.def: The act of erasing; a scratching out; obliteration.
the place where something has been erased.

entry.def: Pertaining to the Muse Erato who presided over amatory poetry.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � to love
entry.def: The Muse who presided over lyric and amatory poetry.

entry.ety: NL. from Ytterby, in Sweden, where gadolinite is found. Cf. Terbium Yttrium Ytterbium
entry.def: A rare earth element of the lanthanide series associated with several other rare elements in the mineral gadolinite from Ytterby in Sweden. Symbol Er. It has atomic number 68 and an atomic weight of 167.26. The pure element is metallic with a bright, silvery luster. It is relatively stable in air, not oxidizing as quickly as some other rare earths. Its salts are rose-colored and give characteristic spectra, and the pink oxide has been added as a colorant in glass and porcelain enamel glazes. Its sesquioxide Er2O3 is called erbia.

entry.ety: OE., fr. pref. erce- = archi- + deken a deacon
entry.def: An archdeacon.

cs.cd: the common European shrew (Sorex vulgaris); the shrewmouse.

entry.ety: OE. erd eard, earth, land, country, AS. eard; akin to OS. ard dwelling place, OHG. art plowing, tillage, Icel. örð crop, and to L. arare to plow, E. ear to plow
entry.def: The earth.

entry.cs:
Ere long before, shortly. Shak. Ere now formerly, heretofore. Shak.
Ere thatandOr are . Same as Ere. Shak.
entry.ety: AS. ǣr, prep., adv., & conj.; akin to OS., OFries., & OHG. ēr, G. eher, D. eer, Icel. ār, Goth. air. √204. Cf. Early Erst Or adv.

sn.def: Before; sooner than.
sn.q: Myself was stirring ere the break of day.
Ere sails were spread new oceans to explore.
Sir, come down ere my child die.

sn.def: Rather than.
sn.q: I will be thrown into Etna, . . . ere I will leave her.

entry.def: To plow. Obs See Ear v. t.

sn.def: A place of nether darkness, being the gloomy space through which the souls passed to Hades. See Milton's “Paradise Lost,” Book II., line 883.
The son of Chaos and brother of Nox, who dwelt in Erebus.
sn.q: To the infernal deep, with Erebus and tortures vile.

entry.ety: L. erectus, p. p. of erigere to erect; e out + regere to lead straight. See Right, and cf. Alert

sn.def: Upright, or having a vertical position; not inverted; not leaning or bent; not prone; as, to stand erect .
sn.q: Two of far nobler shape, erect and tall.
Among the Greek colonies and churches of Asia, Philadelphia is still erecta column of ruins.

sn.def: Directed upward; raised; uplifted.
sn.q: His piercing eyes, erect, appear to view Superior worlds, and look all nature through.

sn.def: Bold; confident; free from depression; undismayed.
sn.q: But who is he, by years Bowed, but erect in heart?

sn.def: Watchful; alert.
sn.q: Vigilant and erect attention of mind.

sn.def: Standing upright, with reference to the earth's surface, or to the surface to which it is attached.
Elevated, as the tips of wings, heads of serpents, etc.

cs.cd: a place where large machines, as engines, are put together and adjusted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Erected; p. pr. & vb. n. Erecting

sn.def: To raise and place in an upright or perpendicular position; to set upright; to raise; as, to erect a pole, a flagstaff, a monument, etc.
To raise, as a building; to build; to construct; as, to erect a house or a fort; to set up; to put together the component parts of, as of a machine.
To lift up; to elevate; to exalt; to magnify.
sn.q: That didst his state above his hopes erect.
I, who am a party, am not to erect myself into a judge.

sn.def: To animate; to encourage; to cheer.
sn.q: It raiseth the dropping spirit, erecting it to a loving complaisance.

sn.def: To set up as an assertion or consequence from premises, or the like.
sn.q: Toerectconclusions.
Malebrancheerectsthis proposition.

sn.def: To set up or establish; to found; to form; to institute.
sn.q: Toerecta new commonwealth.
sn.syn: To set up; raise; elevate; construct; build; institute; establish; found.

entry.def: To rise upright.
entry.q: By wet, stalks do erect.

entry.def: Capable of being erected; as, an erectable feather.
An erector; one who raises or builds.

cs.cd: a tissue, such as that contained in the penis, which is capable of being greatly dilated and made rigid by accumulation of blood in and the consequent distension of the numerous blood vessels which it contains.

sn.def: Capable of being erected; susceptible of being erected of dilated; as, erectile tissue.
Of or pertaining to an erection{5}; as, erectile dysfunction.

entry.def: The quality or state of being erectile.

sn.def: The act of erecting, or raising upright; the act of constructing, as a building or a wall, or of fitting together the parts of, as a machine; the act of founding or establishing, as a commonwealth or an office; also, the act of rousing to excitement or courage.
The state of being erected, lifted up, built, established, or founded; exaltation of feelings or purposes.
sn.q: Her peerless height my mind to high erection draws up.

sn.def: State of being stretched to stiffness; tension.
Anything erected; a building of any kind.

The state of a body part which, from having been soft, has become hard and swollen by the accumulation of blood in the erectile tissue; -- used especially of the penis; as, to get or have an erection .

entry.def: the act of building or putting up.
Making erect or upright; raising; tending to erect.
In an erect manner or posture.
Uprightness of posture or form.

sn.def: Having a position intermediate between erect and patent, or spreading.
Standing partially spread and erect; -- said of the wings of certain insects.
One who, or that which, erects.
A muscle which raises any part.
An attachment to a microscope, telescope, or other optical instrument, for making the image erect instead of inverted.

entry.def: Before the �apse of a long time; soon; -- usually separated, ere long.
entry.q: A man, . . . following the stag, erelong slew him.
The world, erelong, a world of tears must weep.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � quietly + � burning, fr. � to burn
entry.def: A gradual oxidation from exposure to air and moisture, as in the decay of old trees or of dead animals.
See Hermitage.
A hermit.
entry.q: Thou art my heaven, and I thy eremite.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an eremite; hermitical; living in solitude.
entry.q: Aneremiticallife in the woods.
Theeremiticinstinct.

entry.def: Eremitic.
The state of a hermit; a living in seclusion from social life.

entry.ety: L. erepere to creep out; e out + repere to creep
entry.def: A creeping forth.

entry.ety: L. ereptio, fr. eripere to snatch away; e out + rapere to snatch
entry.def: A snatching away.

entry.ety: Gr. � irritation, fr. � to stir, rouse, fr. � to stir: cf. F. éréthisme
entry.def: A morbid degree of excitement or irritation in an organ.
Relating to erethism.
Some time ago; a little while before; heretofore.
entry.q: I am as fair now as I was erewhile.

entry.def: the fictitious land described in the novel Erewhon by Samuel Butler.

entries.entry: Erf Erf n.; pl.Erven #. D A garden plot, usually about half an acre. Cape Colony

entry.def: The unit of work or energy in the C. G. S. system, being the amount of work done by a dyne working through a distance of one centimeter; the amount of energy expended in moving a body one centimeter against a force of one dyne (981 dynes exert the same force as a one gram mass in the earth's gravitational field). One foot pound is equal to 13,560,000 ergs. The absolute Joule is equivalent to 107 ergs, which are equivalent to 0.2389 gram-calories at 15° C. See also mechanical equivalent of heat under equivalent.
Potential energy; negative value of the force function.
To deduce logically, as conclusions.
An instrument for measuring energy in ergs.
Therefore; consequently; -- often used in a jocular way.
vitamin D2, one of the D vitamins, a group of related substances that prevent rickets.
An instrument for measuring and recording the work done by a single muscle or set of muscles, the rate of fatigue, etc.
A device for measuring, or an instrument for indicating, energy expended or work done; a dynamometer.
Work, measured in terms of the quantity of heat to which it is equivalent.
same as Erg.
biological science applied to study the relation between workers and their environments.
a plant sterol that is converted into vitamin D by ultraviolet radiation.

entry.ety: F. ergot argot, lit., a spur

sn.def: A diseased condition of rye and other cereals, in which the grains become black, and often spur-shaped. It is caused by a parasitic fungus, Claviceps purpurea.

The mycelium or spawn of this fungus infecting grains of rye and wheat. It is a powerful remedial agent, and also a dangerous poison, and is used as a means of hastening childbirth, and to arrest bleeding.
A stub, like soft horn, about the size of a chestnut, situated behind and below the pastern joint.
See 2d Calcar, 3 .

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, ergot; as, ergotic acid.
An extract made from ergot.

entries.entry: Er"go*tine. Chem A powerful astringent alkaloid extracted from ergot as a brown, amorphous, bitter substance. It is used to produce contraction of the uterus.

entry.def: A logical deduction.

entry.ety: From Ergot n.; cf. F. ergotisme
entry.def: A diseased condition produced by eating rye affected with the ergot fungus.
Affected with the ergot fungus; as, ergotized rye.
A recompense formerly given by a murderer to the relatives of the murdered person.
a genus of reedlike grasses having spikes crowded in a panicle covered with long silky hairs.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. erice heath, Gr. �
entry.def: A genus of shrubby plants, including the heaths, many of them producing beautiful flowers.
Belonging to the Heath family, or resembling plants of that family; consisting of heats.
an order including the Ericaceae; Clethraceae; Diapensiaceae; Epacridaceae; Lennoaceae; Pyrolaceae; and Monotropaceae.

entry.ety: NL. ericaceae the Heath family + L. oleum oil
entry.def: A colorless oil (quickly becoming brown), with a pleasant odor, obtained by the decomposition of ericolin.
The Vulgate rendering of the Hebrew word qipōd, which in the “Authorized Version” is translated bittern, and in the Revised Version, porcupine.
entry.q: I will make it [Babylon] a possession for the ericius and pools of waters.

entry.def: A glucoside found in the bearberry (and others of the Ericaceæ), and extracted as a bitter, yellow, amorphous mass.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �, the Greek name of the River Po
entry.def: A long, winding constellation extending southward from Taurus and containing the bright star Achernar.
a cosmopolitan genus of usually perennial herbs with asterlike flowers; the leaves were formerly used medicinally, but now are only occasionally so used.
Capable of being erected.
a genus including the bearded seal, Erignathus barbatus.
An early, and now a poetic, name of Ireland.
a natural family including the true hedgehogs.
Of the Hedgehog family; like, or characteristic of, a hedgehog.
the type genus of the family Erinaceidae, composed of hedgehogs.
The sea holly. See Eryngo.
A hydrous arseniate of copper, of an emerald-green color; -- so called from Erin, or Ireland, where it occurs.

entries.entry:
E*rin"ys n.; pl.Erinyes #. L., fr. Gr. � Class. Myth An avenging deity; one of the Furies; sometimes, conscience personified.
Erinnys

entry.def: An instrument for measuring the diameters of minute particles or fibers, from the size of the colored rings produced by the diffraction of the light in which the objects are viewed.
a genus of hairy herbs and shrubs of Western North America.
a genus of plant lice of the family Aphididae, consisting of one type of the wooly aphids.

entries.entry: E*ris"ta*lis‖n. NL Zoöl A genus of dipterous insects whose young (called rat-tailed larvæ) are remarkable for their long tapering tail, which spiracles at the tip, and for their ability to live in very impure and salt waters; -- also called drone fly.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � to strive, wrangle, � strife
entry.def: Controversial.
entry.q: A specimen of admirable special pleading in the court of eristic logic.

entry.def: a genus of songbirds, consisting of certain of the Old World thrushes.

sn.def: a province of N Ethiopia on the Red Sea.

entry.def: a native or inhabitant of Eritrea.

sn.def: of or pertaining to Eritrea; as, Eritrean civil war.
of or pertaining to the inhabitants of Eritrea; as, Eritrean story tellers.

entry.def: Slothful.

entry.ety: G. erlkönig, fr. Dan. ellekonge elfking
entry.def: A personification, in German and Scandinavian mythology, of a spirit or natural power supposed to work mischief and ruin, esp. to children.

entry.ety: OE. ermen, AS. yrman. Cf. Yearn
entry.def: To grieve; to feel sad.
See Ermine.
An Armenian.

entry.note: ☞ Ermine is represented by an argent field, tufted with black. Ermines is the reverse of ermine, being black, spotted or timbered with argent. Erminois is the same as ermine, except that or is substituted for argent.

cs.cd: a white moth with black spots (esp. Yponomeuta padella of Europe); -- so called on account of the resemblance of its covering to the fur of the ermine; also applied to certain white bombycid moths of America.

entry.ety: OF. ermine, F. hermine, prob. of German origin; cf. OHG. harmo, G. hermelin, akin to Lith. szarm� szarmonys, weasel, cf. AS. hearma; but cf. also LL. armelinus armellina hermellina, and pellis Armenia, the fur of the Armenian rat, mus Armenius, the animal being found also in Armenia

sn.def: A valuable fur-bearing animal of the genus Mustela (M. erminea), allied to the weasel; the stoat. It is found in the northern parts of Asia, Europe, and America. In summer it is brown, but in winter it becomes white, except the tip of the tail, which is always black.
The fur of the ermine, as prepared for ornamenting garments of royalty, etc., by having the tips of the tails, which are black, arranged at regular intervals throughout the white.
By metonymy, the office or functions of a judge, whose state robe, lined with ermine, is emblematical of purity and honor without stain.
One of the furs. See Fur Her

entry.def: To clothe with, or as with, ermine.
entry.q: The snows that have ermined it in the winter.

entry.def: Clothed or adorned with the fur of the ermine.
See Note under Ermine n., 4.
A hermit.

entry.ety: AS. earn eagle; akin to D. arend, OHG. aro, G. aar, Icel., Sw., & Dan. örn, Goth. ara, and to Gr. � bird. √11. Cf. Ornithology
entry.def: A sea eagle, esp. the European white-tailed sea eagle (Haliæetus albicilla).
To stir with strong emotion; to grieve; to mourn. Corrupted into yearn in modern editions of Shakespeare
See Earnest.
Serious.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eroded; p. pr. & vb. n. Eroding
entry.ety: L. erodere erosum; e out + rodere to gnaw. See Rodent

sn.def: To eat into or away; to corrode; as, canker erodes the flesh.
sn.q: The blood . . .erodesthe vessels.
The smaller charge is more apt to . . . erode the gun.

sd.def: To wear away; as, streams and glaciers erode the land.
To produce by erosion, or wearing away; as, glaciers erodeU-shaped valleys.

sn.def: to reduce or lessen as if by eroding; as, a politician's base of support is eroded by evidence of corruption; the buying power of the dollar is eroded by inflation.
Eaten away; gnawed; irregular, as if eaten or worn away.
Having the edge worn away so as to be jagged or irregularly toothed.

entry.ety: L. erodens -entis, p. pr. of erodere. See Erode
entry.def: A medicine which eats away extraneous growths; a caustic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Erogated; p. pr. & vb. n. Erogating
entry.ety: L. erogatus, p. p. of erogare; e out + rogare to ask
entry.def: To lay out, as money; to deal out; to expend.
The act of giving out or bestowing.

sn.def: causing sexual excitement when stimulated.
relating to or arousing sexual excitement.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. � love, � (personified) Eros, fr. � to love
entry.def: Love; the god of love; -- by earlier writers represented as one of the first and creative gods, by later writers as the son of Aphrodite, equivalent to the Latin god Cupid.

entry.ety: L. erosus, p. p. See Erode

sn.def: Irregular or uneven as if eaten or worn away.
Jagged or irregularly toothed, as if nibbled out or gnawed.
The act or operation of eroding or eating away.
The state of being eaten away; corrosion; canker.
The wearing away of the earth's surface by any natural process. The chief agent of erosion is running water; minor agents are glaciers, the wind, and waves breaking against the coast.
a gradual reduction or lessening as if by an erosive force; as, erosion of political support due to scandal; erosion of buying power by inflation.

entry.def: That erodes or gradually eats away; tending to erode; corrosive.
Without a beak.
A mark indicating a question; a note of interrogation.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a questioning, fr. � to ask
entry.def: A figure of speech by which a strong affirmation of the contrary, is implied under the form of an earnest interrogation, as in the following lines; -
entry.q: Must I give way and room to your rash choler? Shall I be frighted when a madman stares?

entry.ety: Gr. �: cf. F. érotique. See Eros
entry.def: Of or pertaining to the passion of love; treating of love; amatory.
An amorous composition or poem.
Erotic quality.
Herpetologist.
Herpetology.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Erred; p. pr. & vb. n. Erring ?; 277, 85
entry.ety: F. errer, L. errare; akin to G. irren, OHG. irran, v. t., irrōn, v. i., OS. irrien, Sw. irra, Dan. irre, Goth, aírzjan to lead astray, airzise astray

sn.def: To wander; to roam; to stray.
sn.q: Why wilt thouerrfrom me?
What seemeth to you, if there were to a man an hundred sheep and one of them hath erred.

sn.def: To deviate from the true course; to miss the thing aimed at.
sn.q: My jealous aim mighterr.

sn.def: To miss intellectual truth; to fall into error; to mistake in judgment or opinion; to be mistaken.
sn.q: The man may err in his judgment of circumstances.

sn.def: To deviate morally from the right way; to go astray, in a figurative sense; to do wrong; to sin.
sn.q: Do they not err that devise evil?

sn.def: To offend, as by erring.

entry.def: Liable to error; fallible.
Liability to error.
Erratic.
entry.q: Errabundguesses.

entry.def: A wandering; state of being in error.

cs.cd: To perform an errand{2}.

entry.ety: OE. erende erande, message, business, AS. ærende ærend; akin to OS. arundi, OHG. arunti, Icel. eyrendi örendi erendi, Sw. ärende, Dan. ærende; perh. akin to AS. earu swift, Icel. örr, and to L. oriri to rise, E. orient
entry.def: A special business intrusted to a messenger; something to be told or done by one sent somewhere for the purpose; often, a verbal message; a commission; as, the servant was sent on an errand; to do an errand . Also, one's purpose in going anywhere.
entry.q: I have a secret errand to thee, O king.
I will not eat till I have told mine errand.

sn.def: Any specific task, usually of a routine nature, requiring some form of travel, usually locally. An errand is often on behalf of someone else, but sometimes for one's own purposes.
A mission.

entry.ety: F. errant, p. pr. fr. OF. errer to travel, LL. iterare, fr. L. iter journey; confused somewhat with L. errare to err. See Eyre, and cf. Arrant Itinerant

sn.def: Wandering; deviating from an appointed course, or from a direct path; roving.
sn.q: Seven planets or errant stars in the lower orbs of heaven.

sn.def: Notorious; notoriously bad; downright; arrant.
sn.q: Would make me an errant fool.

sn.def: Journeying; itinerant; -- formerly applied to judges who went on circuit and to bailiffs at large.

entry.def: One who wanders about.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. errare to wander. See Err
entry.def: A group of chætopod annelids, including those that are not confined to tubes. See Chætopoda.

sn.def: A wandering; a roving; esp., a roving in quest of adventures.
The employment of a knight-errant.

entry.def: See Erratum.

cs.cd: masses of stone which have been transported from their original resting places by the agency of water, ice, or other causes.
the phenomena which relate to transported materials on the earth's surface.

entry.ety: L. erraticus, fr. errare to wander: cf. F. erratique. See Err

sn.def: Having no certain course; roving about without a fixed destination; wandering; moving; -- hence, applied to the planets as distinguished from the fixed stars.
sn.q: The earth and each erratic world.

sn.def: Deviating from a wise of the common course in opinion or conduct; eccentric; strange; queer; as, erratic conduct.
Irregular; changeable.
sn.q: Erraticfever.

entry.note: ☞ In the plural the term is applied especially to the loose gravel and stones on the earth's surface, including what is called drift.

sn.def: One who deviates from common and accepted opinions; one who is eccentric or preserve in his intellectual character.
A rogue.
Any stone or material that has been borne away from its original site by natural agencies; esp., a large block or fragment of rock; a bowlder.

entry.def: Erratic.
A wandering; a roving about.

entries.entry:
Er*ra"tum Er*ra"tum n.; pl.Errata #. L., fr. errare erratum, to wander, err. See Err
An error or mistake in writing or printing. A single erratum may knock out the brains of a whole passage.

entry.def: capable of making an error.

entry.ety: Gr. �; � in + �, �, nose: cf. F. errhin
entry.def: A medicine designed to be snuffed up the nose, to promote discharges of mucus; a sternutatory.

def2.def: Causing or increasing secretion of nasal mucus.

entry.ety: L. erroneus, fr. errare to err. See Err

sn.def: Wandering; straying; deviating from the right course; -- hence, irregular; unnatural.
sn.q: Erroneouscirculation.
Stopped much of the erroneous light, which otherwise would have disturbed the vision.

sn.def: Misleading; misled; mistaking.
sn.q: An erroneous conscience commands us to do what we ought to omit.

sn.def: Containing error; not conformed to truth or justice; incorrect; false; mistaken; as, an erroneous doctrine; erroneous opinion, observation, deduction, view, etc.

entry.def: inadvertent incorrectness.

entry.cs:
Law of errororLaw of frequency of error
Mensuration the law which expresses the relation between the magnitude of an error and the frequency with which that error will be committed in making a large number of careful measurements of a quantity. Probable error. Mensuration See under Probable. Writ of error Law an original writ, which lies after judgment in an action at law, in a court of record, to correct some alleged error in the proceedings, or in the judgment of the court. Bouvier. Burrill.
entry.ety: OF. error errur, F. erreur, L. error, fr. errare to err. See Err

sn.def: A wandering; a roving or irregular course.
sn.q: The rest of his journey, his error by sea.

sn.def: A wandering or deviation from the right course or standard; irregularity; mistake; inaccuracy; something made wrong or left wrong; as, an error in writing or in printing; a clerical error.
A departing or deviation from the truth; falsity; false notion; wrong opinion; mistake; misapprehension.
sn.q: His judgment was often in error, though his candor remained unimpaired.

sn.def: A moral offense; violation of duty; a sin or transgression; iniquity; fault.
The difference between the approximate result and the true result; -- used particularly in the rule of double position.

sd.def: The difference between an observed value and the true value of a quantity.
The difference between the observed value of a quantity and that which is taken or computed to be the true value; -- sometimes called residual error.

sn.def: A mistake in the proceedings of a court of record in matters of law or of fact.
A fault of a player of the side in the field which results in failure to put out a player on the other side, or gives him an unearned base.
sn.syn: Mistake; fault; blunder; failure; fallacy; delusion; hallucination; sin. See Blunder.

entry.def: Full of error; wrong.
One who encourages and propagates error; one who holds to error.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. ervum a kind of pulse, bitter vetch
entry.def: The bitter vetch (Ervum Ervilia).

entry.ety: A modification of Irish, OE. Irishe
entry.def: A name sometimes given to that dialect of the Celtic which is spoken in the Highlands of Scotland; -- called, by the Highlanders, Gaelic.
Of or pertaining to the Celtic race in the Highlands of Scotland, or to their language.
See Arrish.

cs.cd: at first; at the beginning.
at this present time.

entry.ety: Orig. superlative of ere; AS. ǣrest. See Ere

sn.def: First.
Previously; before; formerly; heretofore.
sn.q: Tityrus, with whose style he had erst disclaimed all ambition to match his pastoral pipe.

entry.def: Till then or now; heretofore; formerly.
The act of becoming red; redness of the skin or surface of anything; a blushing.

entry.ety: L. erubescens, p. pr. erubescere to grow red; e out + rubescere. See Rubescent
entry.def: Red, or reddish; blushing.
See Bornite.

entries.entry: E*ru"ca E*ru"ca n.; pl.Erucæ #. L., a caterpillar, also, a sort of colewort Zoöl An insect in the larval state; a caterpillar; a larva.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, a genus of cruciferous Mediterranean herbs (Eruca or Brassica); as, erucic acid, a fatty acid resembling oleic acid, and found in colza oil, mustard oil, etc.
Having the form of a caterpillar; -- said of insect larvæ.

entry.ety: L. eructare; e out + ructare to belch: cf. F. éructer
entry.def: To eject, as wind, from the stomach; to belch.

sn.def: The act of belching wind from the stomach; a belch.
A violent belching out or emitting, as of gaseous or other matter from the crater of a volcano, geyser, etc.

entry.def: To instruct; to educate; to teach.
entry.q: The skillful goddess there erudiates these In all she did.

entry.ety: L. eruditus, p. p. of erudire to free from rudeness, to polish, instruct; e out + rudis rude: cf. F. érudit. See Rude
entry.def: Characterized by extensive reading or knowledge; well instructed; learned.
entry.q: A mosteruditeprince.
Erudite. . . theology.

entry.def: profound knowledge.

The act of instructing; the result of thorough instruction; the state of being erudite or learned; the acquisitions gained by extensive reading or study; particularly, learning in literature or criticism, as distinct from the sciences; scholarship.
entry.q: The management of a young lady's person is not be overlooked, but the erudition of her mind is much more to be regarded.
The gay young gentleman whose erudition sat so easily upon him.

entry.ety: L. erugatus, p. p. of erugare to smooth; e out + ruga wrinkle
entry.def: Freed from wrinkles; smooth.
Partaking of the substance or nature of copper, or of the rust of copper; resembling the rust of copper or verdigris; æruginous.

entry.ety: L. erumpens -entis, p. pr. of erumpere
entry.def: Breaking out; -- said of certain fungi which burst through the texture of leaves.
To cause to burst forth; to eject; as, to erupt lava.

sn.def: To eject something, esp. lava, water, etc., as a volcano or geyser; as, when Mount Saint Helens erupted, some people were taken by surprise.
To burst forth; to break out, as ashes from a volcano, teeth through the gums, etc.; as, the third molar erupts late in most people, and in some persons does not occur at all.
sn.q: When the amount and power of the steam is equal to the demand, it erupts with violence through the lava flood and gives us a small volcano.

entry.def: currently undergoing eruption; -- of volcanoes.

entry.ety: L. eruptio, fr. erumpere eruptum, to break out; e out + rumpere, to break: cf. F. éruption. See Rupture
entry.sn:
The act of breaking out or bursting forth; as: A violent throwing out of flames, lava, etc., as from a volcano or a fissure in the earth's crust.
