entry.def: A colorless, gaseous hydrocarbon, C2H4, forming an important ingredient of illuminating gas, and also obtained by the action of concentrated sulphuric acid in alcohol. It is an unsaturated compound and combines directly with chlorine and bromine to form oily liquids (Dutch liquid), -- hence called olefiant gas. Called also ethene elayl, and formerly, bicarbureted hydrogen.

entries.entry: E*thyl"ic. Chem Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, ethyl; as, ethylic alcohol.

E*thyl"i*dene. Chem An unsymmetrical, divalent, hydrocarbon radical, C2H4 metameric with ethylene but written thus, CH3.CH= to distinguish it from the symmetrical ethylene, CH2=CH2. Its compounds are derived from aldehyde. Formerly called also ethidene.

entry.def: Any one of the several complex ethers of ethyl and glycerin.
A gaseous substance (C2H5.SH) used as an odorant in natural gas and propane to facilitate detection and serve as a warning of leaks.

cs.cd: an acid sulphate of ethyl, H.C2H5.SO4, produced as a thick liquid by the action of sulphiric acid on alcohol. It appears to be the active catalytic agent in the process of etherification.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or containing, ethyl and sulphuric acid.

entries.entry:
E"ti*o*late. v. i.
imp. & p. p. Etiolated #; p. pr. & vb. n. Etiolating
F. étioler to blanch
To become white or whiter; to be whitened or blanched by excluding the light of the sun, as, plants.
Med To become pale through disease or absence of light.

sn.def: To blanch; to bleach; to whiten by depriving of the sun's rays.
To cause to grow pale by disease or absence of light.

entry.def: Having a blanched or faded appearance, as birds inhabiting desert regions.

sn.def: The operation of blanching plants, by excluding the light of the sun; the condition of a blanched plant.
Paleness produced by absence of light, or by disease.

entry.def: A yellowish coloring matter found in plants grown in darkness, which is supposed to be an antecedent condition of chlorophyll.
Pertaining to, or inquiring into, causes; ætiological.
The science of causes. Same as �tiology.

entry.ety: F. prop., a little piece of paper, or a mark or title, affixed to a bag or bundle, expressing its contents, a label, ticket, OF.estiquete, of German origin; cf. LG. stikke peg, pin, tack, stikken to stick, G. stecken. See Stick, and cf. Ticket
entry.def: The forms required by good breeding, or prescribed by authority, to be observed in social or official life; observance of the proprieties of rank and occasion; conventional decorum; ceremonial code of polite society.
entry.q: The pompous etiquette to the court of Louis the Fourteenth.

entry.def: A kind of small, portable, cooking apparatus for which heat is furnished by a spirit lamp.
entry.q: There should certainly be an etna for getting a hot cup of coffee in a hurry.

entry.ety: L. Aetnaeus, Gr. �, fr.� (L. Aetna Aetne)
entry.def: Pertaining to Etna, a volcanic mountain in Sicily.
See Estoile.
Of or relating to ancient Etruria, in Italy.
entry.q: EtrurianShades.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of ancient Etruria.

entry.def: Of or relating to Etruria.

def2.def: A native or inhabitant of Etruria.

entry.def: The stingfish, or lesser weever (Tranchinus vipera).

entry.ety: SA. eten eoten, orig., gluttonous, fr. etan to eat
entry.def: A giant.

entry.ety: Perh. the same word as addle to earn; bur cf. OE. atlien etlien, to intend, prepare, Icel. ætla to think, suppose, mean
entry.def: To earn. Obs See Addle, to earn.

sn.def: A composition in the fine arts which is intended, or may serve, for a study.
A study; an exercise; a piece for practice of some special point of technical execution.

entry.def: A case for one or several small articles; esp., a box in which scissors, tweezers, and other articles of toilet or of daily use are carried.
See Étui.
See Etymon.
Relating to the etymon; as, an etymic word.
An etymologist.

entry.ety: L. etymologicus, Gr. 'etymologiko`s: cf. F. étymologique. See Etymology
entry.def: Pertaining to etymology, or the derivation of words.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. 'etymologiko`n, prop. neut. sing. from 'etymologiko`s
entry.def: An etymological dictionary or manual.
One who investigates the derivation of words.
To give the etymology of; to trace to the root or primitive, as a word.
To search into the origin of words; to deduce words from their simple roots.
entry.q: How perilous it is to etymologize at random.

entries.entry:
Et`y*mol"o*gy -j� n.; pl.Etymologies -jĭz. L.etymologia, Gr. 'etymologi`a; 'e`tymon etymon + lo`gos discourse, description: cf. F. étymologie. See Etymon, and -logy
That branch of philological science which treats of the history of words, tracing out their origin, primitive significance, and changes of form and meaning.
That part of grammar which relates to the changes in the form of the words in a language; inflection.

Et"y*mon n.; pl. E. Etymons #, Gr. Etyma #. L., fr. Gr. 'e`tymon the true literal sense of a word according to its derivation, an etymon, fr. � true, real, prob, akin to Skr. sotya, E. sooth. See Sooth
An original form; primitive word; root.
Original or fundamental signification. R Given as the etymon or genuine sense of the word.

entry.def: Diverging from, or lacking conformity to, a type.
the chemical symbol for Europium, an element with atomic number 63 and atomic weight 151.96.

entries.entry:
Eu Eu. Gr. e'y^ well, orig. neut. of e'y`s good; prob. connected with Skr. su, from the same root as E. is; or with Skr. vasu good, prob. fr. the same root as E. was
A prefix used frequently in composition, signifying well good advantageous; -- the opposite of dys-.

entry.def: one of two usually recognized orders of true bacteria; gram-positive spherical or rod-shaped forms; some are motile; in some classifications it is considered an order of Schizomycetes.
an order of mosses with perennial erect gametophores and stems with rows of leaves and drooping capsules.

entry.ety: Gr. � seasonable, opportune; e'y^ well, good + � season
entry.def: A metallic mineral, a selenide of copper and silver; -- so called by Berzelius on account of its being found soon after the discovery of the metal selenium.
An unfermentable sugar, obtained as an uncrystallizable sirup by the decomposition of melitose; also obtained from a Tasmanian eucalyptus, -- whence its name.
a tree of the genus Eucalyptus.

entry.note: In the 1913 Webster eucalytpol was defined as an oil “consisting largely of cymene”. Cymene (isopropyltoluene, C10H14) differs from that of the substance currently called eucalyptol, in having an unsaturated ring and no oxygen. Para-cymene does occur in eucalyptus oil as well as some other essential oils.
entry.def: A volatile, terpenelike oil (C10H18O), which is the main constituent of the oil of eucalyptus. It has cockroach repellent activity and is used as a flavoring aid in pharmaceuticals. Chemically it is 1,3,3-trimethyl-2-oxabicyclo-[2,2,2]-octane.

entry.note: ☞ They have rigid, entire leaves with one edge turned toward the zenith. Most of them secrete resinous gums, whence they called gum trees, and their timber is of great value. Eucalyptus Globulus is the blue gum; E. gigantea, the stringy bark: E. amygdalina, the peppermint tree. E. Gunnii, the Tasmanian cider tree, yields a refreshing drink from wounds made in the bark in the spring. Other species yield oils, tars, acids, dyes and tans. It is said that miasmatic valleys in Algeria and Portugal, and a part of the unhealthy Roman Campagna, have been made more salubrious by planting groves of these trees.
entry.ety: NL., from Gr. e'y^ well, good + � covered. The buds of Eucalyptus have a hemispherical or conical covering, which falls off at anthesis
entry.def: A myrtaceous genus of trees, mostly Australian. Many of them grow to an immense height, one or two species exceeding the height even of the California Sequoia.

sn.def: quandong trees.

entry.def: an organism with "good" or membrane-bound nuclei having multiple chromosomes; eucaryotes also have other membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria or chloroplasts, within the cytoplasm enclosed by the outer membrane. Such cells are characteristic of all life forms except primitive microorganisms such as bacteria and blue-green algae. Contrasted with prokaryote.
of or pertaining to eukaryotes; same as eukaryotic. Contrasted with prokaryotic.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. eucharis agreeable, Gr. e'y`charis See Eucharist
entry.def: A genus of South American amaryllidaceous plants with large and beautiful white blossoms.

entry.ety: L. eucharistia, Gr. e'ycharisti`a, lit., a giving of thanks; e'y^ + cha`ris favor, grace, thanks; akin to chai`rein to rejoice, and prob. to yearn: cf. F. eucharistie

sn.def: The act of giving thanks; thanksgiving.
sn.q: Led through the vale of tears to the region of eucharist and hallelujahs.

entry.sn: Eccl The sacrament of the Lord's Supper; the solemn act of ceremony of commemorating the death of Christ, in the use of bread and wine, as the appointed emblems; the communion.See Sacrament.

sn.def: Giving thanks; expressing thankfulness; rejoicing.
sn.q: The eucharistical part of our daily devotions.

sn.def: Pertaining to the Lord's Supper.
sn.q: Theeucharisticsacrament.

entry.def: One who resolves religion into prayer.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y`chlwro`s fresh and green; e'y^ well + chlwro`s pale green
entry.def: Relating to, or consisting of, euchlorine; as, euchloric gas.
A yellow or greenish yellow gas, first prepared by Davy, evolved from potassium chlorate and hydrochloric acid. It is supposed to consist of chlorine tetroxide with some free chlorine.

entry.ety: NL. euchologion, Gr. � prayer book; � prayer, vow (fr. � to pray) + � to say, speak
entry.def: A formulary of prayers; the book of offices in the Greek Church, containing the liturgy, sacraments, and forms of prayers.
Euchology.

A game at cards, that may be played by two, three, or four persons, the highest card (except when an extra card called the Joker is used) being the knave of the same suit as the trump, and called right bower, the lowest card used being the seven, or frequently, in two-handed euchre, the nine spot. See Bower.

sn.def: To defeat, in a game of euchre, the side that named the trump.
To defeat or foil thoroughly in any scheme.

cs.cd: an organic, imide acid, obtained as a colorless crystalline substance, C12H4N2O8 by heating an ammonium salt of mellitic acid. By reduction it is changed to a dark blue substance (euchrone), -- hence its name.

entry.def: Having a fine color.
A mineral occurring in transparent emerald green crystals. It is hydrous arseniate of copper.
A substance obtained from euchroic acid. See Eychroic.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y^ well + � juice liquid. See Chyme
entry.def: A good state of the blood and other fluids of the body.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y^ well, easily + � to break. Cf. F. euclase, G. euklas. See named from its brittleness
entry.def: A brittle gem occurring in light green, transparent crystals, affording a brilliant clinodiagonal cleavage. It is a silicate of alumina and glucina.
A Greek geometer of the 3d century b. c.; also, his treatise on geometry, and hence, the principles of geometry, in general.

cs.cd: the kind of space to which the axioms and definitions of Euclid, relative to straight lines and parallel lines, apply; -- called also flat space, and homaloidal space.

entry.def: Related to Euclid, or to the geometry of Euclid.
A group which includes the typical copepods and the lerneans.

entries.entry:
Eu"cra*sy. Gr. �; �, well-tempered; e'y^ well + � to mix, temper: cf. F. eucrasie
Med Such a due mixture of qualities in bodies as constitutes health or soundness.

entry.def: Expecting a wish; supplicatory.
entry.q: Sacrifices . . . distinguished into expiatory, euctical, and eucharistical.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y^ well, good + � one's demon
entry.def: A good angel.

entry.ety: Gr. � conducive to happiness. See Eudemonism
entry.def: That part of moral philosophy which treats of happiness; the science of happiness; -- contrasted with aretaics.

entry.ety: Gr. � a thinking happy, fr, � blessed with a good genius, happy; e'y^ well, good + � one's demon of genius. See Demon
entry.def: That system of ethics which defines and enforces moral obligation by its relation to happiness or personal well-being.
One who believes in eudemonism.
entry.q: I am too much of a eudæmonist; I hanker too much after a state of happiness both for myself and others.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to eudemonism.
Eudemonistic.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y^ well, easily + � to dissolve. So called because easily dissolvable in acids
entry.def: A mineral of a brownish red color and vitreous luster, consisting chiefly of the silicates of iron, zirconia, and lime.

entry.note: ☞ It usually consists of a finely graduated and calibrated glass tube, open at one end, the bottom; and having near the top a pair of platinum wires fused in, to allow the passage of an electric spark, as the process involves the explosion and combustion of one of the ingredients to be determined. The operation is conducted in a trough of mercury, or sometimes over water. Cf. Burette. Ure's eudiometer has the tube bent in the form of the letter. U.
entry.ety: Gr. � fair, clear weather, fr. � fine, clear ( said of the air or weather) + -meter: cf. F. ediomètre
entry.def: An instrument for the volumetric measurement of gases; -- so named because frequently used to determine the purity of the air.
Of or pertaining to a eudiometer; as, eudiometrical experiments or results.
The art or process of determining the constituents of a gaseous mixture by means of the eudiometer, or for ascertaining the purity of the air or the amount of oxygen in it.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. e'y^ well + � double + � rib,�, pl.,side
entry.def: The fundamental forms of organic life, that are composed of two equal and symmetrical halves.
A follower of Eudoxius, patriarch of Antioch and Constantinople in the 4th century, and a celebrated defender of the doctrines of Arius.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. e'y^ well + NL. ganoidei. See Ganoid
entry.def: A group which includes the bony ganoids, as the gar pikes.
Applause.
The quality or condition of having strong reproductive powers; generation with full fertility between different species or races, specif. between hybrids of the first generation.

entry.ety: NL. Named in honor of Prince Eugene of Savoy
entry.def: A genus of myrtaceous plants, mostly of tropical countries, and including several aromatic trees and shrubs, among which are the trees which produce allspice and cloves of commerce.
Pertaining to, or derived from, cloves; as, eugenic acid.
Well-born; of high birth.
The science of improving stock, whether human or animal.
A colorless, crystalline substance extracted from oil of cloves; -- called also clove camphor.
A colorless, aromatic, liquid hydrocarbon, C10H12O2 resembling the phenols, and hence also called eugenic acid. It is found in the oils of pimento and cloves.

entries.entry: Eu"ge*ny. Gr. �, fr. e'ygenh`s well born; e'y^ well + � race Nobleness of birth. Obs

entry.def: Pertaining to, or derived from, eugenol; as, eugetic acid.
The yew.
Of or pertaining to the ancient town of Eugubium (now Gubbio); as, the Eugubine tablets, or tables, or inscriptions.
Producing mathematically perfect harmony or concord; sweetly or perfectly harmonious.

entry.ety: L. Euhemerus, Gr. � a philosopher, about 300 �
entry.def: The theory, held by Euhemerus, that the gods of mythology were but deified mortals, and their deeds only the amplification in imagination of human acts.
One who advocates euhemerism.
Of or pertaining to euhemerism.
To interpret (mythology) on the theory of euhemerism.

entries.entry:
Eu`i*sop"o*da Eu`i*sop"o*da. pl. NL. See Eu- and Isopoda
Zoöl A group which includes the typical Isopoda.

entry.def: an organism with "good" or membrane-bound nuclei having multiple chromosomes; eucaryotes also have other membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria or chloroplasts, within the cytoplasm enclosed by the outer membrane. Such cells are characteristic of all life forms except primitive microorganisms such as bacteria and blue-green algae. Contrasted with prokaryote.
having cells with visible nuclei surrounded by a nuclear membrane; pertaining to eukaryotes. Contrasted with prokaryotic.
The candlefish. oulachan oolacan ulikon See Candlefish.

cs.cd: certain definite integrals whose properties were first investigated by Euler.

entry.def: Pertaining to Euler, a German mathematician of the 18th century.
Bestowing praise of eulogy; commendatory; eulogistic.
One who eulogizes or praises; panegyrist; encomiast.
Of or pertaining to eulogy; characterized by eulogy; bestowing praise; panegyrical; commendatory; laudatory; as, eulogistic speech or discourse.

entries.entry: Eu*lo"gi*um n.; pl.Eulogiums #. LL., fr. Gr. � eulogy A formal eulogy.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eulogized. (�); p. pr. & vb. n. Eulogizing
entry.def: To speak or write in commendation of (another); to extol in speech or writing; to praise.

entries.entry:
Eu"lo*gy
Eulogy Eulogium Encomium Panegyric. The idea of praise is common to all these words. The word encomium is used of both persons and things which are the result of human action, and denotes warm praise. Eulogium and eulogy apply only to persons and are more studied and of greater length. A panegyric was originally a set speech in a full assembly of the people, and hence denotes a more formal eulogy, couched in terms of warm and continuous praise, especially as to personal character. We may bestow encomiums on any work of art, on production of genius, without reference to the performer; we bestow eulogies, or pronounce a eulogium, upon some individual distinguished for his merit public services; we pronounce a panegyric before an assembly gathered for the occasion. n.; pl.Eulogies #. Gr. �, from � well speaking; e'y^ well + � to speak. Cf. Eulogium, and see Legend
A speech or writing in commendation of the character or services of a person; as, a fitting eulogy to worth.
Eulogies turn into elegies. Encomium; praise; panegyric; applause.

entry.def: A mineral, consisting chiefly of the silicate of bismuth, found at Freiberg; -- called also culytine.

entry.ety: L., from Gr. � lit., gracious goddesses
entry.def: A euphemistic name for the Furies of Erinyes.
A genus of small beetles, one species of which (E. viti) is very injurious to the vines in the wine countries of Europe.
one of the genera of mastiff bats, of the family Molossidae.
a class used in some classifications, which is coextensive with the division Eumycota.

a division consisting of the true fungi, eukaryotic heterotrophic walled organisms distinguished from the Myxomycotafunguslike slime molds). It comprises subdivisions Mastigomycotina; Zygomycotina; Ascomycotina; Basidiomycotina; Deuteromycotina (imperfect fungi).
a genus of boas consisting of anacondas, large South American snakes that may grow to 25 feet.
A follower of Eunomius, bishop of Cyzicus (4th century A. D.), who held that Christ was not God but a created being, having a nature different from that of the Father.

def2.def: Of or pertaining to Eunomius or his doctrine.

entry.def: Equal law, or a well-adjusted constitution of government.

entry.ety: L. eunuchus, Gr. �, prop., keeping or guarding the couch; � couch, bed, + � to have, hold, keep
entry.def: A male of the human species castrated; commonly, one of a class of such persons, in Oriental countries, having charge of the women's apartments. Some of them, in former times, gained high official rank.
To make a eunuch of; to castrate. as a man.

entry.ety: L. eunuchismus an unmanning, Gr. �: cf. F. eunuchisme eunuchism
entry.def: The state of being eunuch.
A principle or mixture of principles derived from Euonymus atropurpureus, or spindle tree.

entry.ety: NL. (cf. L. euonymos). fr. Gr. �, lit., of good name
entry.def: A genus of small European and American trees; the spindle tree. The bark is used as a cathartic.

entry.ety: NL., fr., Gr. e'y^ well + �, � a bird
entry.def: The division of Aves which includes all the typical birds, or all living birds except the penguins and birds of ostrichlike form.
A fossil resin, so called from its strong, peculiar, pleasant odor.

entry.ety: Gr. � comfort, happy condition of the soul. See Eu-, and Pathetic
entry.def: Right feeling.
A principle or mixture of principles extracted from various species of Eupatorium.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Eupator, king of Pontus, said to have used it as a medicine
entry.def: A genus of perennial, composite herbs including hemp agrimony, boneset, throughwort, etc.
One well born, or of noble birth.

entry.ety: NL. eupepsia, Fr. Gr. �, fr. � easy of digestion; e'y^ well + � to cook, digest
entry.def: Soundness of the nutritive or digestive organs; good concoction or digestion; -- opposed to dyspepsia.
Of or pertaining to good digestion; easy of digestion; having a good digestion; as, eupeptic food; an eupeptic man.
entry.q: Wrapt in lazy eupeptic fat.

entry.def: an order of small, commonly luminescent crustaceans: krill.

entry.ety: Gr. � fr. � to use word of a good omen; e'y^ well + � to speak: cf. F. euphémisme. See Fame
entry.def: A figure in which a harsh or indelicate word or expression is softened; a way of describing an offensive thing by an inoffensive expression; a mild name for something disagreeable.
Pertaining to euphemism; containing a euphemism; softened in expression.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Euphemized; p. pr. & vb. n. Euphemizing
entry.def: To express by a euphemism, or in delicate language; to make use of euphemistic expressions.
An instrument in which are combined the characteristic tones of the organ and various other instruments.
Pertaining to, or exhibiting, euphony; agreeable in sound; pleasing to the ear; euphonious; as, a euphonic expression; euphonical orthography.
A kind of upright piano.
Pleasing or sweet in sound; euphonic; smooth-sounding.
An agreeable combination of sounds; euphony.
A bass instrument of the saxhorn family.
To make euphonic.
An instrument resembling the organ in tone and the upright piano in form. It is characterized by great strength and sweetness of tone.
Euphonious.

entries.entry:
Eu"pho*ny n.; pl.Euphonies #. L. euphonia, Gr. �, fr. � sweet-voiced; e'y^ well + � sound, voice; akin to � to speak: cf. F. euphonie
A pleasing or sweet sound; an easy, smooth enunciation of sounds; a pronunciation of letters and syllables which is pleasing to the ear.

Eu*phor"bi*a‖n. NL., fr. L. euphorbea. See Euphorrium
Bot Spurge, or bastard spurge, a genus of plants of many species, mostly shrubby, herbaceous succulents, affording an acrid, milky juice. Some of them are armed with thorns. Most of them yield powerful emetic and cathartic products.

entry.def: Of, relating to, or resembling, the Euphorbia family.
A principle, or mixture of principles, derived from various species of Euphorbia.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. euphorbeum, from Gr. �; -- so called after Euphorbus, a Greek physician
entry.def: An inodorous exudation, usually in the form of yellow tears, produced chiefly by the African Euphorbia resinifera. It was formerly employed medicinally, but was found so violent in its effects that its use is nearly abandoned.

a strong pleasant feeling of well-being or happiness; it is often caused by attainment of a desired goal or other incident of accomplishment, but may irrationally accompany a pathological manic state.
inducing euporia.
a substance which may induce euporia.

entries.entry: euphoric adj. strongly experiencing a feeling of well-being; feeling euphoria. Opposite of dysphoric.Narrower terms: expansive elated, happy.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y^ well + �, �, light. So called because of its pleasing combination of white and green

entry.ety: NL. euphrasia, fr. Gr. e'yfrasi`a delight, fr. e'yfrai`nein to delight; e'y^ well + frh`n heart, mind: cf. LL. eufrasia, F. eufraise
entry.def: The plant eyebright Euphrasia officionalis), formerly regarded as beneficial in disorders of the eyes.
entry.q: Then purged with euphrasy and rue The visual nerve, for he had much to see.

entry.ety: Gr. e'yfyh`s well grown, graceful; e'y^ well + fyh` growth, fr. fy`ein to grow. entry.def: Of European and Asiatic descent; of or pertaining to both Europe and Asia; as, the great Eurasian plain.

entries.entry: Eu*re"ka Eu*re"ka. Gr. � I have found, perfect indicative of � to find The exclamation attributed to Archimedes, who is said to have cried out “Eureka! eureka!” (I have found it! I have found it!), upon suddenly discovering a method of finding out how much the gold of King Hiero's crown had been alloyed. Hence, an expression of triumph concerning a discovery.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y^ well + � a fan + � a tail
entry.def: Having a fanlike tail; belonging to the Eurhipiduræ, a division of Aves which includes all living birds.
To whirl hither and thither.

entry.ety: L., fr. Gr. �; e'y^ well + � a rushing motion
entry.def: A strait; a narrow tract of water, where the tide, or a current, flows and reflows with violence, as the ancient frith of this name between Eubœa and Bœotia. Hence, a flux and reflux.
A compact feldspathic rock; felsite. See Felsite.
Of or relating to eurite.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; � the southeast wind + � wave, billow; according to another reading, �, i. e. a north-east wind, as in the Latin Vulgate Euro-aquilo
entry.def: A tempestuous northeast wind which blows in the Mediterranean. See Levanter.
entry.q: A tempestuous wind called Euroclydon.

cs.cd: having rooms to let, and leaving it optional with guests whether they will take meals in the house; -- said of hotels.

entry.ety: L. europeaus, Gr. �, fr. Gr. � (L. europa.)
entry.def: Of or pertaining to Europe, or to its inhabitants.
A native or an inhabitant of Europe.
the process of becoming like the Europeans in manners or character; assimilation into European culture.
To cause to become like the Europeans in manners or character; to habituate or accustom to European usages.
entry.q: A state of society . . . changed and Europeanized.

entry.def: A metallic element of the rare-earth group (Lanthanide series), discovered spectroscopically by Demarcay in 1896. Symbol, Eu; atomic number 63; at. wt., 151.965 (C=12.011); valence = +2 or +3.
an order of fungi having a closed ascocarp (cleistothecium) with the asci scattered rather than gathered into a hymenial layer.
The east wind.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Euryale, one of the Gorgons

sn.def: A genus of water lilies, growing in India and China. The only species (Euryale ferox) is very prickly on the peduncles and calyx. The rootstocks and seeds are used as food.
A genus of ophiurans with much-branched arms.

entry.def: A tribe of Ophiuroidea, including the genera Euryale Astrophyton, etc. They generally have the arms branched. See Astrophyton.
Having broad horns.
Like, or pertaining to, the genus Euryperus.
An extinct order of Merostomata, of which the genus Eurypterus is the type. They are found only in Paleozoic rocks.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � broad + � a wing
entry.def: A genus of extinct Merostomata, found in Silurian rocks. Some of the species are more than three feet long.

entry.ety: L. eurythmia, Gr. �; e'y^ well + � rhythm, measure, proportion, symmetry: cf. F. eurythmie

sn.def: Just or harmonious proportion or movement, as in the composition of a poem, an edifice, a painting, or a statue.
Regularly of the pulse.

entry.def: A follower of Eusebius, bishop of Cæsarea, who was a friend and protector of Arius.

cs.cd: a tubular instrument to be introduced into the Eustachian tube so as to allow of inflation of the middle ear through the nose or mouth.
a passage from the tympanum of the ear to the pharynx. See Ear.

a crescent-shaped fold of the lining membrane of the heart at the entrance of the vena cava inferior. It directs the blood towards the left auricle in the fetus, but is rudimentary and functionless in the adult.

entry.ety: From Eustachi, a learned Italian physician who died in Rome, 1574
entry.def: Discovered by Eustachius.
Pertaining to the Eustachian tube; as, Eustachian catheter.

entry.ety: Gr. �, neut. of � with pillars at the best distances; e'y^ well + � pillar: cf. F. eustyle
entry.def: See Intercolumnlation.

entry.ety: Gr. �; e'y^ well + � arrangement: cf. F. eutaxie
entry.def: Good or established order or arrangement.

entry.ety: Gr. e'y`thktos easily melted; e'y^ well + th`kein to melt
entry.def: Of maximum fusibility; -- said of an alloy or mixture which has the lowest melting point which it is possible to obtain by the combination of the given components.
a mixture of substances having a composition providing the minimum melting point ofr mixtures of those substances. Called also a eutectic mixture.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � a being easily melted
entry.def: The principle or process of forming from given components the eutectic alloy, or alloy of maximum fusibility.

entries.entry:
Eu*ter"pe. L., fr. Gr. �, fr. � delightful; e'y^ well + � to delight
Class. Myth The Muse who presided over music.
Bot A genus of palms, some species of which are elegant trees.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to Euterpe or to music.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; e'y^ well + � death, �, �, to die: cf. F. euthanasie

sn.def: An easy death; a mode of dying to be desired.
sn.q: Aneuthanasiaof all thought.
The kindest wish of my friends is euthanasia.

sn.def: the act or process of putting to death for humane purposes; -- used to refer to the killing of animals in order to relieve or avoid pain.

entry.def: Same as Euthanasia.

cs.cd: a complex derivative of hydroquinone and sulphonic (thionic) acid. -- so called because it contains sulphur, and forms brilliantly colored (yellow) salts.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or denoting, an acid so called.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � straight + � a nerve
entry.def: A large division of gastropod molluske, including the Pulmonifera and Opisthobranchiata.

entry.ety: Gr. �, fr. � nourishing, healthy; e'y^ well + � to nourish
entry.def: Healthy nutrition; soundless as regards the nutritive functions.
A follower of Eutyches [5th century], who held that the divine and the human in the person of Christ were blended together as to constitute but one nature; a monophysite; -- opposed to Nestorian.
The doctrine of Eutyches and his followers.

cs.cd: a yellow, crystalline, organic acid, extracted from euxanthin.

entry.def: Having a yellow color; pertaining to, derived from, or resembling, euxanthin.

A yellow pigment imported from India and China. It has a strong odor, and is said to be obtained from the urine of herbivorous animals when fed on the mango. It consists if a magnesium salt of euxanthic acid. Called also puri purree, and Indian yellow.

entry.ety: Gr. � hospitable. So named because it contains a number of rare elements
entry.def: A brownish black mineral with a metallic luster, found in Norway. It contains niobium, titanium, yttrium, and uranium, with some other metals.
To empty.

entry.ety: L.evacuans -antis, p. pr. of evacuare: cf. F. évacuant
entry.def: Emptying; evacuative; purgative; cathartic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evacuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Evacuating
entry.ety: l. evacuatus, p. p. of evacuare to empty, nullify; e out + vacuus empty, vacare to be empty. See Vacate

sn.def: To make empty; to empty out; to remove the contents of; as, to evacuate a vessel or dish.
Fig.: To make empty; to deprive.
sn.q: Evacuate the Scriptures of their most important meaning.

sn.def: To remove; to eject; to void; to discharge, as the contents of a vessel, or of the bowels.
To withdraw from; to quit; to retire from; as, soldiers from a country, city, or fortress.
sn.q: The Norwegians were forced to evacuate the country.

sn.def: To make void; to nullify; to vacate; as, to evacuate a contract or marriage.
To let blood
to expel stool from the bowels; to defecate.
p. p. of evacuate.
emptied of gas by being pumped out or having a vacuum created; as, a highly evacuated glass tube.

cs.cd: the anniversary of the day on which the British army evacuated the city of New York, November 25, 1783.

entry.sn:
The act of emptying, clearing of the contents, or discharging. Specifically: Mil Withdrawal of troops from a town, fortress, etc.
Med Voidance of any matter by the natural passages of the body or by an artificial opening; defecation; also, a diminution of the fluids of an animal body by cathartics, venesection, or other means.

sn.def: That which is evacuated or discharged; especially, a discharge by stool or other natural means.
Abolition; nullification.

entry.def: Serving of tending to evacuate; cathartic; purgative.
One who evacuates; a nullifier.
entry.q: Evacuatorsof the law.

entry.def: A purgative.

entries.entry:
E*vade"�), v. t.
imp. & p. p. Evaded; p. pr. & vb. n.. Evading
L. evadere evasum e out + vadere to go, walk: cf. F. s'évader. See Wade
To get away from by artifice; to avoid by dexterity, subterfuge, address, or ingenuity; to elude; to escape from cleverly; as, to evade a blow, a pursuer, a punishment; to evade the force of an argument. The heathen had a method, more truly their own, of evading the Christian miracles.

sn.def: To escape; to slip away; -- sometimes with from.
sn.q: Evadingfrom perils.
Unarmed they might Have easily, as spirits evaded swift By quick contraction or remove.

sn.def: To attempt to escape; to practice artifice or sophistry, for the purpose of eluding.
sn.q: The ministers of God are not to evade and take refuge any of these . . . ways.

entry.def: Capable of being evaded.

entry.ety: L. evagatio, fr. evagari to wander forth: cf. F. évagation. See Vagary
entry.def: A wandering about; excursion; a roving.

entry.ety: L. evaginatus, p. p., unsheathed. See Evagination
entry.def: Protruded, or grown out, as an evagination{2}; turned inside out; unsheathed; evaginated; as, an evaginate membrane.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evaginated; p. pr. & vb. n. Evaginating
entry.def: To become evaginate; to cause to be evaginate.

entry.ety: L. evaginatio an extending, evaginare to unsheathe; e out + vagina sheath

sn.def: The act of unsheathing.
An outgrowth or protruded part.

entry.def: Relating to time or duration.
To fix the value of; to rate; to appraise.
Valuation; appraisement.
exercising or involving careful analytical evaluations.
an authority who is able to estimate worth or quality; an appraiser.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evanesced ĕv`ȧ*nĕst"; p. pr. & vb. n. Evanescing. ĕv`ȧ*nĕs"sĭng
entry.ety: L. evanescere; e out + vanescere to vanish, fr. vanus empty, vain. See Vain, and cf. Evanish
entry.def: To vanish away; to become dissipated and disappear, like vapor.
entry.q: I believe him to have evanesced or evaporated.

entry.def: The act or state of vanishing away; disappearance; as, the evanescence of vapor, of a dream, of earthly plans or hopes.

entry.ety: L. evanescens -entis, p. pr. of evanescere

sn.def: Liable to vanish or pass away like vapor; vanishing; fleeting; as, evanescent joys.
sn.q: So evanescent are the fashions of the world in these particulars.

sn.def: Vanishing from notice; imperceptible.
sn.q: The difference between right and wrong, in some petty cases, is almost evanescent.

entry.def: In a vanishing manner; imperceptibly.

entry.ety: F. évangile, L. evangelium, Gr. e'yagge`lion good news, glad tidings, gospel, fr. e'ya`ggelos bringing good news; e'y^ well + 'a`ggelein to bear a message. See Eu-, and Angel and cf. Evangely
entry.def: Good news; announcement of glad tidings; especially, the gospel, or a gospel.
entry.q: Her funeral anthem is a glad evangel.

entry.def: Rendering thanks for favors.

entry.ety: L. evangelicus, Gr. e'yaggeliko`s: cf. F. évangélique. See Evangel
entry.def: Belonging to, or contained in, the gospel; evangelical.
entry.q: Evangelictruth.

entry.cs: Evangelical Alliance an alliance for mutual strengthening and common work, comprising Christians of different denominations and countries, organized in Liverpool, England, in 1845. Evangelical Church. The Protestant Church in Germany. A church founded by a fusion of Lutherans and Calvinists in Germany in 1817. Evangelical Union a religious sect founded in Scotland in 1843 by the Rev. James Morison; -- called also Morisonians.

sn.def: Contained in, or relating to, the four Gospels; as, the evangelical history.
Belonging to, agreeable or consonant to, or contained in, the gospel, or the truth taught in the New Testament; as, evangelical religion.

Earnest for the truth taught in the gospel; strict in interpreting Christian doctrine; preëminently orthodox; -- technically applied to that party in the Church of England, and in the Protestant Episcopal Church, which holds the doctrine of “Justification by Faith alone;” the Low Church party. The term is also applied to other religious bodies not regarded as orthodox.
Having or characterized by a zealous, crusading enthusiasm for a cause.
Adhering to a form of Christianity characterized by a conservative interpretation of the bible, but disavowing the label 'bdfundamentalist`'b8.

entry.def: One of evangelical principles.
Adherence to evangelical doctrines; evangelism.
In an evangelical manner.
State of being evangelical.
Evangelical principles; evangelism.
Evangelicism.
Same as evangelize.
The preaching or promulgation of the gospel.

entry.ety: F. évangéliste, L. evangelista, fr. Gr. e'yaggelisth`s
entry.def: A bringer of the glad tidings of Church and his doctrines.
A missionary preacher sent forth to prepare the way for a resident pastor; an itinerant missionary preacher.
A writer of one of the four Gospels (With the definite article); as, the four evangelists Matthew Mark Luke, and John .
A traveling preacher whose efforts are chiefly directed to arouse to immediate repentance.
entry.q: The Apostles, so far as they evangelized, might claim the title though there were many evangelists who were not Apostles.

entry.def: A selection of passages from the Gospels, as a lesson in divine service.
Pertaining to the four evangelists; designed or fitted to evangelize; evangelical; as, evangelistic efforts.
The act of evangelizing; the state of being evangelized.
entry.q: The work of Christ's ministers is evangelization.

entries.entry:
e*van"gel*ize �*văn"jĕl*īz v. t.
imp. & p. p. evangelized �*văn"jĕl*īzd; p. pr. & vb. n. evangelizing �*văn"jĕl*ī*zĭng . F. évangélisre, LL. evangelizare, fr. Gr. e'yaggeli`zesqai
To instruct in the gospel; to preach the gospel to; to convert to Christianity; as, to evangelize the world. His apostles whom he sends To evangelize the nations.
Hence: metaphorical To preach and attempt to convert (people) to one's firmly held belief.

entry.def: To preach the gospel.
Evangel.
entry.q: The sacred pledge of Christ's evangely.

entry.def: Good tidings; evangel.
entry.q: Above all, the Servians . . . read, with much avidity, the evangile of their freedom.

entry.ety: L. evanidus, fr. evanescere. See Evanesce
entry.def: Liable to vanish or disappear; faint; weak; evanescent; as, evanid color.

entry.ety: Pref. e- + vanish: cf. L. evanescere. See Evanesce vanish
entry.def: To vanish.
entry.q: Or like the rainbow's lovely form,Evanishing amid the storm.

entry.def: A vanishing; disappearance.
Capable of being converted into vapor, or dissipated by evaporation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evaporated; p. pr. & vb. n. Evaporating
entry.ety: L. evaporatus, p. p. of evaporare; e out + vapor steam or vapor. See Vapor

sn.def: To pass off in vapor, as a fluid; to escape and be dissipated, either in visible vapor, or in particles too minute to be visible.
To escape or pass off without effect; to be dissipated; to be wasted, as, the spirit of a writer often evaporates in the process of translation.
sn.q: To give moderate liberty for griefs and discontents to evaporate . . . is a safe way.

cs.cd: that part of the heating surface with which water is in contact.

sn.def: To convert from a liquid or solid state into vapor (usually) by the agency of heat; to dissipate in vapor or fumes.
To expel moisture from (usually by means of artificial heat), leaving the solid portion; to subject to evaporation; as, to evaporate apples.
To give vent to; to dissipate.
sn.q: My lord of Essex evaporated his thoughts in a sonnet.

entry.def: Dispersed in vapors.
reduced in volume by having moisture expelled before canning; same as condensed, 3; as, unsweetened evaporated milk.

sn.def: The process by which any substance is converted from a liquid state into, and carried off in, vapor; as, the evaporation of water, of ether, of camphor.
The transformation of a portion of a fluid into vapor, in order to obtain the fixed matter contained in it in a state of greater consistence.
That which is evaporated; vapor.
See Vaporization.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or producing, evaporation; as, the evaporative process.

cs.cd: a device used in laboratories in which a liquid is evaporated by reducing the pressure and applying heat, while rotating the liquid in a vessel such as a round-bottomed flask. The reduced pressure speeds the evaporation process and allows the evaporation to be conducted at temperatures lower than would otgherwise be possible, thus reducing decomposition of unstable substances. The rotation also serves to increase the surface area from which evaporation takes place and to reduce the effect of "bumping", the sudden burst of vaporization that can scatter liquid exposed to reduced pressure.

sn.def: An apparatus for condensing vegetable juices, or for drying fruit by heat.
Any device designed to evaporate a fluid.
The portion of a refrigeration system in which the refrigerant evaporates and thus absorbs heat.

entry.ety: L. evaporare to evaporate + -meter: cf. F. évapormètre
entry.def: An instrument for ascertaining the quantity of a fluid evaporated in a given time; an atmometer.
That may be evaded.

entry.ety: L. evasio: cf. F. évasion. See Evade
entry.def: The act of eluding or avoiding, particularly the pressure of an argument, accusation, charge, or interrogation; artful means of eluding.
entry.q: Thou . . . by evasions thy crime uncoverest more.

entry.def: Tending to evade, or marked by evasion; elusive; shuffling; avoiding by artifice.
entry.q: Thus he, though conscious of the ethereal guest, Answered evasive of the sly request.
Stammered out a few evasive phrases.

entry.def: Deliberate vagueness or ambiguity; failing to answer a question while trying to seem as though one is answering.

cs.cd: the European goatsucker or nightjar; -- called also night churr, and churr owl.

sn.def: Evening.
sn.q: Winter oft, at eve resumes the breeze.

sn.def: The evening before a holiday, -- from the Jewish mode of reckoning the day as beginning at sunset, not at midnight; as, Christmas eve is the evening before Christmas; also, the period immediately preceding some important event.
sn.q: On theeveof death.

entry.def: The branch of medical science which teaches the method of acquiring a good habit of body.

entries.entry:
E*vec"tion. L. evectio a going up, fr. evehere to carry out; e out + vehere to carry: cf. F évection
The act of carrying up or away; exaltation. Obs
Astron
An inequality of the moon's motion in its orbit, due to the attraction of the sun, by which the equation of the center is diminished at the syzygies, and increased at the quadratures by about 1° 20'.
The libration of the moon.

entry.ety: OE. eve even efen æfen. AS. ǣfen; akin to OS. āband, OFries, āvend, D. avond, OHG. āband, Icel. aptan, Sw. afton, Dan. aften; of unknown origin. Cf. Eve Evening
entry.def: Evening. See Eve n. 1.

cs.cd: with equal advantage.
in a level or horizontal position.

entry.ety: AS. efen. efn; akin to OS. eban, D. even, OHG. eban, G. efen, Icel. jafn, Dan. jevn, Sw. jämn, Goth. ibns. Cf. Anent Ebb

sn.def: Level, smooth, or equal in surface; not rough; free from irregularities; hence uniform in rate of motion of action; as, even ground; an even speed; an even course of conduct.
Equable; not easily ruffled or disturbed; calm; uniformly self-possessed; as, an even temper.
Parallel; on a level; reaching the same limit.
sn.q: And shall lay thee even with the ground.

sn.def: Balanced; adjusted; fair; equitable; impartial; just to both sides; owing nothing on either side; -- said of accounts, bargains, or persons indebted; as, our accounts are even; an even bargain.
sn.q: To make the even truth in pleasure flow.

sn.def: Without an irregularity, flaw, or blemish; pure.
sn.q: I know my life soeven.

sn.def: Associate; fellow; of the same condition.
sn.q: Hisevenservant.

sn.def: Not odd; capable of division by two without a remainder; -- said of numbers; as, 4 and 10 are even numbers.
sn.q: Whether the number of the stars is even or odd.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evened; p. pr. & vb. n. Evening

sn.def: To make even or level; to level; to lay smooth.
sn.q: His temple Xerxes evened with the soil.
It will even all inequalities

sn.def: To equal.
sn.q: Toevenhim in valor.

sn.def: To place in an equal state, as to obligation, or in a state in which nothing is due on either side; to balance, as accounts; to make quits; to make equal; as, to even the score.
To set right; to complete.
To act up to; to keep pace with.

entry.def: To be equal.

entry.note: ☞ Even is sometimes used to emphasize a word or phrase. “I have debated even in my soul.”
entry.ety: AS. efne. See Even a., and cf. E'en

sn.def: In an equal or precisely similar manner; equally; precisely; just; likewise; as well.
sn.q: Is itevenso?
Even so did these Gauls possess the coast.

sn.def: Up to, or down to, an unusual measure or level; so much as; fully; quite.
sn.q: Thou wast a soldierEven to Cato's wish.
Without . . . making us even sensible of the change.

sn.def: As might not be expected; -- serving to introduce what is unexpected or less expected.
sn.q: I have made several discoveries, which appear new, even to those who are versed in critical learning.

sn.def: At the very time; in the very case.
sn.q: I knew they were bad enough to please, even when I wrote them.
By these presence, even the presence of Lord Mortimer.

entry.def: To happen.

sn.def: One who, or that which makes even.
In vehicles, a swinging crossbar, to the ends of which other crossbars, or whiffletrees, are hung, to equalize the draught when two or three horses are used abreast.

entry.def: Beginning of evening.
entry.q: At the quietevenfall.

entry.def: Equality.
Fair or impartial; unbiased.
entry.q: Evenhandedjustice.

entry.note: ☞ Sometimes, especially in the Southern parts of the United States, the afternoon is called evening.
☞ Sometimes used adjectively; as, evening gun. “Evening Prayer.”
entry.cs: Evening flower Bot a genus of iridaceous plants (Hesperantha) from the Cape of Good Hope, with sword-shaped leaves, and sweet-scented flowers which expand in the evening. Evening grosbeak Zoöl an American singing bird (Coccothraustes vespertina) having a very large bill. Its color is olivaceous, with the crown, wings, and tail black, and the under tail coverts yellow. So called because it sings in the evening. Evening primrose. See under Primrose. The evening star the bright star of early evening in the western sky, soon passing below the horizon; specifically, the planet Venus; -- called also Vesper and Hesperus. During portions of the year, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn are also evening stars. See Morning Star.
entry.ety: AS. ǣfnung. See even n., and cf. Eve

sn.def: The latter part and close of the day, and the beginning of darkness or night; properly, the decline of the day, or of the sun.
sn.q: In the ascending scale Of heaven, the stars that usher evening rose.

sn.def: The latter portion, as of life; the declining period, as of strength or glory.

entry.def: a small dressy handbag, richly decorated, carried by women for formal occasions in the evening.
small California annual (Linanthus dichotomus) with white flowers.
attire to wear on formal occasions in the evening.
With an even, level, or smooth surface; without roughness, elevations, or depression; uniformly; equally; comfortably; impartially; serenely.
Having equanimity.

The state of being ven, level, or disturbed; smoothness; horizontal position; uniformity; impartiality; calmness; equanimity; appropriate place or level; as, evenness of surface, of a fluid at rest, of motion, of dealings, of temper, of condition.
entry.q: It had need be something extraordinary, that must warrant an ordinary person to rise higher than his own evenness.

entry.def: A song for the evening; the evening service or form of worship (in the Church of England including vespers and compline); also, the time of evensong.

entry.usage: Event Occurrence Incident Circumstance. An event denotes that which arises from a preceding state of things. Hence we speak or watching the event; of tracing the progress of events. An occurrence has no reference to any antecedents, but simply marks that which meets us in our progress through life, as if by chance, or in the course of divine providence. The things which thus meet us, if important, are usually connected with antecedents; and hence event is the leading term. In the “Declaration of Independence” it is said, “When, in the cource of human events, it becomes necessary.” etc. Here, occurrences would be out of place. An incident is that which falls into a state of things to which is does not primarily belong; as, the incidents of a journey. The term is usually applied to things of secondary importance. A circumstance is one of the things surrounding us in our path of life. These may differ greatly in importance; but they are always outsiders, which operate upon us from without, exerting greater or less influence according to their intrinsic importance. A person giving an account of a campaign might dwell on the leading events which it produced; might mention some of its striking occurrences; might allude to some remarkable incidents which attended it; and might give the details of the favorable or adverse circumstances which marked its progress.
entry.ety: L. eventus, fr. evenire to happen, come out; e out + venire to come. See Come

sn.def: That which comes, arrives, or happens; that which falls out; any incident, good or bad.
sn.q: Theeventsof his early years.
To watch quietly the course of events.
There is one event to the righteous, and to the wicked.

sn.def: An affair in hand; business; enterprise.
sn.q: Leave we him to hisevents.

sn.def: The consequence of anything; the issue; conclusion; result; that in which an action, operation, or series of operations, terminates.
sn.q: Dark doubts between the promise and event.
sn.syn: Incident; occurrence; adventure; issue; result; termination; consequence; conclusion.

entry.ety: F. éventer to fan, divulge, LL. eventare to fan, fr., L. e out + ventus wind
entry.def: To break forth.

entry.ety: L. e out + venter the belly: cf. F. éventer
entry.def: To rip open; to disembowel.
Full of, or rich in, events or incidents; as, an eventful journey; an eventful period of history; an eventful period of life.
The time of evening; evening.

the boundary surface surrounding a black hole, from outside of which nothing inside can be observed, because nothing inside that surface, even light, can escape beyond it. See also black hole and escape velocity.

entry.ety: L. eventilatus, p. p. of eventilare to fan. See Ventilate

sn.def: To winnow out; to fan.
To discuss; to ventilate.

entry.def: The act of eventilating; discussion.
Without events; tame; monotonous; marked by nothing unusual; uneventful.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Dr. e'y^ well + � within gna`qos the jaw
entry.def: An order of fishes including a vast number of freshwater species such as the carp, loach, chub, etc.
A tumor containing a large portion of the abdominal viscera, occasioned by relaxation of the walls of the abdomen.
A wound, of large extent, in the abdomen, through which the greater part of the intestines protrude.
The act of disemboweling.

sn.def: Coming or happening as a consequence or result; consequential.
Final; ultimate.
sn.q: Eventualsuccess.

sn.def: Dependent on events; contingent.

entries.entry:
E*ven`tu*al"i*ty n.; pl.Eventualities #. Cf. F. éventualité
The coming as a consequence; contingency; also, an event which comes as a consequence.
Phren Disposition to take cognizance of events.

entry.def: In an eventual manner; finally; ultimately.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Eventuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Eventuating
entry.def: To come out finally or in conclusion; to result; to come to pass.
The act of eventuating or happening as a result; the outcome.

entry.note: ☞ Ever is sometimes used as an intensive or a word of enforcement. “His the old man e'er a son?”
entry.cs: Ever and anon now and then; often. See under Anon. Ever is one continually; constantly. Obs Chaucer. Ever so in whatever degree; to whatever extent; -- used to intensify indefinitely the meaning of the associated adjective or adverb. See Never so, under Never. “Let him be ever so rich.” Emerson. And all the question (wrangle e'er so long), Is only this, if God has placed him wrong. Pope. You spend ever so much money in entertaining your equals and betters. Thackeray. For ever eternally. See Forever. For ever and a day emphatically forever. Shak. She [Fortune] soon wheeled away, with scornful laughter, out of sight for ever and day. Prof. Wilson. Or everfor or ere), before. See Or ere. Archaic Would I had met my dearest foe in heavenOr ever I had seen that day, Horatio! Shak.
entry.note: ☞ Ever is sometimes joined to its adjective by a hyphen, but in most cases the hyphen is needless; as, ever memorable ever watchful ever burning.
entry.ety: OE. ever æfre, AS. æfre; perh. akin to AS. ā always. Cf. Aye Age,Evry Never

sn.def: At any time; at any period or point of time.
sn.q: No man ever yet hated his own flesh.

sn.def: At all times; through all time; always; forever.
sn.q: He shall ever love, and always be The subject of by scorn and cruelty.

sn.def: Without cessation; continually.
sn.q: To produce as much as ever they can.

entry.def: Everlasting.

entry.note: Also used as a metaphor for a high mountain.
entry.def: the highest mountain in the world, situated in Nepal and Tibet; 29,028 feet high.

entry.note: ☞ When used in the United States without qualification, the word Everglades is understood to refer to the Everglades of southern Florida.
entry.def: A swamp or low tract of land inundated with water and interspersed with hummocks, or small islands, and patches of high grass; as, the everglades of Florida.
Remaining unwithered through the winter, or retaining unwithered leaves until the leaves of the next year are expanded, as pines cedars, hemlocks, and the like.

sn.def: An evergreen plant.
Twigs and branches of evergreen plants used for decoration.
sn.q: The funeralevengreensentwine.

entries.entry: Evergreen State. Washington; -- a nickname alluding to the abundance of evergreen trees.

entry.def: each one; every one; each of two. See Every.

entry.ety: OE. everich + oon on, one. See Every, and One
entry.def: Every one.

entry.usage: Everlasting Eternal. Eternal denotes (when taken strictly) without beginning or end of duration; everlasting is sometimes used in our version of the Scriptures in the sense of eternal, but in modern usage is confined to the future, and implies no intermission as well as no end.
entry.cs: Everlasting flower. Sane as Everlasting n., 3. Everlasting pea an ornamental plant (Lathyrus latifolius) related to the pea; -- so called because it is perennial.

sn.def: Lasting or enduring forever; exsisting or continuing without end; immortal; eternal.
sn.q: TheEverlastingGod.

sn.def: Continuing indefinitely, or during a long period; perpetual; sometimes used, colloquially, as a strong intensive; as, this everlasting nonsence.
sn.q: I will give to thee, and to thy seed after thee . . . the land of Canaan, for an everlasting possession.
And heard thy everlasting yawn confess The pains and penalties of idleness.
sn.syn: Eternal; immortal, interminable; endless; never-ending; infinite; unceasing; uninterrupted; continual; unintermitted; incessant.

sn.def: Eternal duration, past or future; eternity.
sn.q: From everlasting to everlasting, thou art God.

sn.def: With the definite article) The Eternal Being; God.

A plant whose flowers may be dried without losing their form or color, as, the pearly everlasting
Anaphalis margaritacea), the immortelle Xeranthemum anuum) of the French, the cudweeds, etc.
A cloth fabric for shoes, etc. See Lasting.

entry.def: In an everlasting manner.
The state of being everlasting; endless duration; indefinite duration.

sn.def: Living always; immoral; eternal; as, the everliving God.
Continual; incessant; unintermitted.

entry.def: During eternity; always; forever; for an indefinite period; at all times; -- often used substantively with for.
entry.q: Seek the Lord . . . Seek his face evermore.
And, behold, I am alive for evermore.
Which flow from the presence of God for evermore.
I evermore did love you, Hermia.

entry.def: Pertaining to Evernia, a genus of lichens; as, evernic acid.

entry.ety: L. eversus, p. p. of evertere to turn out, overthrow; e out + vertere to turn. Cf. Evert
entry.def: To overthrow or subvert.

sn.def: The act of eversing; destruction.
The state of being turned back or outward; as, eversion of eyelids; ectropium.

entry.def: Tending to evert or overthrow; subversive; with of.
entry.q: A maxim eversive . . . of all justice and morality.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Everted; p. pr. & vb. n. Everting

sn.def: To overthrow; to subvert.
To turn outwards, or inside out, as an intestine.

entry.cs: Every each every one. Obs “Every each of them hath some vices.” Burton.. Every now and then at short intervals; occasionally; repeatedly; frequently. Colloq
entry.note: ☞ Every may, by way of emphasis, precede the article the with a superlative adjective; as, every the least variation.
entry.usage: Any denotes one, or some, taken indifferently from the individuals which compose a class. Every differs from each in giving less prominence to the selection of the individual. Each relates to two or more individuals of a class. It refers definitely to every one of them, denoting that they are considered separately, one by one, all being included; as, each soldier was receiving a dollar per day. Every relates to more than two and brings into greater prominence the notion that not one of all considered is excepted; as, every soldier was on service, except the cavalry, that is, all the soldiers, etc.
entry.ety: OE. everich everilk; AS. ǣfre ever + ælc each. See Ever each

sn.def: All the parts which compose a whole collection or aggregate number, considered in their individuality, all taken separately one by one, out of an indefinite number.
sn.q: Every man at his best state is altogether vanity.
Every door and window was adorned with wreaths of flowers.

sn.def: Every one. Cf. Each.
sn.q: Everyof your wishes.
Daily occasions given to every of us.
In each division there were four pentecosties, in every pentecosty four enomoties, and of each enomoty there fought in the front rank four [soldiers].
If society is to be kept together and the children of Adam to be saved from setting up each for himself with every one else his foe.

entry.def: Every person.
Used or fit for every day; common; usual; as, an everyday suit of clothes.
entry.q: The mechanical drudgery of his everyday employment.

entry.def: Everybody; -- commonly separated, every one.
Whatever pertains to the subject under consideration; all things.
entry.q: More wise, more learned, more just, more everything.

entry.def: At any or all times; every instant.
entry.q: Eternal law is silently present everywhere andeverywhen.

entry.def: In every place; in all places; hence, in every part; thoroughly; altogether.
Ubiquity; omnipresence.
See Eavesdrop.
See Eavesdropper.

entry.ety: L. evestigatus traced out; e out + vestigatus, p. p. of vestigare. See Vestigate
entry.def: To investigate.
The common newt or eft. In America often applied to several species of aquatic salamanders.
To vibrate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evicted; p. pr. & vb. n. Evicting
entry.ety: L. evictus, p. p. of evincere to overcome completely, evict. See Evince

sn.def: To dispossess by a judicial process; to dispossess by paramount right or claim of such right; to eject; to oust.
sn.q: The law of England would speedily evict them out of their possession.

sn.def: To evince; to prove.

The act or process of evicting; or state of being evicted; the recovery of lands, tenements, etc., from another's possession by due course of law; dispossession by paramount title or claim of such title; ejectment; ouster.
Conclusive evidence; proof.
sn.q: Full eviction of this fatal truth.

cs.cd: See under Circumstantial Conclusive, etc.
evidence for the crown, in English courts; equivalent to state's evidence in American courts.
evidence for the government or the people.
cs.mcol: To turn King's evidence To turn Queen's evidenceorTo turn State's evidence
cs.cd: to confess a crime and give evidence against one's accomplices.

entry.ety: F. évidence, L. Evidentia. See Evident

sn.def: That which makes evident or manifest; that which furnishes, or tends to furnish, proof; any mode of proof; the ground of belief or judgement; as, the evidence of our senses; evidence of the truth or falsehood of a statement.
sn.q: Faith is . . . the evidence of things not seen.
O glorious trial of exceeding love Illustrious evidence, example high.

sn.def: One who bears witness.
sn.q: Infamous and perjuredevidences.

sn.def: That which is legally submitted to competent tribunal, as a means of ascertaining the truth of any alleged matter of fact under investigation before it; means of making proof; -- the latter, strictly speaking, not being synonymous with evidence, but rather the effect of it.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evidenced; p. pr. & vb. n. Evidencing
entry.def: To render evident or clear; to prove; to evince; as, to evidence a fact, or the guilt of an offender.
One who gives evidence.

entry.ety: F. évinent, l. evidens -entis; e out + videns, p. pr. of videre to see. See Vision
entry.def: Clear to the vision; especially, clear to the understanding, and satisfactory to the judgment; as, the figure or color of a body is evident to the senses; the guilt of an offender can not always be made evident.
entry.q: Your honor and your goodness is so evident.
And in our faces evident the signs Of foul concupiscence.
entry.syn: Manifest; plain; clear; obvious; visible; apparent; conclusive; indubitable; palpable; notorious. See Manifest.

entry.def: Relating to, or affording, evidence; indicative; especially, relating to the evidences of Christianity.
entry.q: Evidentialtracks.

entry.def: Furnishing evidence; asserting; proving; evidential.
entry.q: When a fact is supposed, although incorrectly, to be evidentiary of, or a mark of, some other fact.

entry.def: In an evident manner; clearly; plainly.
entry.q: Before whose eyes Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth.
He was evidently in the prime of youth.

entry.def: State of being evident.

entry.ety: L. evigilatio; e out + vigilare to be awake. See Vigilant
entry.def: A waking up or awakening.

cs.cd: an eye which inflicts injury by some magical or fascinating influence. It is still believed by the ignorant and superstitious that some persons have the supernatural power of injuring by a look.
cs.q: It almost led him to believe in the evil eye.
cs.cd: speaking ill of others; calumny; censoriousness.
the Devil; Satan.

entry.note: ☞ Evil is sometimes written as the first part of a compound (with or without a hyphen). In many cases the compounding need not be insisted on. Examples: Evil doer or evildoer, evil speaking or evil-speaking, evil worker, evil wishing, evil-hearted, evil-minded.
entry.ety: OE. evel evil ifel uvel, AS. yfel; akin to OFries, evel, D. euvel, OS. & OHG. ubil, G. übel, Goth. ubils, and perh. to E. over

sn.q: A good tree can not bring forth evil fruit.

sn.def: Having or exhibiting bad moral qualities; morally corrupt; wicked; wrong; vicious; as, evil conduct, thoughts, heart, words, and the like.
sn.q: Ah, what a sign it is of evil life, When death's approach is seen so terrible.

sn.def: Producing or threatening sorrow, distress, injury, or calamity; unpropitious; calamitous; as, evil tidings; evil arrows; evil days.

sn.syn: Mischieveous; pernicious; injurious; hurtful; destructive; wicked; sinful; bad; corrupt; perverse; wrong; vicious; calamitous.

sn.def: Anything which impairs the happiness of a being or deprives a being of any good; anything which causes suffering of any kind to sentient beings; injury; mischief; harm; -- opposed to good.
sn.q: Evils which our own misdeeds have wrought.
The evil that men do lives after them.

sn.def: Moral badness, or the deviation of a moral being from the principles of virtue imposed by conscience, or by the will of the Supreme Being, or by the principles of a lawful human authority; disposition to do wrong; moral offence; wickedness; depravity.

sn.def: malady or disease; especially in the phrase king's evil, the scrofula.

evil behavior.

The condition or quality of being evil; badness; viciousness; malignity; vileness; as, evilness of heart; the evilness of sin.

Avoidable.

To shun.

Eternity.

entry.def: To call out or forth; to summon; to evoke.
The act of calling out or forth.
entry.q: The evocation of that better spirit.

entry.def: Calling forth; serving to evoke; developing.
entry.q: Evocative power over all that is eloquent and expressive in the better soul of man.

entry.note: ☞ Any curve may be an evolute, the term being applied to it only in its relation to the involute.
entry.ety: L. evolutus unrolled, p. p. of evolvere. See Evolve
entry.def: A curve from which another curve, called the involute or evolvent, is described by the end of a thread gradually wound upon the former, or unwound from it. See Involute. It is the locus of the centers of all the circles which are osculatory to the given curve or evolvent.
The faculty possessed by all substances capable of self-nourishment of manifesting the nutritive acts by changes of form, of volume, or of structure.

entry.ety: L. evolutio an unrolling: cf. F. évolution evolution. See Evolve

sn.def: The act of unfolding or unrolling; hence, any process of growth or development; as, the evolution of a flower from a bud, or an animal from the egg.
A series of things unrolled or unfolded.
sn.q: The wholeevolutionof ages.

sn.def: The formation of an involute by unwrapping a thread from a curve as an evolute.
The extraction of roots; -- the reverse of involution.
A prescribed movement of a body of troops, or a vessel or fleet; any movement designed to effect a new arrangement or disposition; a maneuver.
sn.q: Those evolutions are best which can be executed with the greatest celerity, compatible with regularity.

sn.def: A general name for the history of the steps by which any living organism has acquired the morphological and physiological characters which distinguish it; a gradual unfolding of successive phases of growth or development.
That theory of generation which supposes the germ to preëxist in the parent, and its parts to be developed, but not actually formed, by the procreative act; -- opposed to epigenesis.

That series of changes under natural law which involves continuous progress from the homogeneous to the heterogeneous in structure, and from the single and simple to the diverse and manifold in quality or function. The process is by some limited to organic beings; by others it is applied to the inorganic and the psychical. It is also applied to explain the existence and growth of institutions, manners, language, civilization, and every product of human activity. The agencies and laws of the process are variously explained by different philosophrs.
sn.q: Evolution is to me series with development.

entry.def: Relating to evolution.
entry.q: Evolutionalchanges.

entry.def: Relating to evolution; as, evolutionary discussions.
The theory of, or belief in, evolution. See Evolution, 6 and 7.

sn.def: One skilled in evolutions.
One who holds the doctrine of evolution, either in biology or in metaphysics.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Evolved; p. pr. & vb. n. Evolving
entry.ety: L. evolvere evolutum; e out + volvere to roll. See Voluble

sn.def: To unfold or unroll; to open and expand; to disentangle and exhibit clearly and satisfactorily; to develop; to derive; to educe.
sn.q: The animal soul sooner evolves itself to its full orb and extent than the human soul.
The principles which art involves, science alone evolves.
Not by any power evolved from man's own resources, but by a power which descended from above.

sn.def: To throw out; to emit; as, to evolve odors.

entry.def: To become open, disclosed, or developed; to pass through a process of evolution.
The act of evolving, or the state of being evolved; evolution.

entry.ety: L. evolvens -entis, unrolling, p. pr. of evolvere
entry.def: The involute of a curve. See Involute, and Evolute.

entry.ety: L. evomitus, p. p. of evomere to vomit forth; e out + vomere
entry.def: To vomit.
The act of vomiting.

entry.ety: L. evulgatus, p. p. of evulgare to publish
entry.def: To publish abroad.
A divulging.

entry.ety: L. evulsio, fr. evellere evulsum, to pluck out; e out + vellere to pluck; cf. F. évulsion
entry.def: The act of plucking out; a rooting out.
A yew.

entry.ety: AS. eówu; akin to D. ooi, OHG. awi ouwi, Icel. ær, Goth. awēþi a flock of sheep, awistr a sheepfold, Lith. avis a sheep, L. ovis, Gr. 'o`i:s, Skr. avi. √231
entry.def: The female of the sheep, and of sheeplike animals.
Having a neck like a ewe; -- said of horses in which the arch of the neck is deficient, being somewhat hollowed out.

entry.ety: OF. ewer euwier, prop. a water carrier, F. évier a washing place, sink, aiguière ewer, L. aquarius, adj., water carrying, n., a water carrier, fr. aqua water; akin to Goth. ahwa water, river, OHG. aha, G. au aue, meadow. √219. Cf. Aquarium Aquatic Island
entry.def: A kind of wide-mouthed pitcher or jug; esp., one used to hold water for the toilet.
entry.q: Basins and ewers to lave her dainty hands.

entry.def: An office or place of household service where the ewers were formerly kept.
The newt.

entries.entry: Ex-. A prefix from the latin preposition, ex, akin to Gr. 'ex or 'ek signifying out of out proceeding from. Hence, in composition, it signifies out of as, in exhale, exclude; off from, or out, as in exscind; beyond, as, in excess, exceed, excel; and sometimes has a privative sense of without, as in exalbuminous, exsanguinous. In some words, it intensifies the meaning; in others, it has little affect on the signification. It becomes ef- before f, as in effuse. The form e- occurs instead of ex- before b d g l m n r, and v, as in ebullient, emanate, enormous, etc. In words from the French it often appears as es-, sometimes as s- or é-; as, escape, scape, élite. Ex-, prefixed to names implying office, station, condition, denotes that the person formerly held the office, or is out of the office or condition now; as, ex-president, ex-governor, ex-mayor, ex-convict. The Greek form 'ex becomes ex in English, as in exarch; 'ek becomes ec, as in eccentric.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exacerbated ĕgz*ăs"ẽr*bā`tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Exacerbating ĕgz*ăs"ẽr*bā`tĭng
entry.ety: L. exacerbatus, p. p. of exacerbare; ex out (intens.) + acerbare. See Acerbate
entry.def: To render more violent or bitter; to irritate; to exasperate; to imbitter, as passions or disease.
Making worse.

sn.def: The act of rendering more violent or bitter; the state of being exacerbated or intensified in violence or malignity; as, exacerbation of passion.
A periodical increase of violence in a disease, as in remittent or continuous fever; an increased energy of diseased and painful action.

entry.ety: L. exacerbescens -entis, p. pr. of exacerbescere, incho. of exacerbare
entry.def: Increase of irritation or violence, particularly the increase of a fever or disease.

entry.ety: L. exacervare to heap up exceedingly. See Ex-, and Acervate
entry.def: The act of heaping up.
To remove the kernel form.
Removal of the kernel.

entry.ety: L. exactus precise, accurate, p. p. of exigere to drive out, to demand, enforce, finish, determine, measure; ex out + agere to drive; cf. F. exact. See Agent Act

sn.def: Precisely agreeing with a standard, a fact, or the truth; perfectly conforming; neither exceeding nor falling short in any respect; true; correct; precise; as, the clock keeps exact time; he paid the exact debt; an exact copy of a letter; exact accounts.
sn.q: I took a great pains to make out the exact truth.

sn.def: Habitually careful to agree with a standard, a rule, or a promise; accurate; methodical; punctual; as, a man exact in observing an appointment; in my doings I was exact.
sn.q: I see thou artexactof taste.

sn.def: Precisely or definitely conceived or stated; strict.
sn.q: An exact command, Larded with many several sorts of reason.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exacted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exacting
entry.ety: From L. exactus, p. p. of exigere; or fr. LL. exactare: cf. OF. exacter. See Exact a.
entry.def: To demand or require authoritatively or peremptorily, as a right; to enforce the payment of, or a yielding of; to compel to yield or to furnish; hence, to wrest, as a fee or reward when none is due; -- followed by from or of before the one subjected to exaction; as, to exact tribute, fees, obedience, etc., from or of some one.
entry.q: He said into them, Exact no more than that which is appointed you.
Years of servise past From grateful souls exact reward at last
My designsExact me in another place.

entry.def: To practice exaction.
entry.q: The anemy shall not exact upon him.

entry.def: An exactor.
Oppressive or unreasonably severe in making demands or requiring the exact fulfillment of obligations; harsh; severe.
entry.q: A temper soexacting.

sn.def: The act of demanding with authority, and compelling to pay or yield; compulsion to give or furnish; a levying by force; a driving to compliance; as, the exaction to tribute or of obedience; hence, extortion.
sn.q: Take away your exactions from my people.
Daily new exactions are devised.
Illegal exactions of sheriffs and officials.

sn.def: That which is exacted; a severe tribute; a fee, reward, or contribution, demanded or levied with severity or injustice.

entry.def: The quality of being exact; exactness.
In an exact manner; precisely according to a rule, standard, or fact; accurately; strictly; correctly; nicely.
entry.q: Exactlywrought.
His enemies were pleased, for he had acted exactly as their interests required.

sn.def: The condition of being exact; accuracy; nicety; precision; regularity; as, exactness of judgement or deportment.
Careful observance of method and conformity to truth; as, exactness in accounts or business.
sn.q: He had . . . that sort of exactness which would have made him a respectable antiquary.

entry.def: One who exacts or demands by authority or right; hence, an extortioner; also, one unreasonably severe in injunctions or demands.
A woman who is an exactor.

entry.ety: L. exacure; ex out (intens.) + acuere to make sharp
entry.def: To whet or sharpen.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr.� a taking away
entry.def: In old writers, the operations concerned in the removal of parts of the body.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exaggerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Exaggerating .
entry.ety: L. exaggeratus , p. p. of exaggerare to heap up; ex out + aggerare to heap up, fr. agger heap, aggerere to bring to; ad to + gerere to bear. See Jest.

sn.def: To heap up; to accumulate.
sn.q: Earthexaggeratedupon them [oaks and firs].

sn.def: To amplify; to magnify; to enlarge beyond bounds or the truth ; to delineate extravagantly ; to overstate the truth concerning.
sn.q: A friend exaggerates a man's virtues.

entry.def: Enlarged beyond bounds or the truth.
That exaggerates; enlarging beyond bounds.

sn.def: The act of heaping or piling up.
sn.q: Exaggerationof sand.

sn.def: The act of exaggerating; the act of doing or representing in an excessive manner; a going beyond the bounds of truth reason, or justice; a hyperbolical representation; hyperbole; overstatement.
sn.q: No need of an exaggeration of what they saw.

sn.def: A representation of things beyond natural life, in expression, beauty, power, vigor.

entry.def: Tending to exaggerate; involving exaggeration.
entry.q: Exaggerativelanguage.
Exaggerativepictures.

entry.def: One who exaggerates; one addicted to exaggeration.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exalted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exalting

sn.def: To raise high; to elevate; to lift up.

sn.def: To elevate in rank, dignity, power, wealth, character, or the like; to dignify; to promote; as, to exalt a prince to the throne, a citizen to the presidency.

sn.def: To elevate by prise or estimation; to magnify; to extol; to glorify.

sn.def: To lift up with joy, pride, or success; to inspire with delight or satisfaction; to elate.

sn.def: To elevate the tone of, as of the voice or a musical instrument.
sn.q: Now Mars, she said, let Fame exalt her voice.

sn.def: To render pure or refined; to intensify or concentrate; as, to exalt the juices of bodies.

entry.ety: L. exaltatus, p. p. of exaltare to exalt
entry.def: Exercising its highest influence; -- said of a planet.

sn.def: The act of exalting or raising high; also, the state of being exalted; elevation.
sn.q: Wondering at my flight, and change To this high exaltation.

sn.def: The refinement or subtilization of a body, or the increasing of its virtue or principal property.
That place of a planet in the zodiac in which it was supposed to exert its strongest influence.
An abnormal sense of personal well-being, power, or importance, -- a symptom observed in various forms of insanity.

entry.def: Raised to lofty height; elevated; extolled; refined; dignified; sublime.

entry.def: One who exalts or raises to dignity.

entry.ety: L., the tongue of a balance, examination; for exagmen, fr. exigere to weigh accurately, to treat: cf. F. examen. See Exact a.

sn.def: One who examines; an examiner.
One who is to be examined.

that made by the opposite party.
that questioning of a witness at trial made by the party calling the witness, after, and upon matters arising out of, the cross-examination; also called informally re-direct.

A process prescribed or assigned for testing qualification; as, the examination of a student, or of a candidate for admission to the bar or the ministry.
sn.q: He neglected the studies, . . . stood low at the examinations.
sn.syn: Search; inquiry; investigation; research; scrutiny; inquisition; inspection; exploration.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Examined; p. pr. & vb. n. Examining
entry.ety: L. examinare examinatum, fr. examen examinis: cf. F. examiner. See Examen

sn.def: To test by any appropriate method; to inspect carefully with a view to discover the real character or state of; to subject to inquiry or inspection of particulars for the purpose of obtaining a fuller insight into the subject of examination, as a material substance, a fact, a reason, a cause, the truth of a statement; to inquire or search into; to explore; as, to examine a mineral; to examine a ship to know whether she is seaworthy; to examine a proposition, theory, or question.
sn.q: Examine well your own thoughts.
Examine their counsels and their cares.

sn.def: To interrogate as in a judicial proceeding; to try or test by question; as, to examine a witness in order to elicit testimony, a student to test his qualifications, a bankrupt touching the state of his property, etc.
