sn.syn: To discuss; debate; scrutinize; search into; investigate; explore. See Discuss.

entry.def: A person examined.

One who examines, tries, or inspects; one who interrogates; an officer or person charged with the duty of making an examination; as, an examiner of students for a degree; an examiner in chancery, in the patent office, etc.
The office or rank of an examiner.

Serving for example or pattern; exemplary.

entry.usage: Example Instance. The discrimination to be made between these two words relates to cases in which we give “instances” or “examples” of things done. An instance denotes the single case then “standing” before us; if there be others like it, the word does not express this fact. On the contrary, an example is one of an entire class of like things, and should be a true representative or sample of that class. Hence, an example proves a rule or regular course of things; an instance simply points out what may be true only in the case presented. A man's life may be filled up with examples of the self-command and kindness which marked his character, and may present only a solitary instance of haste or severity. Hence, the word “example” should never be used to describe what stands singly and alone. We do, however, sometimes apply the word instance to what is really an example, because we are not thinking of the latter under this aspect, but solely as a case which “stands before us.” See Precedent.
entry.ety: A later form for ensample, fr. L. exemplum, orig., what is taken out of a larger quantity, as a sample, from eximere to take out. See Exempt, and cf. Ensample Sample

sn.def: One or a portion taken to show the character or quality of the whole; a sample; a specimen.
That which is to be followed or imitated as a model; a pattern or copy.
sn.q: For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you.
I gave, thou sayest, the example; I led the way.

sn.def: That which resembles or corresponds with something else; a precedent; a model.
sn.q: Such temperate order in so fierce a cause Doth want example.

sn.def: That which is to be avoided; one selected for punishment and to serve as a warning; a warning.
sn.q: Hang him; he'll be made an example.

entry.def: A pattern; an exemplar.

entries.entry:

Excellence; virtue; dignity; worth; superiority. His excellency is over Israel. Extinguish in men the sense of their own excellency.
A title of honor given to certain high dignitaries, esp. to viceroys, ministers, and ambassadors, to English colonial governors, etc. It was formerly sometimes given to kings and princes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excepted; p. pr. & vb. n. Excepting
entry.ety: L. exceptus, p. p. of excipere to take or draw out, to except; ex out + capere to take: cf. F. excepter. See Capable

sn.def: To take or leave out (anything) from a number or a whole as not belonging to it; to exclude; to omit.
sn.q: Who never touched The excepted tree.
Wherein (if we only except the unfitness of the judge) all other things concurred.

sn.def: To object to; to protest against.

entry.def: To take exception; to object; -- usually followed by to, sometimes by against; as, to except to a witness or his testimony.
entry.q: Except thou wilt except against my love.

entry.usage: Excepting except but, and save are exclusive. Except marks exclusion more pointedly. “I have finished all the letters except one,” is more marked than “I have finished all the letters but one.” Excepting is the same as except, but less used. Save is chiefly found in poetry. Besideslit., by the side of) is in the nature of addition. “There is no one here except or but him,” means, take him away and there is nobody present. “There is nobody here besides him,” means, he is present and by the side of, or in addition to, him is nobody. “Few ladies, except her Majesty, could have made themselves heard.” In this example, besides should be used, not except.
entry.ety: Originally past participle, or verb in the imperative mode
entry.def: With exclusion of; leaving or left out; excepting.
entry.q: God and his Son except,Created thing naught valued he nor . . . shunned.

entry.note: ☞ As a conjunction unless has mostly taken the place of except.
entry.def: Unless; if it be not so that.
entry.q: And he said, I will not let thee go, except thou bless me.
But yesterday you never opened lip,Except, indeed, to drink.

entry.def: Making exception.

entries.entry:
Ex*cept"ing prep. & conj., but properly a participle. With rejection or exception of; excluding; except.
Exceptingyour worship's presence. No one was ever yet made utterly miserable, excepting by himself.

entry.note: Often with to.

cs.cd: a statement of exceptions to the decision, or instructions of a judge in the trial of a cause, made for the purpose of putting the points decided on record so as to bring them before a superior court or the full bench for review.

sn.def: The act of excepting or excluding; exclusion; restriction by taking out something which would otherwise be included, as in a class, statement, rule.
That which is excepted or taken out from others; a person, thing, or case, specified as distinct, or not included; as, almost every general rule has its exceptions .
sn.q: Such rare exceptions, shining in the dark, Prove, rather than impeach, the just remark.
That proud exception to all nature's laws.

sn.def: An objection, oral or written, taken, in the course of an action, as to bail or security; or as to the decision of a judge, in the course of a trail, or in his charge to a jury; or as to lapse of time, or scandal, impertinence, or insufficiency in a pleading; also, as in conveyancing, a clause by which the grantor excepts something before granted.
An objection; cavil; dissent; disapprobation; offense; cause of offense; -- usually followed by to or against.
sn.q: I will never answer what exceptions they can have against our account [relation].
He . . . took exception to the place of their burial.
She takes exceptions at your person.

entry.def: Liable to exception or objection; objectionable.
entry.q: This passage I look upon to be the most exceptionable in the whole poem.

entry.def: Forming an exception; not ordinary; uncommon; rare; hence, better than the average; superior.
entry.q: This particular spot had exceptional advantages.

entry.def: One who takes exceptions or makes objections.
Without exception.
entry.q: A universal, . . . exceptionless disqualification.

entry.def: Disposed or apt to take exceptions, or to object; captious.
entry.q: At least effectually silence the doubtful and exceptious.

entry.def: That excepts; including an exception; as, an exceptive proposition.
entry.q: A particular and exceptive law.

entry.def: Not exceptional; usual.
entry.q: My general and exceptless rashness.

entry.def: One who takes exceptions.

entry.ety: L. excerebratus deprived of brains; ex out + cerebrum brain
entry.def: The act of removing or beating out the brains.

To excrete; to throw off through the pores; as, fluids are excerned in perspiration.
Connected with, or pertaining to, excretion.

entry.ety: L. excerpere excerptum; ex out + carpere to pick, gather. See Harvest, and cf. Scarce a.
entry.def: To pick out.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excerpted; p. pr. & vb. n. Excerpting
entry.ety: From L. excerptus, p. p. See Excerp
entry.def: To select; to extract; to cite; to quote.
entry.q: Out of which we have excerpted the following particulars.

entry.def: An extract; a passage selected or copied from a book or record.

sn.def: The act of excerpting or selecting.
That which is selected or gleaned; an extract.
sn.q: His excerptions out of the Fathers.

entry.def: That excerpts, selects, or chooses.
One who makes excerpts; a picker; a culler.

cs.cd: the amount by which the sum of the three angles of a spherical triangle exceeds two right angles. The spherical excess is proportional to the area of the triangle.

entry.ety: OE. exces excess, ecstasy, L. excessus a going out, loss of self-possession, fr. excedere excessum, to go out, go beyond: cf. F. excès. See Exceed

sn.def: The state of surpassing or going beyond limits; the being of a measure beyond sufficiency, necessity, or duty; that which exceeds what is usual or proper; immoderateness; superfluity; superabundance; extravagance; as, an excess of provisions or of light.
sn.q: To gild refined gold, to paint the lily, To throw a perfume on the violet, . . . Is wasteful and ridiculous excess.
That kills me with excess of grief, this with excess of joy.

sn.def: An undue indulgence of the appetite; transgression of proper moderation in natural gratifications; intemperance; dissipation.
sn.q: Be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess.
Thy desire . . . leads to no excess That reaches blame.

sn.def: The degree or amount by which one thing or number exceeds another; remainder; as, the difference between two numbers is the excess of one over the other.

entry.def: Characterized by, or exhibiting, excess; overmuch.
entry.q: Excessive grief [is] the enemy to the living.
entry.syn: Undue; exorbitant; extreme; overmuch; enormous; immoderate; monstrous; intemperate; unreasonable. See Enormous

entry.note: ☞ A in London is creditor to B in New York, and C in London owes D in New York a like sum. A in London draws a bill of exchange on B in New York; C in London purchases the bill, by which A receives his debt due from B in New York. C transmits the bill to D in New York, who receives the amount from B.
entry.cs: Arbitration of exchange. See under Arbitration. Bill of exchange. See under Bill. Exchange broker. See under Broker. Par of exchange the established value of the coin or standard of value of one country when expressed in the coin or standard of another, as the value of the pound sterling in the currency of France or the United States. The par of exchange rarely varies, and serves as a measure for the rise and fall of exchange that is affected by the demand and supply. Exchange is at par when, for example, a bill in New York, for the payment of one hundred pounds sterling in London, can be purchased for the sum. Exchange is in favor of a place when it can be purchased there at or above par. Telephone exchange a central office in which the wires of any two telephones or telephone stations may be connected to permit conversation.
entry.ety: OE. eschange eschaunge, OF. eschange, fr. eschangier, F. échanger, to exchange; pref. ex- out + F. changer. See Change, and cf. Excamb

sn.def: The act of giving or taking one thing in return for another which is regarded as an equivalent; as, an exchange of cattle for grain.

The act of substituting one thing in the place of another; as, an exchange of grief for joy, or of a scepter for a sword, and the like; also, the act of giving and receiving reciprocally; as, an exchange of civilities or views.
The thing given or received in return; esp., a publication exchanged for another.

The process of setting accounts or debts between parties residing at a distance from each other, without the intervention of money, by exchanging orders or drafts, called bills of exchange. These may be drawn in one country and payable in another, in which case they are called foreign bills; or they may be drawn and made payable in the same country, in which case they are called inland bills. The term bill of exchange is often abbreviated into exchange; as, to buy or sell exchange .
A mutual grant of equal interests, the one in consideration of the other. Estates exchanged must be equal in quantity, as fee simple for fee simple.

The place where the merchants, brokers, and bankers of a city meet at certain hours, to transact business; also, the institution which sets regulations and maintains the physical facilities of such a place; as, the New York Stock Exchange; a commodity exchange . In this sense the word was at one time often contracted to 'change

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exchanged; p. pr. & vb. n. Exchanging
entry.ety: Cf.OF. eschangier, F. échanger. See Exchange n.

sn.def: To part with give, or transfer to another in consideration of something received as an equivalent; -- usually followed by for before the thing received.
sn.q: Exchange his sheep for shells, or wool for a sparking pebble or a diamond.

sn.def: To part with for a substitute; to lay aside, quit, or resign (something being received in place of the thing parted with); as, to exchange a palace for cell.
sn.q: And death for life exchanged foolishly.
To shift his being Is to exchange one misery with another.

sn.def: To give and receive reciprocally, as things of the same kind; to barter; to swap; as, to exchange horses with a neighbor; to exchange houses or hats.
sn.q: Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.
sn.syn: To barter; change; commute; interchange; bargain; truck; swap; traffic.

entry.def: To be changed or received in exchange for; to pass in exchange; as, dollar exchanges for ten dimes.
The quality or state of being exchangeable.
entry.q: The law ought not be contravened by an express article admitting the exchangeability of such persons.

sn.def: Capable of being exchanged; fit or proper to be exchanged.
sn.q: The officers captured with Burgoyne were exchangeable within the powers of General Howe.

sn.def: Available for making exchanges; ratable.
sn.q: Anexchangeablevalue.

entry.def: By way of exchange.

entries.entry: Ex*change" ed"i*tor. An editor who inspects, and culls from, periodicals, or exchanges, for his own publication.

entry.def: One who exchanges; one who practices exchange.
See Escheat.
See Escheator.

entry.note: ☞ The exchequer was a court of law and equity. In the revenue department, it had jurisdiction over the proprietary rights of the crown against subjects; in the common law department, it administered justice in personal actions between subject and subject. A person proceeding against another in the revenue department was said to exchequer him. The judges of this court were one chief and four puisne barons, so styled. The Court of Exchequer Chamber sat as court of error in which the judgments of each of the superior courts of common law, in England, were subject to revision by the judges of the other two sitting collectively. Causes involving difficult questions of law were sometimes after argument, adjourned into this court from the other courts, for debate before judgment in the court below. Recent legislation in England (1880) has abolished the Court of Exchequer and the Court of Exchequer Chamber, as distinct tribunals, a single board of judiciary, the High Court of Justice, being established for the trial of all classes of civil cases.
entry.cs:
Barons of the exchequer. See under Baron. Chancellor of the exchequer. See under Chancellor.
Exchequer billsorExchequer bonds
Eng bills of money, or promissory bills, issued from the exchequer by authority of Parliament; a species of paper currency emitted under the authority of the government, and bearing interest.
entry.ety: OE. escheker, OF. eichekier, fr. LL. scaccarium. See Checker Chess Check

sn.def: One of the superior courts of law; -- so called from a checkered cloth, which covers, or formerly covered, the table.

The department of state having charge of the collection and management of the royal revenue. Eng Hence, the treasury; and, colloquially, pecuniary possessions in general; as, the company's exchequer is low.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exchequered; p. pr. & vb. n. Exchequering
entry.def: To institute a process against (any one) in the Court of Exchequer.

entry.ety: L. excidere excisum; ex out + caedere to cut. See Concise, and cf. Excise to cut off
entry.def: To cut off.

entry.ety: L. excipients -entis, p. pr. of exipere. See Except v. t.
entry.def: Taking an exception.

sn.def: An exceptor.
An inert or slightly active substance used in preparing remedies as a vehicle or medium of administration for the medicinal agents.

entry.ety: NL. excipulum, fr. L. excipere. See Except
entry.def: The outer part of the fructification of most lichens.
Liable or subject to excise; as, tobacco in an excisable commodity.

entry.ety: Apparently fr. L. excisum cut off, fr. excidere to cut out or off; ex out, off + caedere to cut; or, as the word was formerly written accise, fr. F. accise, LL. accisia, as if fr. L. accidere accisum, to cut into; ad + caedere to cut; but prob. transformed fr. OF. assise, LL. assisa assisia, assize. See Assize Concise

sn.def: In inland duty or impost operating as an indirect tax on the consumer, levied upon certain specified articles, as, tobacco, ale, spirits, etc., grown or manufactured in the country. It is also levied to pursue certain trades and deal in certain commodities. Certain direct taxes (as, in England, those on carriages, servants, plate, armorial bearings, etc.), are included in the excise. Often used adjectively; as, excise duties; excise law; excise system.
sn.q: The English excise system corresponds to the internal revenue system in the United States.
An excise . . . is a fixed, absolute, and direct charge laid on merchandise, products, or commodities.

sn.def: That department or bureau of the public service charged with the collection of the excise taxes.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excised; p. pr. & vb. n. Excising

sn.def: To lay or impose an excise upon.
To impose upon; to overcharge.

entry.def: To cut out or off; to separate and remove; as, to excise a tumor.

entries.entry: Ex*cise"man n.; pl.Excisemen. An officer who inspects and rates articles liable to excise duty.

entry.ety: L. excisio: cf. F. excision. See Excide

sn.def: The act of excising or cutting out or off; extirpation; destruction.
sn.q: Such conquerors are the instruments of vengeance on those nations that have . . . grown ripe for excision.

sn.def: The act of cutting off from the church; excommunication.
The removal, especially of small parts, with a cutting instrument.
The quality of being readily excited; proneness to be affected by exciting causes.
The property manifested by living organisms, and the elements and tissues of which they are constituted, of responding to the action of stimulants; irritability; as, nervous excitability .

entry.ety: L. excitabilis inciting: cf. F. excitable
entry.def: Capable of being excited, or roused into action; susceptible of excitement; easily stirred up, or stimulated.
being easily excited.

entry.ety: L. excitans -antis, p. pr. of excitare: cf. F. excitant
entry.def: Tending to excite; exciting.
An agent or influence which arouses vital activity, or produces increased action, in a living organism or in any of its tissues or parts; a stimulant.

entry.ety: L. excitatus, p. p. of excitare. See Excite
entry.def: To excite.

sn.def: The act of exciting or putting in motion; the act of rousing up or awakening.
The act of producing excitement (stimulation); also, the excitement produced.

entry.def: Having power to excite; tending or serving to excite; excitatory.
A kind of discarder.
Tending to excite; containing excitement; excitative.

entry.usage: To Excite Incite. When we excite we rouse into action feelings which were less strong; when we incite we spur on or urge forward to a specific act or end. Demosthenes excited the passions of the Athenians against Philip, and thus incited the whole nation to unite in the war against him. Antony, by his speech over the body of Cæsar, so excited the feelings of the populace, that Brutus and his companions were compelled to flee from Rome; many however, were incited to join their standard, not only by love of liberty, but hopes of plunder.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excited; p. pr. & vb. n. exciting
entry.ety: L. excitare; ex out + citare to move rapidly, to rouse: cf. OF. esciter exciter, F. exciter. See Cite

sn.def: To call to activity in any way; to rouse to feeling; to kindle to passionate emotion; to stir up to combined or general activity; as, to excite a person, the spirits, the passions; to excite a mutiny or insurrection; to excite heat by friction.
To call forth or increase the vital activity of an organism, or any of its parts.
To energize (an electro-magnet); to produce a magnetic field in; as, to excite a dynamo.

To raise to a higher energy level; -- used especially of atoms or molecules, or of electrons within atoms or molecules; as, absorption of a photon excites the cesium atom, which subsequently radiates the excess energy.
sn.syn: To incite; awaken; animate; rouse or arouse; stimulate; inflame; irritate; provoke.

entry.def: Full of exciting qualities; as, an exciteful story; exciteful players.

sn.def: The act of exciting, or the state of being roused into action, or of having increased action; impulsion; agitation; as, an excitement of the people.
That which excites or rouses; that which moves, stirs, or induces action; a motive.
sn.q: The cares and excitements of a season of transition and struggle.

sn.def: A state of aroused or increased vital activity in an organism, or any of its organs or tissues.

entry.def: One who, or that which, excites.
entry.q: Hope is the grand exciter of industry.

cs.cd: those which immediately produce disease, or those which excite the action of predisposing causes.

entry.def: Calling or rousing into action; producing excitement; as, exciting events; an exciting story.
Serving or tending to excite; excitative.
That which excites; an excitant.
Motion excited by reflex nerves. See Excito-motory.
Excito-motory; as, excito-motor power or causes.

Exciting motion; -- said of that portion of the nervous system concerned in reflex actions, by which impressions are transmitted to a nerve center and then reflected back so as to produce muscular contraction without sensation or volition.
Exciting nutrition; said of the reflex influence by which the nutritional processes are either excited or modified.
Exciting secretion; -- said of the influence exerted by reflex action on the function of secretion, by which the various glands are excited to action.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exclaimed; p. pr. & vb. n. Exclaiming
entry.ety: L. exclamare exclamatum; ex + clamare to cry out; cf. OF. exclamer. See Clam
entry.def: To cry out from earnestness or passion; to utter with vehemence; to call out or declare loudly; to protest vehemently; to vociferate; to shout; as, to exclaim against oppression with wonder or astonishment; “The field is won!” he exclaimed .
Outcry; clamor.
entry.q: Cursing cries and deep exclaims.

entry.def: One who exclaims.

sn.def: A loud calling or crying out; outcry; loud or emphatic utterance; vehement vociferation; clamor; that which is cried out, as an expression of feeling; sudden expression of sound or words indicative of emotion, as in surprise, pain, grief, joy, anger, etc.
sn.q: Exclamations against abuses in the church.
Thus will I drown your exclamations.
A festive exclamation not unsuited to the occasion.

sn.def: A word expressing outcry; an interjection; a word expressing passion, as wonder, fear, or grief.
A mark or sign by which outcry or emphatic utterance is marked; thus [!]; -- called also exclamation point.

entry.def: Exclamatory.
Containing, expressing, or using exclamation; as, an exclamatory phrase or speaker.

entry.note: ☞ The same territory is an enclave in respect to the surrounding country and an exclave with respect to the country to which it is politically attached.
entry.ety: Formed fr. enclave by substitution of ex- for en-
entry.def: A portion of a country which is separated from the main part and surrounded by politically alien territory.

entry.cs: Excluded middle. logic The name given to the third of the “three logical axioms,” so-called, namely, to that one which is expressed by the formula: “Everything is either A or Not-A.” no third state or condition being involved or allowed. See Principle of contradiction, under Contradiction.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excluded; p. pr. & vb. n. Excluding
entry.ety: L. excludere exclusum; ex out + claudere to shut. See Close

sn.def: To shut out; to hinder from entrance or admission; to debar from participation or enjoyment; to deprive of; to except; -- the opposite to admit; as, to exclude a crowd from a room or house; to exclude the light; to exclude one nation from the ports of another; to exclude a taxpayer from the privilege of voting.
sn.q: And none but such, from mercy I exclude.

sn.def: To thrust out or eject; to expel; as, to exclude young animals from the womb or from eggs.

entry.ety: L. exclusio: cf. F. exclusion. See Exclude

sn.def: The act of excluding, or of shutting out, whether by thrusting out or by preventing admission; a debarring; rejection; prohibition; the state of being excluded.
sn.q: His sad exclusion from the doors of bliss.
The exclusion of the duke from the crown of England and Ireland.

sn.def: The act of expelling or ejecting a fetus or an egg from the womb.
Thing emitted.

entry.def: Tending to exclude; causing exclusion; exclusive.
The character, manner, or principles of an exclusionist.
One who would exclude another from some right or privilege; esp., one of the anti-popish politicians of the time of Charles II.

sn.def: Having the power of preventing entrance; debarring from participation or enjoyment; possessed and enjoyed to the exclusion of others; as, exclusive bars; exclusive privilege; exclusive circles of society.
Not taking into the account; excluding from consideration; -- opposed to inclusive; as, five thousand troops, exclusive of artillery.

entry.def: One of a coterie who exclude others; one who from real of affected fastidiousness limits his acquaintance to a select few.
Quality of being exclusive.
The act or practice of excluding being exclusive; exclusiveness.
One who favor or practices any from of exclusiveness or exclusivism.
entry.q: The field of Greek mythology . . . the favorite sporting ground of the exclusivists of the solar theory.

entry.def: Able to exclude; excluding; serving to exclude.

entry.ety: L. excoctus, p. p. of excoquere to excoct. See 3d Cook
entry.def: To boil out; to produce by boiling.

entries.entry:
Ex*coc"tion. L. excoctio
The act of excocting or boiling out. Obs

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excogitated #; p. pr. & vb. n.. Excogitating
entry.ety: L. excogitatus, p. p. of excogitare to excogitate; ex out + cogitare to think. See Cogitate
entry.def: To think out; to find out or discover by thinking; to devise; to contrive.
entry.q: Excogitatestrange arts.
This evidence . . . thus excogitated out of the general theory.

entry.def: To cogitate.
The act of excogitating; a devising in the thoughts; invention; contrivance.
To exclude from participation in; to excommunicate.
entry.q: Poets . . . were excommuned Plato's common wealth

entry.def: Liable or deserving to be excommunicated; making excommunication possible or proper.
entry.q: Personsexcommunicable.
What offenses are excommunicable ?

entry.def: One who has been excommunicated.

entry.ety: L. excommunicatus, p. p. of communicare to excommunicate; ex out + communicare. See Communicate
entry.def: Excommunicated; interdicted from the rites of the church.
entry.q: Thou shalt stand cursed and excommunicate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excommunicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Excommunicating

sn.def: To put out of communion; especially, to cut off, or shut out, from communion with the church, by an ecclesiastical sentence.
To lay under the ban of the church; to interdict.
sn.q: Martin the Fifth . . . was the first that excommunicated the reading of heretical books.

entry.note: ☞ excommunication is of two kinds, the lesser and the greater; the lesser excommunication is a separation or suspension from partaking of the Eucharist; the greater is an absolute execution of the offender from the church and all its rights and advantages, even from social intercourse with the faithful.
entry.def: The act of communicating or ejecting; esp., an ecclesiastical censure whereby the person against whom it is pronounced is, for the time, cast out of the communication of the church; exclusion from fellowship in things spiritual.
One who excommunicates.

entries.entry:
Ex`com*mun"ion. A shutting out from communion; excommunication. Obs
Excommunication is the utmost of ecclesiastical judicature.
Ex*co"ri*a*ble. Capable of being excoriated. The scaly covering of fishes, . . . even in such as are excoriatable.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excoriated; p. pr. & vb. n. excoriating
entry.ety: L. excoriare; ex out + corium hide. cf. Scourge; see Cuirass
entry.def: To strip or wear off the skin of; to abrade; to gall; to break and remove the cuticle of, in any manner, as by rubbing, beating, or by the action of acrid substances.

sn.def: The act of excoriating or flaying, or state of being excoriated, or stripped of the skin; abrasion.
Stripping of possession; spoliation.
sn.q: A pitiful excoriation of the poorer sort.

entry.ety: L. ex out, from + cortex corticis, bark
entry.def: To strip of bark or skin; to decorticate.
entry.q: Excorticatethe tree.

entry.def: The act of stripping off bark, or the state of being thus stripped; decortication.

entry.ety: L. excreabilis exscreabilis, fr. exscreare. See Excreate
entry.def: Capable of being discharged by spitting.

entry.ety: L. excreare exsreare; ex out + screare to hawk
entry.def: To spit out; to discharge from the throat by hawking and spitting.
Act of spitting out.

entry.ety: L. excrementum, fr. excernere excretum, to skin out, discharge: cf. F. excrément. See Excrete
entry.def: Matter excreted and ejected; that which is excreted or cast out of the animal body by any of the natural emunctories; especially, alvine, discharges; dung; ordure.

entry.ety: L. excrementum, fr. excrescere excretum, to grow out. See Excrescence
entry.def: An excrescence or appendage; an outgrowth.
entry.q: Ornamentalexcrements.
Living creatures put forth (after their period of growth) nothing that is young but hair and nails, which are excrements and no parts.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to excrement.
Pertaining to, or consisting of, excrement; of the nature of excrement.
Serving to excrete; connected with excretion or excrement.
entry.q: Theexcrementiveparts.

entry.def: To void excrement.

entry.ety: F. excrescence excroissanse, L. excrescentia excrescences, neut. pl. of p. pr. of excrescere. See Excrescent
entry.def: An excrescent appendage, as, a wart or tumor; anything growing out unnaturally from anything else; a preternatural or morbid development; hence, a troublesome superfluity; an incumbrance; as, an excrescence on the body, or on a plant.
entry.q: Excrescencesof joy.
The excrescences of the Spanish monarchy.

entry.def: Excrescence.

cs.cd: a letter which has been added to a root; as, the d in alderAS. alr) is an excrescent letter.

entry.ety: L. excresens -entis, p. pr. of excrescere to grow out ; ex out + crescere to grow. See Crescent
entry.def: Growing out in an abnormal or morbid manner or as a superfluity.
entry.q: Expunge the whole, or lip the excrescent parts.

entry.def: Pertaining to, or resembling, an excrescence.
Matters to be excreted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excreted; p. pr. & vb. n. Excreting
entry.ety: L. excretus, p. p. of excernere to sift out, discharge; ex out + cernere to sift, separate. See Crisis
entry.def: To separate and throw off; to excrete urine.
entry.q: The mucus thusexcreted.

entry.def: A nonnitrogenous, crystalline body, present in small quantity in human fæces.

sn.def: The act of excreting.
sn.q: To promote secretion and excretion.

sn.def: That which is excreted; excrement.

entry.def: Having the power of excreting, or promoting excretion.
Having the quality of excreting, or throwing off excrementitious matter.
Liable to torment.

entry.ety: L. excruciatus, p. p. of excruciare to excruciate; ex out + cruciare to put to death on a cross, to torment. See Cruciate Cross
entry.def: Excruciated; tortured.
entry.q: And here my heart long time excruciate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excruciated; p. pr. & vb. n. Excruciating
entry.def: To inflict agonizing pain upon; to torture; to torment greatly; to rack; as, to excruciate the heart or the body.
entry.q: Their thoughts, like devils, them excruciate.

entries.entry:
Ex*cru"ci*a`ting
Ex*cru"ci*a`ting*ly adv. . Torturing; racking.
Excruciatingpain. V. Knox.
Excruciatingfears. Bentley

entry.def: The act of inflicting agonizing pain, or the state of being thus afflicted; that which excruciates; torture.

entry.ety: L. excubatio, fr. excubare to lie out on guard; ex out on guard; ex out + cubare to lie down
entry.def: A keeping watch.

entry.ety: LL. excubitorium; ex out + cubare cubitum, to lie
entry.def: A gallery in a church, where persons watched all night.

entries.entry: Ex*cul"pa*ble. Capable of being exculpated; deserving exculpation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exculpated p. pr. & vb. n.. Exculpating�)
entry.ety: L. ex out + culpatus, p. p. of culpare to find fault with, to blame, culpa fault. See Culpable
entry.def: To clear from alleged fault or guilt; to prove to be guiltless; to relieve of blame; to acquit.
entry.q: He exculpated himself from being the author of the heroic epistle.
I exculpate him further for his writing against me.
entry.syn: To exonerate; absolve; clear; acquit; excuse; vindicate; justify.

entry.def: freed from any question of guilt; having suspicion of guilt eliminated.
The act of exculpating from alleged fault or crime; that which exculpates; excuse.
entry.q: These robbers, however, were men who might have made out a strong case in exculpation of themselves.

entries.entry: Ex*cul"pa*to*ry. Clearing, or tending to clear, from alleged fault or guilt; excusing. Anexculpatoryletter.

entry.def: To run out or forth; to extend.

entry.ety: L. excurrens, p. p. of excurrere, excursum, to run out; ex out + currere to run. See Current
entry.sn: Running or flowing out; as: Bot Running or extending out; as, an excurrent midrib, one which projects beyond the apex of a leaf; an excurrent steam or trunk, one which continues to the top.

sn.def: Characterized by a current which flows outward; as, an excurrent orifice or tube.

entry.def: To journey or pass thought.

entries.entry:
Ex*cur"sion. L. excursio: cf. F. excursion. See Excurrent
A running or going out or forth; an expedition; a sally. Far on excursion toward the gates of hell. They would make excursions and waste the country.
A journey chiefly for recreation; a pleasure trip; a brief tour; as, an excursion into the country.
A wandering from a subject; digression. I am not in a scribbling mood, and shall therefore make no excursions.
Mach Length of stroke, as of a piston; stroke. [An awkward use of the word Journey; tour; ramble; jaunt. See Journey.

entry.def: One who goes on an excursion, or pleasure trip.
Prone to make excursions; wandering; roving; exploring; as, an excursive fancy.
entry.q: The course of excursive . . . understandings.

entry.ety: L., fr. excurrere excursum. See Excurrent
entry.def: A dissertation or digression appended to a work, and containing a more extended exposition of some important point or topic.

entry.ety: L. excusabilis: cf. F. excusable. See Excuse
entry.def: That may be excused, forgiven, justified, or acquitted of blame; pardonable; as, the man is excusable; an excusable action.
entry.q: The excusableness of my dissatisfaction.

entry.def: Excuse; apology.
One who makes, or is authorized to make, an excuse; an apologist.
Making or containing excuse or apology; apologetical; as, an excusatory plea.

entry.usage: - To Pardon Excuse Forgive. A superior pardons as an act of mercy or generosity; either a superior or an equal excuses. A crime, great fault, or a grave offence, as one against law or morals, may be pardoned; a small fault, such as a failure in social or conventional obligations, slight omissions or neglects may be excused. Forgive relates to offenses against one's self, and punishment foregone; as, to forgive injuries or one who has injured us; to pardon grave offenses, crimes, and criminals; to excuse an act of forgetfulness, an unintentional offense. Pardon is also a word of courtesy employed in the sense of excuse.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Excused; p. pr. & vb. n. Excusing
entry.ety: OE. escusen cusen, OF. escuser excuser, F. excuser, fr. L. excusare; ex out + causa cause, causari to plead. See Cause

sn.def: To free from accusation, or the imputation of fault or blame; to clear from guilt; to release from a charge; to justify by extenuating a fault; to exculpate; to absolve; to acquit.
sn.q: A man's persuasion that a thing is duty, will not excuse him from guilt in practicing it, if really and indeed it be against Gog's law.

sn.def: To pardon, as a fault; to forgive entirely, or to admit to be little censurable, and to overlook; as, we excuse irregular conduct, when extraordinary circumstances appear to justify it.
sn.q: I must excuse what can not be amended.

sn.def: To regard with indulgence; to view leniently or to overlook; to pardon.
sn.q: And in our own (excuse some courtly stains No whiter page than Addison remains.

sn.def: To free from an impending obligation or duty; hence, to disengage; to dispense with; to release by favor; also, to remit by favor; not to exact; as, to excuse a forfeiture.
sn.q: I pray thee have me excused.

sn.def: To relieve of an imputation by apology or defense; to make apology for as not seriously evil; to ask pardon or indulgence for.
sn.q: Think ye that we excuse ourselves to you?

entry.ety: Cf. F. excuse. See Excuse v. t.

sn.def: The act of excusing, apologizing, exculpating, pardoning, releasing, and the like; acquittal; release; absolution; justification; extenuation.
sn.q: Pleading so wisely in excuse of it.

sn.def: That which is offered as a reason for being excused; a plea offered in extenuation of a fault or irregular deportment; apology; as, an excuse for neglect of duty; excuses for delay of payment.
sn.q: Hence with denial vain and coy excuse.

sn.def: That which excuses; that which extenuates or justifies a fault.
sn.q: It hath theexcuseof youth.
If eyes were made for seeing. Then beauty is its own excuse for being.

entry.def: Having no excuse; not admitting of excuse or apology.
Excuse.

sn.def: One who offers excuses or pleads in extenuation of the fault of another.
One who excuses or forgives another.

entry.ety: L. excussus. p. p. of excutere to shake off; ex out, from + quatere to shake. Cf. Quash

sn.def: To shake off; to discard.
sn.q: To excuss the notation of a Geity out of their minds.

sn.def: To inspect; to investigate; to decipher.
sn.q: To take some pains in excusing some old monuments.

sn.def: To seize and detain by law, as goods.

entry.ety: L. excussio a shaking down; LL., a threshing of corn: cf. F. excussion
entry.def: The act of excusing; seizure by law.

sn.def: A license for absence from a college or a religious house.
A permission which a bishop grants to a priest to go out of his diocese.

entry.ety: L. execrabilis exsecrabilis: cf. F. exécrable. See Execrate
entry.def: Deserving to be execrated; accursed; damnable; detestable; abominable; as, an execrable wretch.
entry.q: Execrablepride.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Execrated; p. pr. & vb. n. Execrating
entry.ety: L. execratus exsecratus, p. p. of execrare exsecrare, to execrate; ex out + sacer holy, sacred. See Sacred
entry.def: To denounce evil against, or to imprecate evil upon; to curse; to protest against as unholy or detestable; hence, to detest utterly; to abhor; to abominate.
entry.q: They . . .execratetheir lct.

entry.ety: L. execratio exsecratio: cf. F. exécration

sn.def: The act of cursing; a curse dictated by violent feelings of hatred; imprecation; utter detestation expressed.
sn.q: Cease, gentle, queen, these execrations.

sn.def: That which is execrated; a detested thing.
sn.q: Ye shall be an execration and . . . a curse.

entry.def: Cursing; imprecatory; vilifying.
A word used for cursing; an imprecatory word or expression.
Of the nature of execration; imprecatory; denunciatory.
To cut off or out. Obs See Exsect.
See Exsection.
Capable of being executed; feasible; as, an executable project.
One who executes or performs; esp., a performer on a musical instrument.
entry.q: Great executants on the organ.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Executed; p. pr. & vb. n. Executing
entry.ety: F. exécuter, L. executus exsecutus, p. p. of exequi to follow to the end, pursue; ex out + sequi to follow. See Second Sue to follow up, and cf. Exequy

sn.def: To follow out or through to the end; to carry out into complete effect; to complete; to finish; to effect; to perform.
sn.q: Why delays His hand to execute what his decree Fixed on this day?

sn.def: To complete, as a legal instrument; to perform what is required to give validity to, as by signing and perhaps sealing and delivering; as, to execute a deed, lease, mortgage, will, etc.
To give effect to; to do what is provided or required by; to perform the requirements or stipulations of; as, to execute a decree, judgment, writ, or process.
To infect capital punishment on; to put to death in conformity to a legal sentence; as, to execute a traitor.
To put to death illegally; to kill.

To perform, as a piece of music or other feat of skill, whether on an instrument or with the voice, or in any other manner requiring physical activity; as, to execute a difficult part brilliantly; to execute a coup; to execute a double play.
sn.syn: To accomplish; effect; fulfill; achieve; consummate; finish; complete. See Accomplish.

sn.def: To do one's work; to act one's part or purpose.
To perform musically.

entry.def: One who performs or carries into effect. See Executor.
putting a condemned person to death.

sn.def: The act of executing; a carrying into effect or to completion; performance; achievement; consummation; as, the execution of a plan, a work, etc.
sn.q: The excellence of the subject contributed much to the happiness of the execution.

sn.def: A putting to death as a legal penalty; death lawfully inflicted; as, the execution of a murderer; to grant a stay of execution .
sn.q: A warrant for his execution.

sn.def: The act of the mode of performing a work of art, of performing on an instrument, of engraving, etc.; as, the execution of a statue, painting, or piece of music.
sn.q: The first quality of execution is truth.

sn.def: The mode of performing any activity; as, the game plan was excellent, but its execution was filled with mistakes.

sd.def: The carrying into effect the judgment given in a court of law.
A judicial writ by which an officer is empowered to carry a judgment into effect; final process.
The act of signing, and delivering a legal instrument, or giving it the forms required to render it valid; as, the execution of a deed, or a will.

sn.def: That which is executed or accomplished; effect; effective work; -- usually with do.
sn.q: To do some fatal execution.

sn.def: The act of sacking a town.
One who executes; an executer.
One who puts to death in conformity to legal warrant, as a hangman.

entry.note: ☞ In government, executive is distinguished from legislative and judicial; legislative being applied to the organ or organs of government which make the laws; judicial, to that which interprets and applies the laws; executive, to that which carries them into effect or secures their due performance.

sn.def: Designed or fitted for execution, or carrying into effect; as, executive talent; qualifying for, concerned with, or pertaining to, the execution of the laws or the conduct of affairs; as, executive power or authority; executive duties, officer, department, etc.
of or pertaining to an executive{2} or to the group of executives within an organization; as, executive compensation increased more rapidly than wages in the 1980's; the executive suite.
An impersonal title of the chief magistrate or officer who administers the government, whether king, president, or governor; the governing person or body.

a person who has administrative authority over an organization or division of an organization; a manager, supervisor or administrator at a high level within an organization; as, all executives of the company were given stock options

entry.def: In the way of executing or performing.

cs.ety: Of., executor of his own wrong
cs.cd: a stranger who intermeddles without authority in the distribution of the estate of a deceased person.

entry.ety: L. executor exsecutor: cf. F. exécuteur. Cf. Executer

sn.def: One who executes or performs; a doer; as, an executor of baseness.
An executioner.
sn.q: Delivering o'er to executors paw� The lazy, yawning drone.

sn.def: The person appointed by a testator to execute his will, or to see its provisions carried into effect, after his decease.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an executive.
The office of an executor.

entry.ety: LL. executorius, L. exsecutorius: cf.F. exécutoire

sn.def: Pertaining to administration, or putting the laws in force; executive.
sn.q: The official and executory duties of government.

sn.def: Designed to be executed or carried into effect in time to come, or to take effect on a future contingency; as, an executory devise, reminder, or estate; an executory contract.

entry.def: An executrix.
A woman exercising the functions of an executor.

entry.ety: L. exedent -entis, p. pr. of exedere. See Exesion
entry.def: Eating out; consuming.

entries.entry:
Ex"e*dra Ex"e*dra ĕks"�*drȧ n.; pl.Exedræ ĕks"�*drē. L., fr. Gr 'exe`dra; 'ex out + "e`dra seat
Class. Antiq A room in a public building, furnished with seats.
Arch
The projection of any part of a building in a rounded form.
Any out-of-door seat in stone, large enough for several persons; esp., one of curved form.

sn.def: clarifying by use of examples.

entries.entry:
Ex`e*ge"sis n.; pl.Exegeses #. NL., fr.Gr. �,fr. � to explain, interpret; � out + � to guide, lead, akin, to � to lead. See Agent
Exposition; explanation; especially, a critical explanation of a text or portion of Scripture.
Math The process of finding the roots of an equation. Obs

entry.def: An exegetist.
Pertaining to exegesis; tending to unfold or illustrate; explanatory; expository.
The science of interpretation or exegesis.
One versed in the science of exegesis or interpretation; -- also called exegete.

entry.ety: L. exemplar exemplum: cf. F. exemplaire. See Example, and cf. Examper Sampler

sn.def: A model, original, or pattern, to be copied or imitated; a specimen; sometimes; an ideal model or type, as that which an artist conceives.
sn.q: Such grand exemplar as make their own abilities the sole measure of what is fit or unfit.

sn.def: A copy of a book or writing.

entry.def: Exemplary.
entry.q: The exemplar piety of the father of a family.

entry.def: In a manner fitted or designed to be an example for imitation or for warning; by way of example.
entry.q: She is exemplarily loyal.
Some he punisheth exemplarily.

entry.def: The state or quality of being exemplary; fitness to be an example.
Exemplariness.
entry.q: The exemplarity of Christ's life.

entry.cs: Exemplary damages. Law See under Damage.
entry.ety: L. exemplaris, fr. exemplar: cf. F. exemplaire. See Exemplar

sn.def: Serving as a pattern; deserving to be proposed for imitation; commendable; as, an exemplary person; exemplary conduct.
sn.q: Bishops'] lives and doctrines ought to be exemplary.

sn.def: Serving as a warning; monitory; as, exemplary justice, punishment, or damages.
Illustrating as the proof of a thing.

entry.def: An exemplar; also, a copy of a book or writing.
That can be exemplified.

sn.def: The act of exemplifying; a showing or illustrating by example.
That which exemplifies; a case in point; example.
A copy or transcript attested to be correct by the seal of an officer having custody of the original.

entry.def: One who exemplifies by following a pattern.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exemplified; p. pr. & vb. n. Exemplifying
entry.ety: L. exemplum example + -fy: cf. LL. exemplificare to copy, serve as an example

sn.def: To show or illustrate by example.
sn.q: He did but . . . exemplify the principles in which he had been brought up.

sn.def: To copy; to transcribe; to make an attested copy or transcript of, under seal, as of a record.
To prove or show by an attested copy.

entry.ety: F. exempt, L. exemptus, p. p. of eximere to take out, remove, free; ex out + emere to buy, take. Cf. Exon Redeem

sn.def: Cut off; set apart.
sn.q: Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry.

sn.def: Extraordinary; exceptional.

Free, or released, from some liability to which others are subject; excepted from the operation or burden of some law; released; free; clear; privileged; -- (with from): not subject to; not liable to; as, goods exempt from execution; a person exempt from jury service.
sn.q: True nobility is exempt from fear.
T is laid on all, not any one exempt.

sn.def: One exempted or freed from duty; one not subject.
One of four officers of the Yeomen of the Royal Guard, having the rank of corporal; an Exon.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exempted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exempting

sn.def: To remove; to set apart.

To release or deliver from some liability which others are subject to; to except or excuse from he operation of a law; to grant immunity to; to free from obligation; to release; as, to exempt from military duty, or from jury service; to exempt from fear or pain.
sn.q: Death So snatched will not exempt us from the pain We are by doom to pay.

entry.def: That may be exempted.

entry.ety: L. exemptio a removing: cf. F. exemption exemption
entry.def: The act of exempting; the state of being exempt; freedom from any charge, burden, evil, etc., to which others are subject; immunity; privilege; as, exemption of certain articles from seizure; exemption from military service; exemption from anxiety, suffering, etc.
Separable.
entry.q: Exemptitiousfrom matter.

entry.ety: L. exenteratus, p. p. of exenterare; cf. Gr. �; � out + � intestine
entry.def: To take out the bowels or entrails of; to disembowel; to eviscerate; as, exenterated fishes.
entry.q: Exenterated rule-mongers and eviscerated logicians.

entry.def: Act of exenterating.

entry.ety: L., 3d pers. sing. pres. subj. of exequi exsequi, to perform, execute

sn.def: A written official recognition of a consul or commercial agent, issued by the government to which he is accredited, and authorizing him to exercise his powers in the place to which he is assigned.
Official recognition or permission.

entry.ety: L. exequialis exsequialis, fr. exsequiae exequies
entry.def: Of or pertaining to funerals; funereal.
Funereal.

entries.entry:
Ex"e*quy n.; pl.Exequies #. L. exequiae exsequiae, a funeral procession, fr. exsequi to follow out: cf. OF. exeques. See Exequte
A funeral rite (usually in the plural); the ceremonies of burial; obsequies; funeral procession. But see his exequies fulfilled in Rouen.

entry.ety: L. exercents -entis, p. pr. of exercere. See Exercise
entry.def: Practicing; professional.
entry.q: Everyexercentadvocate.

entry.def: That may be exercised, used, or exerted; as, the stock options are exercisable for only five years from the date of issue.

cs.cd: a deposit of bony matter in the soft tissues, produced by pressure or exertion.

entry.ety: F. exercice, L. exercitium, from exercere exercitum, to drive on, keep, busy, prob. orig., to thrust or drive out of the inclosure; ex out + arcere to shut up, inclose. See Ark

sn.def: The act of exercising; a setting in action or practicing; employment in the proper mode of activity; exertion; application; use; habitual activity; occupation, in general; practice.
sn.q: exercise of the important function confided by the constitution to the legislature.
O we will walk this world, Yoked in all exercise of noble end.

sn.def: Exertion for the sake of training or improvement whether physical, intellectual, or moral; practice to acquire skill, knowledge, virtue, perfectness, grace, etc.
sn.q: Desire of knightlyexercise.
An exercise of the eyes and memory.

sn.def: Bodily exertion for the sake of keeping the organs and functions in a healthy state; hygienic activity; as, to take exercise on horseback; to exercise on a treadmill or in a gym.
sn.q: The wise for cure on exercise depend.

sn.def: The performance of an office, a ceremony, or a religious duty.
sn.q: Lewis refused even those of the church of England . . . the public exercise of their religion.
To draw him from his holy exercise.

sn.def: That which is done for the sake of exercising, practicing, training, or promoting skill, health, mental, improvement, moral discipline, etc.; that which is assigned or prescribed for such ends; hence, a disquisition; a lesson; a task; as, military or naval exercises; musical exercises; an exercise in composition; arithmetic exercises.
sn.q: The clumsy exercises of the European tourney.
He seems to have taken a degree, and performed public exercises in Cambridge, in 1565.

sn.def: That which gives practice; a trial; a test.
sn.q: Patience is more oft the exercise Of saints, the trial of their fortitude.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exercised; p. pr. & vb. n. Exercising

sn.def: To set in action; to cause to act, move, or make exertion; to give employment to; to put in action habitually or constantly; to school or train; to exert repeatedly; to busy.
sn.q: Herein do I Exercise myself, to have always a conscience void of offence.

sn.def: To exert for the sake of training or improvement; to practice in order to develop; hence, also, to improve by practice; to discipline, and to use or to for the purpose of training; as, to exercise arms; to exercise one's self in music; to exercise troops.
sn.q: About him exercised heroic games The unarmed youth.

sn.def: To occupy the attention and effort of; to task; to tax, especially in a painful or vexatious manner; harass; to vex; to worry or make anxious; to affect; to discipline; as, exercised with pain.
sn.q: Where pain of unextinguishable fire Must exercise us without hope of end.

sn.def: To put in practice; to carry out in action; to perform the duties of; to use; to employ; to practice; as, to exercise authority; to exercise an office.
sn.q: I am the Lord which exercise loving-kindness, judgment, and righteousness in the earth.
The people of the land have used oppression and exercised robbery.

entry.def: To exercise one's self, as under military training; to drill; to take exercise; to use action or exertion; to practice gymnastics; as, to exercise for health or amusement.
entry.q: I wear my trusty sword, When I do exercise.

sn.def: One who exercises.
one who supervises the exercise of animals, such as horses or dogs.
a device used for exercising muscles; as, a thigh exerciser .

entry.def: Capable of being exercised, employed, or enforced; as, the authority of a magistrate is exercisible within his jurisdiction.

entry.ety: L. exercitatio, fr. exercitare, intense., fr. exercere to exercise: Cf. f. exercitation
entry.def: exercise; practice; use.
a stationary bike for exercising.

entry.ety: F., fr. Gr. � out + � work; lit., out work, i. e., accessory work. See Work
entry.def: The small space beneath the base line of a subject engraved on a coin or medal. It usually contains the date, place, engraver's name, etc., or other subsidiary matter.

cs.cd: to use efforts or endeavors; to strive; to make an attempt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exerted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exerting
entry.ety: L. exertus exsertus, p. p. of exerere exserere, to thrust out; ex out + serere to join or bind together. See Series, and cf. Exsert

sn.def: To thrust forth; to emit; to push out.
sn.q: So from the seas exerts his radiant head The star by whom the lights of heaven are led.

sn.def: To put force, ability, or anything of the nature of an active faculty; to put in vigorous action; to bring into active operation; as, to exert the strength of the body, limbs, faculties, or imagination; to exert the mind or the voice.
To put forth, as the result or exercise of effort; to bring to bear; to do or perform.
sn.q: When we will has exerted an act of command on any faculty of the soul or member of the body.

entry.def: The act of exerting, or putting into motion or action; the active exercise of any power or faculty; an effort, esp. a laborious or perceptible effort; as, an exertion of strength or power; an exertion of the limbs or of the mind; it is an exertion for him to move, to-day.
entry.syn: Attempt; endeavor; effort; essay; trial. See Attempt.

entry.def: Having power or a tendency to exert; using exertion.
Exertion.

entry.ety: L. exedere exesum, to eat up; ex out + edere to eat
entry.def: The act of eating out or through.

entry.ety: L. exaestuatus,p. p. of exaestuare to boil up. See Estuate
entry.def: To be agitated; to boil up; to effervesce.
A boiling up; effervescence.

entries.entry: Ex"e*unt Ex"e*unt. L., 3d pers. pl. pres. of exire to go out They go out, or retire from the scene; as, exeunt all except Hamlet. See 1st Exit.

entry.def: Imperfect fetation in some organ exterior to the uterus; extra-uterine fetation.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exfoliated; p. pr. & vb. n. Exfoliating
entry.ety: L. exfoliare to strip of leaves; ex out, from + folium leaf

sn.def: To separate and come off in scales or laminæ, as pieces of carious bone or of bark.
To split into scales, especially to become converted into scales at the result of heat or decomposition.

entry.def: To remove scales, laminæ, or splinters from the surface of.
The scaling off of a bone, a rock, or a mineral, etc.; the state of being exfoliated.
Having the power of causing exfoliation.
a former gambler.
Capable of being exhaled or evaporated.
Having the quality of exhaling or evaporating.

entry.ety: L. exhalatio: cf. F. exhalaison exhalation

sn.def: The act or process of exhaling, or sending forth in the form of steam or vapor; evaporation.
That which is exhaled, or which rises in the form of vapor, fume, or steam; effluvium; emanation; as, exhalations from the earth or flowers, decaying matter, etc.
sn.q: Ye mists and exhalations, that now rise From hill or steaming lake.

sn.def: A bright phenomenon; a meteor.
sn.q: I shall fall Like a bright exhalation in the evening.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exaled p. pr. & vb. n.. Exaling
entry.ety: L. exhalare; ex out + halare to breathe; cf.F. exhaler. Cf. Inhale

sn.def: To breathe out. Hence: To emit, as vapor; to send out, as an odor; to evaporate; as, the earth exhales vapor; marshes exhale noxious effluvia.
sn.q: Less fragrant scents the unfolding rose exhales.

sn.def: To draw out; to cause to be emitted in vapor; as, the sun exhales the moisture of the earth.

entry.def: To rise or be given off, as vapor; to pass off, or vanish.
entry.q: Their inspiration exhaled in elegies.

entry.def: Exhalation.
Exhalation.
breathing out; exhalation{1}.

entry.cs: Exhausted receiver. Physics See under Receiver.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exhausted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exhausting
entry.ety: L. exhaustus, p. p. of exhaurire; ex out + haurire haustum, to draw, esp. water; perhaps akin to Icel. asua to sprinkle, pump

sn.def: To draw or let out wholly; to drain off completely; as, to exhaust the water of a well; the moisture of the earth is exhausted by evaporation.
To empty by drawing or letting out the contents; as, to exhaust a well, or a treasury.

To drain, metaphorically; to use or expend wholly, or till the supply comes to an end; to deprive wholly of strength; to use up; to weary or tire out; to wear out; as, to exhaust one's strength, patience, or resources.
sn.q: A decrepit, exhausted old man at fifty-five.

sn.def: To bring out or develop completely; to discuss thoroughly; as, to exhaust a subject.
To subject to the action of various solvents in order to remove all soluble substances or extractives; as, to exhaust a drug successively with water, alcohol, and ether.
sn.syn: To spend; consume; tire out; weary.

cs.cd: a forced draught produced by drawing air through a place, as through a furnace, instead of blowing it through.
a fan blower so arranged as to produce an exhaust draught, or to draw air or gas out of a place, as out of a room in ventilating it.
the blast orifice or nozzle.
the pipe that conveys exhaust steam from the cylinder to the atmosphere or to the condenser.
the opening, in the cylinder or valve, by which the exhaust steam escapes.
a machine for sorting grains, or purifying middlings by an exhaust draught.
steam which is allowed to escape from the cylinder after having been employed to produce motion of the piston.
a valve that lets exhaust steam escape out of a cylinder.

sn.def: Drained; exhausted; having expended or lost its energy.
Pertaining to steam, air, gas, etc., that is released from the cylinder of an engine after having preformed its work.
The steam let out of a cylinder after it has done its work there.
The foul air let out of a room through a register or pipe provided for the purpose.
same as burned-out, 1.
sn.syn: burned-out(prenominal), burnt-out(prenominal), burned out(predicate), burnt out(predicate), fagged, fatigued, played-out(prenominal), played out(predicate), spent, washed-out(prenominal), washed out(predicate), worn-out(prenominal), worn out(predicate).

sn.def: emptied by being pumped out or having a vacuum created. Opposite of unexhausted.

entry.def: One who, or that which, exhausts or draws out.
Capability of being exhausted.
entry.q: I was seriously tormented by the thought of the exhaustibility of musical combinations.

entry.def: Capable of being exhausted, drained off, or expended. Opposite of inexhaustible.
Producing exhaustion; as, exhausting labors.

entry.note: ☞ The method of exhaustions was applied to great variety of propositions, pertaining to rectifications and quadratures, now investigated by the calculus.

sn.def: The act of draining out or draining off; the act of emptying completely of the contents.
The state of being exhausted or emptied; the state of being deprived of strength or spirits.
An ancient geometrical method in which an exhaustive process was employed. It was nearly equivalent to the modern method of limits.

entry.def: Serving or tending to exhaust; exhibiting all the facts or arguments; as, an exhaustive method .
Not be exhausted; inexhaustible; as, an exhaustless fund or store.
Exhaustion; drain.
Exhaustion.
See Exedra.

entry.ety: L., exheredatus, p. p. of exheredare to disinherit; ex out + heres heredis, heir
entry.def: To disinherit.
A disinheriting; disherison.
A disinheriting; disherison.

cs.col: To exhibit a foundation or prize
cs.cd: to hold it forth or to tender it as a bounty to candidates.
to declaim or otherwise present it in public.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exhibited; p. pr. & vb. n. Exhibiting
entry.ety: L. exhibitus, p. p. of exhibere to hold forth, to tender, exhibit; ex out + habere to have or hold. See Habit

sn.def: To hold forth or present to view; to produce publicly, for inspection; to show, especially in order to attract notice to what is interesting; to display; as, to exhibit commodities in a warehouse, a picture in a gallery.
sn.q: Exhibiting a miserable example of the weakness of mind and body.

sn.def: To submit, as a document, to a court or officer, in course of proceedings; also, to present or offer officially or in legal form; to bring, as a charge.
sn.q: He suffered his attorney-general to exhibit a charge of high treason against the earl.

sn.def: To administer as a remedy; as, to exhibit calomel.
Any article, or collection of articles, displayed to view, as in an industrial exhibition; a display; as, this exhibit was marked A; the English exhibit.
A document produced and identified in court for future use as evidence.

entry.def: One who exhibits; one who presents a petition, charge or bill.

entry.ety: L. exhibitio a delivering: cf. F. exhibition

sn.def: The act of exhibiting for inspection, or of holding forth to view; manifestation; display.

That which is exhibited, held forth, or displayed; also, any public show; a display of works of art, or of feats of skill, or of oratorical or dramatic ability; as, an exhibition of animals; an exhibition of pictures, statues, etc.; an industrial exhibition.
Sustenance; maintenance; allowance, esp. for meat and drink; pension.
Private benefaction for the maintenance of scholars.
sn.q: What maintenance he from his friends receives, Like exhibition thou shalt have from me.
I have given more exhibitions to scholars, in my days, than to the priests.

sn.def: The act of administering a remedy.

entry.def: One who has a pension or allowance granted for support.
entry.q: A youth who had as an exhibitioner from Christ's Hospital.

sn.def: a person with a compulsive desire to expose the genitals; -- usually a male.
someone who deliberately behaves in such a way as to attract attention.
compulsively attracting attention to oneself especially by boasting or exaggerated behavior.

entry.def: Serving for exhibition; representative; exhibitory.
One who exhibits.

entry.ety: L. exhibitorius relating to giving up: cf. F. exhibitoire exhibiting
entry.def: Exhibiting; publicly showing.

entry.ety: L. exhilarans. -antis, p. pr. See Exhilarate
entry.def: Exciting joy, mirth, or pleasure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exhilarated; p. pr. & vb. n. Exilarating
entry.ety: L. exhilaratus, p. p. of exhilarare to gladden; ex out + hilarare to make merry, hilaris merry, cheerful. See Hilarious
entry.def: To make merry or jolly; to enliven; to animate; to gladden greatly; to cheer; as, good news exhilarates the mind; wine exhilarates a man.
To become joyous.
elated, in high spirits, and envigorated. Opposite of dejected.
That exhilarates; cheering; gladdening.

sn.def: The act of enlivening the spirits; the act of making glad or cheerful; a gladdening.
The state of being enlivened or cheerful.
sn.q: Exhilaration hath some affinity with joy, though it be a much lighter motion.
sn.syn: Animation; joyousness; gladness; cheerfulness; gayety; hilarity; merriment; jollity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exhorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exhorting
entry.ety: L. exhortari; ex out + hortari to incite, encourage; cf. F. exhorter. See Hortative
entry.def: To incite by words or advice; to animate or urge by arguments, as to a good deed or laudable conduct; to address exhortation to; to urge strongly; hence, to advise, warn, or caution.
entry.q: Examples gross as earth exhort me.
Let me exhort you to take care of yourself.

entry.def: To deliver exhortation; to use words or arguments to incite to good deeds.
entry.q: With many other words did he testify and exhort.

entry.def: Exhortation.

sn.def: The act of practice of exhorting; the act of inciting to laudable deeds; incitement to that which is good or commendable.
Language intended to incite and encourage; advice; counsel; admonition.
sn.q: I'll end my exhortation after dinner.

entry.def: Serving to exhort; exhortatory; hortative.
Of or pertaining to exhortation; hortatory.
One who exhorts or incites.
Disinterred.
The act of exhuming that which has been buried; as, the exhumation of a body.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exhumed p. pr. & vb. n.. Exhuming
entry.ety: LL. exhumare; L. ex out + humus ground, soil: cf. F. exhumer. See Humble
entry.def: To dig out of the ground; to take out of a place of burial; to disinter.
See Exsiccate.
See Exsiccation.
Exigency.

entries.entry:
Ex"i*gen*cy n.; pl.Exigencies #. LL. exigentia: cf. F. exigence
The state of being exigent; urgent or exacting want; pressing necessity or distress; need; a case demanding immediate action, supply, or remedy; as, an unforeseen exigency . The presentexigencyof his affairs. Demand; urgency; distress; pressure; emergency; necessity; crisis.

entry.def: See Exigenter.

entry.ety: L. exigens -entis, p. pr. of exigere to drive out or forth, require, exact. See Exact
entry.def: Exacting or requiring immediate aid or action; pressing; critical.
entry.q: At thisexigentmoment.

sn.def: Exigency; pressing necessity; decisive moment.
sn.q: Why do you cross me in this exigent?

sn.def: The name of a writ in proceedings before outlawry.

entry.def: An officer in the Court of King's Bench and Common Pleas whose duty it was to make out exigents. The office is now abolished.
That may be exacted; repairable.

entry.ety: L. exiguitas, fr. exiguus small: cf. F. exiguité
entry.def: Scantiness; smallness; thinness.
Scanty; small; slender; diminutive.
entry.q: Exiguousresources.

entry.ety: OE. exil, fr. L. exilium exsilium, fr. exsuil one who quits, or is banished from, his native soil; ex out + solum ground, land, soil, or perh. fr.the root of salire to leap, spring; cf. F. exil. Cf. Sole of the foot, Saltation

sn.def: Forced separation from one's native country; expulsion from one's home by the civil authority; banishment; sometimes, voluntary separation from one's native country.
sn.q: Let them be recalled from their exile.

sn.def: The person expelled from his country by authority; also, one who separates himself from his home.
sn.q: Thou art in exile, and thou must not stay.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exiled; p. pr. & vb. n. Exiling
entry.def: To banish or expel from one's own country or home; to drive away.
entry.q: Exiledfrom eternal God.
Calling home our exiled friends abroad.

entry.def: Small; slender; thin; fine.
entry.q: Anexilesound.

entry.def: Banishment.
Pertaining to exile or banishment, esp. to that of the Jews in Babylon.

entry.ety: L. exsilire to spring from; ex out + salire to spring, leap
entry.def: A sudden springing or leaping out.

entry.ety: L. exilitas: cf. F. exilité. See Exile a.
entry.def: Smallness; meagerness; slenderness; fineness, thinness.

entry.ety: L. eximius taken out, i. e. select, fr. eximere to take out. See Exempt
entry.def: Select; choice; hence, extraordinary, excellent.
entry.q: The eximious and arcane science of physic.

entry.ety: L. exinanitus, p. p. of exinanire; ex out (intens.) + inanire to make empty, inanis, empty
entry.def: To make empty; to render of no effect; to humble.
An emptying; an enfeebling; exhaustion; humiliation.
entry.q: Fastings to the exinanition of spirits.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Existed; p. pr. & vb. n. Existing
entry.ety: L. existere exsistere, to step out or forth, emerge, appear, exist; ex out + sistere to cause to stand, to set, put, place, stand still, fr. stare to stand: cf. F. exister. See Stand

sn.def: To be as a fact and not as a mode; to have an actual or real being, whether material or spiritual.
sn.q: Who now, alas! no more is missed Than if he never did exist.
To conceive the world . . . to have existed from eternity.

sn.def: To be manifest in any manner; to continue to be; as, great evils existed in his reign.
To live; to have life or the functions of vitality; as, men can not exist in water, nor fishes on land.
The state of existing or being; actual possession of being; continuance in being; as, the existence of body and of soul in union; the separate existence of the soul; immortal existence.
sn.q: The main object of our existence.

sn.def: Continued or repeated manifestation; occurrence, as of events of any kind; as, the existence of a calamity or of a state of war.
sn.q: The existence therefore, of a phenomenon, is but another word for its being perceived, or for the inferred possibility of perceiving it.

sn.def: That which exists; a being; a creature; an entity; as, living existences .

entry.def: Existence.

entry.ety: L. existens -entis, p. pr. of existere. See Exist
entry.def: Having being or existence; existing; being; occurring now; taking place.
entry.q: The eyes and mind are fastened on objects which have no real being, as if they were truly existent.

sn.def: Having existence.
of or pertaining to, or having the character of, existentialism.
specifying actual existence, rather than only possibility; as, the existential operator.
sn.q: Existentially as well as essentially intelligent.

entry.def: a philosophical theory or attitude having various interpretations, generally emphasising the existence of the individual as a unique agent with free will and responsibility for his or her own acts, though living in a universe devoid of any certain knowledge of right and wrong; from one's plight as a free agent with uncertain guidelines may arise feelings of anguish. Existentialism is concerned more with concrete existence rather than abstract theories of essences; is contrasted with rationalism and empiricism; and is associated with Kierkegaard Heidegger and Sartre, as well as others.
One who exists.
Capable of existence.

entry.ety: L. existimatio judgment, opinion, fr. existimare to estimate. See Estimate
entry.def: Esteem; opinion; reputation.

entry.sn: having existence or being or actuality; as, much of the beluga caviar existing in the world is found in the Soviet Union and Iran. Opposite of nonexistent.Narrower terms: active, alive; extant, surviving Also See: extant. existent.

sn.def: Present. Opposite of absent.
Presently existing; as, the existing system.

entries.entry:
Ex"it Ex"it ☞ The Latin words exithe or she goes out), and exeuntthey go out), are used in dramatic writings to indicate the time of withdrawal from the stage of one or more of the actors.. L., 3d pers. sing. pres. of exire to go out. See Exeunt Issue
He (or she ) goes out, or retires from view; as, exit Macbeth.

sn.def: The departure of a player from the stage, when he has performed his part.
sn.q: They have their exits and their entrances.

sn.def: Any departure; the act of quitting the stage of action or of life; death; as, to make one's exit .
sn.q: Sighs for his exit, vulgarly called death.

sn.def: A way of departure; passage out of a place; egress; way out.
sn.q: Forcing the water forth through its ordinary exits.

entry.ety: L. exitialis exitious, fr. exitium a going out, a going to naught, i. e., ruin, fr.exire to go out: cf. F. exitial
entry.def: Destructive; fatal.
entry.q: Exitialfevers.

entries.entry: ex"it poll`. a survey poll taken by interviewing voters as they leave (exit) the polling place, to determine how they voted and for what reasons; -- it is usually taken by news media to learn at an early time (often before the balloting has finished) who the winners are, and sometimes the reasons for the voters' choices.
Ex` li"bris Ex` li"bris. L. ex from + libris books An inscription, label, or the like, in a book indicating its ownership; esp., a bookplate.

entry.def: a former mayor.

entry.ety: From Exmoor, a district in Somersetshire and Devonshire

sn.def: One of a breed of horned sheep of Devonshire, England, having white legs and face and black nostrils. They are esp. valuable for mutton.
A breed of ponies native to the Exmoor district.

entries.entry:
Ex"o-. Gr. � out of, outside, fr. � out. See Ex-
A prefix signifying out of outside; as in exocarp, exogen, exoskeleton.

entry.def: Situated or arising outside of the heart; as, exocardial murmurs; -- opposed to endocardiac.
The outer portion of a fruit, as the flesh of a peach or the rind of an orange. See Illust. of Drupe.
Pertaining to a bone or region on each side of the great foremen of the skull.

def2.def: The exoccipital bone, which often forms a part of the occipital in the adult, but is usually distinct in the young.

entry.ety: NL. exocetus, L. exocoetus a fish that sleeps on the shore, Gr. 'exw`koitos, lit., sleeping out; 'e`xw outside of + koi`th bed
entry.def: A genus of fishes, including the common flying fishes. See Flying fish.

entry.ety: L. exoculatus, p. p. of exoculare to exoculate; ex out + oculus an eye
entry.def: To deprive of eyes.

entry.ety: L. exodium, Gr. � (sc. � song) fr. � belonging to an exit, or to the finale of a tragedy, fr. �: cf. F. exode. See Exodus

sn.def: Departure; exodus; esp., the exodus of the Israelites from Egypt.
The final chorus; the catastrophe.
An afterpiece of a comic description, either a farce or a travesty.

entry.ety: Gr. � belonging to departure. See Exodus
entry.def: Conducting influences from the spinal cord outward; -- said of the motor or efferent nerves. Opposed to esodic.
the branch of dentistry dealing with extraction of teeth.
a dentist specializing in the extraction of teeth.

sn.def: by virtue of an office or position.
sn.illu: the head of the department served as an ex-officio member of the board

entry.def: same as exogenous.
See Exode.

entry.ety: L., the book of Exodus, Gr. � a going or marching out; � out + � way, cf. Skr. ā-sad to approach

sn.def: A going out; particularly (the Exodus), the going out or journey of the Israelites from Egypt under the conduct of Moses; and hence, any large migration from a place.
The second of the Old Testament, which contains the narrative of the departure of the Israelites from Egypt.

entry.def: Exodus; withdrawal.
entry.q: The time of the Jewish exody.

entry.def: Proceeding from office or authority.

entries.entry: Ex` of*fi"ci*o Ex` of*fi"ci*o; pl.Ex officiis #. L From office; by virtue, or as a consequence, of an office; officially.

entry.def: Relating to exogamy; marrying outside of the limits of one's own tribe; -- opposed to endogenous.
The custom, or tribal law, which prohibits marriage between members of the same tribe; marriage outside of the tribe; -- opposed to endogamy.

A plant belonging to one of the greater part of the vegetable kingdom, and which the plants are characterized by having c wood bark, and pith, the wood forming a layer between the other two, and increasing, if at all, by the animal addition of a new layer to the outside next to the bark. The leaves are commonly netted-veined, and the number of cotyledons is two, or, very rarely, several in a whorl. Cf. Endogen.
Arising or growing from without; exogenous.

cs.cd: an aneurism which is produced by causes acting from without, as from injury.

sn.def: derived from or originating outside; pertaining to, or having the character of, an exogen; -- the opposite of endogenous.
Growing by addition to the exterior; growing by addition of a new external layer of cells on the surface just beneath the bark; -- of plants.
Growing from previously ossified parts; -- opposed to autogenous.
caused by factors from outside the body, rather than from an abnormality of internal functions; -- of illness.
not synthesized within the organism; absorbed or assimilated from outside the organism.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. � out, outside + � circle
entry.def: A genus of Cretaceous fossil shells allied to oysters.

entry.ety: L. exoletus, p. p. of exolescere to grow out, grow out of use; ex out + olescere to grow
entry.def: Obsolete; out of use; state; insipid.

entry.ety: L. exolutio a release. See Exolve
entry.def: See Exsolution.

entry.ety: L. exolvere exsolutum; ex out + solvere
entry.def: To loose; to pay.

entry.ety: NL., from E. ExeCelt. uisge water) the name of a river
entry.def: A native or inhabitant of Exeter, in England.
An officer of the Yeomen of the Guard; an Exempt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exonerated; p. pr. & vb. n. Exonerating
entry.ety: L. exoneratus, p. p. of exonerare to free from a burden; ex out, from onerare to load, onus load. See Onerous

sn.def: To unload; to disburden; to discharge.
sn.q: All exonerate themselves into one common duct.

sn.def: To relieve, in a moral sense, as of a charge, obligation, or load of blame resting on one; to clear of something that lies upon oppresses one, as an accusation or imputation; as, to exonerate one's self from blame, or from the charge of avarice.
To discharge from duty or obligation, as a bail.
sn.syn: To absolve; acquit; exculpate. See Absolve.

entry.def: same as exculpated.
The act of disburdening, discharging, or freeing morally from a charge or imputation; also, the state of being disburdened or freed from a charge.
Freeing from a burden or obligation; tending to exonerate.
One who exonerates or frees from obligation.

entry.ety: Nl.,fr. Gr. � with prominent eyes; � out + � the eye
