entry.def: The protrusion of the eyeball so that the eyelids will not cover it, in consequence of disease.

entry.cs: Exophthalmic golter. Same as Rasedow's disease.
entry.def: Of or pertaining to, or characterized by, exophthalmia.
Same as Exophthalmia.
Exophthalmia.
Not sheathed in another leaf.

entry.ety: Exo- + Gr. � from, fr. � to mold
entry.def: See Ectosarc, and Ectoplasm.
The external branch of the appendages of Crustacea.
Very desirable.
A name given by Lestiboudois to dicotyledons; -- so called because the plumule is naked.

entry.ety: L. exorabilis: cf. F. exorable. See Exorate
entry.def: Capable of being moved by entreaty; pitiful; tender.

entry.ety: L. exoratus, p. p. of exorare to gain by entreaty; ex out, from + orare to pay
entry.def: To persuade, or to gain, by entreaty.
Entreaty.

A going out of or beyond the usual or due limit; hence, enormity; extravagance; gross deviation from rule, right, or propriety; as, the exorbitances of the tongue or of deportment; exorbitance of demands.
entry.q: A curb to yourexorbitancies.
The lamentable exorbitances of their superstitions.

entry.ety: L. exorbitans -antis, p. pr. of exorbitare to go out of the track; ex out + orbita track: cf. F. exorbitant. See Orbit

sn.def: Departing from an orbit or usual track; hence, deviating from the usual or due course; going beyond the appointed rules or established limits of right or propriety; excessive; extravagant; enormous; inordinate; as, exorbitant appetites and passions; exorbitant charges, demands, or claims.
sn.q: Foul exorbitant desires.

sn.def: Not comprehended in a settled rule or method; anomalous.
sn.q: The Jews . . . [were] inured with causes exorbitant, and such as their laws had not provided for.

entry.def: In an exorbitant, excessive, or irregular manner; enormously.

entry.ety: L.exorbitatus, p. p. of exorbitare. See Exorbitant
entry.def: To go out of the track; to deviate.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exorcised -sīzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Exorcising -sī`zĭng
entry.ety: L. exorcizare, Gr. 'exorki`zein; 'ex out + "orki`zein to make one swear, bind by an oath, fr. "o`rkos oath: cf. F. exorciser

sn.def: To cast out, as a devil, evil spirits, etc., by conjuration or summoning by a holy name, or by certain ceremonies; to expel (a demon) or to conjure (a demon) to depart out of a person possessed by one.
sn.q: He impudently excorciseth devils in the church.

sn.def: To deliver or purify from the influence of an evil spirit or demon.
sn.q: Exorcise the beds and cross the walls.
Mr. Spectator . . . do all you can to exorcise crowds who are . . . processed as I am.

entry.def: An exorcist.

entry.ety: L. exorcismus, Gr. 'exorkizmo`s; cf. F. exorcisme

sn.def: The act of exorcising; the driving out of evil spirits from persons or places by conjuration; also, the form of conjuration used.
Conjuration for raising spirits.

entry.ety: L. exorcista, Gr. 'exorkisth`s: cf. F. exorciste

sn.def: One who expels evil spirits by conjuration or exorcism.
sn.q: Certain of the vagabond Jews, exorcists.

sn.def: A conjurer who can raise spirits.
sn.q: Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up My mortified spirit.

entry.def: Pertaining to the exordium of a discourse: introductory.
entry.q: The exordial paragraph of the second epistle.

entries.entry:
Ex*or"di*um -ŭm n.; pl. E. Exordiums -ŭmz, L. Exordia -ȧ. L. fr. exordiri to begin a web, lay a warp, begin; ex out + ordiri to begin a web, begin; akin to E. order. See Order
A beginning; an introduction; especially, the introductory part of a discourse or written composition, which prepares the audience for the main subject; the opening part of an oration. Theexordiumof repentance. Jer. Taylor. Long prefaces andexordiums. Addison.
Ex`o*rhi"za‖ĕks`�*rī"zȧ n.; pl.Exorhizæ -zē. NL. fr. Gr. 'e`xw outside + 'ri`za root Bot A plant Whose radicle is not inclosed or sheathed by the cotyledons or plumule.

entry.def: Having a radicle which is not inclosed by the cotyledons or plumule; of or relating to an exorhiza.

entry.ety: L. exornatio, fr. exornare. See Ornate
entry.def: Ornament; decoration; embellishment.
entry.q: Hyperbolical exornations . . . many much affect.

entry.ety: L. exortivus, fr. exortus a coming forth, rising; ex out + orivi to rise, come forth
entry.def: Rising; relating to the east.

entry.ety: L. exosculatus, p. p. of exosculari to kiss. See Osculate
entry.def: To kiss; especially, to kiss repeatedly or fondly.
Pertaining to the exoskeleton; as exoskeletal muscles.

The hardened parts of the external integument of an animal, including hair, feathers, nails, horns, scales, etc.,as well as the armor of armadillos and many reptiles, and the shells or hardened integument of numerous invertebrates; external skeleton; dermoskeleton.
The passage of gases, vapors, or liquids through membranes or porous media from within outward, in the phenomena of osmose; -- opposed to endosmose. See Osmose.
See Exosmose.
Pertaining to exosmose.
The extreme outer wall of a spore; the epispore.

entry.ety: L. exossatus, p. p. of exossare to bone , fr. exos without bones; ex out + os ossis, bone
entry.def: To deprive of bones; to take out the bones of; to bone.
A depriving of bone or of fruit stones.
Boneless.
entry.q: Exosseousanimals.

entry.def: The small aperture or foremen in the outer coat of the ovule of a plant.

entry.ety: NL., fr. Gr. �; � out + � bone: cf. F � exostose

sn.def: Any protuberance of a bone which is not natural; an excrescence or morbid enlargement of a bone.
A knot formed upon or in the wood of trees by disease.

entry.ety: L. exotericus, Gr. � fr. � out: cf. F. exotérique. See Ex-
entry.def: External; public; suitable to be imparted to the public; hence, capable of being readily or fully comprehended; -- opposed to esoteric, or secret.
entry.q: The foppery of an exoteric and esoteric doctrine.

entry.def: The public lectures or published writings of Aristotle. See Esoterics.

entries.entry: Ex"o*ter*y n.; pl.Exoteries -�. That which is obvious, public, or common. Dealing out exoteries only to the vulgar.

entry.ety: Nl., fr. Gr. 'e`xw outside + � a case, box
entry.def: The tissue which fills the interspaces between the costæ of many madreporarian corals, usually consisting of small transverse or oblique septa.
The outer coat of the anther.
Characterized by, or formed with, evolution of heat; as, an exothermic reaction; -- opposed to endothermic.

entry.ety: L. exoticus, Gr. � fr. 'e`xw outside: cf. F. exotique. See Exoteric
entry.def: Introduced from a foreign country; not native; extraneous; foreign; as, an exotic plant; an exotic term or word.
entry.q: Nothing was so splendid and exotic as the ambassador.

entry.def: Anything of foreign origin; something not of native growth, as a plant, a word, a custom.
entry.q: Plants that are unknown to Italy, and such as the gardeners call exotics.

entry.def: Foreign; not native; exotic.
The state of being exotic; also, anything foreign, as a word or idiom; an exotic.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expanded; p. pr. & vb. n. Expanding
entry.ety: L. expandere expansum; ex out + pandere to spread out, to throw open; perh. akin to E. patent. Cf. Spawn

sn.def: To lay open by extending; to open wide; to spread out; to diffuse; as, a flower expands its leaves.
sn.q: Then with expanded wings he steers his flight.

sn.def: To cause the particles or parts of to spread themselves or stand apart, thus increasing bulk without addition of substance; to make to occupy more space; to dilate; to distend; to extend every way; to enlarge; -- opposed to contract; as, to expand the chest; heat expands all bodies; to expand the sphere of benevolence.
To state in enlarged form; to develop; as, to expand an equation. See Expansion, 5.

entry.def: To become widely opened, spread apart, dilated, distended, or enlarged; as, flowers expand in the spring; metals expand by heat; the heart expands with joy.
able to expand or to be expanded.

entries.entry:
expanded adj. increased in extent or size or bulk or scope. Opposite of contracted.Narrower terms: blown-up, enlarged; dilated; distended, swollen; inflated
Printnig wider than usual for a particular height; -- of printers' type. Contrasted with condensed. extended.

entry.def: Anything which causes expansion esp. Mech a tool for stretching open or expanding a tube, etc.
same as expandable.

cs.cd: a bit or drill made adjustable for holes of various sizes; one which can be expanded in diameter while boring.
a pulley so made, as in sections, that its diameter can be increased or diminished.

entry.def: That expands, or may be expanded; extending; spreading; enlarging.

entry.ety: From L. expansus, p. p. of expandere. See Expand
entry.def: That which is expanded or spread out; a wide extent of space or body; especially, the arch of the sky.
entry.q: The greenexpanse.
Lights . . . high in the expanse of heaven.
The smooth expanse of crystal lakes.

entry.def: To expand.
entry.q: That lies expansed unto the eyes of all.

entry.def: The capacity of being expanded; as, the expansibility of air.
Capable of being expanded or spread out widely.
entry.q: Bodies are not expansible in proportion to their weight.

entry.def: Expansible.
entry.q: Ether and alcohol are more expansile than water.

entry.note: ☞ Expansion is also used adjectively, as in expansion joint, expansion gear, etc.
entry.cs:
Expansion curve a curve the coördinates of which show the relation between the pressure and volume of expanding gas or vapor; esp. Steam engine, that part of an indicator diagram which shows the declining pressure of the steam as it expands in the cylinder. Expansion gear Steam Engine. a cut-off gear. See Illust. of Link motion.
Automatic expansion gearorAutomatic cut-off
one that is regulated by the governor, and varies the supply of steam to the engine with the demand for power.
Fixed expansion gearorFixed cut-off
one that always operates at the same fixed point of the stroke.
Expansion jointorExpansion coupling
Mech. & Engin a yielding joint or coupling for so uniting parts of a machine or structure that expansion, as by heat, is prevented from causing injurious strains; as: A slide or set of rollers, at the end of bridge truss, to support it but allow end play. A telescopic joint in a steam pipe, to permit one part of the pipe to slide within the other. A clamp for holding a locomotive frame to the boiler while allowing lengthwise motion. a strip of compressible material placed at intervals between blocks of poured concrete, as in roads or sidewalks. Expansion valve Steam Engine a cut-off valve, to shut off steam from the cylinder before the end of each stroke.

sn.def: The act of expanding or spreading out; the condition of being expanded; dilation; enlargement.
That which is expanded; expanse; extend surface; as, the expansion of a sheet or of a lake; the expansion was formed of metal.
sn.q: The starred expansion of the skies.

sn.def: Space through which anything is expanded; also, pure space.
sn.q: Lost in expansion, void and infinite.

sn.def: an increase in the production of goods and services over time, and in the volume of business transactions, generally associated with an increase in employment and an increase in the money supply. Opposite of contraction.

The developed result of an indicated operation; as, the expansion of a + b2 is a2 + 2ab + b2
.
The operation of steam in a cylinder after its communication with the boiler has been cut off, by which it continues to exert pressure upon the moving piston.
The enlargement of the ship mathematically from a model or drawing to the full or building size, in the process of construction.
an enlarged or extended version of something, such as a writing or discourse; as, the journal article is an expansion of the lecture she gave.
an expansion joint. See below.
Having a capacity or tendency to expand or dilate; diffusive; of much expanse; wide-extending; as, the expansive force of heat; the expansive quality of air.
sn.q: A more expansive and generous compassion.
His forehead was broad and expansive.

sn.def: causing expansion; as, the expansive force of heat.
of much expanse; wide-extending; as, an expansive view of the mountains.
friendly, open, and unrestrained in conversation or discourse; -- of people; as, wine made the guest expansive .
characterized by exaggerated feelings of euphoria and delusions of grandeur.
a quality characterized by magnificence of scale; as, the expansiveness of their extravagant lifestyle was soon curtailed.
a friendly open trait of a talkative person.
the fractional change in length or area or volume per unit change in temperature at a given constant pressure.

entry.def: Expanse.
entry.q: Night's richexpansure.

entries.entry:
Ex` par"te Ex` par"te
Ex parte application one made without notice or opportunity to oppose. Ex parte council one that assembles at the request of only one of the parties in dispute.
Ex parte hearingorEx parte evidence
Law that which is had or taken by one side or party in the absence of the other. Hearings before grand juries, and affidavits, are ex parte. Wharton's Law Dict. Burrill. . L. See Ex-, and Part
Upon or from one side only; one-sided; partial; as, an ex parte statement.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expatiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Expariating
entry.ety: L. expatiatus exspatiatus, p. p. of expatiari exspatiari, to expatiate; ex out + spatiari to walk about spread out, fr. spatium space. See Space

sn.def: To range at large, or without restraint.
sn.q: Bids his free soul expatiate in the skies.

sn.def: To enlarge in discourse or writing; to be copious in argument or discussion; to descant.
sn.q: He expatiated on the inconveniences of trade.

entry.def: To expand; to spread; to extend; to diffuse; to broaden.
entry.q: Afford art an ample field in which to expatiate itself.

entry.def: Act of expatiating.
Expansive; diffusive.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expatriated; p. pr. & vb. n. Expatriating
entry.ety: LL. expatriatus, p. p. of expatriare; L. ex out + patria fatherland, native land, fr. pater father. See Patriot

sn.def: To banish; to drive or force (a person) from his own country; to make an exile of.
sn.q: The expatriated landed interest of France.

sn.def: Reflexively, as To expatriate one's self: To withdraw from one's native country; to renounce the rights and liabilities of citizenship where one is born, and become a citizen of another country.

entry.def: The act of banishing, or the state of banishment; especially, the forsaking of one's own country with a renunciation of allegiance.
entry.q: Expatriation was a heavy ransom to pay for the rights of their minds and souls.

entry.usage: To Expect Think Believe Await. Expect is a mental act and has aways a reference to the future, to some coming event; as a person expects to die, or he expects to survive. Think and believe have reference to the past and present, as well as to the future; as I think the mail has arrived; I believe he came home yesterday, that he is he is at home now. There is a not uncommon use of expect, which is a confusion of the two; as, I expect the mail has arrived; I expect he is at home. This misuse should be avoided. Await is a physical or moral act. We await that which, when it comes, will affect us personally. We expect what may, or may not, interest us personally. See Anticipate.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expected; p. pr. & vb. n. Expecting
entry.ety: L. expectatum, to look out for, await, expect; ex + out spectare to look at. See Spectacle

sn.def: To wait for; to await.
sn.q: Let's in, and there expect their coming.

sn.def: To look for (mentally); to look forward to, as to something that is believed to be about to happen or come; to have a previous apprehension of, whether of good or evil; to look for with some confidence; to anticipate; -- often followed by an infinitive, sometimes by a clause (with, or without, that); as, I expect to receive wages; I expect that the troops will be defeated.
sn.q: Good: I willexpectyou.
Expectingthy reply.
The Somersetshire or yellow regiment . . . was expected to arrive on the following day.
sn.syn: To anticipate; look for; await; hope.

entry.def: To wait; to stay.
Expectation.
That may be expected or looked for.

cs.cd: one the possession of which a person is entitled to have at some future time, either as a remainder or reversion, or on the death of some one.

sn.def: The act of expecting; expectation.
That which is expected, or looked or waited for with interest; the object of expectation or hope.
sn.q: The expectancy and rose of the fair state.

entries.entry:
Ex*pect"ant
Expectant estate Law an estate in expectancy. See under Expectancy.
a. L.expectans exspectans, p. pr. of expectare exspectare: cf. F. expectant
Waiting in expectation; looking for; Med waiting for the efforts of nature, with little active treatment.

entry.def: One who waits in expectation; one held in dependence by hope of receiving some good.
entry.q: An expectant of future glory.
Those who had employments, or were expectants.

cs.cd: the mean or average duration of the life individuals after any specified age.

entry.ety: L. expectio. exspectio: cf. F. expectation

sn.def: The act or state of expecting or looking forward to an event as about to happen.
sn.q: Inexpectationof a guest.
My soul, wait thou only upon God, for my expectation is from him.

sn.def: That which is expected or looked for.
sn.q: Why our great expectation should be called The seed of woman.

sn.def: The prospect of the future; grounds upon which something excellent is expected to happen; prospect of anything good to come, esp. of property or rank.
sn.q: His magnificent expectations made him, in the opinion of the world, the best match in Europe.
By all men's eyes a youth of expectation.

sn.def: The value of any chance (as the prospect of prize or property) which depends upon some contingent event. Expectations are computed for or against the occurrence of the event.
The leaving of the disease principally to the efforts of nature to effect a cure.

cs.cd: a mandate given by the pope or a prince appointing a successor to any benefice before it becomes vacant.

entry.def: Constituting an object of expectation; contingent.
Something in expectation; esp., an expectative grace.
In conformity with expectation.
One who expects.
In a state of expectation.
Expectative.

entry.ety: L. expectorans, p. pr. of expectorare to drive from the breast: cf. F. expectorant
entry.def: Tending to facilitate expectoration or to promote discharges of mucus, etc., from the lungs or throat.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expectorated; p. pr. & vb. n. Expectorating
entry.ety: L. expecrorare to drive from the breast; ex out + pectus pectiris, breast. See Pectoral
entry.def: To eject from the trachea or lungs; to discharge, as phlegm or other matter, by coughing, hawking, and spitting; to spit forth.
To discharge matter from the lungs or throat by hawking and spitting; to spit.

sn.def: The act of ejecting phlegm or mucus from the throat or lungs, by coughing, hawking, and spitting.
That which is expectorated, as phlegm or mucus.

entry.def: Same as Expectorant.
To expedite; to hasten.
To hasten; to expedite.
entry.q: Toexpediatetheir business.

sn.def: The quality of being expedient or advantageous; fitness or suitableness to effect a purpose intended; adaptedness to self-interest; desirableness; advantage; advisability; -- sometimes contradistinguished from moral rectitude or principle.
sn.q: Divine wisdom discovers no expediency in vice.
To determine concerning the expedience of action.
Much declamation may be heard in the present day against expediency, as if it were not the proper object of a deliberative assembly, and as if it were only pursued by the unprincipled.

sn.def: Expedition; haste; dispatch.
sn.q: Making hither with all due expedience.

sn.def: An expedition; enterprise; adventure.
sn.q: Forwarding this dear expedience.

entry.ety: L. expediens -entis, p. pr. of expedire to be expedient, release, extricate: cf. F. expédient. See Expedite

sn.def: Hastening or forward; hence, tending to further or promote a proposed object; fit or proper under the circumstances; conducive to self-interest; desirable; advisable; advantageous; -- sometimes contradistinguished from right or principled.
sn.q: It is expedient for you that I go away.
Nothing but the right can ever be expedient, since that can never be true expediency which would sacrifice a greater good to a less.

sn.def: Quick; expeditious.
sn.q: His marches are expedient to this town.

sn.def: That which serves to promote or advance; suitable means to accomplish an end.
sn.q: What sure expedient than shall Juno find, To calm her fears and ease her boding mind?

sn.def: Means devised in an exigency; shift.

entries.entry:
Ex*pe`di*en"tial
Ex*pe`di*en"tial*ly , adv. �. . Governed by expediency; seeking advantage; as an expediential policy. Calculating,expedientialunderstanding. Hare.

sn.def: In an expedient manner; fitly; suitably; conveniently.
With expedition; quickly.

entry.def: An expedient.
entry.q: A like expediment to remove discontent.

entry.ety: LL. expeditatus, p. p. of expeditare to expeditate; ex out + pes pedis, foot
entry.def: To deprive of the claws or the balls of the fore feet; as, to expeditate a dog that he may not chase deer. See also declaw.

entry.ety: L. expeditus, p. p. of expedire to free one caught by the foot, to extricate, set free, bring forward, make ready; ex out + pes, prdis, t. See Foot

sn.def: Free of impediment; unimpeded.
sn.q: To make the way plain and expedite.

sn.def: Expeditious; quick; speedily; prompt.
sn.q: Nimble and expedite . . . in its operation.
Speech is a very short and expedite way of conveying their thoughts.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expedited; p. pr. & vb. n. Expediting

sn.def: To relieve of impediments; to facilitate; to accelerate the process or progress of; to hasten; to quicken; as, to expedite the growth of plants.
sn.q: To expedite your glorious march.

sn.def: To despatch; to send forth; to issue officially.
sn.q: Such charters be expedited of course.

entry.def: In expedite manner; expeditiously.
Quality of being expedite.

sn.def: The quality of being expedite; efficient promptness; haste; dispatch; speed; quickness; as to carry the mail with expedition.
sn.q: With winged expedition
Swift as the lightning glance. �

sn.def: A sending forth or setting forth the execution of some object of consequence; progress.
sn.q: Putting it straight in expedition. �

sn.def: An important enterprise, implying a change of place; especially, a warlike enterprise; a march or a voyage with martial intentions; an excursion by a body of persons for a valuable end; as, a military, naval, exploring, or scientific expedition; also, the body of persons making such excursion.
sn.q: The expedition miserably failed.
Narrative of the exploring expedition to the Rocky Mountains.

entry.def: Of or pertaining to an expedition; as, an expeditionary force.
One who goes upon an expedition. R.

Possessed of, or characterized by, expedition, or efficiency and rapidity in action; performed with, or acting with, expedition; quick; having celerity; speedily; as, an expeditious march or messenger .
entry.syn: Prompt; ready; speedy; alert. See Prompt.

entry.def: Performing with speed.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expelled p. pr. & vb. n.. Expelling
entry.ety: L. expellere expulsum; ex out + pellere to drive: cf.F. expeller. See Pulse a beat

sn.def: To drive or force out from that within which anything is contained, inclosed, or situated; to eject; as, to expel air from a bellows.
sn.q: Did not ye . . . expel me out of my father's house?

entry.sn: To drive away from one's country; to banish. Forewasted all their land, and them expelled..He shall expel them from before you . . . and ye shall possess their land.

sn.def: To cut off from further connection with an institution of learning, a society, and the like; as, to expel a student or member.
To keep out, off, or away; to exclude.
sn.q: Toexpelthe winter's flaw.

entry.sn: To discharge; to shoot. Obs Then he another and another [shaft] did expel..To banish; exile; eject; drive out. See Banish.

entry.def: Capable of being expelled or driven out.
entry.q: Expellableby heat.

entry.def: One who, or that which, expels.
any of several bodily processes by which substances go out of the body.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expended; p. pr. & vb. n. Expending
entry.ety: L. expendere expensum, to weigh out, pay out, lay out, lay out; ex out + pendere to weigh. See Poise, and cf. Spend
entry.def: To lay out, apply, or employ in any way; to consume by use; to use up or distribute, either in payment or in donations; to spend; as, they expend money for food or in charity; to expend time labor, and thought; to expend hay in feeding cattle, oil in a lamp, water in mechanical operations.
entry.q: If my death might make this island happy . . . I would expend it with all willingness.

sn.def: To be laid out, used, or consumed.

entry.sn: To pay out or disburse money. They go elsewhere to enjoy and to expend..

entry.def: nonexistent or unavailable as a consequence of use or exchange.
A disburser; especially, one of the disbursers of taxes for the repair of sewers.

sn.def: The act of expending; a laying out, as of money; disbursement.
sn.q: Our expenditure purchased commerce and conquest.

sn.def: That which is expended or paid out; expense.
sn.q: The receipts and expenditures of this extensive country.

cs.cd: a small magazine containing ammunition for immediate use.

entry.ety: L. expensasc. pecunia), or expensum, fr. expensus, p. p. of expendere. See Expend

sn.def: A spending or consuming; disbursement; expenditure.
sn.q: Husband nature's riches from expense.

sn.def: That which is expended, laid out, or consumed; cost; outlay; charge; -- sometimes with the notion of loss or damage to those on whom the expense falls; as, the expenses of war; an expense of time.
sn.q: Courting popularity at his party's expense.

sn.def: Loss.
sn.q: And moan the expense of many a vanished sight.

entry.def: Full of expense; costly; chargeable.
Without cost or expense.

sn.def: Occasioning expense; calling for liberal outlay; costly; dear; liberal; as, expensive dress; an expensive house or family.
sn.q: War is expensive, and peace desirable.

sn.def: Free in expending; very liberal; especially, in a bad sense: extravagant; lavish.
sn.q: An active, expensive, indefatigable goodness.
The idle and expensive are dangerous.

entry.ety: F. expérience, L. experientia, tr. experiens experientis, p. pr. of experiri expertus, to try; ex out + the root of peritus experienced. See Peril, and cf. Expert

sn.def: Trial, as a test or experiment.
sn.q: She caused him to make experience Upon wild beasts.

sn.def: The effect upon the judgment or feelings produced by any event, whether witnessed or participated in; personal and direct impressions as contrasted with description or fancies; personal acquaintance; actual enjoyment or suffering.
sn.q: Guided by other'sexperiences.
I have but one lamp by which my feet are guided, and that is the lamp of experience.
To most men experience is like the stern lights of a ship, which illumine only the track it has passed.
When the consuls . . . came in . . . they knew soon by experience how slenderly guarded against danger the majesty of rulers is where force is wanting.
Those that undertook the religion of our Savior upon his preaching, had no experience of it.

sn.def: An act of knowledge, one or more, by which single facts or general truths are ascertained; experimental or inductive knowledge; hence, implying skill, facility, or practical wisdom gained by personal knowledge, feeling or action; as, a king without experience of war.
sn.q: Whence hath the mind all the materials of reason and knowledge? To this I answer in one word, from experience.

Experience may be acquired in two ways; either, first by noticing facts without any attempt to influence the frequency of their occurrence or to vary the circumstances under which they occur; this is observation; or, secondly, by putting in action causes or agents over which we have control, and purposely varying their combinations, and noticing what effects take place; this is experiment.

cs.cd: to become a convert to the doctrines of Christianity; to yield to the power of religious truth.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Experienced ĕks*pē"rĭ*�nst; p. pr. & vb. n. Experiencing ĕks*pē"rĭ*�n*sĭng

sn.def: To make practical acquaintance with; to try personally; to prove by use or trial; to have trial of; to have the lot or fortune of; to have befall one; to be affected by; to feel; as, to experience pain or pleasure; to experience poverty; to experience a change of views.
sn.q: The partial failure and disappointment which he had experienced in India.

sn.def: To exercise; to train by practice.
sn.q: The youthful sailors thus with early care Their arms experience, and for sea prepare.

entry.def: Taught by practice or by repeated observations; skillful or wise by means of trials, use, or observation; as, an experienced physician, workman, soldier; an experienced eye.
entry.q: The ablest and most experienced statesmen.

sn.def: One who experiences.
An experimenter.

entries.entry: Ex*pe"ri*ence ta"ble. Life Insurance A table of mortality computed from the experience of one or more life-insurance companies.

entry.def: Experienced.
entry.q: The prince now ripe and full experient.

entry.def: Derived from, or pertaining to, experience.
entry.q: It is called empirical or experiential . . . because it is given to us by experience or observation, and not obtained as the result of inference or reasoning.

entry.def: The doctrine that experience, either that of ourselves or of others, is the test or criterion of general knowledge; -- opposed to intuitionalism.
entry.q: Experientialism is in short, a philosophical or logical theory, not a psychological one.

entry.def: One who accepts the doctrine of experientialism. Also used adjectively.

entry.ety: L. experimentum, fr. experiri to try: cf. OF. esperiment experiment. See Experience

sn.def: A trial or special observation, made to confirm or disprove something uncertain; esp., one under controlled conditions determined by the experimenter; an act or operation undertaken in order to discover some unknown principle or effect, or to test, establish, or illustrate some hypothesis, theory, or known truth; practical test; proof.
sn.q: A political experiment can not be made in a laboratory, nor determined in a few hours.

sn.def: Experience.
sn.q: Adam, by sad experiment I know How little weight my words with thee can find.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Experimented; p. pr. & vb. n. Experinenting
entry.def: To make experiment; to operate by test or trial; -- often with on upon, or in, referring to the subject of an experiment; with, referring to the instrument; and by, referring to the means; as, to experiment upon electricity; he experimented in plowing with ponies, or by steam power.
To try; to know, perceive, or prove, by trial or experience.

sn.def: Pertaining to experiment; founded on, or derived from, experiment or trial; as, experimental science; given to, or skilled in, experiment; as, an experimental philosopher.
Known by, or derived from, experience; as, experimental religion.
an empirical doctrine that advocates experimental principles.
an orientation that favors experimentation and innovation; as, the children of psycholoigsts are often raised in an atmosphere of experimentalism .
One who makes experiments, especially one who likes to experiment; an experimenter.
One who relies primarily on experimentation and the evidence of one's own senses; an empiricist; -- contrasted with theoretician or dogmatist.

entry.def: To make experiments (upon); to experiment.
By experiment; by experience or trial.
Relying on experiment or experience.
entry.q: anexperimentarianphilosopher.

def2.def: One who relies on experiment or experience.

entry.def: The act of experimenting; practice by experiment.
Experimental; of the nature of experiment.
An experimenter.
One who makes experiments; one skilled in experiments.
An experimenter.

entry.ety: L. expergisci, p. p. experrectus, to rouse up; ex out + pergere to wake up
entry.def: A waking up or arousing.

entry.ety: F. expert, L. expertus, p. p. of experiri to try. See Experience
entry.def: Taught by use, practice, or experience, experienced; having facility of operation or performance from practice; knowing and ready from much practice; clever; skillful; as, an expert surgeon; expert in chess or archery.
entry.q: A valiant and most expert gentleman.
What practice, howsoe'er expert In fitting aptest words to things . . . Hath power to give thee as thou wert?

entry.note: ☞ Such specialists may be witnesses in matters as to which ordinary observers could not without such aid form just conclusions, and are liable for negligence in case they injure another from want of proper qualifications or proper care in the exercise of their specialty.

sn.def: An expert or experienced person; one instructed by experience; one who has skill, experience, or extensive knowledge in his calling or in any special branch of learning.

sd.def: A specialist in a particular profession or department of science requiring for its mastery peculiar culture and erudition.
A sworn appraiser.

entry.def: To experience.
entry.q: Die would we daily, once it to expert.

entry.def: In a skillful or dexterous manner; adroitly; with readiness and accuracy.
Skill derived from practice; readiness; as, expertness in seamanship, or in reasoning.
entry.syn: Facility; readiness; dexterity; adroitness; skill. See Facility.

entry.ety: L., expetibilis, fr. expetere to wish for; ex out + petere to seek
entry.def: Worthy of being wished for; desirable.
Capable of being expiated or atoned for; as, an expiable offense; expiable guilt.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expiated; p. pr. & vb. n. Expiating
entry.ety: L. expiatus, p. p. of expiare to expiate; ex out + piare to seek to appease, to purify with sacred rites, fr. pius pious. See Pious

sn.def: To extinguish the guilt of by sufferance of penalty or some equivalent; to make complete satisfaction for; to atone for; to make amends for; to make expiation for; as, to expiate a crime, a guilt, or sin.
sn.q: To expiate his treason, hath naught left.
The Treasurer obliged himself to expiate the injury.

sn.def: To purify with sacred rites.
sn.q: Neither let there be found among you any one that shall expiate his son or daughter, making them to pass through the fire.

entry.def: Terminated.

sn.def: The act of making satisfaction or atonement for any crime or fault; the extinguishing of guilt by suffering or penalty.
sn.q: His liberality seemed to have something in it of self-abasement and expiation.

sn.def: The means by which reparation or atonement for crimes or sins is made; an expiatory sacrifice or offering; an atonement.
sn.q: Those shadowy expiations weak, The blood of bulls and goats.

sn.def: An act by which the threats of prodigies were averted among the ancient heathen.

entry.def: An expiator.
One who makes expiation or atonement.
Of an expiatory nature; expiatory.
Having power, or intended, to make expiation; atoning; as, an expiatory sacrifice.
The act of expilating or stripping off; plunder; pillage.
entry.q: This ravenous expilation of the state.

entry.def: One who pillages; a plunderer; a pillager.
That may expire; capable of being brought to an end.
One who expires or is expiring.

entry.ety: L. expiratio,exspiratio: cf. F. expiration. See Expire
entry.sn:
The act of expiring; as: Physiol The act or process of breathing out, or forcing air from the lungs through the nose or mouth; as, respiration consists of inspiration and expiration ; -- opposed to inspiration.
Emission of volatile matter; exhalation. The true cause of cold is an expiration from the globe of the earth.
The last emission of breath; death. The groan ofexpiration.
A coming to a close; cessation; extinction; termination; end. Before the expiration of thy time.

sn.def: That which is expired; matter breathed forth; that which is produced by breathing out, as a sound.
sn.q: The aspirate “he,” which is . . . a gentle expiration.

entry.def: bearing a date after which it is no longer valid or salable; -- of a security, option, or perishable item.
Pertaining to, or employed in, the expiration or emission of air from the lungs; as, the expiratory muscles.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expired; p. pr & vb. n. Expiring
entry.ety: L. expirare exspirare expiratum exspiratum; ex out + spirare to breathe: cf. F. expirer. See Spirit

sn.def: To breathe out; to emit from the lungs; to throw out from the mouth or nostrils in the process of respiration; -- opposed to inspire.
sn.q: Anatomy exhibits the lungs in a continual motion of inspiring and expiring air.
This chafed the boar; his nostrils flames expire.

sn.def: To give forth insensibly or gently, as a fluid or vapor; to emit in minute particles; to exhale; as, the earth expires a damp vapor; plants expire odors.
sn.q: The expiring of cold out of the inward parts of the earth in winter.

sn.def: To emit; to give out.
To bring to a close; to terminate.
sn.q: Expire the term Of a despised life.

sn.def: To emit the breath.
To emit the last breath; to breathe out the life; to die; as, to expire calmly; to expire in agony.
To come to an end; to cease; to terminate; to perish; to become extinct; as, the flame expired; his lease expires to-day; the month expired on Saturday.
To burst forth; to fly out with a blast.
sn.q: The ponderous ballexpires.

entry.def: having come to an end or become void after passage of a period of time; as, an expired passport; caught driving with an expired license. Opposite of unexpired.

sn.def: Breathing out air from the lungs; emitting fluid or volatile matter; exhaling; breathing the last breath; dying; ending; terminating.
Pertaining to, or uttered at, the time of dying; as, expiring words; expiring groans.

entry.def: Expiration.
entry.q: He had to leave at the expiry of the term.
The Parliament . . . now approaching the expiry of its legal term.

entry.ety: L. expiscatus, p. p. of expiscari to fish out; ex out+piscari to fish, piscis fish
entry.def: To fish out; to find out by skill or laborious investigation; to search out.
entry.q: Toexpiscateprinciples.
Dr. Burton has with much ingenuity endeavored to expiscate the truth which may be involved in them.

entry.def: The act of expiscating; a fishing.
Tending to fish out; searching out

entry.cs: To explain away to get rid of by explanation. “Those explain the meaning quite away.” Pope.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Explained ĕks*plānd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Explaining
entry.ety: L. explandare to flatten, spread out, explain; ex out + plandare to make level or plain, planus plain: cf. OF. esplaner explaner. See Plain,a., and cf. Esplanade

sn.def: To flatten; to spread out; to unfold; to expand.
sn.q: The horse-chestnut is . . . ready to explain its leaf.

sn.def: To make plain, manifest, or intelligible; to clear of obscurity; to expound; to unfold and illustrate the meaning of; as, to explain a chapter of the Bible.
sn.q: Commentators to explain the difficult passages to you.
sn.syn: To expound; interpret; elucidate; clear up.

entry.def: To give an explanation.
Capable of being explained or made plain to the understanding; capable of being interpreted.
One who explains; an expounder or expositor; a commentator; an interpreter.

entry.ety: L. explanatus, p. p. of explanare. See Explain
entry.def: Spreading or extending outwardly in a flat form.

sn.def: The act of explaining, expounding, or interpreting; the act of clearing from obscurity and making intelligible; as, the explanation of a passage in Scripture, or of a contract or treaty.
That which explains or makes clear; as, a satisfactory explanation .
The meaning attributed to anything by one who explains it; definition; interpretation; sense.
sn.q: Different explanationsof the Trinity].

sn.def: A mutual exposition of terms, meaning, or motives, with a view to adjust a misunderstanding, and reconcile differences; reconciliation; agreement; as, to come to an explanation .
sn.syn: Definition; description; explication; exposition; interpretation; detail. See Definition.

entry.def: Explanatory.
The quality of being explanatory.
Serving to explain; containing explanation; as explanatory notes.
To explain; to unfold.
entry.q: Like Solon's self explatest the knotty laws.

entry.ety: L. expletio a satisfying. See Expletive
entry.def: Accomplishment; fulfillment.

entry.ety: L. expletivus, from expletus, p. p. of explere to fill up; ex out+plere to fill, akin to plenus full: cf. F. explétif. See Full
entry.def: Filling up; hence, added merely for the purpose of filling up; superfluous.
entry.q: Expletiveimagery.
Expletive phrases to plump his speech.

entry.def: A word, letter, or syllable not necessary to the sense, but inserted to fill a vacancy; an oath.
entry.q: While explectives their feeble aid to join, And ten low words oft creep in one dull line.

entry.def: In the manner of an expletive.
Serving to fill up; expletive; superfluous; as, an expletory word.
Capable of being explicated; that may be explained or accounted for; admitting explanation.
entry.q: It is not explicable upon any grounds.

entry.def: Quality of being explicable.

entry.ety: L. explicatus, p. p. of explicare
entry.def: Evolved; unfolded.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Explicated; p. pr. & vb. n. Explicating

sn.def: To unfold; to expand; to lay open.
sn.q: Theyexplicatethe leaves.

sn.def: To unfold the meaning or sense of; to explain; to clear of difficulties or obscurity; to interpret.
sn.q: The last verse of his last satire is not yet sufficiently explicated.

sn.def: The act of opening, unfolding, or explaining; explanation; exposition; interpretation.
sn.q: The explication of our Savior's parables.

sn.def: The sense given by an expositor.

entry.def: Serving to unfold or explain; tending to lay open to the understanding; explanatory.
One who unfolds or explains; an expounder; an explainer.
Explicative.

entries.entry:
Ex"pli*cit Ex"pli*cit. LL., an abbreviation of explicitusest liber) the book (which anciently was a roll of parchment) is unfolded (and, of course, “finished”). See Explicit a.
A word formerly used (as finis is now) at the conclusion of a book to indicate the end.

entry.cs: Explicit function. Math See under Function.
entry.usage: Explicit Express. Explicit denotes a setting forth in the plainest language, so that the meaning can not be misunderstood; as, an explicit promise. Express is stronger than explicit: it adds force to clearness. An express promise or engagement is not only unambiguous, but stands out in bold relief, with the most binding hold on the conscience. An explicit statement; a clear and explicit notion; explicit direction; no words can be more explicit. An explicit command; an express prohibition. “An express declaration goes forcibly and directly to the point. An explicit declaration leaves nothing ambiguous.” C. J. Smith.
entry.ety: L. explicitus; p. p. of explicare to unfold: cf. F. explicite. See Explicate Exploit

sn.def: Not implied merely, or conveyed by implication; distinctly stated; plain in language; open to the understanding; clear; not obscure or ambiguous; express; unequivocal; as, an explicit declaration. Opposite of implicit.
sn.q: The language of the charter was too explicit to admit of a doubt.

sn.def: Having no disguised meaning or reservation; unreserved; outspoken; -- applied to persons; as, he was earnest and explicit in his statement.
sn.syn: Express; clear; plain; open; unreserved; unambiguous.

entry.def: In an explicit manner; clearly; plainly; without disguise or reservation of meaning; not by inference or implication; as, he explicitly avows his intention.
The quality of being explicit; clearness; directness.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exploded; p. pr. & vb. n. Exploding
entry.ety: L. explodere explosum, to drive out, drive out a player by clapping; ex out + plaudere plodere, to clap, strike, applaud: cf. OF. exploder. See Plausible

sn.def: To become suddenly expanded into a great volume of gas or vapor; to burst violently into flame; as, gunpowder explodes .
To burst with force and a loud report; to detonate, as a shell filled with powder or the like material, or as a boiler from too great pressure of steam.
To burst forth with sudden violence and noise; as, at this, his wrath exploded .
To drive from the stage by noisy expressions of disapprobation; to hoot off; to drive away or reject noisily; as, to explode a play.
sn.q: Him old and youngExploded, and seized with violent hands.

sn.def: To bring into disrepute, and reject; to drive from notice and acceptance; as, to explode a scheme, fashion, or doctrine.
sn.q: Old exploded contrivances of mercantile fraud.
To explode and exterminate dark atheism.

sn.def: To cause to explode or burst noisily; to detonate; as, to explode powder by touching it with fire.
To drive out with violence and noise, as by powder.
sn.q: But late the kindled powder did explode The massy ball and the brass tube unload.

sn.def: An instrument or agent causing explosion; an exploder; also, an explosive.
See Explosive n., 2.
One who or that which explodes.
One who rejects an opinion or scheme with open contempt.

entry.ety: OE. esploit success, OF. esploit espleit,revenue, product, vigor, force, exploit, F. exploit exploit, fr. L. explicitum, prop. p. p. neut. of explicare to unfold, display, exhibit; ex + plicare to fold. See Ply, and cf. Explicit Explicate

sn.def: A deed or act; especially, a heroic act; a deed of renown; an adventurous or noble achievement; as, the exploits of Alexander the Great.
sn.q: Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises.

sn.def: Combat; war.
sn.q: He made haste to exploit some warlike service.

sn.def: To utilize; to make available; to get the value or usefulness out of; as, to exploit a mine or agricultural lands; to exploit public opinion.
Hence: To draw an illegitimate profit from; to speculate on; to put upon.
sn.q: In no sense whatever does a man who accumulates a fortune by legitimate industry exploit his employés or make his capital “out of” anybody else.

entry.def: The act of exploiting or utilizing.
tending to exploit or make use of.

sn.def: The act of exploiting or accomplishing; achievement.
Exploitation.

entry.def: That may be explored; as, an explorable region.
To explore.

entries.entry:
Ex`plo*ra"tion n. L. exploratio: cf. F. exploration
The act of exploring, penetrating, or ranging over for purposes of discovery, especially of geographical discovery; examination; as, the exploration of unknown countries ; Med physical examination. “An exploration of doctrine.”

entry.def: Exploratory.
One who explores; one who examines closely; a searcher.
Serving or intended to explore; searching; examining; explorative.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Explored; p. pr. & vb. n. Exploring
entry.ety: L. explorare to explore; ex out+plorare to cry out aloud,prob. orig., to cause to flow; perh. akin to E. flow: cf. F. explorer

sn.def: To seek for or after; to strive to attain by search; to look wisely and carefully for.
sn.q: Explores the lost, the wandering sheep directs.

sn.def: To search through or into; to penetrate or range over for discovery; to examine thoroughly; as, to explore new countries or seas; to explore the depths of science.
sn.q: Hidden frauds [toexplore.

entry.def: The act of exploring; exploration.
One who explores; also, an apparatus with which one explores, as a diving bell.
Employed in, or designed for, exploration.
entry.q: Exploringparties.

entry.ety: L. explosio a driving off by clapping: cf. F. explosion explosion. See Explode

sn.def: The act of exploding; detonation; a chemical action which causes the sudden formation of a great volume of expanded gas; as, the explosion of gunpowder, of fire damp, etc.
A bursting with violence and loud noise, because of internal pressure; as, the explosion of a gun, a bomb, a steam boiler, etc.
A violent outburst of feeling, manifested by excited language, action, etc.; as, an explosion of wrath.
sn.q: A formidable explosion of high-church fanaticism.

sn.def: a sudden and substantial increase; a rapid acceleration; as, the population explosion .

entry.def: Driving or bursting out with violence and noise; causing explosion; as, the explosive force of gunpowder.

sn.def: An explosive agent; a compound or mixture susceptible of a rapid chemical reaction, as gunpowder TNT dynamite, or nitro-glycerine.
A sound produced by an explosive impulse of the breath; Phonetics one of consonants p b t d k g, which are sounded with a sort of explosive power of voice. See Guide to Pronunciation, √ 155-7, 184

entry.def: In an explosive manner.
See Exspoliation.
To polish thoroughly.
To expound; to explain; also, to expose; to imperil.

entry.note: thus a2 denotes the second power, and ax the xth power, of a2 and x being the exponents). A fractional exponent, or index, is used to denote the root of a quantity. Thus, a 1/3 denotes the third or cube root of a.

cs.cd: the quotient arising when the antecedent is divided by the consequent; thus, 6 is the exponent of the ratio of 30 to 5.

entry.ety: L. exponens -entis, p. pr. of exponere to put out, set forth, expose. See Expound
entry.sn: Alg A number, letter, or any quantity written on the right hand of and above another quantity, and denoting how many times the latter is repeated as a factor to produce the power indicated;

sn.def: One who, or that which, stands as an index or representative; as, the leader of a party is the exponent of its principles.
one who explains, expounds, or interprets.

entry.note: ☞ Exponential growth is characteristic of bacteria and other living populations in circumstances where the conditions of growth are favorable, and all required nutrients are plentiful. For example, the bacterium Escherichia coli in rich media may double in number every 20 minutes until one of the nutrients becomes exhausted or waste products begin to inhibit growth. Many fascinating thought experiments are proposed on the theme of exponential growth. One may calculate, for example how long it would take the progeny of one Escherichia coli to equal the mass of the known universe if it multiplied unimpeded at such a rate. The answer, assuming the equivalent of 1080 hydrogen atoms in the universe, is less than three days. Exponential increases in a quantity can be surprising, and this principle is often used by banks to make investment at a certain rate of interest seem to be very profitable over time. Exponential decay is exhibited by decay of radioactive materials and some chemical reactions (first order reactions), in which one-half of the initial quantity of radioactive element (or chemical substance) is lost for each lapse of a characteristic time called the half-life.

cs.cd: a curve whose nature is defined by means of an exponential equation.
an equation which contains an exponential quantity, or in which the unknown quantity enters as an exponent.
a quantity whose exponent is unknown or variable, as ax.
a series derived from the development of exponential equations or quantities.

sn.def: Pertaining to exponents; involving variable exponents; as, an exponential expression; exponential calculus; an exponential function.
changing over time in an exponential manner, i. e. increasing or decreasing by a fixed ratio for each unit of time; as, exponential growth; exponential decay.

entry.def: the process of raising a quantity to some assigned power.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exported; p. pr. & vb. n. Exporting
entry.ety: L. exportare exportatum; ex out+portare to carry : cf. F. exporter. See Port demeanor

sn.def: To carry away; to remove.
sn.q: Theyexport honor from a man, and make him a return in envy.

sn.def: To carry or send abroad, or out of a country, especially to foreign countries, as merchandise or commodities in the way of commerce; -- the opposite of import; as, to export grain, cotton, cattle, goods, etc.
The act of exporting; exportation; as, to prohibit the export of wheat or tobacco.
That which is exported; a commodity conveyed from one country or State to another in the way of traffic; -- used chiefly in the plural, exports.
sn.q: The ordinary course of exchange . . . between two places must likewise be an indication of the ordinary course of their exports and imports.

entry.def: The quality or state of being suitable for exportation.
entry.q: To increase the exportability of native goods.

entry.def: Suitable for exportation; as, exportable products.

sn.def: The act of exporting; the act of conveying or sending commodities abroad or to another country, in the course of commerce.
Commodity exported; an export.
The act of carrying out.

entry.def: One who exports; the person who sends goods or commodities to a foreign country, in the way of commerce; -- opposed to importer.
Exposure.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exposed; p. pr. & vb. n. Exposing
entry.ety: F. exposer; pref. ex-L. ex out)+poser to place. See Pose v. t.

sn.def: To set forth; to set out to public view; to exhibit; to show; to display; as, to expose goods for sale; to expose pictures to public inspection.
sn.q: Those who seek truth only, freely expose their principles to the test, and are pleased to have them examined.

sn.def: To lay bare; to lay open to attack, danger, or anything objectionable; to render accessible to anything which may affect, especially detrimentally; to make liable; as, to expose one's self to the heat of the sun, or to cold, insult, danger, or ridicule; to expose an army to destruction or defeat.
sn.q: Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel.

sn.def: To deprive of concealment; to discover; to lay open to public inspection, or bring to public notice, as a thing that shuns publicity, something criminal, shameful, or the like; as, to expose the faults of a neighbor.
sn.q: You only expose the follies of men, without arraigning their vices.

sn.def: To disclose the faults or reprehensible practices of; to lay open to general condemnation or contempt by making public the character or arts of; as, to expose a cheat, liar, or hypocrite.

entry.ety: F., prop. p. p. of exposer. See Expose v. t.
entry.def: A formal recital or exposition of facts; exposure, or revelation, of something which some one wished to keep concealed.

sn.def: with no protection or shield; as, the exposed northeast frontier.
visible due to absence of clothing at that point; -- of body parts.

entry.def: The state of being exposed, laid open, or unprotected; as, an exposedness to sin or temptation.
One who exposes or discloses.

sn.def: to set forth reasons; to explain or expound.
to make external.

entry.ety: L. expositio, fr. exponere expositum: cf. F. exposition. See Expound

sn.def: The act of exposing or laying open; a setting out or displaying to public view.

The act of expounding or of laying open the sense or meaning of an author, or a passage; explanation; interpretation; the sense put upon a passage; a law, or the like, by an interpreter; hence, a work containing explanations or interpretations; a commentary.
sn.q: You know the law; your exposition Hath been most sound.

sn.def: Situation or position with reference to direction of view or accessibility to influence of sun, wind, etc.; exposure; as, an easterly exposition; an exposition to the sun.
A public exhibition or show, as of industrial and artistic productions; as, the Paris Exposition of 1878.

entry.def: Serving to explain; expository.
One who, or that which, expounds or explains; an expounder; a commentator.
Pertaining to, or containing, exposition; serving to explain; explanatory; illustrative; exegetical.
entry.q: A glossary or expository index to the poetical writers.

entries.entry:
‖Ex" post` fac"toor ‖Ex" post`fac"to ĕks" pōst" făk"t�
Ex post facto law a law which operates by after enactment. The phrase is popularly applied to any law, civil or criminal, which is enacted with a retrospective effect, and with intention to produce that effect; but in its true application, as employed in American law, it relates only to crimes, and signifies a law which retroacts, by way of criminal punishment, upon that which was not a crime before its passage, or which raises the grade of an offense, or renders an act punishable in a more severe manner that it was when committed. Ex post facto laws are held to be contrary to the fundamental principles of a free government, and the States are prohibited from passing such laws by the Constitution of the United States. Burrill. Kent.
Ex post facto law a law which operates by after enactment. The phrase is popularly applied to any law, civil or criminal, which is enacted with a retrospective effect, and with intention to produce that effect; but in its true application, as employed in American law, it relates only to crimes, and signifies a law which retroacts, by way of criminal punishment, upon that which was not a crime before its passage, or which raises the grade of an offense, or renders an act punishable in a more severe manner that it was when committed. Ex post facto laws are held to be contrary to the fundamental principles of a free government, and the States are prohibited from passing such laws by the Constitution of the United States. Burrill. Kent. . L., from what is done afterwards Law From or by an after act, or thing done afterward; in consequence of a subsequent act; retrospective.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expostulated; p. pr. & vb. n. Expostulating
entry.ety: L. expostulatus, p. p. of expostulare to demand vehemently; ex out + postulare to ask, require. See Postulate
entry.def: To reason earnestly with a person on some impropriety of his conduct, representing the wrong he has done or intends, and urging him to make redress or to desist; to remonstrate; -- followed by with.
entry.q: Men expostulate with erring friends; they bring accusations against enemies who have done them a wrong.

entry.def: To discuss; to examine.
entry.q: To expostulate What majesty should be, what duty is.

entry.def: The act of expostulating or reasoning with a person in opposition to some impropriety of conduct; remonstrance; earnest and kindly protest; dissuasion.
entry.q: We must use expostulation kindly.

entry.def: One who expostulates.
Containing expostulation or remonstrance; as, an expostulatory discourse or letter.
Exposure.

sn.def: The act of exposing or laying open, setting forth, laying bare of protection, depriving of care or concealment, or setting out to reprobation or contempt.
sn.q: The exposure of Fuller . . . put an end to the practices of that vile tribe.

sn.def: The state of being exposed or laid open or bare; openness to danger; accessibility to anything that may affect, especially detrimentally; as, exposure to observation, to cold, to inconvenience.
sn.q: When we have our naked frailties hid, That suffer in exposure.

sn.def: Position as to points of compass, or to influences of climate, etc.
sn.q: Under a southernexposure.
The best exposure of the two for woodcocks.

sn.def: The exposing of a sensitized plate to the action of light.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expounded; p. pr. & vb. n. Expounding
entry.ety: OE. exponen expounen expounden, fr. L. exponere to set out, expose, expound; ex out + ponere to put: cf. OE. expondre expondre. See Position

sn.def: To lay open; to expose to view; to examine.
sn.q: He expounded both his pockets.

sn.def: To lay open the meaning of; to explain; to clear of obscurity; to interpret; as, to expound a text of Scripture, a law, a word, a meaning, or a riddle.
sn.q: Expound this matter more fully to me.

entry.def: One who expounds or explains; an interpreter.
a former president.

entry.cs: Express color. Law See the Note under Color n., 8.
entry.ety: F. exprès, L. expressus, p. p. of exprimere to express; ex. out + premere To press. See Press

sn.def: Exactly representing; exact.
sn.q: Their human countenance The express resemblance of the gods.

sn.def: Directly and distinctly stated; declared in terms; not implied or left to inference; made unambiguous by intention and care; clear; not dubious; as, express consent; an express statement.
sn.q: I have express commandment.

sn.def: Intended for a particular purpose; relating to an express; sent on a particular errand; dispatched with special speed; as, an express messenger or train. Also used adverbially.
sn.q: A messenger sent express from the other world.

sn.def: of or pertaining to an express train or other conveyance designated an express{5}; makiung few or no intermediate stops; as, an express stop; an express fare; an express elevator.

cs.cd: an office where packages for an express are received or delivered.
a railway train (such as a subway train) that does not stop at certain stations, but only at stations designated express stops.

sn.def: A clear image or representation; an expression; a plain declaration.
sn.q: The only remanent express of Christ's sacrifice on earth.

sn.def: A messenger sent on a special errand; a courier; hence, a regular and fast conveyance; commonly, a company or system for the prompt and safe transportation of merchandise or parcels.
An express office.
sn.q: She charged him . . . to ask at the express if anything came up from town.

sn.def: That which is sent by an express messenger or message.

a railway train or bus for transporting passengers or goods with speed and punctuality; a train or bus that does not stop at certain stations. Contrasted to local; as, take the express to get there faster.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expressed; p. pr. & vb. n. Expressing
entry.ety: Cf. OF. espresser expresser, L. exprimere expressum. See Express a.; cf. Sprain

sn.def: To press or squeeze out; as, to express the juice of grapes, or of apples; hence, to extort; to elicit.
sn.q: All the fruits out of which drink is expressed.
And th'idle breath all utterly expressed.
Halters and racks can not express from thee More than by deeds.

sn.def: To make or offer a representation of; to show by a copy or likeness; to represent; to resemble.
sn.q: Each skillful artist shall express thy form.
So kids and whelps their sires and dams express.

sn.def: To give a true impression of; to represent and make known; to manifest plainly; to show in general; to exhibit, as an opinion or feeling, by a look, gesture, and esp. by language; to declare; to utter; to tell.
sn.q: My words express my purpose.
They expressed in their lives those excellent doctrines of morality.

sn.def: To make known the opinions or feelings of; to declare what is in the mind of; to show (one's self); to cause to appear; -- used reflexively.
sn.q: Mr. Phillips did express with much indignation against me, one evening.

sn.def: To denote; to designate.
sn.q: Moses and Aaron took these men, which are expressed by their names.

sn.def: To send by express messenger; to forward by special opportunity, or through the medium of an express; as, to express a package.
to produce products that cause the appearance of the corresponding phenotype; -- of a gene or of an organism with a specific gene; as, to express the beta-galactosidase gene,
sn.syn: To declare; utter; signify; testify; intimate.

entry.def: The charge for carrying a parcel by express.

sn.def: Communicated in words.

entry.sn: Precisely and clearly expressed, leaving nothing to implication. Opposite of implicit.Narrower terms: graphic Also See: definite denotative denotive overt open unequivocal unambiguous. explicit, express.

entry.def: Capable of being expressed, squeezed out, shown, represented, or uttered.

entry.note: In most programming languages, (a + b) is an expression indicating simple arithmetic addition, if the variables a and b are real numbers. Many other types of operation may be used in programs, and each set of symbols indicating an operation is an expression in that program.
entry.cs:
Past expression Beyond expression
beyond the power of description. “Beyond expression bright.” Milton.

sn.def: The act of expressing; the act of forcing out by pressure; as, the expression of juices or oils; also, of extorting or eliciting; as, a forcible expression of truth.
The act of declaring or signifying; declaration; utterance; as, an expression of the public will.
sn.q: With this tone of philosophy were mingled expressions of sympathy.

sn.def: Lively or vivid representation of meaning, sentiment, or feeling, etc.; significant and impressive indication, whether by language, appearance, or gesture; that manner or style which gives life and suggestive force to ideas and sentiments; as, he reads with expression; her performance on the piano has expression.
sn.q: The imitators of Shakespeare, fixing their attention on his wonderful power of expression, have directed their imitation to this.

sn.def: That which is expressed by a countenance, a posture, a work of art, etc.; look, as indicative of thought or feeling.
sn.q: Theexpressionof an eye.
It still wore the majesty of expression so conspicuous in his portraits by the inimitable pencil of Titian.

sn.def: A form of words in which an idea or sentiment is conveyed; a mode of speech; a phrase; as, a common expression; an odd expression.
The representation of any quantity or relation by appropriate characters or symbols, usually in a specific order.

the production of products by a gene that cause the appearance of the corresponding protein or phenotype; -- of a gene or of an organism with a specific gene; as, the expression the beta-galactosidase positive phenotype,

a combination of characters linked by operators, occurring as part of the code of a computer program, which must be evaluated according to the rules of the computer language in order to produce a resulting value.

entry.def: Of, or relating to, expression; phraseological; also, vividly representing or suggesting an idea or sentiment.

sn.def: an art movement early in the 20th century; the artist's subjective expression of inner experiences was emphasized.
a genre of German painting that tried to show the subjective responses to scenes rather than the scenes themselves.
of or pertaining to expressionism (definition 2); as, expressionist art.

entry.def: an artist who is an adherent of expressionism.
Destitute of expression.

sn.def: Serving to express, utter, or represent; indicative; communicative; -- followed by of; as, words expressive of his gratitude.
sn.q: Each verse so swells expressive of her woes.

sn.def: Full of expression; vividly representing the meaning or feeling meant to be conveyed; significant; emphatic; as, expressive looks or words.
sn.q: You have restrained yourself within the list of too cold an adieu; be more expressive to them.
Through her expressive eyes her soul distinctly spoke.

entry.def: the quality of being expressive.
In an express manner; in direct terms; with distinct purpose; particularly; as, a book written expressly for the young.
entry.q: The word of the Lord came expressly unto Ezekiel.
I am sent expressly to your lordship.

entries.entry: Ex*press"man -m�n n.; pl.Expressmen -m�n. A person employed in the express business; also, the driver of a job wagon.

entry.def: The state or quality of being express; definiteness.

entries.entry: Ex*press" ri"fle. A sporting rifle for use at short ranges, employing a large charge of powder and a light (short) bullet, giving a high initial velocity and consequently a flat trajectory. It is usually of moderately large caliber.
Express train. Formerly, a railroad train run expressly for the occasion; a special train; now, a train run at express or special speed and making few stops.

entry.def: The act of expressing; expression; utterance; representation.
entry.q: An operation more divine Than breath or pen can give expressure to.

entry.ety: L. exprobratus, p. p. of exprobrare; ex out + probrum a shameful or disgraceful act
entry.def: To charge upon with reproach; to upbraid.
Reproachful accusation; upbraiding.
entry.q: A fearful exprobration of our unworthiness.

entry.def: Expressing reproach; upbraiding; reproachful.

entry.ety: L. ex out, from + proprius one's own: cf. F. exproprier
entry.def: To put out of one's possession; to surrender the ownership of; also, to deprive of possession or proprietary rights.
entry.q: Expropriate these [bad landlords] as the monks were expropriated by Act of Parliament.

entry.def: taken out of the possession of another and transferred to one's own use often without permission; as, the expropriated land was developed into a public playground.
The act of expropriating; the surrender of a claim to exclusive property; the act of depriving of ownership or proprietary rights.
entry.q: The expropriation of bad landlords.

entry.ety: L. expugnare; ex out + pugnare to fight, pugna fight. Cf. Impugn
entry.def: To take by assault; to storm; to overcome; to vanquish; as, to expugn cities; to expugn a person by arguments.
Capable of being expugned.
The act of taking by assault; conquest.
One who expugns.

entry.ety: F. expulser or L. expulsare, intens. fr. expellere. See Expel
entry.def: To drive out; to expel.
entry.q: If charity be thus excluded and expulsed.

entry.def: An expeller.

entry.ety: L. expulsio, fr. expellere: cf. F. expulsion. See Expel

sn.def: The act of expelling; a driving or forcing out; summary removal from membership, association, etc.
sn.q: The expulsion of the Tarquins.

sn.def: The state of being expelled or driven out.

entry.def: Having the power of driving out or away; serving to expel.
entry.q: The expulsive power of a new affection.

entry.ety: L. expunctio execution, performance, from expungere. See Expunge
entry.def: The act of expunging or erasing; the condition of being expunged.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expunged ĕks*pŭnjd"; p. pr. & vb. n. Expunging ĕks*pŭn"jĭng
entry.ety: L. expungere expunctum, prick out, expunge, settle an account, execute; ex out + pungere to prick, puncture. See Pungent.

sn.def: To blot out, as with pen; to rub out; to efface designedly; to obliterate; to strike out wholly; as, to expunge words, lines, or sentences.
To strike out; to wipe out or destroy; to annihilate; as, to expunge an offense.
sn.q: Expunge the whole, or lop th' excrescent parts.
sn.syn: To efface; erase; obliterate; strike out; destroy; annihilate; cancel.

entry.def: deletion by an act of expunging or erasing.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Expurgated ĕks`pŭr*gā"tĕd; p. pr. & vb. n. Expurgating ĕks`pŭr*gā"tĭng
entry.ety: L. expurgatus, p. p. of expurgare to purge, purify; ex out, from + purgare to cleanse, purify, purge. See Purge, and cf. Spurge
entry.def: To purify; to clear from anything noxious, offensive, or erroneous; to cleanse; to purge; as, to expurgate a book.
having material deleted; -- of books; as, at that time even Shakespeare was considered dangerous except in the expurgated versions.

entry.ety: L. expurgatio justification, excuse: cf. F. expurgation
entry.def: The act of expurgating, purging, or cleansing; purification from anything noxious, offensive, sinful, or erroneous.
One who expurgates or purifies.
Tending or serving to expurgate; expurgatory.
Expurgatory.
entry.q: Expurgatoriousindexes.

entry.cs: Expurgatory Index. See Index Expurgatorius, under Index.
entry.def: Serving to purify from anything noxious or erroneous; cleansing; purifying.
entry.q: Expurgatoryanimadversions.

entry.def: To purge away.
To search into or out.

entry.ety: L. exquisitus, p. p. of exquirere to search out; ex out + quarere to seek, search. See Quest

sn.def: Carefully selected or sought out; hence, of distinguishing and surpassing quality; exceedingly nice; delightfully excellent; giving rare satisfaction; as, exquisite workmanship.
sn.q: Plate of rare device, and jewels Of reach and exquisite form.
I have no exquisite reason for 't, but I have reason good enough.

sn.def: Exceeding; extreme; keen; -- used in a bad or a good sense; as, exquisite pain or pleasure.
Of delicate perception or close and accurate discrimination; not easy to satisfy; exact; nice; fastidious; as, exquisite judgment, taste, or discernment.
sn.q: His books of Oriental languages, wherein he was exquisite.
sn.syn: Nice; delicate; exact; refined; choice; rare; matchless; consummate; perfect.

entry.def: One who manifests an exquisite attention to external appearance; one who is overnice in dress or ornament; a fop; a dandy.
In an exquisite manner or degree; as, lace exquisitely wrought.
entry.q: To a sensitive observer there was something exquisitely painful in it.

entry.def: Quality of being exquisite.
Eager to discover or learn; curious.
Bloodless.
Destitute of blood; anæmic; exsanguious.
Privation or destitution of blood; -- opposed to plethora.
See Exsanguious.

entry.ety: L. exsanguis; ex out + sanguis sanguinis, blood. Cf. Exsanguineous

sn.def: Destitute of blood.
Destitute of true, or red, blood, as insects.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exscinded; p. pr. & vb. n. Exscinding
entry.ety: L. exscindere; ex out, from + scindere to cut
entry.def: To cut off; to separate or expel from union; to extirpate.
entry.q: The second presbytery of Philadelphia was also exscinded by that Assembly.

entry.ety: L. excribere; ex out, from + scribere to write
entry.def: To copy; to transcribe.

entry.ety: L. exscriptus, p. p. of exscribere
entry.def: A copy; a transcript.
Not in accordance with the doctrines of Scripture; unscriptural.
Without, or apparently without, a scutellum; -- said of certain insects.

sn.def: A cutting out or away.
The removal by operation of a portion of a limb; particularly, the removal of a portion of a bone in the vicinity of a joint; the act or process of cutting out.

entry.ety: L. exsertus, p. p. of exserere to stretch out or forth. See Exert
entry.def: Standing out; projecting beyond some other part; as, exsert stamens.
entry.q: A small portion of the basal edge of the shell exserted.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exserted; p. pr. & vb. n. Exserting
entry.def: To thrust out; to protrude; as, some worms are said to exsert the proboscis.
Capable of being thrust out or protruded.
a person who has served in the armed forces.

entry.ety: L. exsiccans, p. pr. of exsiccare. See Exsiccate
entry.def: Having the quality of drying up; causing a drying up.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exsiccated; p. pr. & vb. n. Exsiccating
entry.ety: L. exsiccatus, p. p. of exsiccare to dry up; ex out + siccare to make dry, siccus dry
entry.def: To exhaust or evaporate moisture from; to dry up.
The act of operation of drying; evaporation or expulsion of moisture; state of being dried up; dryness.
Tending to make dry; having the power of drying.
An apparatus for drying substances or preserving them from moisture; a desiccator; also, less frequently, an agent employed to absorb moisture, as calcium chloride, or concentrated sulphuric acid.

entry.ety: L. exsiliens leaping out, p. pr. of exsilire; ex out + salire to leap
entry.def: A leaping out.
Relaxation.

entry.ety: L. exspoliatio, fr. exspoliare to spoil, to plunder; ex out, from + spoliare. See Spoliate
entry.def: Spoliation.
a person who was formerly a spouse.

entry.ety: L. exspuitio; ex out + spuere to spit: cf. F. exspuition
entry.def: A discharge of saliva by spitting.
Spit out, or as if spit out.
entry.q: Exsputorylines.

entry.def: Having no stipules.

entry.ety: Gr. � to turn inside out; � = � out + � to turn
entry.def: The eversion or turning out of any organ, or of its inner surface; as, exstrophy of the eyelid or of the bladder.

entry.ety: L. exsuccus; ex out + succus juice
entry.def: Destitute of juice; dry; sapless. Latham.

entry.ety: L. exsugere exsuctum, to suck out; ex out + sugere to suck: cf. F. exsuccion
entry.def: The act of sucking out.
Exudation.

entry.ety: L. exsufflare to blow at or upon; ex out + sufflare. See Sufflate
entry.def: To exorcise or renounce by blowing.

sn.def: A blast from beneath.
A kind of exorcism by blowing with the breath.
A strongly forced expiration of air from the lungs.

entry.def: Empty; frivolous.
entry.mark: A Shakespearean word only once used.
entry.q: Such exsufflicate and blown surmises.

entry.ety: L. exsuscitatus, p. p. of exsuscitare; ex out + suscitare. See Suscitate
entry.def: To rouse; to excite.
A stirring up; a rousing.
See Ecstasy.

entry.ety: L. extantia exstantia, a standing out, fr. exstans, p. pr. See Extant
entry.def: Outward existence.
The state of rising above others; a projection.

entry.ety: L. extans -antis, or exstans -antis, p. pr. of extare exstare, to stand out or forth; ex out + stare to stand: cf. F. extant. See Stand

sn.def: Standing out or above any surface; protruded.
sn.q: That part of the teeth which is extant above the gums.
A body partly immersed in a fluid and partly extant.

sn.def: Still existing; not destroyed or lost; outstanding.
sn.q: Writings that were extant at that time.
The extant portraits of this great man.

sn.def: Publicly known; conspicuous.

entry.def: See Ecstasy n. & v. t.
See Ecstatic a.
Extemporaneous; unpremeditated.
Extemporaneous.
Composed, performed, or uttered on the spur of the moment, or without previous study; unpremeditated; off-hand; ad-lib; extempore; extemporary; as, an extemporaneous address or production.
Extemporaneously.

sn.def: Extemporaneous.
sn.q: Inextemporaryprayer.

sn.def: Made for the occasion; for the time being.
sn.q: Extemporaryhabitations.

entry.ety: L. ex out + tempus temporis, time. See Temporal
entry.def: Without previous study or meditation; without preparation; on the spur of the moment; suddenly; extemporaneously; as, to write or speak extempore .
entry.def2: a. Done or performed extempore. “Extempore dissertation.” Addison. “Extempore poetry.” Dryden.

entry.def: The quality of being done or devised extempore
The act of extemporizing; the act of doing anything extempore.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extemporized; p. pr. & vb. n. Extemporizing
entry.def: To speak extempore; especially, to discourse without special preparation; to make an offhand address.
To do, make, or utter extempore or off-hand; to prepare in great haste, under urgent necessity, or with scanty or unsuitable materials; as, to extemporize a dinner, a costume, etc.
entry.q: Themistocles . . . was of all men the best able to extemporize the right thing to be done.
Pitt, of whom it was said that he could extemporize a Queen's speech

entry.def: One who extemporizes.

cs.cd: a letter, or style of type, having a broader face than is usual for a letter or type of the same height.

entry.note: ☞ This is extended type.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extended; p. pr. & vb. n. Extending
entry.ety: L. extendere extentum extensum; ex out + tendere to stretch. See Trend

sn.def: To stretch out; to prolong in space; to carry forward or continue in length; as, to extend a line in surveying; to extend a cord across the street.
sn.q: Few extend their thoughts toward universal knowledge.

sn.def: To enlarge, as a surface or volume; to expand; to spread; to amplify; as, to extend metal plates by hammering or rolling them.

To enlarge; to widen; to carry out further; as, to extend the capacities, the sphere of usefulness, or commerce; to extend power or influence; to continue, as time; to lengthen; to prolong; as, to extend the time of payment or a season of trial.
To hold out or reach forth, as the arm or hand.
sn.q: His helpless hand extend.

sn.def: To bestow; to offer; to impart; to apply; as, to extend sympathy to the suffering.
To increase in quantity by weakening or adulterating additions; as, to extend liquors.
