To value, as lands taken by a writ of extent in satisfaction of a debt; to assign by writ of extent.
sn.syn: To increase; enlarge; expand; widen; diffuse. See Increase.

entry.def: Displaced.
In an extended manner.
One who, or that which, extends or stretches anything.

sn.def: Capable of being extended, susceptible of being stretched, extended, enlarged, widened, or expanded.
Liable to be taken by a writ of extent.

entry.def: Unlimited extension.
entry.q: An . . . extendlessness of excursions.

entry.ety: L. extensus, p. p. See Extend v. t.
entry.def: Outreaching; expansive; extended, superficially or otherwise.
entry.q: Men and gods are too extense; Could you slacken and condense?

entry.def: The quality of being extensible; the capacity of being extended; as, the extensibility of a fiber, or of a plate of metal.
Capable of being extended, whether in length or breadth; susceptible of enlargement; extensible; extendible; -- the opposite of contractible or compressible.
entry.q: Anextensiblemembrane

entry.def: Extensibility.
Suited for, or capable of, extension; extensible.

entry.cs: Counter extension. Surg See under Counter. Extension table a table so constructed as to be readily extended or contracted in length.
entry.ety: L. extensio: cf. F. extension. See Extend v. t.

sn.def: The act of extending or the state of being extended; a stretching out; enlargement in breadth or continuation of length; increase; augmentation; expansion.
That property of a body by which it occupies a portion of space.

sd.def: Capacity of a concept or general term to include a greater or smaller number of objects; -- correlative of intension.

the class or set of objects to which a term refers; -- contrasted with intension, the logical specification which defines members of a class, being the set of attributes which are necessary and sufficient to recognize an object as a member of the class.
sd.q: The law is that the intension of our knowledge is in the inverse ratio of its extension.
The extension of [the term] plant is greater than that of geranium, because it includes more objects.

sn.def: The operation of stretching a broken bone so as to bring the fragments into the same straight line.
The straightening of a limb, in distinction from flexion.
A written engagement on the part of a creditor, allowing a debtor further time to pay a debt.

entry.def: Having great extent.
One who favors or advocates extension.

entry.ety: L. extensivus: cf. F. extensif. See Extend

sn.def: Having wide extent; of much superficial extent; expanded; large; broad; wide; comprehensive; as, an extensive farm; an extensive lake; an extensive sphere of operations; extensive benevolence; extensive greatness.
Capable of being extended.
sn.q: Silver beaters choose the finest coin, as that which is most extensive under the hammer.

entry.def: To a great extent; widely; largely; as, a story is extensively circulated.
The state of being extensive; wideness; largeness; extent; diffusiveness.
An instrument for measuring the extension of a body, especially for measuring the elongation of bars of iron, steel, or other material, when subjected to a tensile force.

entry.ety: L., one who stretches. See Extend
entry.def: A muscle which serves to extend or straighten any part of the body, as an arm or a finger; -- opposed to flexor.
Extension.

entry.ety: L. extentus, p. p. of extendere. See Extend
entry.def: Extended.

entry.ety: L. extentus, fr. extendere. See Extend

sn.def: Space or degree to which a thing is extended; hence, superficies; compass; bulk; size; length; as, an extent of country or of line; extent of information or of charity.
sn.q: Life in its large extent is scare a span.

sn.def: Degree; measure; proportion.
sn.q: Theextentto which we can make ourselves what we wish to be.

sd.def: A peculiar species of execution upon debts due to the crown, under which the lands and goods of the debtor may be seized to secure payment.
A process of execution by which the lands and goods of a debtor are valued and delivered to the creditor.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extenuated; p. pr. & vb. n. Extenuating
entry.ety: L. extenuatus, p. p. of extenuare to make thin, loosen, weaken; ex out + tenuare to make thin, tenuis thin. See Tenuity

sn.def: To make thin or slender; to draw out so as to lessen the thickness.
sn.q: His body behind the head becomes broad, from whence it is again extenuated all the way to the tail.

sn.def: To lessen; to palliate; to lessen or weaken the force of; to diminish the conception of, as crime, guilt, faults, ills, accusations, etc.; -- opposed to aggravate.
sn.q: But fortune there extenuates the crime.
Let us extenuate, conceal, adorn the unpleasing reality.

sn.def: To lower or degrade; to detract from.
sn.q: Who can extenuate thee?
sn.syn: To palliate; to mitigate. See Palliate.

entry.def: To become thinner; to make excuses; to advance palliating considerations.
Thin; slender.
serving or tending to reduce the severity of guilt or blameworthiness; as, extenuating circumstances.

The act of axtenuating or the state of being extenuated; the act of making thin, slender, or lean, or of palliating; diminishing, or lessening; palliation, as of a crime; mitigation, as of punishment.
entry.q: To listen . . . to every extenuation of what is evil.

entry.def: One who extenuates.
Tending to extenuate or palliate.

cs.cd: the angle included between any side of a triangle or polygon and the prolongation of the adjacent side; also, an angle included between a line crossing two parallel lines and either of the latter on the outside.
the side of the polygon upon which a front of fortification is formed.

entry.note: See Illust. of Ravelin.
entry.ety: L. exterior, compar. of exter or exterus on the outside, outward, foreign, strange, a compar. fr. ex: cf. F. extérieur. See Ex-, and cf. Extreme Interior

sn.def: External; outward; pertaining to that which is external; -- opposed to interior; as, the exterior part of a sphere.
sn.q: Sith nor the exterior nor the inward man Resemble that it was.

sn.def: External; on the outside; without the limits of; extrinsic; as, an object exterior to a man, opposed to what is within, or in his mind.
sn.q: Without exterior help sustained.

sn.def: Relating to foreign nations; foreign; as, the exterior relations of a state or kingdom.
The outward surface or part of a thing; that which is external; outside.
Outward or external deportment, form, or ceremony; visible act; as, the exteriors of religion.

entry.def: same as exteriorization.
embodying in an outward form.
Surface; superficies; externality.
Outwardly; externally; on the exterior.
entry.q: They are exteriorly lifelike.

entry.def: capable of being totally destroyed or wiped out.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Exterminated; p. pr. & vb. n. Exterminating
entry.ety: L. exterminatus, p. p. of exterminare to abolish, destroy, drive out or away; ex out + terminus boundary, limit. See Term

sn.def: To drive out or away; to expel.
sn.q: They deposed, exterminated, and deprived him of communion.

sn.def: To destroy utterly; to cut off; to extirpate; to annihilate; to root out; as, to exterminate a colony, a tribe, or a nation; to exterminate error or vice.
sn.q: To explode and exterminate rank atheism.

sn.def: To eliminate, as unknown quantities.

entry.def: destroyed completely.

sn.def: The act of exterminating; total destruction; eradication; excision; as, the extermination of inhabitants or tribes, of error or vice, or of weeds from a field.
Elimination.

entry.def: One who, or that which, exterminates.
Of or pertaining to extermination; tending to exterminate.
entry.q: Exterminatorywar.

entry.def: To exterminate; to destroy.
External; outward; not inherent.

sn.def: A pupil in a seminary who lives without its walls; a day scholar.
Outward form or part; exterior.
same as externe.

entry.cs: External angles. Geom See under Angle.
entry.ety: L. externus, fr. exter exterus, on the outside, outward. See Exterior

sn.def: Outward; exterior; relating to the outside, as of a body; being without; acting from without; -- opposed to internal; as, the external form or surface of a body.
sn.q: Of all external things, . . . She [Fancy] forms imaginations, aery shapes.

sn.def: Outside of or separate from ourselves; Metaph separate from the perceiving mind.
Outwardly perceptible; visible; physical or corporeal, as distinguished from mental or moral.
sn.q: Her virtues graced with external gifts.

sn.def: Not intrinsic nor essential; accidental; accompanying; superficial.
sn.q: The external circumstances are greatly different.

sn.def: Foreign; relating to or connected with foreign nations; as, external trade or commerce; the external relations of a state or kingdom.
Away from the mesial plane of the body; lateral.

entry.def: Something external or without; outward part; that which makes a show, rather than that which is intrinsic; visible form; -- usually in the plural.
entry.q: Adam was then no less glorious in his externals
God in externals could not place content.

entry.def: embodying in an outward form.
to make external.

sn.def: The quality of being manifest to the senses; external acts or appearances; regard for externals.
sn.q: This externalism gave Catholicism a great advantage on all sides.

sn.def: That philosophy or doctrine which recognizes or deals only with externals, or objects of sense perception; positivism; phenomenalism.

entry.def: Pertaining to externalism.

entries.entry: Ex`ter*nal"i*ty n. State of being external; exteriority; Metaph separation from the perceiving mind. Pressure or resistance necessarily supposes externality in the thing which presses or resists.

sn.def: attributing to outside causes.
embodying in an outward form.

entry.def: To make external; to manifest by outward form.
entry.q: Thought externalizes itself in language.

entry.def: In an external manner; outwardly; on the outside; in appearance; visibly.
a person affiliated with an institution who does not reside there;
a doctor or medical student who is in attendance upon, or is assisting at, a hospital, but who does not reside in it.

entry.ety: L. exterraneus; es out + terra land
entry.def: Foreign; belonging to, or coming from, abroad.
Beyond the territorial limits; foreign to, or exempt from, the territorial jurisdiction.

sn.def: The state of being beyond the limits of a country.
The state of being free from the jurisdiction of a country when within its territorial limits.

entry.ety: L. extergere extersum, to wipe out; ex out + tergere to wipe or rub off
entry.def: The act of wiping or rubbing out.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extilled; p. pr. & vb. n. Extilling
entry.ety: L. extillare exstillare; ex out + stillare to drop, stilla drop
entry.def: To drop or distill.
Distillation.
entry.q: An exudation or extillation of petrifying juices.

entry.ety: L. extimulatus exstimulatus, p. p. of extimulare exstimulare, to goad. See Stimulate
entry.def: To stimulate.
Stimulation.
entry.q: Things insipid, and without any extimulation.

entry.ety: L. extinctus exstinctus, p. p. of extinguere exstinguere. See Extinguish

sn.def: Extinguished; put out; quenched; as, a fire, a light, or a lamp, is extinct; an extinct volcano.
sn.q: Light, the prime work of God, to me is extinct.

sn.def: Without a survivor; without force; dead; as, a family becomes extinct; an extinct feud or law.
Once existing as a species but now having no living members; -- used of species of living organisms, especially of animals and plants; as, dinosaurs are now extinct; the dodo bird is extinct .

entry.def: To cause to be extinct.

entry.note: ☞ Extinctions have occurred many times throughout the history of life on Earth, and abundant evidence of the prior existence of animals and plants are found as fossils in rock formations many millions of years old. It is believed by some that due to the influence of man on the environment and destruction of habitat, the rate of extinction of species is now higher than at any previous time on this planet. Extinctions of some animals in recent years have actually been reliably recorded, such as that of the dodo bird. A remarkable example of extinction is that of the passenger pigeon Ectopistes migratorius) in North America, which once numbered in the billions, and the last living member of which species was recorded as dying in captivity in 1914.
entry.ety: L. extinctio exstinction: cf. F. extinction

sn.def: The act of extinguishing or making extinct; a putting an end to; the act of putting out or destroying light, fire, life, activity, influence, etc.
State of being extinguished or of ceasing to be; destruction; suppression; as, the extinction of life, of a family, of a quarrel, of claim.

The ceasing to exist of a species of living organism, such as a plant or animal, whose numbers declined to the point where the last member of the species died and therefore no new members of the species could ever again be born.

entry.ety: L. exter on the outside. Cf. Intine
entry.def: The outer membrane of the grains of pollen of flowering plants.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extinguished ĕks*tĭṉ"gwĭsht; p pr. & vb. n. Extinguishing
entry.ety: L. extinguere exstinguere; ex out + stinguere to quench. See Distinguish Finish

sn.def: To quench; to put out, as a light or fire; to stifle; to cause to die out; to put an end to; to destroy; as, to extinguish a flame, or life, or love, or hope, a pretense or a right.
sn.q: A light which the fierce winds have no power to extinguish.
This extinguishes my right to the reversion.

entry.sn: To obscure; to eclipse, as by superior splendor. Natural graces that extinguish art..

entry.def: Capable of being quenched, destroyed, or suppressed.

sn.def: caused to die out because of the absence or withdrawal of reinforcement; -- of a conditioned response.
no longer burning; -- of a fire.
no longer existing; -- of species.

cs.cd: a portable device designed to deliver chemicals, usually in a stream, that can suppress or extinguish a fire. Examples of fire extinghuishers are a carbon dioxide extinguisher, or CO2 extinguisher, and soda-acid extinguisher.

entry.def: One who, or that which, extinguishes; esp., a hollow cone or other device for extinguishing a flame, as of a torch or candle.

sn.def: The act of extinguishing, putting out, or quenching, or the state of being extinguished; extinction; suppression; destruction; nullification; as, the extinguishment of fire or flame, of discord, enmity, or jealousy, or of love or affection.
The annihilation or extinction of a right or obligation.

entries.entry:
Ex*tirp" v. t. Cf. F. extirper
To extirpate. Obs It is impossible to extirp it quite, friar..

entry.def: Capable of being extirpated or eradicated; as, an extirpable plant.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extirpated; p. pr. & vb. n. Extirpating
entry.ety: L. extirpatus exstirpatus, p. p. of extirpare exstirpare; ex out + strips stock, stem, root
entry.def: To pluck up by the stem or root; to root out; to eradicate, literally or figuratively; to destroy wholly; as, to extirpate weeds; to extirpate a tumor; to extirpate a sect; to extirpate error or heresy.
entry.syn: To eradicate; root out; destroy; exterminate; annihilate; extinguish.

entry.ety: L. extirpatio exstirpatio: cf. F. extirpation
entry.def: The act of extirpating or rooting out, or the state of being extirpated; eradication; excision; total destruction; as, the extirpation of weeds from land, of evil from the heart, of a race of men, of heresy.
Capable of rooting out, or tending to root out.

entry.ety: L. extirpator exstirpator: cf. F. extirpateur
entry.def: One who extirpates or roots out; a destroyer.
Extirpative.
Extirpator.

entry.ety: L. extispicium an inspection of the inwards for divination; extra the entrails + specer to look at
entry.def: Relating to the inspection of entrails for prognostication.
Exogenous.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extolled; p. pr. & vb. n. Extolling
entry.ety: L. extollere; ex out + tollere to lift, take up, or raise: cf. OF. extoller. See Tollerate, and cf. Flate

sn.def: To place on high; to lift up; to elevate.
sn.q: Who extolled you in the half-crown boxes, Where you might sit and muster all the beauties.

sn.def: To elevate by praise; to eulogize; to praise; to magnify; as, to extol virtue; to extol an act or a person.
sn.q: Wherein have I so deserved of you, That you extol me thus?
sn.syn: To praise; applaud; commend; magnify; celebrate; laud; glorify. See Praise.

entry.def: One who extols; one who praises.
Praise.
Serving or tending to extort.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extorted; p. pr. & vb. n. Extorting
entry.ety: L. extortus, p. p. of extorquere to twist or wrench out, to extort; ex out + torquere to turn about, twist. See Torsion

sn.def: To wrest from an unwilling person by physical force, menace, duress, torture, or any undue or illegal exercise of power or ingenuity; to wrench away (from); to tear away; to wring (from); to exact; as, to extort contributions from the vanquished; to extort confessions of guilt; to extort a promise; to extort payment of a debt.
To get by the offense of extortion. See Extortion, 2.

entry.def: To practice extortion.
Extorted.
One who practices extortion.

sn.def: The act of extorting; the act or practice of wresting anything from a person by force, by threats, or by any undue exercise of power; undue exaction; overcharge.
The offense committed by an officer who corruptly claims and takes, as his fee, money, or other thing of value, that is not due, or more than is due, or before it is due.
That which is extorted or exacted by force.

entry.def: Extortionate.
Characterized by extortion; oppressive; hard.
One who practices extortion; an extortionist.
One who practices extortion.
Extortionate.
entry.q: Extortiouscruelties.

entries.entry:
Ex"tra- Ex"tra-. L., fr. exter. See Exterior
A Latin preposition, denoting beyond outside of; -- often used in composition as a prefix signifying outside of beyond besides, or in addition to what is denoted by the word to which it is prefixed.

entry.def: Beyond what is due, usual, expected, or necessary; additional; supernumerary; also, extraordinarily good; superior; as, extra work; extra pay.
entry.q: By workingextrahours.

entries.entry:
Ex"tra n.; pl.Extras.
Something in addition to what is due, expected, or customary; esp., an added charge or fee, or something for which an additional charge is made; as, at some hotels air conditioning is an extra .
An edition of a newspaper issued at a time other than the regular one.
Cricket A run, as from a bye, credited to the general score but not made from a hit.
Something of an extra quality or grade.

entry.def: Situated outside of a joint.
Growing outside of the axils; as, an extra-axillary bud.
Outside of the branchial arches; -- said of the cartilages thus placed in some fishes.
Situated outside of a capsule, esp. outside the capsular ligament of a joint.
located or occurring outside of a living cell or cells; as, extracellular fluid. Opposite of intracellular.

cs.cd: to ascertain the root of a number or quantity.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Extracted; p. pr. & vb. n. Extracting
entry.ety: L. extractus, p. p. of extrahere to extract; ex out + trahere to draw. See Trace, and cf. Estreat

sn.def: To draw out or forth; to pull out; to remove forcibly from a fixed position, as by traction or suction, etc.; as, to extract a tooth from its socket, a stump from the earth, a splinter from the finger.
sn.q: The bee Sits on the bloom extracting liquid sweet.

sn.def: To withdraw by expression, distillation, or other mechanical or chemical process; as, to extract an essence. Cf. Abstract v. t., 6.
sn.q: Sunbeams may be extracted from cucumbers, but the process is tedious.

sn.def: To take by selection; to choose out; to cite or quote, as a passage from a book.
sn.q: I have extracted out of that pamphlet a few notorious falsehoods.

cs.cd: a concentrated liquid preparation, containing a definite proportion of the active principles of a medicinal substance. At present a fluid gram of extract should represent a gram of the crude drug.

sn.def: That which is extracted or drawn out.
A portion of a book or document, separately transcribed; a citation; a quotation.

A decoction, solution, or infusion made by dissolving out from any substance that which gives it its essential and characteristic virtue; essence; as, extract of beef; extract of dandelion; also, any substance so extracted, and characteristic of that from which it is obtained; as, quinine is the most important extract of Peruvian bark.
A solid preparation obtained by evaporating a solution of a drug, etc., or the fresh juice of a plant; -- distinguished from an abstract. See Abstract n., 4.
A peculiar principle once erroneously supposed to form the basis of all vegetable extracts; -- called also the extractive principle.
Extraction; descent.
A draught or copy of writing; certified copy of the proceedings in an action and the judgement therein, with an order for execution.

entry.def: Capable of being extracted.
Having the form, appearance, or nature, of an extract.

entry.cs: The extraction of roots. Math The operation of finding the root of a given number or quantity. The method or rule by which the operation is performed; evolution.

sn.def: The act of extracting, or drawing out; as, the extraction of a tooth, of a bone or an arrow from the body, of a stump from earth, of a passage from a book, of an essence or tincture.
Derivation from a stock or family; lineage; descent; birth; the stock from which one has descended.
sn.q: A family of ancientextraction.

sn.def: That which is extracted; extract; essence.
sn.q: They [books] do preserve as in a vial the purest efficacy and extraction of that living intellect that bred them.

sn.def: Capable of being extracted.
sn.q: Thirty grains ofextractivematter.

sn.def: Tending or serving to extract or draw out.

entry.ety: Prob. fr. nye an eye being for a nye. See Nye
entry.def: A brood; as, an eye of pheasants.

entry.note: ☞ The essential parts of the eye are inclosed in a tough outer coat, the sclerotic, to which the muscles moving it are attached, and which in front changes into the transparent cornea. A little way back of cornea, the crystalline lens is suspended, dividing the eye into two unequal cavities, a smaller one in front filled with a watery fluid, the aqueous humor, and larger one behind filled with a clear jelly, the vitreous humor. The sclerotic is lined with a highly pigmented membrane, the choroid, and this is turn is lined in the back half of the eyeball with the nearly transparent retina, in which the fibers of the optic nerve ramify. The choroid in front is continuous with the iris, which has a contractile opening in the center, the pupil, admitting light to the lens which brings the rays to a focus and forms an image upon the retina, where the light, falling upon delicate structures called rods and cones, causes them to stimulate the fibres of the optic nerve to transmit visual impressions to the brain.
entry.cs:
By the eye in abundance. Obs Marlowe. Elliott eye Naut a loop in a hemp cable made around a thimble and served. Eye agate a kind of circle agate, the central parts of which are of deeper tints than the rest of the mass. Brande & C. Eye animalcule Zoöl a flagellate infusorian belonging to Euglena and related genera; -- so called because it has a colored spot like an eye at one end. Eye doctor an opthalmologist or optometrist; -- formerly called an oculist. Eye of a volute Arch the circle in the center of volute.
Eye of day Eye of the morning Eye of heaven
the sun. “So gently shuts the eye of day.” Mrs. Barbauld. Eye of a ship the foremost part in the bows of a ship, where, formerly, eyes were painted; also, the hawser holes. Ham. Nav. Encyc. Half an eye very imperfect sight; a careless glance; as, to see a thing with half an eye; often figuratively. “Those who have but half an eye.” B. Jonson. To catch one's eye to attract one's notice. To find favor in the eyes (of to be graciously received and treated. To have an eye to to pay particular attention to; to watch. “Have an eye to Cinna.” Shak. To keep an eye on to watch. To set the eyes on to see; to have a sight of. In the eye of the wind Naut in a direction opposed to the wind; as, a ship sails in the eye of the wind .
entry.ety: OE. eghe eighe eie eye, AS. eáge; akin to OFries. āge, OS. ōga, D. oog, Ohg. ouga, G. auge, Icel. auga, Sw. öga, Dan. öie, Goth. augō; cf. OSlav. oko, Lith. akis, L. okulus, Gr. 'o`kkos, eye, 'o`sse, the two eyes, Skr. akshi. √10, 212. Cf. Diasy Ocular Optic Eyelet Ogle

sn.def: The organ of sight or vision. In man, and the vertebrates generally, it is properly the movable ball or globe in the orbit, but the term often includes the adjacent parts. In most invertebrates the eyes are immovable ocelli, or compound eyes made up of numerous ocelli. See Ocellus.
sn.caption: Description of illustration: a b Conjunctiva; c Cornea; d Sclerotic; e Choroid; f Cillary Muscle; g Cillary Process; h Iris; i Suspensory Ligament; k Prosterior Aqueous Chamber between h and i; l Anterior Aqueous Chamber; m Crystalline Lens; n Vitreous Humor; o Retina; p Yellow spot; q Center of blind spot; r Artery of Retina in center of the Optic Nerve.

sn.def: The faculty of seeing; power or range of vision; hence, judgment or taste in the use of the eye, and in judging of objects; as, to have the eye of a sailor; an eye for the beautiful or picturesque.
The action of the organ of sight; sight, look; view; ocular knowledge; judgment; opinion.
sn.q: In my eye, she is the sweetest lady that I looked on.

sn.def: The space commanded by the organ of sight; scope of vision; hence, face; front; the presence of an object which is directly opposed or confronted; immediate presence.
sn.q: We shell express our duty in his eye.
Her shell your hear disproved to her eyes.

sn.def: Observation; oversight; watch; inspection; notice; attention; regard.
sn.q: Keepeyesupon her.
Booksellers . . . have an eye to their own advantage.

entry.sn:
That which resembles the organ of sight, in form, position, or appearance; as: Zoöl The spots on a feather, as of peacock.

The center of a target; the bull's-eye.

A loop forming part of anything, or a hole through anything, to receive a rope, hook, pin, shaft, etc.; as, an eye at the end of a tie bar in a bridge truss; an eye through a crank; an eye at the end of rope.
The hole through the upper millstone.

a radiant glance of the eye; as, he pretended profundity by eye-beamings at people.

a cosmetic pencil-like device used to apply a tint to the eyebrows, or darken lighter areas on the eyebrows. It is sometimes used to create a “beauty mark” on the face.
An object or person that seizes the attention; as, her Statue of Liberty outfit was an eye-catcher .
Seizing the attention; as, eye-catching posters; as, she wore an eye-catching low-cut gown.
A small oval porcelain or glass cup, having a rim curved to fit the orbit of the eye. it is used in the application of liquid remedies to eyes; -- called also eyeglass.
Heaving (such or so many) eyes; -- used in composition; as, sharp-eyed; blue-eyed; dull-eyed; sad-eyed; ox-eyed Juno; myriad-eyed .
creating the illusion of seeing reality.
A tear.
a small dropping tube for delivering drops of a liquid; same as dropper{2.
A blinder on a horse's bridle.
Filling or satisfying the eye; visible; remarkable.
entry.q: Eyefultrophies.

sn.def: a view of something remarkable; a completely satisfying view; as much as, or more than, one would want to see; as, he got an eyeful of burnt-out buildings on his tour of the south Bronx.
an unusually attractive person, especially a beautiful woman.

entry.def: A glance of eye.

sn.def: A lens of glass worn in front of the eye to assist vision; -- usually used in the plural, referring to a pair of lenses fixed together in a frame, and worn resting on the bridge of the nose, to improve the vision. A single eyeglass in a frame is called a monocle.
Eyepiece of a telescope, microscope, etc.
The retina.
A glass eyecup. See Eyecup.

entry.def: a pair of lenses fixed together in a frame, used for correcting defective vision. Also called a pair of eyeglasses. See also eyeglass{1}.
A circular opening to recive a hook, cord, ring, or rope; an eyelet.

sn.def: The fringe of hair that edges the eyelid; -- usually in the pl.
A hair of the fringe on the edge of the eyelid.

entry.def: Without eyes; blind.
entry.q: Eyelessrage.

entry.cs: Eyelet hole a hole made for an eyelet. Eyelet punch a machine for punching eyelet holes and fastening eyelets, as in paper or cloth. Eyelet ring. See Eyelet, 2.
entry.ety: F. œillet, dim. of œil eye, fr. L. oculus. See Eye, and cf. Oillet

sn.def: A small hole or perforation to receive a cord or fastener, as in garments, sails, etc.
A metal ring or grommet, or short metallic tube, the ends of which can be bent outward and over to fasten it in place; -- used to line an eyelet hole.

entry.def: A small, sharp-pointed instrument used in piercing eyelet holes; a stiletto.
The cover of the eye; that portion of movable skin with which an animal covers or uncovers the eyeball at pleasure.
a solution used as a cleanser for the eyes.
a cosmetic powder of a dark tint, applied to the eyelid close to the base of the eyelashes to accentuate the eyes. Compare eye shadow.
Having one's mental imagery prevailingly of the visual type; having one's thoughts and memories mainly in the form of visual images.
Eyes.

sn.def: That which makes the eyes open, as startling news or occurrence; something which causes one to suddenly understand what was not previously known.
A drink of liquor, especially the first one in the morning.

entry.def: Causing one suddenly to learn or understand what was not previously known; as, an eye-opening look into the private machinations of the governor.
a protective covering, usually made of cloth, for an injured eye.

entry.cs:
Collimating eyepiece. See under Collimate.
Negative, or Huyghenian eyepiece
an eyepiece consisting of two plano-convex lenses with their curved surfaces turned toward the object glass, and separated from each other by about half the sum of their focal distances, the image viewed by the eye being formed between the two lenses. it was devised by Huyghens, who applied it to the telescope. Campani applied it to the microscope, whence it is sometimes called Campani's eyepiece. Positive eyepiece an eyepiece consisting of two plano-convex lenses placed with their curved surfaces toward each other, and separated by a distance somewhat less than the focal distance of the one nearest eye, the image of the object viewed being beyond both lenses; -- called also, from the name of the inventor, Ramsden's eyepiece.
terrestrial, or Erecting eyepiece
an eyepiece used in telescopes for viewing terrestrial objects, consisting of three, or usually four, lenses, so arranged as to present the image of the object viewed in an erect position.
entry.def: The lens, or combination of lenses, at the eye end of a microscope, telescope or other optical instrument, through which the image formed by the mirror or object glass is viewed.
One who eyes another.
The range or reach of the eye; eyeshot.
entry.q: A seat ineyereachof him.

entry.def: An object of interest to the eye; one worshiped with the eyes.
entry.q: That's the eye-saint, I know, Among young gallants.

entry.def: Ointment for the eye.
A servant who attends faithfully to his duty only when watched.
Service performed only under inspection, or the eye of an employer.
entry.q: Not with eyeservice, as menpleasers.

entry.def: a cosmetic powder or cream of a dark tint, applied on the eyelids or just under the eyebrows to accentuate the eyes. Compare eyeliner.
Range, reach, or glance of the eye; view; sight; as, to be out of eyeshot .
Sight of the eye; the sense of seeing; view; observation.
entry.q: Josephus sets this down from his own eyesight.

entry.def: Something offensive to the eye or sight; a blemish.
entry.q: Mordecai was an eyesore to Haman.

entry.def: A splice formed by bending a rope's end back, and fastening it into the rope, forming a loop or eye. See Illust. under Splice.
A simple visual organ found in many invertebrates, consisting of pigment cells covering a sensory nerve termination.
An eyelike spot of color.
Marked with spots like eyes.
entry.q: Juno's bird, in her eye-spotted train.

entry.def: One of the movable peduncles which, in the decapod Crustacea, bear the eyes at the tip.

sn.def: A small, lenticular, calcareous body, esp. an operculum of a small marine shell of the family Turbinidæ, used to remove a foreign substance from the eye. It is put into the inner corner of the eye under the lid, and allowed to work its way out at the outer corner, bringing with it the substance.
Eye agate. See under Eye.

entry.def: The tendon by which the eye is moved.
An island. See Eyot.

entries.entry:
Eye"tooth
To cut one's eyeteeth to become acute or knowing. Colloq
ī"t�th` n.; pl.Eyeteeth ī"tēth`
Anat A canine tooth of the upper jaw. See Teeth.

entry.def: See Eyewater.
A wash or lotion for application to the eyes.
A wink; a token.
An eyelash.
One who sees a thing done; one who has ocular view of anything.
entry.q: We . . . were eyewitnesses of his majesty.

entry.def: Eyes.
An island. See Eyot.
To ail.
See Œiliad.
Plural of eye; -- now obsolete, or used only in poetry.
entry.q: With such a plaintive gaze their eyne Are fastened upwardly on mine.

entry.ety: EyAS. īg or Icel. ey) + F. dim. termination -ot; cf. AS. īgeoð. See Island, and cf. Ait
entry.def: A little island in a river or lake. See Ait.
Air.

entries.entry: Ey"ra‖n. Native South American name Zoöl A wild cat (Felis eyra) ranging from southern Brazil to Texas. It is reddish yellow and about the size of the domestic cat, but with a more slender body and shorter legs.

entry.note: ☞ They were itinerant judges, who rode the circuit, holding courts in the different counties.
entry.ety: OF. erre journey, march, way, fr. L. iter itineris, a going, way, fr. the root of ire to go. Cf. Errant Itinerant Issue
entry.def: A journey in circuit of certain judges called justices in eyreor in itinere).
See Ey, an egg.

entries.entry:
Ey"rie Ey"ry ā"r� or ē"r�; 277
n.; pl. Ey"ries -rĭz. See Aerie
The nest of a bird of prey or other large bird that builds in a lofty place; aerie. The eagle and the stork On cliffs and cedar tops their eyries build.

entry.def: Same as Eisel.
